questions.text: What potential diagnosis should be considered for a patient admitted to the Emergency department following a road traffic accident exhibiting an altered level of consciousness and a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 10, as depicted in the provided CT scan?
questions.solution:
Correct answer C) Extradural hematoma

Explanation:

  • The common radiological finding in the case of an extradural hematoma is a characteristic biconvex or lens-shaped hyperdense lesion in the temporal region. This description is similar to the findings given in the CT scan image.

 

Subdural hematoma (Option A) is commonly seen due to injury in cortical bridging veins. In the CT scan, the lesion is seen as a concave-convex lesion in the subdural space.

Intracerebral hemorrhage (Option B) Commonly seen due to rupture of an aneurysm inside the brain. The CT scan usually shows a well-defined hyperdensity and is usually surrounded by hypodense edema.

Hemorrhagic contusion (Option D) Usually seen as small punctate hyperdense foci in the CT.

questions.text: A patient presented with retrosternal chest pain radiating to the jaw and dysphagia. A barium swallow was performed, and the following image was shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B) Diffuse esophageal spasm

Explanation:

  • Diffuse esophageal spasm is a motility disorder of the esophagus. In barium swallow, we can observe a “corkscrew esophagus'' Clinically, chest pain and dysphagia, predominantly while eating spicy food, are the symptoms.
  • Sacculations and pseudo diverticula can also be seen.

 

Infectious esophagitis (Option A) In infectious esophagitis, linear, regular plaque-like lesions can be seen on the contrast X-ray.

Barette’s esophagus (Option C) In Barette's esophagus, the X-ray does not show any specific findings.

Esophageal stricture (Option D) Barium meal shows a narrow esophagus with a shoulder-like appearance

questions.text: The provided barium swallow indicates
questions.solution:
Correct answer A) Achalasia cardia

Explanation:

  • Achalasia cardia is a massively dilated esophagus. It has a narrow distal end. Radiologically we can observe a bird beak sign as seen in the given image. A patient suffering from achalasia cardia has more difficulty swallowing liquids than solids.

 

Diffuse esophageal spasm (Option B) A corkscrew sign is seen in the diffuse esophagus.

Nutcracker esophagus (Option C) The nutcracker esophagus also shows a corkscrew sign similar to the diffuse esophageal spasm.

Hypertensive lower esophageal sphincter (Option D) It does not show a bird beak sign, and hence, it is an incorrect choice.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions has a barium enema as shown in the picture below?
questions.solution:
Correct answer C) Diverticulosis

  • Diverticulosis is the outpouching of the colon wall. In a barium swallow, the contrast x ray shows an outpouching filled with barium as seen in the image it presents as a “Saw tooth appearance” It is most commonly seen in the sigmoid colon.

 

Multiple colonic polyps (Option A) Colonic polyps appear as single polypoid lesions in the radiograph. It does not present a Sawtooth appearance.

Ulcerative colitis (Option B) A smooth colon with no haustrations “Lead pipe colon” is seen in the radiograph.

Irritable bowel Syndrome (Option D) Saw tooth appearance is not seen in irritable bowel syndrome.

Diverticulosis

Definition

Presence of small, bulging pouches (diverticula) in the colon, most commonly in the sigmoid colon.

Etiology

Diet: A low-fiber diet increases colon pressure.

Age: More common in those over 60.

Genetics: Family history may increase risk.

Pathophysiology

Increased pressure: High colon pressure causes weak spots to bulge.

Weak colonic wall: Weak areas, especially where blood vessels enter the mucosa, are prone to forming diverticula.

Characteristics

False diverticula: Involve only the mucosa and submucosa.

Multiple and acquired: Typically multiple and not congenital.

Location: Most commonly in the sigmoid colon, along the mesenteric aspect.

Symptoms

Often asymptomatic; may include mild abdominal discomfort, bloating, and changes in bowel habits.

Diagnosis

 

Colonoscopy: Direct visualization.

CT Scan: Detailed images of the colon.

Barium enema: Less common, shows a characteristic sawtooth appearance

Management

Diet: Increase fiber intake.

Hydration: Drink plenty of fluids.

Exercise: Promotes healthy bowel function.

Complications

Lower GI Bleed: Common cause of lower gastrointestinal bleeding.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient involved in a road traffic accident was managed upon arrival at the emergency room, with a respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute and a blood pressure of 80/45mmHg, and exhibiting hyper-resonance on the left side of the chest, what is the appropriate action based on the findings from the chest x-ray?

choices.text: Wide bore needle insertion in the 2nd ICS
Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th ICS followed by an intercostal drain in the 5th ICS

questions.solution:
Correct answer B) Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th ICS followed by an intercostal drain in the 5th ICS

Explanation:

  • The above condition indicates a tension pneumothorax. It is a life-threatening condition and should be immediately attended to.
  • The appropriate management of a tension pneumothorax includes inserting a Wide-bore needle insertion in the 5th ICS along the axillary line, followed by an intercostal drain in the 5th ICS to achieve decompression.

 

Wide bore needle insertion in the 2nd ICS (Option A) The wide bore needle is to be inserted into the ICS 5th at the mid-clavicular line. Hence, this option is incorrect.

Aspiration of the Pleural fluid (Option C) Aspiration of the pleural fluid is not done in case of a tension pneumothorax

No intervention needed (Option D) A tension pneumothorax is a highly life-threatening condition and needs immediate intervention.

questions.text: Which of the following regulate serum calcium levels?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) All of the above

Explanation:

Serum calcium levels are regulated by a combination of calcitonin, parathormone (PTH), and vitamin D.

  • Calcitonin lowers blood calcium levels by inhibiting osteoclast activity in bones, reducing calcium release.
  • Parathormone (PTH) increases blood calcium levels by stimulating osteoclast activity and promoting calcium reabsorption in the kidneys.
  • Vitamin D enhances calcium absorption from the intestines and helps in bone mineralization.

questions.text: What is the reason that hemoglobin cannot pass through the glomerulus in a normal physiological state?

choices.text: It is a large molecule bound with another protein
It gets attracted to the negative charge of the glomerular filtration barrier

questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) It is a large molecule bound with another protein

Explanation:

Hemoglobin, when bound to haptoglobin or other proteins, becomes too large to pass through the filtration barrier. Hemoglobin is a complex protein with a molecular weight of about 64,500 Daltons. The glomerular filtration barrier in the kidneys allows the passage of small molecules and ions but restricts the movement of large proteins and cells. Hemoglobin is too large to pass through the filtration barrier, so it is retained within the bloodstream and does not get filtered into the renal tubules.

It gets attracted to the negative charge of the glomerular filtration barrier (Option B): The glomerular filtration barrier does have negative charges due to the presence of glycoproteins in the glomerular basement membrane. These negative charges repel negatively charged molecules, preventing them from being filtered. However, hemoglobin is not positively charged; its inability to pass through the glomerulus is primarily due to its large size, not its charge.

questions.text: Which hormone is responsible for the breast cramps experienced by a mother during breastfeeding her child?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Oxytocin

Explanation:

During breastfeeding, oxytocin is released in response to nipple stimulation. Oxytocin causes the smooth muscles around the mammary glands to contract, leading to milk ejection (the "let-down" reflex). These contractions can sometimes cause breast cramps or discomfort.

Progesterone (option A): Progesterone plays a role in preparing the breast tissue for lactation but is not directly responsible for the cramps experienced during breastfeeding.

Estrogen (option B): Estrogen is involved in breast development and lactation preparation, but it does not directly cause the cramps during breastfeeding.

Prolactin (option C): Prolactin stimulates milk production but does not contribute to the breast cramps associated with breastfeeding.

questions.text: In a young patient who experienced a head injury from a road traffic accident, his family reports a change in his behavior. They describe him as being excessively curious and constantly touching objects. He also exhibits rapid forgetfulness and attempts to put various things in his mouth, including plates. Additionally, they have observed him squeezing his genitals. Based on these symptoms, which structure is most likely to be affected in this patient?

choices.text: Gray matter around the aqueduct of Sylvius

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Amygdala

 

Explanation:

The symptoms described in the patient, such as excessive curiosity, rapid forgetfulness, inappropriate behavior (putting things in his mouth), and genital squeezing, are suggestive of Klüver-Bucy syndrome. This syndrome is associated with damage to the amygdala, which plays a central role in emotion regulation and behavior. The amygdala’s dysfunction leads to behaviors like hypersexuality, hyperorality (putting objects in the mouth), and changes in emotional responses.

The amygdala is an almond-shaped structure located in the temporal lobe, just beneath the uncus. It is a complex and diverse structure composed of around 13 nuclei, which are interconnected through extensive internuclear and intranuclear pathways. These nuclei are functionally organised into five major groups: basolateral nuclei, cortical-like nuclei, central nuclei, other amygdaloid nuclei, and the extended amygdala.

questions.text: A person is having increased sexual activity ,increased appetite, anger and no fear, which is the structure injured?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Hypothalamus

Explanation:

The hypothalamus is a crucial brain structure that regulates various physiological functions, such as hunger, thirst, sexual behaviour, and emotions. It plays a central role in maintaining homeostasis and coordinating the body's responses to external stimuli. Injury to the hypothalamus can result in changes in behaviour, including heightened sexual activity, increased appetite, and altered emotional responses.

Amygdala (Option A): The amygdala plays a role in processing emotions, particularly fear and aggression. If there were an injury to the amygdala, it might result in altered emotional responses, including decreased fear and potentially increased aggression, but it would not likely be the primary cause of increased sexual activity and appetite.

Thalamus (Option B): The thalamus serves as a relay center for sensory and motor signals. It is not directly responsible for regulating emotions, sexual activity, appetite, or fear responses.

Cingulate Gyrus (Option C): The cingulate gyrus is involved in emotional processing and regulation, but it is not the primary structure responsible for increased sexual activity, increased appetite, anger, and decreased fear

questions.text: Corticospinal tract crosses at?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Lower medulla

Explanation:

The corticospinal tract decussates (crosses) at the lower medulla, specifically at the pyramidal decussation. This crossing allows for the contralateral (opposite side) control of voluntary motor movements.

Midbrain (option A): The corticospinal tract does not cross at the midbrain. While the midbrain is involved in motor control, the decussation occurs lower in the brainstem.

Pons (option B): The corticospinal tract does not decussate at the pons. The pons plays a role in the communication between the cerebrum and cerebellum but not in the decussation of the corticospinal tract.

Upper medulla (option C): The crossing of the corticospinal tract happens in the lower medulla, not the upper medulla. The upper medulla is the region just above the pyramidal decussation, where the fibers begin to descend before crossing over.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man who has the following lesion over the face. He complains of bleeding while itching. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Correct answer C) Basal cell carcinoma

Explanation:

  • Basal cell carcinoma, a slow-growing malignant tumor, invades locally and primarily affects the pilosebaceous skin. It's mainly categorised into localized and generalized forms, with nodular and nodulocystic variants comprising 90% of cases.
  • Typically, it appears as a pink, pearly papule with telangiectasias, rolled borders, and central crusty ulcerations.

 

Dermatofibrosarcoma (Option A) It is a soft tissue sarcoma that presents as a reddish-brown plaque that does not have rolled borders as seen in the image.

Marjolin’s ulcer (Option B) Marjolin’s ulcer can develop into squamous cell carcinoma. It occurs on a previously long-standing scar. The image shown is not marjolin’s ulcer.

Nevus (Option D) It is a benign skin growth that occurs due to the accumulation of melanocytes. The image shown is not a nevus.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is brought to the casualty with severe abdominal pain radiating to the back for the past 1 day and has had 3 episodes of vomiting. The pain radiates to the back and is slightly relieved in the sitting forward position. The following signs are seen on examination and lab investigations reveal elevated lipase and amylase. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer C) Acute pancreatitis

Explanation:

  • The image shows Cullen’s sign, which is superficial edema with bruising in the subcutaneous fatty tissue around the peri-umbilical region, as well as the Grey Turner sign, which is flank ecchymosis.
  • These signs are indicative of acute pancreatitis.
  • Acute pancreatitis is characterised by pain in the abdomen that radiates to the back and is relieved in the sitting forward position.
  • Elevated lipase and amylase are seen in acute pancreatitis.

 

Acute Appendicitis (Option A) Pain typically starts as periumbilical and later localizes to the right lower quadrant (RLQ) (McBurney’s point). No back radiation or elevated lipase/amylase.

Acute Cholecystitis (Option B) presents with RUQ pain, Murphy’s sign (+), and fever. No back radiation or lipase elevation unless complicated by gallstone pancreatitis.

Acute Ischemic Colitis (Option D) presents sudden severe abdominal pain (out of proportion to clinical findings), often in elderly patients with vascular disease. No elevated lipase/amylase or back radiation.

questions.text: In the lungs, which type of cells are responsible for the secretion of surfactant?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Type 2 pneumocyte

Explanation:

Type 2 pneumocytes are responsible for the production and secretion of surfactant in the lungs. Surfactant is essential for reducing surface tension in the alveoli, preventing alveolar collapse, and facilitating gas exchange.

Type 1 pneumocyte (option A): Type 1 pneumocytes are involved in the structural formation of the alveolar walls and are responsible for gas exchange, not surfactant production.

Alveolar macrophage (option B): Alveolar macrophages (also called dust cells) are immune cells in the lungs that help clear debris, pathogens, and particles, but they do not secrete surfactant.

Dust cells (option C): Dust cells are another term for alveolar macrophages, which are involved in immune responses and clearing particles from the lungs but do not play a role in surfactant secretion.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Marjolin’s ulcer is not true?

choices.text: It is seen in sites of chronic wounds or scars
It can progress to squamous cell carcinoma
It is radioresistant due to avascularity

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) It rapidly progresses to malignancy

Explanation:

  • A marjolin’s ulcer usually occurs on long-standing chronic wound scars. It presents as a non-healing ulcer with elevated margins that grow rapidly.
  • In some cases, it can become malignant and progress to squamous cell carcinoma. It is usually treated by surgical excision using Mohs surgery, where the lesion, along with a 1-2 cm margin is removed.

 

It is seen in the site of chronic wounds or scars (Option A). This statement regarding Marjolin’s ulcer is true.

It can progress to squamous cell carcinoma (Option C) It has a greater chance of progressing to squamous cell carcinoma rather than basal cell carcinoma.

It is radioresistant due to avascularity (Option D). This statement is also true as Marjolin’s ulcer has less vascularity and can be radioresistant.

questions.text: Reflex responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension is?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Bain bridge reflex

Explanation:

The Bainbridge reflex is responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension. This reflex occurs when the right atrium is stretched, typically due to increased venous return, which stimulates stretch receptors. This stimulation increases heart rate to accommodate the increased blood volume and maintain circulation.

Bezold-Jarisch reflex (option A): The Bezold-Jarisch reflex is a paradoxical reflex that causes bradycardia, not tachycardia, in response to myocardial ischemia or certain stimuli such as intravenous administration of certain drugs.

Cushing reflex (option C): The Cushing reflex is a physiological response to increased intracranial pressure, leading to hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular respiration, not tachycardia due to right atrial distension.

Baroreceptor reflex (option D): The baroreceptor reflex helps regulate blood pressure by adjusting heart rate in response to changes in blood pressure, but it is not directly responsible for tachycardia caused by right atrial distension.

questions.text: Identify the procedure shown in the image:
questions.solution:
Correct answer B) Whipple’s procedure

Explaantion:

  • The procedure shown in the image is Whipple’s procedure or pancreaticoduodenectomy. It is the primary surgical treatment for pancreatic cancer.
  • The head of the pancreas, most of the duodenum, a portion of the bile duct, the gallbladder, and associated lymph nodes are removed.
  • Whipple's pancreaticoduodenectomy involves resecting the tumour along with the 'C' loop of duodenum up to DJ flexure, proximal jejunum, head of the pancreas up to the  neck, and partial gastrectomy, followed by three anastomoses: Pancreaticojejunostomy, Hepaticojejunostomy and Gastrojejunostomy typically performed for a mobile growth without metastasis.

 

Berger’s procedure (Option A) In Beger’s procedure all of the head of the pancreas is removed but the bile duct, stomach and duodenum are preserved.

Frey’s procedure (Option C) This procedure includes head coring (a portion of the head of the pancreas is incised). The Duodenum is spared.

Pancreatic division (Option D) The image shown indicates Pancreaticoduodenectomy and not pancreatic division.

questions.text: What is the cause of dicrotic notch?

choices.text: Passive filling of blood in ventricles

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Closure of semilunar valves.

Explanation:

  • The dicrotic notch (incisura) is a small downward deflection seen in the arterial pressure waveform just after the systolic peak.
  • It occurs due to sudden closure of the aortic and pulmonary (semilunar) valves at the end of ventricular systole.
  • This closure causes a brief backflow of blood into the aorta and pulmonary artery, which is then halted, leading to a pressure rebound in the arteries.

Phases of the Arterial Pulse Wave

Phase

Event

Upstroke (Systolic Rise)

Ventricular ejection increases aortic pressure

Systolic Peak

Maximum arterial pressure

Dicrotic Notch

Semilunar valve closure and transient backflow

Diastolic Decay

Gradual pressure decrease as blood moves into periphery

Passive filling of blood in ventricles (Option A): Incorrect because ventricular filling occurs in diastole, unrelated to the dicrotic notch.

Rapid Ejection Phase (Option B): Incorrect because this phase occurs before the dicrotic notch, when blood is actively ejected.

Isovolumic Contraction (Option D): Incorrect because this occurs before semilunar valves open, while the dicrotic notch happens after they close.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding Isovolumic relaxation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) AV valves are closed.

Explanation:

  • Isovolumic relaxation is the phase of the cardiac cycle that occurs after ventricular systole when the ventricles relax but before they fill with blood.
  • During this phase:
    • Ventricles relax → Pressure falls.
    • Semilunar valves (aortic & pulmonary) close to prevent backflow.
    • AV valves remain closed until ventricular pressure drops below atrial pressure.
    • There is no volume change in the ventricles, only a pressure drop.

Cardiac Cycle Phases

Phase

AV Valves

Semilunar Valves

Event

Isovolumic Contraction

Closed

Closed

Ventricles contract but no ejection

Ventricular Ejection

Closed

Open

Blood ejected into aorta & pulmonary artery

Isovolumic Relaxation

Closed

Closed

Ventricles relax, no filling yet

Ventricular Filling

Open

Closed

Blood flows into ventricles

 

[1]

QT Interval (Option B): Incorrect because QT interval represents ventricular depolarization and repolarization, not just isovolumic relaxation.

'C' Wave of JVP (Option C): Incorrect because the 'C' wave occurs during ventricular systole due to bulging of the tricuspid valve into the atrium.

Semilunar Valves Open (Option D): Incorrect because semilunar valves are closed in isovolumic relaxation.

questions.text: A 30-year old male with gradual progressive swelling around his wrist joint for 3 months. Image of the swelling on the x-ray film is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Osteoclastoma

Explanation:

Clinical scenario and x-ray showing eccentric expansile lytic lesion on epiphysis is suggestive of Giant cell tumor/Osteoclastoma (GCT). Management of GCT is Extended curettage and Bone grafting.

Osteoclastoma/ Giant Cell Tumor:

Description
  • Benign but locally aggressive tumor of bone.
  • It commonly arises from epiphysis.
  • MC Age: 20 and 45 years of age.
  • Females > males.

Sites affected
  • Distal femur > proximal tibia > distal radius > sacrum.

Malignancy
  • Malignant transformation in <1% of cases.
  • Lungs are the most common site for metastases.

Clinical features
  • Swelling, vague pain.
  • Pathological fracture.

Radiology
  • X-ray: Expansile eccentric lytic lesion on epiphysis

Histo- pathology
  • Multinucleated giant cells and a background network of spindle-shaped mononuclear stromal cells.

Management
  • Extended curettage with Bone grafting

 

Incorrect options:

Osteosarcoma (Option A):

  • Osteosarcoma is a type of malignant bone tumor that commonly affects children and adolescents. It typically presents with pain and swelling, often in the long bones, such as the tibia. Radiographic features may include bone destruction, irregular bone formation, and sunburst appearance.
  • X-ray: Bone destruction, irregular bone formation, and sunburst appearance.

 

Ewing's sarcoma (Option B):

  • Ewing's sarcoma is a highly malignant bone tumor that primarily affects children and adolescents. It commonly presents with pain, swelling, and a palpable mass.
  • Radiographic features may show a permeative bone destruction, onion skin appearance, and soft tissue involvement.

 

Osteochondroma (Option D):

  • The most common bone tumor (not a True bone tumor), usually presents as a painless lump.
  • Radiography shows sessile pedunculated cartilage tumor covered by a cartilage cap originating from the metaphysis.
  • Cartilage thickness > 2 cms is suggestive of malignancy.

questions.text: Which of the following substance, facilitate the absorption of dietary iron?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Vitamin C

Explanation:

Vitamin C enhances dietary iron absorption by:

  • Reducing Ferric to Ferrous Iron: Converts ferric iron (Fe³⁺) to the more absorbable ferrous form (Fe²⁺) in the acidic stomach environment.
  • Chelation: Forms a soluble complex with iron, preventing it from binding to inhibitors like phytates and tannins.
  • Enhanced Transport: Improves iron uptake by intestinal mucosal cells.

questions.text: What is the current stage of the disease in a patient who presents with hip pain and true shortening of the limb, and is diagnosed with tuberculosis of the hip?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Stage of advanced arthritis

Explanation:

Presence of hip pain and true shortening of the limb is suggestive of Stage-III TB hip, known as Stage of advanced arthritis.

Babulkar and Pandey Clinico-Radiological Classification of TB Hip stages:

Stage

Clinical Findings

X-ray findings

Stage I: Synovitis

(Option A)
  • Irritable hip
  • Increased FABER (Flexion, Abduction, External Rotation)
  • Apparent lengthening due to FABER (Position of ease due to synovitis)
  • Terminal movements are restricted by 25%

Normal or haziness of the articular margins

 

Stage II: Early Arthritis

(Option B)

 
  • Early joint pain, stiffness
  • Increased FADIR (Flexion, Adduction, Internal Rotation)
  • Apparent shortening due to FADIR
  • Gluteal and Quadriceps muscle wasting
  • ROM restricted by 50%

Osteopenia and narrowing of joint space

Stage III: Late Arthritis

(Option C)

 
  • Marked FADIR
  • True shortening
  • Gross restriction of movements (usually >50%)

Marked subchondral erosion and destruction

Stage IV: Pathological Dislocation

/severe arthritis

(Option D)

 
  • Marked FADIR
  • Gross shortening

 
  • Severe destruction and loss of joint space
  • "Wandering/traveling Acetabulum": Pathological dislocation/subluxation due to gross destruction of the femoral head or the superior acetabular margin.

 

  • End stage of TB hip/arthritis: Fibrous ankylosis
  • End stage of TB spine: Bony ankylosis

questions.text: A young man is brought to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. He was driving the car when the accident occurred. On examination, it is noted that the injured leg is shortened. The image of the pelvis radiograph is shown below. Which of the following nerves is most commonly injured in the given condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Sciatic nerve

Explanation:

The scenario here points to the diagnosis of posterior dislocation of the hip, which presents the affected limb as internally rotated, adducted, flexed, and shortened (FADIR). Sciatic nerve is commonly injured in posterior hip dislocation.

Classification of the dislocations of the hip:

  • Posterior dislocation: the most common type, often associated with acetabular lip fracture.
  • Anterior dislocation: rare, typically due to forced abduction and external rotation.
  • Central fracture-dislocation: the femoral head is driven through the acetabulum into the pelvic cavity.

Posterior dislocation of hip

Anterior dislocation of hip

Central dislocation of hip

Mechanism of injury:
Caused by force along the femoral shaft with the hip flexed (e.g., dashboard injury in motor accidents).

Mechanism of injury:

Rare injury that occurs with forced abduction and external rotation.

Mechanism of injury:

The femoral head is driven through the medial wall of the acetabulum into the pelvic cavity.

Clinical Features:

  • History of trauma.
  • Pain, swelling.
  • Deformity: flexion, adduction, internal rotation.
  • Shortening of the leg.
  • The femoral head is palpable in the gluteal region.

Clinical features:

  • The limb appears externally rotated.
  • Possible lengthening of the affected limb
  • The femoral head is palpable in the groin.

 

Clinical features:

  • Varying displacement is seen.
  • Joint stiffness and osteoarthritis are very likely.
  • Nerve injury: common, sciatic nerve is injured.
  • Arterial injury: rare
  • Nerve injury: rare
  • Arterial injury: relatively more common, Femoral artery is injured

questions.text: Cholesterol is synthesized from?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Acetyl coA

Explanation:

Cholesterol is synthesized from acetyl-CoA in the liver through a multi-step process called the mevalonate pathway.

  • Acetyl-CoA → HMG-CoA (via HMG-CoA synthase)
  • HMG-CoA → Mevalonate (via HMG-CoA reductase, the rate-limiting step)
  • Mevalonate is further converted into isoprenoid units, which eventually lead to cholesterol formation.

Phenylalanine(Option B): Amino acid, not involved in cholesterol synthesis.

Malonyl CoA (Option C): Involved in fatty acid synthesis.

Oxaloacetate (Option D): Part of the TCA cycle, not cholesterol synthesis.

questions.text: Identify the procedure shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
Correct answer B) Pancreaticojejunostomy:

Explanation:

  • The procedure shown in the above image is pancreaticojejunostomy. Puestow's operation is indicated for diffuse chronic pancreatitis and dilated pancreatic duct. The duct is opened wide, strictures are cut open, stones are removed, and it is anastomosed to one of the loops of jejunum. This is a by-pass procedure. It preserves both endocrine and exocrine functions.

 

Gastrojejunostomy (Option A) It is the anastomosis of the body of the stomach to the first loop of the jejunum, by passing the duodenum. This procedure does not include the pancreas.

Pancreatic Ileostomy (Option C) is done in case of pancreatic duct obstruction, and the pancreas is anastomosed to the ileum. This procedure is not indicated in the image.

Duodenojejunostomy (Option D) It is a procedure done to anastomose a part of the duodenum to the jejunum to bypass an obstruction in the duodenum. This procedure is not indicated in the image.

questions.text: Enzyme deficient in Gaucher disease :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Betaglucocerebrosidase

Explanation:

Gaucher disease, caused by a defect in beta- glucosidase (glucocerebrosidase), leads to the accumulation of glucosylceramide (glucocerebroside) within macrophages.

  • Lysosomal storage disorder of autosomal recessive inheritance.
  • These macrophages, engorged with glucosylceramide, are known as Gaucher cells.
  • The accumulation affects the bone marrow and spleen, leading to anaemia and thrombocytopenia.
  • Gaucher cells have characteristic appearance of crumbled tissue paper look due to accumulation of glucosylceramide in the cytoplasm of macrophages, forming fibril like structures.

questions.text: The patient experiences an inability to extend their wrist upon waking up after sleeping with their arm hanging over the back of a chair. This condition is caused by
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Neuropraxia

Explanation:

Given clinical scenario is suggestive of Saturday night palsy, which is caused due to transient compression of radial nerve - known as Neuropraxia.

The Seddon classification is a system used to categorize peripheral nerve injuries based on the degree of damage to the nerve and its components.

Type

Description

Prognosis

Neurapraxia

(Grade I)
  • Temporary conduction block, myelin damage only.
  • No neuroma and no degeneration.
  • Recovery is complete within 6 weeks.

Axonotmesis

(Grade II)
  • Axonal damage, connective tissue intact.
  • Neuroma in continuity.
  • Degeneration: Proximally+distally.
  • Recovery can take up to months
  • Complete recovery may not occur.
  • Motor march present

Neurotmesis

(Grade III)
  • Complete nerve disruption.
  • End or side neuroma.
  • Degeneration: Proximally+distally.
  • Spontaneous recovery never occurs.
  • Repair is required (poor recovery)

questions.text: The splint depicted below is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Foot abduction orthosis

Explanation:

The splint shown is Foot abduction orthosis, also known as Dennis-Brown splint used in management of CTEV (Congenital Talipes Equinovarus) or Clubfoot.

Management of CTEV:

Age

Preferred Treatment

<6 months

Ponseti technique:

  • Ideally to be started as soon as possible after birth
  • Correction sequence: Adduction→Varus (inversion)→Equinus (last & difficult to correct)
  • Success rate: 15-80%
  • If success achieved,
    • 6-18 months: Day time Phelp’s brace & Night time Dennis brown splint

18 months-4 years: CTEV shoes

 

1-3 years
  • Turco’s posteromedial soft tissue release
  • McKay’s posteromedial soft tissue release

3-5 years
  • Dillwyn Evans procedure (resection & arthrodesis of calcaneo-cuboid joint)

5-8 years
  • Dwyer’s osteotomy (wedge shaped calcaneum resection)

 

8-10 years
  • Davis osteotomy (wedge tarsectomy)

>10 years
  • Triple arthrodesis: Talocalcaneal-Calcaneocuboid-Talonavicular (TC-CC-TN)

Incorrect Options:

Dimeglio splint (Option B): Dimeglio splint is an orthotic device used to treat club foot.

Ponsetti cast (Option C): It is also a Non-operational corrective method for club feet where the feet are kept in the correct position and a plaster cast is made to keep it in position.

Pirani cast (Option D): It is a casting method used to correct club foot involving gentle manipulation of the foot and application of a plaster cast.

questions.text: The subcellular organelle which is associated with the killing of viruses and bacteria is?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Lysosome

Explanation:

  • Lysosomes are membrane-bound organelles containing hydrolytic enzymes (like proteases, lipases, and nucleases) that digest and destroy pathogens, including viruses and bacteria, through a process called phagocytosis.
  • After engulfment by phagocytes (macrophages), the pathogen is enclosed in a phagosome, which fuses with a lysosome to form a phagolysosome, where enzymatic degradation occurs.

Peroxisome (Option A): Involved in fatty acid oxidation and reactive oxygen species detoxification.

Mitochondria (Option B): Powerhouse of the cell, involved in ATP production.

Golgi apparatus (Option D): Involved in protein modification, packaging, and transport.

questions.text:
Which of the following options is correct with respect to a fed state?

1. Insulin secretion is more

2. Glucagon secretion is less

3. Insulin secretions is less

4. Glucagon secretion is more
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Option 1 and 2 are correct.

Explanation:

Insulin secretion is more and glucagon secretion is less in fed state.

  • In the fed state, or postprandial, elevated glucose levels trigger the release of insulin from the pancreatic B cells.
  • As insulin levels rise, there is an increase in glucose uptake, oxidation, and storage in peripheral tissues as well as increases in other anabolic pathways.
  • In the fed state, pancreatic & cells secrete insulin in response to an increase in blood glucose, amíno acids, and fatty acids.
  • Glucagon is secreted from pancreatic a cells, and glucagon secretion is higher in the fasted state and during exercise.
  • Insulin is secreted more in the fed state than in the fasted state.

questions.text: A young boy presented with fissured tongue, lips, and lesions in the angle of the mouth.On investigation, he had low RBC glutathione reductase activity. Which vitamin is deficient here?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Riboflavin

Explanation:

Riboflavin or Vitamin B2 acts as the coenzyme flavin mononucleotide (FMN) and flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD) in oxidation and reduction reactions.

Lesions of the corner of mouth, lips, and prosthetic group of flavoproteins.

  • The main dietary sources of riboflavin are milk and dairy products. In addition, because of its intense yellow color, riboflavin is widely used as a food additive.

Riboflavin deficiency leads to following signs and symptoms:

  • Cheilosis: It is pallor in the angle of mouth and fissuring of lips.
  • Glossitis: Loss of papilla and increased smoothness of tongue
  • Eyes: Keratitis, conjunctivitis, subcorneal congestion(ist sign) •
  • Seborrheic dermatitis
  • Anemia

For Vitamin B2 deficiency - RBC or erythrocyte glutathione reductase activity should be checked.

questions.text: Thermogenin protein is mainly found in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Mitochondria

Explanation:

Thermogenin is an uncoupling protein (UCP).

  • It is mostly found in the inner mitochondrial membrane in the mitochondria of brown adipose tissue cells.
  • Its main function is to produce heat to maintain the body's temperature.
  • It acts by blocking the formation of ATP and instead, the energy from cellular respiration is used in generating heat.
  • Thermogenin plays a crucial role in thermogenesis and maintains the body temperature.

questions.text: A patient presents with acute swelling in the big toe, and his serum uric acid levels were increased. The doctor prescribed medicine to manage this acute condition. What is the mechanism of this drug?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Neutrophil chemotaxis prevention

  • The clinical scenario describes a case of acute gout, characterised by acute inflammation in the big toe (podagra) and elevated serum uric acid levels.
  • The management of acute gout involves medications that reduce inflammation rather than those targeting uric acid levels.
  • Colchicine is the drug of choice for Acute Gout.
  • Mechanism of Action: Colchicine prevents neutrophil chemotaxis and degranulation by disrupting microtubule polymerisation. This reduces the inflammatory response triggered by urate crystals in the joint.

Drugs for acute attack of gout

DOC- NSAIDS (All types)

  • Except for aspirin and paracetamol
  • Anti-inflammatory

Colchicine  (spindle poison)
  • MOA: Microtubule inhibitor
  • Used in acute attacks of gout and familial Mediterranean fever and is also the DOC for karyotyping

Corticosteroids
  • Intra articular injections, avoid oral route
  • Immunosuppressive and anti-inflammatory

 

Drugs for chronic gout

Xanthine oxidase inhibitors  (Option C)
  • Drugs include Allopurinol (DOC), Oxipurinol, Febuxostat
  • MOA: Blocks xanthine oxidase enzyme → Inhibits the conversion of hypoxanthine to uric acid in the liver.

Uric acid oxidase enzyme
  • Drugs include Pegloticase and Rasburicase
  • MOA: Uric acid is converted to allantoin and excreted in urine

Uricosuric agents (Option B)
  • Drugs include Probenecid, Benzbromaron, Sulfinpyrazone, Lesinurad
  • MOA: Inhibit OATP transporter/URAT-1 in the kidney → inhibits reabsorption of uric acid → increased excretion of uric acid.

 

(OATP - Organic anion transport protein, URAT-1 - Uric acid transporter)

questions.text: Menke's disease is due to a deficiency of:
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Copper

Explanation:

Menke's disease occurs due to a deficiency of copper due to a defect in the absorption of copper from the intestine.

  • Menkes disease (also called kinky hair disease) is a rare, X-linked genetic disorder caused by a deficiency in copper absorption due to mutations in the ATP7A gene.

Key features:

  • Brittle, kinky hair
  • Growth failure
  • Neurodegeneration (seizures, developmental delay)

Pathophysiology:

  • Copper is essential for enzymes like lysyl oxidase (collagen cross-linking) and cytochrome c oxidase (cellular respiration).
  • Impaired copper transport leads to systemic deficiency, affecting enzyme functions.
  • The copper gets trapped in the metallothionine present in the intestinal cells.
  • This prevents the copper from being absorbed into the bloodstream.
  • The symptoms of Menke's disease include reduced copper in plasma and urine, anemia and depigmentation of hair.
  • Can be treated by copper replacement therapy.

questions.text: Which enzyme deficiency causesVon Gierke's disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Glucose 6-phosphatase

Explanation:

Von Gierke’s disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type I) is caused by a deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase, an enzyme responsible for the final step of glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis.

Pathophysiology:

  • Impaired conversion of glucose-6-phosphate to free glucose.
  • Leads to glycogen accumulation in the liver and kidneys, causing hepatomegaly and severe hypoglycemia.

Key symptoms:

  • Severe fasting hypoglycemia
  • Hepatomegaly
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Hyperuricemia and hyperlipidemia

Liver phosphorylase (Option A): Deficiency causes Hers disease (GSD VI).

Lysosomal glucosidase (Option B): Deficiency causes Pompe disease (GSD II).

Hepatic glycogen synthase (Option C): Deficiency causes GSD 0 (reduced glycogen storage).

questions.text: What treatment can be administered to a patient brought to the emergency department with symptoms of diarrhea, sweating, excessive lacrimation, salivation, a garlicky odor, a pulse rate of 55/min, and a plasma cholinesterase level of 50 U/mL?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Atropine

  • The patient presents with symptoms consistent with cholinergic toxicity, which could result from exposure to organophosphates or other cholinergic agents. The key signs—diarrhea, sweating, lacrimation, salivation, a garlicky odor (common in organophosphate poisoning), and a low pulse rate (bradycardia)—suggest cholinergic overstimulation.
  • Atropine, an anticholinergic drug, is the treatment of choice to counteract the excessive acetylcholine and relieve symptoms like bradycardia and excessive secretions.

Organophosphate poisoning

Common exposures
  • Pesticide: Farmer/field worker, pediatric ingestion, suicide attempt
  • Nerve agent: Multiple patients presenting with similar symptoms

Manifestations

 

Muscarinic (DUMBBELSS) :

  • D-Diarrhea
  • U-Urination
  • M-Miosis
  • B-Bronchospasms, bronchorrhea, bradycardia
  • E-Excitation, Emesis
  • L-Lacrimation
  • S-Salivation, sweating

Nicotinic:

  • Muscle weakness, paralysis, fasciculations.

Management
  • Decontamination
  • Atropine reverses muscarinic symptoms
  • Pralidoxime reverses nicotinic and muscarinic symptoms (reactivates cholinesterase)

Neostigmine (Option A) is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, which would worsen cholinergic toxicity by increasing acetylcholine levels. It is used in the treatment of myasthenia gravis, not poisoning.

Epinephrine (Option C): While epinephrine may be used in certain acute allergic or anaphylactic reactions, it is not appropriate for cholinergic toxicity, where atropine is needed to block the effects of excessive acetylcholine.

Benztropine (Option D) is an anticholinergic drug used primarily to treat Parkinson’s disease or drug-induced extrapyramidal symptoms, but it is not suitable for treating cholinergic toxicity.

questions.text: The co-factor for glutathione peroxidase is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Selenium

Explanation:

Selenium (Se) is an essential micronutrient for an antioxidant defence that integrates an important part of selenoproteins.

  • The most well-known selenoproteins are five glutathione peroxidases (GPx), which protect cells from damage caused by free radicals such as reactive oxygen species (ROS).
  • Reduce lipid hydroperoxides to their corresponding alcohols and to reduce free hydrogen peroxide to water.

Manganese (Option A): Not the cofactor for glutathione peroxidase.It is a cofactor for manganese superoxide dismutase, arginase, and pyruvate carboxylase.

Copper (Option C): Cofactor and regulator of copper, zinc superoxide dismutase.

Magnesium (Option D): Cofactor in ATP-generating reactions.

questions.text: A 30-year-old lactating mother presents with pain in her left breast and a fever. On examination of the affected side, there is localised erythema, warmth, and point tenderness, and the fluctuation test is positive. Mild axillary lymphadenopathy is on the affected side, and the contralateral breast is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer C) Breast abscess

Breast Abscess

Definition
  • Pus-filled cavity within the breast tissue.

Types
  • Lactational Abscess: Associated with breastfeeding.
  • Non-Lactational Abscess: Occurs in non-lactating women, e.g., periductal mastitis.

Causes and Risk Factors
  • Lactation:
    • Incidence: 3% to 20% in lactating mothers.
    • Common pathogen: Staphylococcus aureus (methicillin-resistant strains in hospital settings).
    • Entry points: Cracked/retracted nipple, blocked lactiferous ducts.
  • Non-Lactation:
    • Often in nulliparous women or post-lactation.
    • Conditions: Periductal mastitis, idiopathic granulomatous mastitis, tubercular mastitis.
    • Smoking and diabetes as risk factors.

Signs and symptoms
  • Fever, leukocytosis, erythema, pain and tenderness, swelling, malaise, difficulty feeding, enlarged and tender axillary nodes

Diagnosis
  • Ultrasonography:
    • Detects cellulitis, and liquefaction necrosis.
    • Confirms abscess size, location, and loculation.

Treatment
  • Lactational Mastitis:
    • Antibiotics: Anti-staphylococcal (e.g., cloxacillin, flucloxacillin, erythromycin).
    • Breast emptying: Frequent breastfeeding or pumping.
    • Support: Breast support garment, cold compresses, analgesia.
    • Drainage: Ultrasound-guided is preferred over surgical incision.
    • Follow-up: Regular clinical and ultrasonographic reviews, and culture-based antibiotic modification.
  • Non-Lactational Mastitis:
    • Broad-spectrum antibiotics for subareolar infections.
    • Needle aspiration for abscess drainage.
    • Major milk duct excision for complications like sepsis or fistula.

 

Lactational mastitis (Option A): In Lactational mastitis, a cracked nipple is a predisposing factor. It presents with engorgement of lactational ducts and the presence of clumps of milk. It does not cause fluctuance.

Breast carcinoma (Option B) In the case of carcinoma of the breast, we see a fixed lump, ulcerated nipple and peu d orange. The swelling is not fluctuate.

Fibroadenoma (Option D) Fibroadenoma is a benign, painless well defined firm mobile mass which does not show fluctuance.

questions.text: Which of the following medications does not require dosage adjustment for individuals with chronic kidney disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Linagliptin

  • Linagliptin is a DPP-4 inhibitor used in the treatment of type 2 diabetes. It is primarily excreted unchanged in the bile and does not require dose adjustment in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD).

Dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitors:

MOA
  • Increase Incretin Levels: Prevents degradation of incretin hormones (GLP-1 and GIP)
  • Enhance Insulin Secretion from the pancreas in response to meals. (no risk of hypoglycemia)
  • Reduce Glucagon Secretion
  • Maintain neutral weight

Uses
  • Oral hypoglycemic drug (type-2 diabetes)

Drugs
  • Linagliptin: Safe in renal failure
  • Teneligliptin: Safe in renal failure
  • Vildagliptin: Hepatotoxic
  • Alogliptin
  • Sitagliptin
  • Saxagliptin:
    • Metabolised by CYP3A4, it has more drug interactions.
    • Requires dose adjustment in renal impairment.
    • Risk of congestive heart failure.

Side effects
  • Nausea and vomiting (most common)
  • Pancreatitis (lesser than GLP-1)
  • Risk of pancreatic and thyroid cancer (lesser than GLP-1)
  • Arthritis, Nasopharyngitis:
    • Increase interleukins and cytokines levels (similar structure to CD26)
  • Hypersensitivity reactions: Steven-Johnson syndrome, angioedema

questions.text: A 45-year-old lady presented with a swelling in her neck. She had an exposure to radiation in the past. Identify the type of disease, image of FNAC is given below:
questions.solution:
Correct answer A) Papillary Carcinoma

Explanation:

Papillary Carcinoma of the Thyroid

Feature

Details

Definition

Most common thyroid malignancy (80–85%) with excellent prognosis.

Risk Factors

Childhood radiation exposure, BRAF & RET/PTC mutations, family history.

Spread

Lymphatic spread (cervical lymph nodes commonly affected).

Clinical Features

Painless thyroid nodule, cervical lymphadenopathy, euthyroid state.

Histopathology

Orphan Annie eye nuclei, Psammoma bodies, Nuclear grooves, Papillary structures with fibrovascular cores.

Diagnosis

1. Ultrasound – Microcalcifications, hypoechoic nodule, irregular margins. 2. FNAC – First-line test.

Treatment

1. Total thyroidectomy (>1 cm, multifocal, lymph node involvement). 2. Lobectomy (<1 cm, no metastasis). 3. RAI therapy (for residual disease or metastasis). 4. TSH suppression therapy (Levothyroxine).

Prognosis

Excellent (>95% 10-year survival). Worse with older age, distant metastasis, large tumor size, BRAF mutation.

 

Follicular Carcinoma (Option B) Hematogenous spread (not lymphatic like PTC) FNAC cannot differentiate follicular adenoma vs. carcinoma (requires capsular/vascular invasion assessment on histology).

Medullary Carcinoma (Option C) Derived from parafollicular C cells (calcitonin-secreting). FNAC shows amyloid deposits (Congo red positive) and polygonal/spindle cells. Associated with MEN 2A/2B mutations (RET oncogene).

Anaplastic Carcinoma (Option D) Highly aggressive with rapid growth, dysphagia, and hoarseness. FNAC shows pleomorphic giant cells, mitotic figures, and necrosis.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents with dull aching epigastric pain. He gives a history of acute abdominal pain following a binge of alcohol 5 weeks back, which was managed conservatively. On examination, he appeared icteric, and a firm mass was palpable in the epigastrium. His CT scan is given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer A) Pancreatic pseudocyst

Explanation:

  • Pancreatic pseudocyst is a complication seen after 2 weeks of an acute pancreatitis attack. It is commonly seen in alcoholism.
  • The cyst is usually located between the stomach and transverse colon, between the stomach and liver or Behind or below the transverse colon.
  • Clinically a tense cystic mass in the epigastrium, umbilical region or left hypochondrium can be seen.

 

Large choledochal cyst (Option B) Choledochal cyst is a congenital cyst and is not caused due to alcoholism. It is not seen as a tense mass in the epigastrium.

Gastric duplication cyst (Option C) It is a congenital cyst and is not caused by alcoholism. It is seen usually in relation to the distal region of the greater curvature. There is no clinically evident tense mass near the epigastrium.

Mesenteric cyst (Option D) This cyst is congenital

questions.text: Which one of the following medications utilized in the immediate treatment of asthma does not exert its effects by widening the bronchial airways?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Hydrocortisone

  • Hydrocortisone is a corticosteroid that works by reducing inflammation in the airways, not by directly widening the bronchial airways.

Mechanism of Corticosteroids in Asthma:

  • Reduces inflammation in the airways by inhibiting inflammatory mediators (prostaglandins, leukotrienes, cytokines).
  • Decreases mucus production in the airways.
  • Inhibits airway remodelling and thickening of airway walls.
  • Enhances the effectiveness of bronchodilators.

Anti-inflammatory drugs in Asthma :

Salbutamol (Option A) is a short-acting beta-2 agonist that works by relaxing the smooth muscles of the bronchial airways, thereby widening them.

Ipratropium (Option B) is an anticholinergic that works by blocking the action of acetylcholine on the muscarinic receptors, leading to bronchodilation.

Deriphylline (Option C) is a bronchodilator that works by inhibiting phosphodiesterase and promoting bronchodilation.

questions.text: A gross specimen of the colon obtained from a 14-year-old boy is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP)

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis in the above condition is FAP ( familial adenomatous polyposis)

Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP):

  • Caused Autosomal dominant mutation in the APC (Adenomatous Polyposis Coli) gene on chromosome 5q21.
  • 100% risk of colorectal cancer in those with APC gene mutation.
  • 80% of cases are from positive family history.

Clinical Features:

  • Numerous (>100) colorectal adenomatous polyps, typically develop in adolescence or early adulthood.
  • Rectal bleeding, diarrhoea, abdominal pain
  • Extracolonic manifestations: Congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE), desmoid tumours, upper gastrointestinal polyps, epidermoid cyst (Gardner syndrome)
  • Increased risk of other cancers: duodenal, thyroid, brain (medulloblastoma), hepatoblastoma

Diagnosis:

  • Colonoscopy showing >100 polyps and biopsy showing an adenomatous variety of polyp.

Treatment: The aim of Surgery in FAP is to prevent the development of colorectal cancer.

  • Restorative proctocolectomy with an ileal pouch-anal anastomosis.
  • Colectomy with ileorectal anastomosis (IRA)
  • Total proctocolectomy and end-ileostomy.

 

Crohn's disease (Option A) While it can cause rectal bleeding, it doesn't typically present with numerous polyps throughout the colon.

Lynch syndrome/Hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC) (Option C) This condition increases cancer risk but doesn't usually cause numerous polyps. The average age of onset is later than FAP.

Juvenile polyposis syndrome (Option D) This can cause multiple polyps, but they are typically hamartomatous rather than adenomatous, fewer in number than FAP.

questions.text: A 10-month-old male baby presented with an empty scrotum. Ultrasonography revealed that the right testis was found in the right inguinal canal, while the left testis was found in the perineum. Comment on the diagnosis of this baby.

choices.text: Right-side undescended testis and left-sided ectopic testis
Right side ectopic testis and left side undescended testis

questions.solution:
Correct Option C) Right-side undescended testis and left-sided ectopic testis

Explanation:

  • In the case of undescended testis the testis is usually found in the route at which it descends, such as the inguinal canal.
  • In the above patient, the right testis was found in the inguinal canal. In ectopic testis, the testis is found in places other than the route of descent of the testis, as in this case, the left testis is seen in the perineum. Hence, the correct choice is Right-side undescended testis and left-sided ectopic testis.

 

Bilateral undescended testis (Option A) The left testis is found in the perineum, which is indicative of ectopic testis.

Bilateral ectopic testis (Option B) The right testis is found in the inguinal canal, which is indicative of an undescended testis.

Right side ectopic testis and left side undescended testis (Option D) The right testis is found in the inguinal canal and is indicative of undescended testi,s whereas the left side is found in the perineum which is indicative of ectopic testis.

 

Ectopic testis

  • An ectopic testis is when a testicle fails to descend into the scrotum and lies outside the normal descent tract, typically due to abnormalities in the gubernaculum

Management:

Surgical Correction (Orchidopexy): To reposition the testis into the scrotum.

Complications:

  • Infertility
  • Increased risk of testicular cancer

questions.text: Dopamine at low doses causes:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Increases renal blood flow.

  • At low doses, dopamine primarily acts on dopaminergic receptors (D1) in the renal and mesenteric vasculature, leading to vasodilation and an increase in renal blood flow.

Action of Dopamine:

Dopamine Dose

Receptor Activation

Effects

< 2 µg/kg/min

D1 receptors

Increases renal blood flow; vasodilation in renal and mesenteric vessels

2-10 µg/kg/min

β1 receptors (heart)

Increases heart rate (positive chronotropic) and contractility (positive inotropy)

> 10 µg/kg/min

α1 receptors

Vasoconstriction (increased systemic vascular resistance) and increased blood pressure

questions.text: Which PDE-5 inhibitor has the longest duration of action among the options provided?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Tadalafil

  • Tadalafil has the longest duration of action among PDE-5 inhibitors, lasting 24 - 36 hours & is used in the management of pulmonary hypertension and erectile dysfunction.
  • PDE-5 inhibitors work by inhibiting the enzyme phosphodiesterase type 5 (PDE-5), which is found in the smooth muscle of the penis, lungs, and other vascular tissues.
  • By blocking PDE-5, these drugs increase the levels of cyclic GMP (cGMP), leading to smooth muscle relaxation and vasodilation.

Duration of other PDE5 inhibitors:

  • Sildenafil - 10-12 hours (Option A)
  • Vardenafil - 8-10 hours (Option C)
  • Avanafil - 4-6 hours (Option D)

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the dose-response curve?

choices.text: Drug B is the most efficacious
Drug B is the most potent
Drug C is more efficacious than drug D
Drug A is more potent than drug B

questions.solution:
Correct Answer B  - Drug B is the most potent

The more the curve is on the left side, the greater its potency. Hence, drug B is the most potent. Order of potency: B > A > C > D

  • Efficacy is the maximal effect a drug can produce, represented by the Vmax /y-axis value. The higher the Vmax, the higher the efficacy.
  • Potency is the amount of drug required to produce a given effect. The lower the drug dose needed, the higher the potency.
  • Both are independent of each other; efficacious drugs can have high or low potency and vice versa.

  • The first graph helps us estimate the efficacy of the drugs (the higher the Vmax, the higher the efficacy, Thus order of efficacy: Drug A > B >C >D.
  • The second graph helps us estimate the drugs' potency (The lower the drug dose needed, the higher the potency). The left shift of the graph indicates an increase in potency.
  • Thus, the order of potency: Drug D > B > C > A.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 14-year-old boy who is experiencing sudden scrotal pain, where physical examination reveals a swollen and red scrotum with the right testes being retracted, absent cremasteric reflex, and negative Prehn's sign?
questions.solution:
Correct answer C) Right testicular torsion

Explanation:

  • In the case of torsion of the testis, the testicular clinical features include an empty, swollen scrotum, which is edematous on the side of the lesion. Tender lump at the external abdominal ring. Elevation of the scrotum increases pain.

 

Right-sided hydrocele (Option A) Hydrocele presents with a painless swelling. No sudden pain is seen in the right-sided hydrocele. Hence, it is not the correct choice.

Strangulated inguinal hernia (Option B) In the case of a strangulated inguinal hernia, the scrotum will show ischemic changes but will not be edematous.

Right epididymo orchitis (Option D) It is an inflammation of the epididymis. It is caused by a bacterial infection and presents as a swelling on the posterior aspect of the epididymis.

questions.text: Patients receiving which of the following antimicrobial drugs are least likely to develop seizures?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Macrolides

  • Macrolides (e.g., azithromycin, clarithromycin) generally have a low risk of causing seizures. They are more commonly associated with side effects like gastrointestinal issues (nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain) and, in rare cases, may cause conditions such as infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS) in children. However, seizures are not a common side effect.

Antimicrobials associated with Seizures:

  • Penicillins (e.g., Piperacillin, Nafcillin) (Option A)
  • Cephalosporins (e.g., Cefepime)
  • Carbapenems (e.g., Imipenem, Meropenem)
  • Quinolones (e.g., Ciprofloxacin, Levofloxacin, Moxifloxacin) (Option B)
  • Isoniazid (Option D)
  • Acyclovir
  • Gancyclovir

questions.text: Which of the following antidepressant drugs acts by inhibiting the reuptake of both serotonin and norepinephrine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Venlafaxine

  • Venlafaxine is a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI) that works by inhibiting serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake, which helps improve mood and reduce anxiety.

Class

Examples

SSRI (Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors)
  • Fluoxetine (Option A)
  • Paroxetine (Option C)
  • Sertralin
  • Citalopram
  • Escitalopram
  • Dapoxetine (Option D)

SNRI (Serotonin-Norepinephrine Reuptake Inhibitors)
  • Venlafaxine
  • Duloxetine
  • Desvenlafaxine
  • Milnacipran

TCA (Tricyclic Antidepressants)
  • Amitriptyline
  • Nortriptyline
  • Imipramine
  • Clomipramine

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used in the closure of patent ductus arteriosus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Indomethacin

  • Indomethacin is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that is commonly used to promote the closure of a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), especially in premature infants.
  • It works by inhibiting prostaglandins, which play a role in keeping the ductus arteriosus open.
  • Ibuprofen, a nonselective COX inhibitor, is the drug of choice for closing a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) in premature infants by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis, primarily PGE2 (maintains ductus arteriosus patency during fetal development) through COX enzyme inhibition.
  • Due to its lower risk of renal toxicity, it is considered a safer option than indomethacin for PDA closure in neonates.

 

Uses of NSAIDs

NSAIDs are avoided in
  • Analgesic (in all types of pain except neuropathic pain)
  • Antipyretic
  • Anti-inflammatory
  • Antiplatelet
  • Tocolytic
  • Closure of PDA
  • Pregnancy (as it causes premature closure of ductus arteriosus)
  • Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD)
  • Safest NSAID in these cases is paracetamol.

Magnesium sulfate (Option A) is used to manage conditions such as preeclampsia, preterm labour, torsades de pointes, acute myocardial infarction, eclampsia, seizure control, and migraines. It does not influence the patency of the ductus arteriosus.

Alprostadil (Option B) is used to treat erectile dysfunction, patent ductus arteriosus, and pulmonary arterial hypertension. It is primarily employed to maintain the patency of the ductus arteriosus, not to close it.

Paracetamol (Option D) is an analgesic and antipyretic used for pain relief and reducing fever. It does not facilitate the closure of the patent ductus arteriosus, as it does not impact prostaglandin synthesis.

questions.text: What is the preferred medication for managing ventricular arrhythmia caused by digoxin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Lignocaine

  • Lignocaine (Lidocaine) is the preferred drug for managing ventricular arrhythmias caused by digoxin toxicity.
  • It is a Class 1b antiarrhythmic that stabilises the cardiac membrane and inhibits abnormal electrical impulses.

Procainamide (Option A) is a Class 1A antiarrhythmic drug primarily used to manage arrhythmias such as Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome, supraventricular arrhythmias, atrial flutter, atrial fibrillation, and AV nodal reentrant tachycardia. However, it is not the first-line treatment for ventricular arrhythmias caused by digoxin toxicity.

Atropine (Option C) is an anticholinergic medication used primarily to treat bradycardia. It can also be utilized in the treatment of diarrhea, as it helps reduce gastrointestinal motility. However, it is not effective for treating arrhythmias caused by digoxin toxicity.

Propranolol (Option D) is a non-selective beta-blocker used to treat various conditions such as high blood pressure, tremors, and irregular heartbeats and to prevent migraines. While effective for managing certain cardiac conditions, it is not recommended for managing ventricular arrhythmias induced by digoxin, as it may exacerbate the toxicity.

questions.text: For the treatment of thyroid cancer, which radioactive iodine isotope among the options listed below is used?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Iodine-131

  • Iodine-131 is the radioactive isotope most commonly used in the treatment of thyroid cancer. It emits both beta radiation (which helps in destroying thyroid cancer cells) and gamma radiation (which is used for diagnostic imaging). Therefore, it is used for both therapeutic and diagnostic purposes in thyroid disorders.

Iodine-131 (I-131):

  • Physical Half-life: 8 days.
  • Radiation Emission: Emits beta particles (for therapeutic effect) and gamma rays (for diagnostic imaging).
  • Uses:
    • Diagnostic: I-131 is used in low doses (25-100 µCi) for thyroid scans to assess thyroid function.
    • Therapeutic: I-131 is used to treat hyperthyroidism (e.g., Graves' disease, toxic nodular goitre) and metastatic thyroid cancer.
  • Mechanism of Action:
    • Concentration in Thyroid: Iodine-131 is concentrated in the thyroid gland, where beta particles destroy thyroid cells, leading to necrosis and fibrosis.
    • Effect on Hyperthyroidism: Gradual onset, typically requiring 2-3 months for full therapeutic effect.

Iodine-125 (Option A): Primarily used in radiotherapy for cancers and for brachytherapy (internal radiation treatment). It has a much longer half-life and lower energy radiation compared to Iodine-131, making it suitable for localized therapy.

Iodine-127 (Option C): This is the stable, naturally occurring isotope of iodine and is not radioactive. It does not have any therapeutic or diagnostic application in radioactive iodine therapy.

Iodine-123 (Option D): A diagnostic isotope used in scintigraphy or thyroid imaging. It emits gamma rays and is commonly used for thyroid scans to assess thyroid function without the therapeutic effects seen with Iodine-131.

questions.text: A child, after disturbing a bee hive, experienced several stings. A few minutes later, the child developed breathing difficulty and hypotension. What is the drug of choice for managing this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Adrenaline

  • Adrenaline (Epinephrine) is the first-line treatment for anaphylactic reactions caused by bee stings, as it quickly reverses symptoms by acting on alpha and beta receptors, helping to improve airway patency and increase blood pressure.
  • Anaphylaxis is a Type I Hypersensitivity reaction.
  • Adrenaline works on all adrenergic receptors and is commonly used in anaphylactic shock in a diluted form, typically a 1:1000 concentration (1 mg of adrenaline in 1 mL of solution). It is administered intramuscularly because, in shock conditions, peripheral blood flow is reduced. If the intramuscular injection does not show a response, intravenous administration may be considered.

Uses of Epinephrine

Condition

Use

Dilution/Concentration

Route of Administration

Anaphylaxis

First-line treatment for severe allergic reactions

1:1000 (1 mg/mL)
  • Intramuscular (IM)

Cardiac arrest

To restore cardiac rhythm and blood pressure

1:10,000 (0.1 mg/mL)
  • Intravenous (IV)
  • Intraosseous (IO)

Asthma

Treatment of acute severe asthma attacks

1:1000 (1 mg/mL)
  • Inhalation via nebulizer
  • Intramuscular (IM)
  • subcutaneous (SC)

Hypotension

To increase blood pressure

1:100,000 (0.01 mg/mL)
  • Intravenous (IV) infusion

Local anesthesia

Enhance duration and intensity of the local anaesthetic effect

1:200,000 to 1:100,000 (0.005 to 0.01 mg/mL)
  • Local injection

Dobutamine (Option A): This is an inotropic agent used for short-term management of severe heart failure, especially after myocardial infarction or cardiac surgery. It is not indicated for anaphylaxis.

Noradrenaline (Option C): Although it acts on alpha-1, alpha-2, and beta-1 receptors, it does not affect beta-2 receptors, which are crucial for bronchial dilation. Therefore, it is not suitable for treating anaphylactic shock, which requires bronchodilation.

Dopamine (Option D): This drug is used in conditions like cardiogenic or septic shock, where it helps to improve renal blood flow and cardiac output. It does not have the bronchodilatory effect needed in anaphylaxis and does not cause tachycardia, as it primarily affects muscle tissues rather than nodal tissues.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with muscle weakness, blurred vision after exertion, and ptosis, which improves after undergoing the edrophonium test. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Myasthenia gravis

  • The presence of ptosis, muscle weakness, and blurred vision, along with a positive edrophonium (Tensilon) test, supports the diagnosis of MG.
  • Edrophonium temporarily improves symptoms by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase, allowing more acetylcholine to bind to receptors.

Edrophonium test (Tensilon test):

  • It helps differentiate between myasthenic and cholinergic crises, which present with similar symptoms but require opposite treatments.
  • Myasthenic crisis arises from inadequate acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction.
  • The cholinergic crisis results from excessive acetylcholine stimulation due to anticholinesterase medication overdose.
  • The tensilon test involves the injection of 10 mg i.v. Edrophonium, a short-acting anticholinesterase agent.
  • 2 mg i.v. Edrophonium → Observe for any adverse reactions → If no adverse reactions occur after 30–60 seconds, the remaining 8 mg is injected.

Results:

  • Myasthenia Gravis: Short-lasting improvement in muscle strength.
  • Other Muscular Dystrophies: No improvement.
  • Cholinergic crisis: No improvement or a worsening of their condition.

Lambert Eaton syndrome (Option A): This disorder is characterized by muscle weakness, but it primarily affects the proximal muscles and is caused by antibodies against presynaptic calcium channels, leading to reduced acetylcholine release. Unlike MG, symptoms of Lambert Eaton syndrome improve with activity rather than worsening.

Guillain-Barré syndrome (Option C): This is an acute polyneuropathy, typically triggered by an infection, leading to rapid progressive weakness, usually starting in the lower limbs and affecting both proximal and distal muscles. It is not associated with the symptoms described in this case.

Bronchial asthma (Option D): This condition primarily involves respiratory symptoms such as wheezing, shortness of breath, and coughing and is not related to the muscle weakness and ptosis seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man who had travelled to Assam recently presents with fever, chills, seizures, and altered sensorium. On examination, his blood pressure is 70/50 mm Hg, and laboured breathing is observed. A blood smear reveals Plasmodium falciparum. What is the drug of choice in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Intravenous artesunate

  • Plasmodium falciparum causes severe malaria, which can lead to complications such as altered consciousness, seizures, and hypotension, making it a life-threatening condition.
    • Intravenous artesunate is the preferred and recommended treatment for severe falciparum malaria, as it acts rapidly and effectively.

Complicated malaria is a life-threatening form of malaria caused by P. falciparum. Treatment is given parenterally.

  • DOC: IV Artemisinin
  • 2nd: IM artemether/arteether
  • 3rd: IV Quinine in 5% dextrose (quinine is hypoglycemic)

NVBDCP guidelines:

Scenario

Treatment

Uncomplicated P. Vivax malaria

Chloroquine 25 mg/kg over 3 days (10-10-5) + Primaquine oral 0.25 mg/kg for 14 days

Complicated malaria

Parenteral ACT-Artesunate IV given for 2 days, followed by a full course of oral ACT.

 

(OR)

 

Parenteral quinine IV given for 2 days, and oral quinine given for 5 days. Add on oral doxycycline

Mixed infection
(P. vivax/ovale/falciparum)

ACT+ Primaquine for 14 days

Pregnancy

1st trimester: Parenteral quinine

2nd and 3rd trimester: Parenteral artemisinin

Chloroquine (Option A) is primarily used to treat conditions like rheumatoid arthritis, extraintestinal amebiasis, and lupus erythematosus, but it is not effective for severe Plasmodium falciparum malaria, especially in regions with resistance.

Quinine (Option B) is used for treating complicated malaria, including cerebral malaria, but intravenous artesunate is preferred due to its faster action and better efficacy in severe cases.

Artemether (Option D): While artemether, another artemisinin derivative, is used to treat malaria, intravenous artesunate is preferred for severe cases of Plasmodium falciparum malaria due to its superior speed of action and effectiveness.

questions.text: Which of the following medications is most suitable for treating cryptorchidism (undescended testes)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Pulsatile GnRH

  • Cryptorchidism (undescended testes) can be treated with pulsatile GnRH (Gonadotropin-releasing hormone).
  • Pulsatile GnRH stimulates the release of LH and FSH, which in turn can promote testicular descent by stimulating testosterone production.

Non-pulsatile GnRH (Option B) does not stimulate the release of LH and FSH in the same way as pulsatile GnRH, making it ineffective for treating cryptorchidism.

Testosterone (Option C) is not typically used to treat cryptorchidism. Although it is involved in the process, direct administration of testosterone does not encourage testicular descent.

Estrogen (Option D) is not used in the treatment of cryptorchidism; it is used for other hormonal purposes such as contraceptives or menopause management.

questions.text: Which neurotransmitter is primarily responsible for the condition observed in a 55-year-old male who presents with rigidity, frequent falls, slowness in movements, tremors, and a short stepping gait?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Dopamine

  • The symptoms described are characteristic of Parkinson's disease, which is caused by a deficiency of dopamine in the brain, particularly in the basal ganglia.
  • Dopamine is essential for regulating movement and coordination, and its deficiency leads to the motor symptoms seen in Parkinson's disease.

Primary Parkinson's disease:

  • Idiopathic progressive neurodegenerative disease of dopaminergic neurons in the basal ganglia.
  • Symptoms: rigidity, bradykinesia (slow movement), resting tremors, shuffling gait
  • Treatment:
    • Levodopa is the DOC in Parkinson’s disease > 65 years
    • The drug is converted into dopamine inside the basal ganglia via dopa decarboxylase.
    • Crosses the BBB and replenishes the dopamine level in the CNS
    • Degraded via MAO-B and COMT enzymes.
  • Alternative treatment options:
    • Amantadine is an NMDA antagonist and increases dopamine release.
    • COMT inhibitors (Entacapone, Tolcapone) and MAO inhibitors (Rasagiline, Selegiline): Prevent dopamine degradation.
    • Benztropine: Reduces central cholinergic activity by blocking muscarinic receptors.

GABA (Option A) is an inhibitory neurotransmitter that helps reduce anxiety, stress, and depression. It also plays a role in regulating the pancreas by inhibiting alpha cells and stimulating beta cells.

Acetylcholine (Option B) is an excitatory neurotransmitter that transmits signals from the brain to other parts of the body. Excessive acetylcholine can lead to muscle weakness, fatigue, and cramps.

Serotonin (Option D) is both a neurotransmitter and a hormone. It is primarily involved in regulating the sleep-wake cycle, as well as influencing mood and feelings of happiness.

questions.text: A student complains of developing urticaria following the consumption of seafood. Considering the need for non-sedating medication due to an upcoming exam, which of the following drugs would you choose to prescribe?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Fexofenadine

  • Fexofenadine is a second-generation antihistamine that is non-sedating and effective for managing allergic reactions like urticaria (hives). It does not cross the blood-brain barrier significantly, so it does not cause sedation, making it ideal for the student who needs to stay alert for the exam.
  • Sedation and drowsiness are common side effects of first-generation antihistamines, which can impair cognitive function and alertness, affecting the patient's ability to perform tasks requiring mental acuity throughout the day.

Drugs that act by blocking Histamine H1 receptors:

Generation

Drug

Side Effects

Generalised Uses

1st Generation

 

Diphenhydramine (Option B)

Sedation, drowsiness, dry mouth, blurred vision

Allergy symptoms, Insomnia, Motion sickness

Chlorpheniramine (Option A)

Sedation, drowsiness, dry mouth

 

Allergy symptoms

Hydroxyzine  (Option C)

Anxiety, Allergy symptoms, Pruritus

2nd Generation

Loratadine

 

Minimal sedation, dry mouth

 

Allergy symptoms, Urticaria

Cetirizine

Allergy symptoms, Itchiness, Urticaria

Fexofenadine

Non-sedating, minimal side effects

Allergy symptoms, Chronic idiopathic urticaria

questions.text: Which of the options below acts as a selective alpha-1 receptor antagonist in medical practice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Prazosin

  • Prazosin is a selective alpha-1 receptor antagonist commonly used to treat hypertension and symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia.
  • It works by blocking alpha-1 receptors, leading to vasodilation and a decrease in blood pressure.

Classification of Alpha-blockers based on their receptor binding

Types

Drugs

Non-
competitive + irreversible type

Phenoxybenzamine

 

Competitive + reversible type

Non-selective

 

 

 

Phentolamine

Ergotamine

Ergotoxine

Chlorpromazine

 

 

 

 

 

Alpha 1 selective

Drugs

Location

Effects

Alpha 1 a

Tamsulosin

Silodosin

Internal Urethral Sphincter

Iris

Ejaculation failure/retrograde ejaculation, miosis, increased urine outflow

Alpha 1 b

Alfuzosin

Doxazosin

Prazosin

Terazosin

Vascular Smooth Muscle

Vasodilatation, reflex tachycardia, reduced GFR (thus leading to RAAS activation)

Alpha 2 selective

Yohimbine

Idoxazon

Central Nervous System

Penile erection (used in depression with sexual dysfunction)

 

Prazosin is a highly selective ɑ1 blocker.

Side effects
  • Postural hypotension (first dose effect) - due to alpha 1b receptor blockade on vascular smooth muscles
  • Retrograde ejaculation: Due to alpha 1a receptors blockade on internal urethral sphincter
  • Floppy iris syndrome: Due to the blockade of the alpha 1a receptor on the iris
  • Reflex tachycardia occurs due to vasodilation.

Uses
  • Hypertension
  • Benign prostatic hyperplasia
  • Raynaud’s disease
  • Scorpion Bite.

Phenoxybenzamine (Option A) is a non-selective alpha blocker that primarily targets both alpha-1 and alpha-2 receptors. It is typically used to treat pheochromocytoma but is not a selective alpha-1 antagonist.

Phentolamine (Option B) is also a non-selective alpha blocker, acting on both alpha-1 and alpha-2 receptors. It is used to manage hypertensive crises and pheochromocytoma.

Idazoxan (Option D) is an alpha-2 receptor antagonist, not an alpha-1 antagonist. It is primarily used in research rather than clinical practice.
