questions.text: During a routine check-up, an elderly male was discovered to have a rectal mass during a digital rectal examination, indicating the possibility of rectal carcinoma. Despite normal bowel habits, the next course of action for managing this patient should be:
questions.solution:
Correct answer C) Full colonoscopy and biopsy

Explanation

  • A full colonoscopy is done to confirm the diagnosis of rectal carcinoma and to rule out the presence of any synchronous lesions.
  • If any lesions are identified, a biopsy should be done to confirm the diagnosis and determine the stage and the characteristics of the tumor.

Investigations and Diagnosis of Rectal Carcinoma

  • Digital Rectal Examination:
    • Used to assess the size, consistency (hard), shape (Irregular), and mobility (mobile, tethered, or fixed).
    • A vaginal examination is recommended for women to check for involvement of the posterior vaginal wall.
  • Rigid Sigmoidoscopy:
    • Outpatient procedure for visualising the neoplasm and obtaining biopsies
  • Biopsy and Histological Analysis:
    • Crucial for confirming the diagnosis and distinguishing rectal carcinoma from conditions that may mimic it, such as inflammatory strictures, granulomas, and benign adenomas.
  • Staging Investigations:
    • CT chest, abdomen, and pelvis.
    • Local pelvic imaging with MRI and/or endoluminal ultrasonography provides detailed information about local tumour spread, including infiltration into surrounding tissues and lymph node involvement.
  • Colonoscopy:
    • Essential for most patients to rule out synchronous tumours elsewhere in the colon.
    • Techniques like "dye spray" colonoscopy help differentiate benign from malignant lesions based on mucosal 'pit patterns'.
    • Proximal adenomas can be removed during the procedure; finding synchronous carcinomas may alter surgical strategy.
  • CT Colonography or Barium Enema:
    • Alternatives to colonoscopy if full visualization of the colon is not possible due to stenosing cancer.

 

CT scan of the abdomen (Option A) CT scan of the abdomen is useful in determining the size, location and staging of the tumour.

Rigid sigmoidoscopy and biopsy (Option B) This procedure can only be used to examine the distal portion of the rectum and sigmoid colon but not the entire colon.

Barium enema (Option D) This technique was used earlier but now is vastly replaced by colonoscopy as it is a better diagnostic procedure.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presented with a low-grade fever of 1-week duration associated with loss of appetite and weight loss. Barium meal follow-through image of the patient is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer A) Ileocaecal TB

Explanation:

  • In the barium study of the ileum in the case of ileocaecal TB, these are the signs that can be seen in the narrowing of the terminal ileum.
  • Thickening of the ileocecal valve and the thickening of the cecal walls, the cecum appears as a conical shape. In later stages, the ileum is fixed and rigid.

Ileocecal Tuberculosis:

Feature

Details

Definition

A form of abdominal tuberculosis affecting the ileocecal region, the most common site of gastrointestinal TB.

Why the Ileocecal Region?

Rich in lymphoid tissue, slow transit time, and increased uptake of tubercle bacilli.

Common Symptoms

Right lower quadrant (RLQ) pain, weight loss, fever, diarrhoea/constipation, and abdominal mass.

Differential Diagnoses

Crohn’s disease, appendicitis, colorectal cancer, lymphoma.

Physical Examination

RLQ tenderness, palpable mass, signs of obstruction (in severe cases).

Imaging Findings

Ultrasound/CT scan: Bowel wall thickening, lymphadenopathy, ascites, strictures.

Endoscopic Findings

Colonoscopy: Ulcers, nodularity, strictures in the ileocecal region.

Histopathology

Caseating granulomas, acid-fast bacilli (AFB) on Ziehl-Neelsen stain.

Definitive Diagnosis

AFB culture, PCR for Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

Treatment

Anti-TB Therapy (ATT): Rifampicin, Isoniazid, Pyrazinamide, Ethambutol (2 months), followed by Rifampicin + Isoniazid (4 months).

Indications for Surgery

Bowel obstruction, perforation, abscess, stricture, and unresponsiveness to ATT.

Surgical Options

Limited resection (if necessary), stricturoplasty (for non-resectable strictures).

 

Ulcerative colitis (Option B): Radiologically, ulcerative colitis presents with a contracted, pipe-stem colon and thickened, edematous haustra.

Crohn’s disease (Option C): Radiologically, Crohn’s disease is characterised by a cobblestone appearance, making it an incorrect choice.

Carcinoma caecum (Option D) In the case of carcinoma of the cecum, you can see apple core deformity on the right side of the right iliac fossa and not at the terminal ileum.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 42-year-old woman who came with symptoms of fever, vomiting, and right hypochondriac pain, which radiates to the neck? She has experienced similar episodes in the past, and a positive Murphy's sign was observed during the examination.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Acute cholecystitis

Explanation:

  • Murphy's sign: when we place the fingers on the right hypochondrium and ask the patient to take deep inspiration. At the height of inspiration, there is a sudden catch. This catch is due to an inflamed gallbladder coming in contact with the abdominal wall. This produces pain.
  • In the case of acute cholecystitis, there is inflammation of the gallbladder, and Murphy's sign is positive.

 

Murphy’s sign is not positive in carcinoma of the gallbladder (Option B), peptic ulcer (Option C), or acute appendicitis (Option D), as it is specifically associated with acute cholecystitis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man arrives at the emergency department with a concern of vomiting blood. He mentions a recent pattern of excessive alcohol consumption. Upon examination, his vital signs are steady, and he has a pale appearance. There are no indications of ongoing bleeding. The results of his liver function tests are within the normal range. To further assess the situation, an upper gastrointestinal endoscopy is scheduled. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer C) Mallory-Weiss tear

Explanation:

  • Mallory-Weiss tears are longitudinal mucosal lacerations that occur at the gastroesophageal junction, usually due to severe vomiting or retching.
  • Binge alcohol drinking can lead to forceful vomiting, which may cause these tears. Mallory-Weiss tears are a common cause of upper gastrointestinal bleeding in individuals with a history of alcohol abuse, and they can present with hematemesis.

 

Esophageal varices (Option A) While alcohol abuse can contribute to liver disease, the absence of liver function abnormalities make esophageal varices less likely.

Gastric ulcer (Option B) Risk factors like Helicobacter pylori infection or non-steroidal anti inflammatory drug (NSAID) use is usually more significant in developing gastric ulcers.

Alcoholic gastritis (Option D) Absence of any liver function abnormalities and considering the presentation with hematemesis, Mallory-Weiss tear is a more probable diagnosis compared to alcoholic gastritis.

questions.text: Which of the following accurately represents Bormann's classification for gastric carcinoma?

choices.text: Type I: Polypoid tumor with a small ulcerated component
Type II: Ulcerated tumor with infiltrative margins
Type III: Diffusely infiltrative tumor with linitis plastica appearance
Type IV: Mucinous carcinoma with extensive peritoneal metastases

questions.solution:
Correct answer A) Type I: Polypoid tumor with a small ulcerated component:

Explanation:

  • Borrman's classification is a pathologic classification system based on the macroscopic appearance of gastric carcinomas.
  • Type I tumours are characterised by a diffuse polypoidal growth pattern.
  • This combination of a predominantly polypoid growth with a small ulcerated area distinguishes Type I gastric carcinomas according to Borrman's classification.

Bormann’s Classification of Gastric Carcinoma

Bormann Type

Macroscopic Appearance

Key Features

Type I (Polypoid type)

Polypoid or fungating mass

Well-defined borders, grow into the lumen, minimal invasion into the gastric wall, mand ay have a small ulcerated component.

Type II (Ulcerated tumor with distinct borders)

Ulcerated lesion with raised margins

Clearly defined infiltrative edges, but not deeply penetrating into surrounding tissues. (Option B ruled out)

Type III (Ulceroinfiltrative type)

(Option C ruled out)

Deep ulceration with infiltrative margins

Irregular and poorly defined borders, penetrate deeper into the gastric wall, more aggressive than Type II.

Type IV (Diffuse/Infiltrative type – Linitis Plastica)

(Option D ruled out)

Diffuse thickening of the stomach wall

Infiltrative growth without a discrete mass, causes "a leather bottle stomach" appearance, commonly associated with signet-ring cell carcinoma.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain and vomiting. He reports a 2-day history of constipation and bloating. On examination, he appears uncomfortable, and his abdomen is distended with high-pitched bowel sounds. X-ray reveals dilated loops of the small bowel. What is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct answer B) Small bowel obstruction

Explanation:

Small bowel obstruction is the most likely cause in this case. The patient's acute symptoms, abdominal distension, high-pitched bowel sounds, and dilated loops of small bowel on X-ray is consistent with a mechanical obstruction in the small bowel.

 

Colonic malignancy (Option A) Colonic malignancy can lead to obstruction, but it typically causes a gradual onset of symptoms, such as changes in bowel habits, blood in stool, and weight Loss.

Acute pancreatitis (Option C) The presentation of acute pancreatitis often includes epigastric pain radiating to the back, elevated serum amylase or lipase levels and may be associated with gallstones or alcohol consumption.

Gastric ulcer (Option D) Gastric ulcers are typically associated with symptoms such as epigastric pain, heartburn, and may be exacerbated by eating.

Small Bowel Obstruction (SBO)

Causes
  • Adhesions (Most common)
  • Malignancy
  • Metastasis
  • Peritoneal carcinomatosis
  • Hernia
  • Crohn's Disease
  • Tb
  • PID
  • Post radiotherapy
  • Cancer

Surgeries with High Risk of Adhesive Small Bowel Obstruction (SBO)
  • Pelvic surgeries (Highest risk)
  • Lower abdominal surgeries
  • Upper abdominal surgeries

Malignancies Responsible for SBO
  • Metastasis
  • Peritoneal carcinomatosis

 

Clinical Features of Small Bowel Obstruction:

  • Colicky Abdominal Pain (First symptom):
    • Due to hyperperistalsis in the small intestine caused by intestinal obstruction.
  • Multiple Episodes of Bilious Vomiting
  • Obstipation (Absolute Constipation)
  • Proximal Small Bowel Obstruction Symptoms:
    • Vomiting
    • Dyselectrolytemia (electrolyte imbalances due to vomiting)
  • Distal Small Bowel Obstruction Symptoms:
    • Distension (more prominent)

questions.text: Which of the following findings of colonoscopy is highly malignant?
questions.solution:
Correct answer A) Multiple flat polyp about 100

Explanation:

  • Among the options you provided, the finding of "Multiple flat polyps about 100" is concerning for a higher risk of malignancy. This is because having a large number of flat  polyps (approximately 100) increases the likelihood of some of these polyps being dysplastic or even cancerous.

 

Single pedunculated polyp (Option B) Any polyp has the potential to be cancerous, a single pedunculated polyp, especially if small and without concerning features, is typically considered low risk for malignancy.

Multiple pedunculated polyps (Option C) In the context of multiple pedunculated polyps, further evaluation and genetic testing may be warranted to assess the risk of malignancy.

Solitary flat polyp (Option D) Flat polyps have a higher potential for malignancy compared to pedunculated polyps; the risk still depends on other factors such as size, morphology, and histological characteristics. The malignancy risk of a solitary flat polyp would need to be assessed based on these factors.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes McBurney's point in cases of acute appendicitis?

choices.text: McBurney point is located in the left lower quadrant of the abdomen.
McBurney point corresponds to the site of maximal tenderness in acute appendicitis.
McBurney point is used to assess rebound tenderness in acute appendicitis.
McBurney point is located at the umbilicus in acute appendicitis.

questions.solution:
Correct answer B) McBurney point corresponds to the site of maximal tenderness in acute appendicitis

Explanation:

  • McBurney point is approximately one-third of the distance from the anterior superior iliac spine to the umbilicus in the right lower quadrant. It is the site where the appendix is most likely to be inflamed and where maximal tenderness is commonly elicited during physical examination in cases of acute appendicitis.

 

McBurney point is located in the left lower quadrant of the abdomen (Option A) McBurney point is not in the left lower quadrant but rather in the right lower quadrant of the Abdomen.

McBurney point is used to assess rebound tenderness in acute appendicitis (Option C) Rebound tenderness is assessed by applying pressure at a different location, typically in the left lower quadrant, and observing if there is increased pain when the pressure is released.

McBurney point is located at the umbilicus in acute appendicitis (Option D) McBurney point is not located at the umbilicus but rather in the right lower quadrant.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a patient who has been experiencing fever and pain in the lower right abdomen for the past 5 days, with the presence of a tender mass in the right iliac fossa and an elevated leukocyte count?
questions.solution:
Correct answer A) Appendicitis

Explanation:

  • Based on the symptoms described, including fever, pain in the right lower abdomen, apainful lump in the right iliac fossa, and an increased leukocyte count, the most probable diagnosis would be appendicitis.
  • Appendicitis is the inflammation of the appendix, a small pouch-like organ located in the lower right abdomen.
  • The classic symptoms include fever, abdominal pain (particularly in the right lower quadrant), and an elevated white blood cell count(leukocytosis).
  • The presence of a painful lump in the right iliac fossa further supportsthe likelihood of appendicitis.

 

Hydronephrosis (Option B) Would present with flank pain, not RLQ pain. No fever or leukocytosis unless there is a secondary infection (pyonephrosis). Ultrasound/CT scan would show dilated renal pelvis and calyces.

Tuberculosis (Ileocecal TB) (Option C) TB presents gradually with weight loss, low-grade fever, and chronic pain, not acute severe RLQ pain. A palpable mass may be present (due to a thickened ileocecal region), but no leukocytosis.

Carcinoma Colon (Right-Sided) (Option D) Presents insidiously with anemia, weight loss, and altered bowel habits. A firm, non-tender mass may be found in the RLQ butis not typically associated with fever or leukocytosis.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of a female patient who presents with a mass in the inguinal area that can be reduced from the deep inguinal ring accompanied by a gurgling sound?
questions.solution:
Correct answer B) Indirect inguinal hernia

Explanation:

  • Indirect inguinal hernias are the most common type, where abdominal contents protrude through the deep inguinal ring into the inguinal canal. They typically manifest as a palpable mass or bulge in the inguinal area, often reducible with manual manipulation, accompanied by a gurgling sound. More prevalent in males, they can be congenital or acquired later in life.

 

Direct inguinal hernia (Option A) Involves protrusion through a weak point in the abdominal wall without passing through the deep inguinal ring. Common in older men, typically lacking the characteristic gurgling sound upon reduction.

Femoral hernia (Option C) Arises when abdominal contents protrude through the femoral canal, primarily affecting women. Presents as a bulge in the upper thigh or groin area, distinct from the inguinal region, with a narrower passage and typically no gurgling sound upon Reduction.

Pantaloon hernia (Option D) A specific type combining direct and indirect hernias, protruding both above and below the inguinal ligament. Presents with bulges on both sides of the inguinal region and may produce a gurgling sound upon reduction.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for an elderly male patient who has come to the hospital with lower back pain, a movable mass in the lower back that becomes more prominent when breathing in and a general feeling of weakness? The lab tests show the presence of red blood cells in the urine, with no sign of pus cells.
questions.solution:
Correct answer C) Renal cell carcinoma

Explanation:

  • Renal cell carcinoma is a type of kidney cancer that originates in the cells of the kidney tubules.
  • It commonly presents with symptoms such as persistent back pain, a palpable mass in the lumbar region, fatigue, and hematuria.
  • The presence of RBCs in the urine without pus cells, along with lumbar pain and a ballotable mass, is consistent with renal cell carcinoma.

 

Polycystic kidney disease (Option A) Polycystic kidney disease (PKD) is a genetic disorder characterized by the growth of multiple cysts in the kidneys. It typically presents with symptoms such as abdominal or flank pain, hypertension, and enlarged kidneys. While PKD can cause hematuria (blood in the urine), the presence of a ballotable mass and lumbar pain during inspiration is not commonly associated with PKD.

Hydronephrosis (Option B) Hydronephrosis refers to the swelling or enlargement of the kidney due to the buildup of urine caused by an obstruction in the urinary tract. It can result from conditions such as kidney stones, tumours, or structural abnormalities. While hydronephrosis can cause lumbar pain and a ballotable mass in the affected area, the presence of RBCs in the urine without pus cells suggests an alternative diagnosis.

Chronic pyelonephritis (Option D) Chronic pyelonephritis is a long-term inflammation of the kidney resulting from recurrent urinary tract infections. It may cause symptoms such as flank pain, fever, frequent urination, and the presence of pus cells in the urine. However, the absence of pus cells and the presence of RBCs in the urine, along with the presence of a ballotable mass, are not typical for chronic pyelonephritis.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a 60-year-old male who is experiencing lower back pain and has sclerotic lesions in the vertebrae?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Carcinoma prostate

Explanation:

  • The most likely primary cancer site associated with sclerotic lesions in the vertebrae in a 60-year-old male is carcinoma prostate. Prostate cancer commonly metastasizes to the bones, including the vertebrae, leading to sclerotic (hardened) lesions.

Carcinoma Prostate with Bone Metastases:

Aspect

Details

Pathophysiology

Prostate cancer spreads hematogenously to bones, commonly affecting the spine, pelvis, ribs, and femur. Metastases are osteoblastic (sclerotic) due to increased osteoblast activity.

Common Symptoms

Lower back pain, pathological fractures, urinary symptoms (hesitancy, frequency), and neurological deficits if spinal cord compression occurs.

Laboratory Findings

PSA – Elevated, ALP – Elevated (bone involvement), Serum Calcium – Normal/mildly elevated (osteoblastic metastases do not cause severe hypercalcemia).

X-ray Findings

Sclerotic (osteoblastic) lesions in vertebrae, pelvis, and long bones.

Bone Scan (Tc-99m)

Shows increased radiotracer uptake in metastatic sites (best for early detection).

MRI Spine

Detects spinal cord compression marrow infiltration.

CT Pelvis/Spine

Defines bone metastases and local spread.

Confirmatory Test

TRUS-guided prostate biopsy (Transrectal Ultrasound Biopsy).

Treatment

Androgen Deprivation Therapy (ADT) (GnRH agonists like Leuprolide), Bisphosphonates for bone health, Radiation for spinal metastases, and Surgical decompression if cord compression occurs.

 

Tuberculosis (Option B) Tuberculosis (TB) typically affects the lungs, but it can also involve other organs, including the spine. Spinal tuberculosis, known as Pott's disease, can cause vertebral destruction and collapse, leading to back pain.

Renal cell carcinoma (Option C) Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is a type of kidney cancer. While it can metastasize to the bones, including the vertebrae, it typically presents with lytic (destructive) lesions rather than sclerotic lesions.

Carcinoma colon (Option D) Colorectal cancer can metastasize to the bones, including the Vertebrae.

questions.text: A 67-year-old diabetic patient presented with swelling around the knee, restriction of movement and minimal or no pain. The x-ray of the knee is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Charcot arthropathy

Explanation:

Known diabetic with arthritic presentation and x-ray showing destruction of lateral femoral condyle is more likely to be Charcot’s arthropathy.

Charcot Joints (Neuropathic joint):

  • Description: Progressive, degenerative & destructive joint disorder due to abnormal pain sensation & proprioception
  • Joints involved:
    • Foot and ankle
    • Shoulder
    • Elbow
    • Knee
    • Hand
  • Most Common Joint Involved: Foot - Tarsometatarsal joint > Metatarsophalangeal joint
  • Etiology:

Cause

Mechanism

Common Joint Involved

Diabetes mellitus (Most common cause) (Option C)

Peripheral neuropathy leads to altered pain sensation and proprioception

Foot

 

Syphilis (Tabes dorsalis)

Neurological deficits affecting joint function

Knee

 

Syringomyelia

Dilatation of the spinal cord; may lead to syringobulbia (if it extends to the Brainstem)

Shoulder

 

Leprosy

Neuropathy leading to loss of sensation

Hand and Foot

 

Meningomyelocele

Neurological deficits impacting joint function

Variable, but often lower limbs
  • X-ray: Rapid destruction of articular surfaces + involvement of multiple small joints

Incorrect Options:

Rheumatoid Arthropathy (RA) (Option A): In the case of rheumatoid arthropathy bone softening and soft tissue changes are seen. Morning stiffness with symmetrical involvement of joints is characteristic of RA.

Osteoarthritis (Option B): In the case of osteoarthritis narrowing of joint space can be noticed which is not seen in the above image.

Psoriatic Arthropathy (Option D): Similar presentation like rheumatoid arthropathy with associated skin and nail lesions.

questions.text: A patient with a history of trauma has a ruptured bulbar urethra. What is the location for the accumulation of urine?
questions.solution:
Correct answer A) Superficial pouch

Explanation:

  • The superficial pouch, also known as the superficial perineal space or superficial perineal compartment, is an anatomical space located between the perineal membrane and the superficial fascia.
  • It contains various structures, including the root of the penis, the bulb of the penis (which includes the bulbar urethra in males), and associated muscles. If the bulbar urethra is ruptured, urine can potentially leak into the superficial pouch and accumulate there.

 

Deep pouch (Option A)The deep pouch (Space of Retzius), also known as the space of Retzius, is an extraperitoneal space located between the pubic symphysis and the anterior bladder wall. It is situated in the lower abdomen and is not directly involved in the accumulation of urine in the case of a ruptured bulbar urethra.

Rectouterine pouch (Option C) The rectouterine pouch (Pouch of Douglas), also referred to as the pouch of Douglas, is a peritoneal space located between the posterior wall of the uterus (in females) or the bladder (in males) and the anterior wall of the rectum.

Uterovesical pouch (Option D) The uterovesical pouch (Vesicouterine pouch), also called the vesicouterine pouch, is a peritoneal space located between the uterus and the bladder in females.

Urethral injury

  • Urethral injuries refer to damage to the urethra, the tube that carries urine from the bladder to the outside of the body.

                             Anterior vs. Posterior Urethral Injuries

 

Feature

Anterior Urethral Injury

Posterior Urethral Injury

Location
  • Bulbar urethra (most common)
  • Penile urethra

 

 
  • Membranous urethra (bulbomembranous junction most common)
  • Prostatic urethra

 

 

Common Causes
  • Straddle injuries
  • Direct trauma
  • Iatrogenic injuries (catheterization, cystoscopy)
  • Penetrating trauma (stab/gunshot wounds)
  • Pelvic fractures (often due to motor vehicle accidents)
  • Blunt trauma

Clinical Features
  • Hematuria (blood in urine)
  • Penile/perineal bruising (butterfly-shaped hematoma)
  • Perineal pain
  • Urinary retention or difficulty voiding
  • Possible swelling of the penis or scrotum due to hematoma
  • Blood at the meatus
  • Inability to void
  • High-riding prostate on rectal exam
  • Perineal or suprapubic pain
  • Pelvic hematoma associated with pelvic fractures
  • Possible concomitant bladder injury

Investigations
  • Retrograde Urethrography (RGU): Gold standard, shows the extent and location of the injury
  • Voiding Cystourethrography (VCUG): Used to assess urethral patency post-repair
  • Ultrasound: Can detect hematoma or associated injuries
  • Retrograde Urethrography (RGU): Gold standard for initial assessment
  • CT Urethrography: Useful in evaluating complex injuries
  • Pelvic CT Scan: Important for associated pelvic fractures
  • Cystoscopy: Sometimes performed for further evaluation
  • If injury at Prostatomembranous junction - High lying prostate → On IVP- Pie in-sky appearance

questions.text: In a newborn male with an undeveloped scrotum, the testis was observed to be located near the peritoneum. Which of the following factors aids in the descent of the testis into the scrotum?

choices.text: Manually bring the testis down to the bottom of scrotum.

questions.solution:
Correct answer A) GnRH Analogue

Explanation:

  • GnRH analogue increases the level of gonadotropin,s which further increases the level of androgens that help in testicular descent as it is an androgen-dependent process.

 

Testosterone (Option B) GnRH analogue is preferred over testosterone as neonatal gonadotropin therapy can increase the testosterone levels without fear of inducing spermatogenesis or negatively affecting an ultimate number of Sertoli cells (an important determinant of fertility).

Cold Compressions (Option C) Cold compresses or ice application is not a recognised method to assist testicular descent in newborns.

Manually bring the testis down to the bottom of the scrotum (Option D). This option describes a manual technique called orchidopexy or surgical orchiopexy. It involves surgically bringing the undescended testis down to the scrotum. It is a definitive treatment for undescended testis, but it is typically performed by a healthcare professional and not manually by parents or Caregivers.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with scrotal enlargement. His LDH levels are notably elevated, while HCG and alpha-fetoprotein levels remain within normal ranges. Upon histopathological examination, the findings are as shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Seminoma

Explanation: Seminoma

Feature

Details

Tumor Type

Seminoma, the most common pure testicular germ cell tumour in men aged 25-45

Origin

Germinal epithelium of the seminiferous tubules

Clinical Features

Painless, firm swelling or mass in the testicle, typically unilateral. Accounts for 50% of all testicular germ cell tumors. 10% have secondary hydrocele, 5% have gynecomastia

Diagnostic Markers

AFP: Normal

hCG: Normal or mildly elevated

LDH: Elevated

Investigation

Ultrasound: Homogeneous, hypoechoic mass

Histology: Sheets of oval cells with clear cytoplasm, large nuclei with prominent acidophilic nucleoli

 

FNAC: Contraindicated due to the risk of tumour cell seeding and lymph node metastasis

Treatment

Primary: High Inguinal Radical Orchidectomy

Adjuvant: Radiation therapy or chemotherapy for positive lymph nodes

 

Leydig cell tumour (Option A) : Benign testicular tumour that typically occurs in adults aged 30-60. While it presents as a painless testicular mass, Leydig cell tumours don't typically elevate beta-hCG.

Embryonal carcinoma (Option B): Aggressive germ cell tumour that often occurs in young men. However, it typically presents with both elevated AFP and beta-hCG, not just beta-hCG alone. It's also usually more heterogeneous on ultrasound.

Teratoma (Option D): Typically occurs in young men and usually presents with normal tumour markers (both beta-hCG and AFP). On ultrasound, it appears heterogeneous with both cystic and solid components.

questions.text: A young male underwent lumbar sympathectomy, and bilateral L1 ganglions were removed. What will be the most common side effect?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B) Retrograde ejaculation

Explanation:

  • Lumbar sympathectomy can disrupt the sympathetic innervation responsible for controlling the closure of the bladder neck during ejaculation.
  • This disruption can lead to retrograde ejaculation, where semen enters the bladder instead of being expelled through the penis during ejaculation.
  • Retrograde ejaculation is a known and frequently reported side effect of lumbar sympathectomy.

 

Impotence (Erectile Dysfunction) (Option A) Erection is mainly parasympathetically mediated (S2-S4, pelvic splanchnic nerves), not lumbar sympathetic nerves. Sympathectomy may affect ejaculation but does not typically cause impotence.

Bladder Dysfunction (Option C) The main control of bladder function (detrusor contraction, micturition reflex) is via S2-S4 parasympathetic fibers, not L1 sympathetic nerves. Some mild urinary dysfunction may occur, but retrograde ejaculation is more common.

Incontinence (Option D) Urinary continence is maintained by external urethral sphincter control (somatic, pudendal nerve - S2-S4), which remains intact after L1 sympathectomy.

questions.text: Which of the statements below is not true regarding the condition depicted in the image?

choices.text: Seen on the dorsal and volar aspects of the wrist

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Less chances of recurrence

Explanation:

The image in the question is suggestive of Ganglion cyst. Ganglion cysts are more prone to recurrence.

Ganglion cyst:

Description
  • Most common swelling of the wrist
  • Arises from the synovial fluid of joint/tendon sheath

Sites
  • Most common: Dorsal > volar aspects of wrist (Option D)

Clinical features
  • Usually seen in young adults
  • Well-defined, cystic, non-tender swelling
  • Smooth, fluctuant and transillumination positive (Option B)
  • Mucous containing cysts are associated with nail changes
  • Rarely can cause compression of ulnar nerve

Treatment
  • Asymptomatic cases do not require treatment, spontaneously undergoes regression.
  • USG-guided aspiration or Surgical excision is done in symptomatic cases and for cosmetic indications (Option C)
  • Recurrence - common (Option A)

questions.text: A patient underwent surgery, for which she was immobilised. Patient started complaining of leg pain on the 5th postoperative day. On examination , Homan’s sign is positive. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer A) Deep Venous thrombosis

Explanation:

  • Based on the information provided, the most probable diagnosis for the patient experiencing leg pain on the 5th postoperative day with a positive Homan's sign is Deep Venous Thrombosis (DVT).
  • Homan's sign refers to calf pain elicited by dorsiflexion of the foot, and it is often associated with DVT. DVT is a condition in which a blood clot forms in a deep vein, commonly in the lower extremities.
  • Immobilization following surgery is a known risk factor for the development of DVT. Other risk factors include a history of DVT, obesity, smoking, and certain medical conditions.

 

Urinary sepsis (Option B) Urinary sepsis typically presents with symptoms such as fever, urinary urgency, and dysuria (painful urination), rather than leg pain.

Peripheral vascular disease (Option C) Peripheral vascular disease refers to conditions that affect blood flow to the extremities and may cause pain or cramping during physical activity, but it is less likely to be related to the immobilization following surgery.

Lymphangitis (Option D) Lymphangitis refers to the inflammation of lymphatic vessels, which can cause red streaks on the skin and swollen lymph nodes but is less likely to be associated with leg pain in this context.

Clinical features of DVT :

Clinical Feature

Significance

Localized tenderness

Specific for DVT; indicates inflammation along the vein.

Asymmetrical calf swelling

Common but not specific to DVT.

Erythema and warmth

Suggestive of inflammation or thrombosis.

Pain in the affected limb

Can occur with or without movement; can indicate venous obstruction.

Dilated superficial veins

May indicate compensatory circulation due to deep venous obstruction.

Homans' sign

Non-specific; Passive forceful dorsiflexion of the foot with extended knee will cause tenderness in the calf.

Mose’s sign

Painful response to gentle squeezing of the lower calf from side-to-side.

Neuhof's Sign

Thickening and deep tenderness in the calf muscles upon palpation.

Phlegmasia Alba Dolens

DVT of the femoral vein causes painful congestion and edema of the leg with lymphangitis, which further increases edema (white leg).

Phlegmasia Caerulea Dolens

Extensive DVT in iliac and pelvic veins leading to a blue leg with possible venous gangrene or infarction.

questions.text: After a surgical procedure, the patient demonstrates a particular clinical sign. Which specific nerve is likely to be damaged in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Median nerve

Explanation:

The image in the question shows the Pointing Index sign seen in Median Nerve injury.

Clinical tests for Median nerve:

Test

Muscle tested and action

Pen test:
  • Muscle: Abductor pollicis brevis
  • Action: Abduction of thumb

Oschner clasp test:
  • Muscle: Flexor digitorum superficialis & flexor digitorum profundus
  • Action: Flexion of lateral 2 digits
  • Pointing index sign seen.

Thumb opposition:
  • Muscle: Opponens pollcis
  • Action: Opposition of thumb
  • O-sign is seen in normal patients

Treatment of median nerve palsy:

  • Conservative management mainly.
  • If not recovered, nerve repair is done by
    • High median nerve palsy (above elbow): 9 months
    • Low median nerve palsy (distal forearm): 12 months

questions.text: How is empyema thoracis treated?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Chest tube drainage and antibiotics

Explanation:

  • Intercostal Chest Drainage (ICD) + IV Antibiotics is the standard treatment.
  • Chest tube (ICD) removes pus, while broad-spectrum antibiotics (e.g., ceftriaxone + metronidazole or piperacillin-tazobactam) control infection.\
  • If loculated collections persist, intrapleural fibrinolytics (streptokinase, urokinase) may be needed.

 

Antibiotics alone (Option A) Antibiotics are necessary but not sufficient because pus in the pleural cavity needs mechanical drainage. Without drainage, antibiotics cannot penetrate the thick fibrinous collections, leading to persistent infection.

ICD alone (Option C) Drainage without antibiotics will not treat the underlying infection, leading to recurrence and sepsis.

Wait and watch (Option D) Empyema needs urgent intervention. Delayed treatment can lead to fibrothorax (thickened pleura), lung entrapment, and sepsis.

questions.text: Diagnosis of Gout is confirmed by which test?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Synovial Fluid Analysis

Explanation:

Gout

  • Inflammatory arthritis caused by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in joints and tissues due to hyperuricemia

Clinical Presentation:

  • Acute Gouty Attack- Sudden onset of intense joint pain, typically affecting the big toe, but can also involve other joints such as the ankle, knee, wrist, or elbow
  • Chronic Gout- Recurrent attacks of joint inflammation, development of tophi (deposits of urate crystals) in joints and soft tissues

Diagnosis:

  • Medical History- History of recurrent joint pain, sudden onset, and self-limiting nature of attacks.
  • Physical Examination- Joint examination revealing signs of inflammation (redness, swelling, warmth)
  • Synovial Fluid Analysis-Detection of monosodium urate crystals in synovial fluid aspirated from an affected joint
  • Serum Uric Acid Level- Elevated serum uric acid levels (>6.8 mg/dL) may support the diagnosis, but levels can be normal during an acute attack.

Treatment:

  • Acute Attack- Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), colchicine, corticosteroids for pain relief and inflammation control
  • Long-term Management- Lifestyle modifications (dietary changes, weight loss), medications to lower uric acid levels (allopurinol, febuxostat) to prevent further attacks.

Serum Uric Acid Level (Option A): While elevated serum uric acid levels are often seen in individuals with gout, they are not sufficient to confirm the diagnosis on their own.

Urine Uric Acid Levels (Option C): Urine uric acid levels are not typically used as a diagnostic test for gout. Although increased urinary excretion of uric acid may be observed in some cases of gout, it is not a specific or reliable marker for diagnosing the condition.

X-Ray Changes (Option D): X-ray changes, such as the presence of joint erosions or bone damage, may occur in advanced stages of gout or if there have been recurrent episodes of inflammation over time.

questions.text: Which enzyme is likely to be deficient in a 4-year-old child who presents with a habit of biting their lips and fingers, and has a missing portion of fingers on their left hand? Further evaluation shows delayed developmental milestones. The parents report that two male cousins on the mother's side have similar symptoms and have been diagnosed with a genetic disorder. Laboratory reports indicate hyperuricemia.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hypoxanthine -guanine phosphoribosyl transferase.

Explanation:

Lesch-Nyhan Syndrome (X-linked recessive disorder)

  • Enzyme deficiency: HGPRT deficiency impairs the purine salvage pathway.
  • Excess uric acid production (hyperuricemia) due to increased purine breakdown.
  • Neurological symptoms due to the lack of purine recycling, affecting brain development.

Key symptoms:

  • Self-mutilation behavior (lip and finger biting)

​​​​ ​​ ​​ ​​ ​​ ​​ ​​ ​​ ​​ ​​ ​​ ​​

 

  • Developmental delay
  • Hyperuricemia → Gout, nephrolithiasis
  • X-linked inheritance: Symptoms in males, family history consistent with maternal transmission.

 

Purine nucleoside phosphorylase (Option A): Inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.

 

Adenine phosphoribosyl transferase (Option C):

Deficiency is characterised by excessive production and renal excretion of 2,8-dihydroxyadenine (DHA), which leads to kidney stone formation and crystal-induced kidney damage (DHA crystal nephropathy).


Adenosine deaminase (Option D): Deficiency damages the immune system and causes severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID).

questions.text: What is the underlying cause of the presenting symptoms in a 21-year-old individual with chronic alcoholism who is admitted to the emergency department with confusion, tremors, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Vitamin B1

Explanation:

Thiamine deficiency is the first seen micronutrient deficiency in chronic alcoholism, as alcohol interferes with thiamine absorption.

  • The patient's symptoms of confusion, difficulty walking (cerebellar ataxia), and abnormal eye movements (nystagmus) are classic signs of Wernicke encephalopathy, which is caused by thiamine deficiency often seen in chronic alcoholics.

WERNICKE-KORSAKOFF SYNDROME (CEREBRAL BERI-BERI)

Clinical Manifestations

Wernicke Encephalopathy:

Symptoms: Ophthalmoplegia, nystagmus, cerebellar ataxia, global confusion.

Korsakoff Psychosis:

Symptoms: Anterograde and retrograde amnesia, sensory agnosia, and confabulation.

Causes of Thiamine Deficiency in Alcoholics
  • Increased thiamine requirements due to alcohol consumption. Alcohol is a source of empty calories.
  • Inhibition of intestinal thiamine absorption by alcohol.

Metabolic Implications
  • Impaired conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA.
  • Accumulation of pyruvate and lactate in the blood.
  • Potential for life-threatening lactic acidosis.

Progression and Risk Factors
  • Progression from Wernicke encephalopathy to Korsakoff psychosis if untreated.
  • Associated with severely compromised nutritional status, often due to chronic alcoholism.

MRI findings

Symmetrical T2/FLAIR signal increase in the mammillary bodies, dorsomedial thalami, tectal plate, periaqueductal area, and around the third ventricle.

questions.text: Which antioxidant deficiency can cause the symptoms of iron-deficiency anemia, painful and tender joints, and bleeding manifestations in a 34-year-old woman who primarily consumes packaged and reheated meals?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Vitamin C

Explanation:

Vitamin C deficiency develops after weeks to months of vitamin C depletion.

Vitamin C (ascorbic acid) deficiency, also known as scurvy, can cause:

  • Iron-deficiency anemia: Impaired non-heme iron absorption.
  • Painful, tender joints: Due to defective collagen synthesis affecting cartilage.
  • Bleeding manifestations: Easy bruising, gum bleeding, and perifollicular hemorrhages due to weakened capillary walls from defective collagen.
  • Scorbutic rosary
  • Risk factor: Diet lacking fresh fruits and vegetables, relying on packaged and reheated meals, as heat destroys vitamin C.

Glutathione (Option A): Involved in oxidative stress protection, no direct link to these symptoms.

ß-carotene (Option B): Precursor of vitamin A, deficiency affects vision and skin, not bleeding or anemia.

Zinc (Option D): Deficiency causes delayed wound healing and dermatitis, not anemia or bleeding.

questions.text: To evaluate a deficiency of vitamin B2 (riboflavin), one can assess the activity of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Glutathione reductase

Explanation:

Laboratory Tests for Vitamin Deficiencies:

Vitamin B1 (Thiamin):

  • Test: Measure transketolase activity in red blood cells with and without thiamin diphosphate.
  • Indicator: Increased activity with thiamin diphosphate indicates deficiency.

Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin):

  • Test: Measure glutathione reductase activity in red blood cells with and without flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD).
  • Indicator: Increased activity with FAD indicates deficiency.

Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine):

Test:

  • Measure activation of red blood cell transaminases with pyridoxal phosphate.
  • Xanthurenic acid in urine Indicator: Increased activity indicates deficiency.
  • The metabolic disorders that respond to vitamin B6 therapy include xanthurenic aciduria and homocystinuria.

Vitamin B12 (Cobalamin):

Tests:

  • Urinary methylmalonic acid: Elevated levels indicate impaired conversion of methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA, suggesting deficiency.
  • Megaloblastic anaemia assessment: Detects anaemia caused by disrupted folate metabolism due to B12 deficiency.

Folate:

Test:

  • Assess for megaloblastic anaemia.

Indicator:

  • The presence of this type of anaemia suggests folate deficiency.
  • When folic acid is deficient, FIGLU is excreted in urine.
  • Histidine can be transaminated with pyruvate to form imidazole pyruvate and alanine.

questions.text: A known alcoholic patient is brought to the emergency in a disoriented state. He complains of seeing snakes and insects crawling on his skin. Which of the following should be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Lorazepam + thiamine

  • The patient exhibits symptoms of alcohol withdrawal with possible thiamine deficiency.
  • Lorazepam, a short-acting benzodiazepine, is used to manage alcohol withdrawal symptoms such as agitation and hallucinations.
  • Thiamine supplementation is essential to prevent or treat Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, a common complication of chronic alcoholism due to Vitamin B1 deficiency.
  • This deficiency can lead to memory gaps and confabulation, where patients unintentionally create false stories to fill those gaps.
  • Chronic alcohol use also impairs thiamine absorption, necessitating its replacement in these patients.

Haloperidol (Options A and D) is indicated only when the symptoms and agitation are severe to control high doses of Benzodiazepines, and thiamine may not suffice. In those cases, we can add antipsychotics such as Olanzapine or Haloperidol.

Lorazepam (Option B) Here, the patient also exhibits symptoms of thiamine deficiency, so Lorazepam alone does not suffice. Thiamine should be given along with lorazepam.

questions.text: Which of the following symptoms is least likely to be associated with a panic attack?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Suicide attempt:

  • Patients with panic attacks experience fear of dying, but suicide attempts are less likely to be a symptom of panic attacks.
  • Although few studies report that patients experience fear of dying, it could be an independent risk factor for subsequent suicide attempts, especially for those patients with depressive disorders.

Panic Disorder

  • It is the recurrent, acute, intense attack of anxiety accompanied by a feeling of impending doom.
  • More common in females than males.
  • Median age of onset: Late adolescence or early adulthood.
  • Familial risk: Highest for early-onset panic disorder.
  • Patients with panic disorder commonly have agoraphobia
  • Panic attacks for more than a month are termed as a Panic disorder.
  • Neurotransmitters that are implicated in the development of panic disorders are norepinephrine, Serotonin, GABA, and Cholecystokinin.

Symptoms:

Panic attacks
  • Unexpected, i.e., not restricted to any particular situation.
  • Usually last for 20 to 30 minutes, rarely, they may last more than one hour.

Cardiopulmonary
  • Feeling short of breath
  • Palpitations (Option A ruled out)
  • Chest discomfort (Option C ruled out)

Gastrointestinal
  • Nausea
  • GI discomfort

Skin and systemic

 
  • Sweating
  • Chills
  • Feeling flushed

Neurologic

 
  • Tremors
  • Dizziness
  • Numbness and tingling sensation

Psychiatric

 
  • Derealisation
  • Depersonalisation
  • Fear of losing control
  • Fear of dying (Option B ruled out)
  • Symptoms are random and unpredictable.
  • The patient is free from anxiety symptoms in between attacks.
  • Anticipatory anxiety: Fearing further attacks. Recurrent attacks of severe anxiety or panic.
  • Unpredictable Physiologic symptoms.
  • Avoidance behaviours: Avoiding real or imagined triggers to prevent another attack.

questions.text: What is the initial indication of alcohol withdrawal?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Tremors

  • Alcohol withdrawal symptoms begin after reducing or stopping alcohol intake.
  • The earliest and most common symptom, appearing within 6-8 hours, is coarse tremors involving shaking of the hands and body.
  • Other early symptoms include gastrointestinal issues (nausea, vomiting) and autonomic hyperactivity (anxiety, sweating, tachycardia, hypertension, mydriasis).

Clinical features of Alcohol Withdrawal

Stage

Symptoms

Onset after last drink

Mild withdrawal
  • Mild anxiety
  • Tremulousness
  • Nausea
  • Headache
  • Palpitations

6-8 hours

Moderate (Alcoholic hallucinosis)
  • Visual, auditory, or tactile hallucinations
  • Intact orientation
  • Normal vital signs

8- 12 hours

Severe (Withdrawal seizures)
  • Generalized tonic-clonic seizures
  • Usually brief and self-limited
  • Also known as rum fits

12-24 hours

Life-threatening (Delirium tremens)
  • Severe agitation
  • Confusion and disorientation
  • Hallucinations (often visual)
  • Autonomic hyperactivity (tachycardia, hypertension, fever)
  • Profound sweating
  • Tremors
  • Insomnia

Within 72 hours

Delirium tremens (Option B): A severe and life-threatening symptom that develops around 72 hours after cessation of alcohol.

Seizures (Option C): Generalized tonic-clonic seizures typically occur within 12-24 hours of stopping alcohol.

Hallucinations (Option D): Alcoholic hallucinosis (commonly auditory, but visual may occur) arises within 8-12 hours after cessation and occurs with clear consciousness, without impairment.

questions.text: What deficiency is responsible for cognitive impairment in the elderly?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Vitamin B12

Vitamin B12 Deficiency is a common cause of cognitive impairment in the elderly. It can lead to memory loss, confusion, and even dementia if untreated. The deficiency affects myelin synthesis, causing demyelination and neuronal dysfunction.

Vitamin C (Option A): Its deficiency causes scurvy, presenting with symptoms like bleeding gums and weakness, but it is not linked to cognitive impairment.

Vitamin B6 (Option C): While deficiency can cause irritability, depression, and confusion, it is less commonly associated with significant cognitive impairment in the elderly.

Vitamin B1 (Thiamine) (Option D): Deficiency leads to Wernicke’s encephalopathy and Korsakoff’s syndrome, but these are less common causes of cognitive impairment in the general elderly population compared to B12 deficiency.

questions.text: What is the recommended treatment for a recently diagnosed female patient with mild depression?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Cognitive behavioural therapy

  • For a patient with mild depression, the first-line treatment typically involves psychotherapy, with Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) being the most commonly recommended approach.

Treatment Approaches for Depression

Type of Therapy

Description

Indication

Combination Therapy
  • Pharmacotherapy + Psychotherapy
  • Combines medications (e.g., antidepressants) with psychotherapy for a higher response rate.

Moderate to severe depression

Single Therapy

Psychotherapy alone may be sufficient for mild cases.

Mild depression

 

Psychotherapy Types

Somatic Treatments
  • Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT)
  • Interpersonal Therapy (IPT)
  • Family Therapy
  • Psychoanalytically Oriented Therapy
  • Behavior Therapy
  • Electroconvulsive Therapy (ECT)
  • Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS)
  • Vagal Nerve Stimulation (VNS)
  • Deep Brain Stimulation (DBS)
  • Phototherapy
  • Sleep Deprivation

Cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) and antidepressants (Option B): For mild depression, CBT alone is typically sufficient. In cases of moderate to severe depression, a combination of CBT and antidepressant medications is recommended for effective treatment.

Mild antidepressants (Option C) are usually indicated in chronic moderate to severe depression, and not mild depression

Vagus nerve stimulation (Option D) is not indicated for mild depression. It involves stimulating the left vagus nerve using electrodes connected to a pulse generator implanted in the chest. This procedure is primarily used for treatment-resistant depression.

questions.text: All the following are features of polycystic disease of kidneys except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Erythrocytosis

Explanation:

  • Polycystic kidney disease (PKD) is characterized by multiple renal cysts, leading to progressive renal failure. The key clinical features include hematuria, hypertension, and renal failure. However, erythrocytosis (increased RBC count) is not a typical feature because PKD often leads to chronic kidney disease (CKD), which is associated with anemia rather than polycythemia.

Polycystic Kidney Disease (PKD)

Feature

Explanation

Hematuria

Due to rupture of cysts into the renal collecting system

Hypertension

Result of renin-angiotensin system (RAS) activation due to ischemia from cyst compression

Renal failure

Progressive cyst expansion leads to nephron loss, causing chronic kidney disease (CKD)

Erythrocytosis (Absent)

CKD leads to decreased erythropoietin (EPO), resulting in anemia rather than polycythemia

 

Characteristics

ADPKD

ARPKD

Affected age group

Adults

Children

Cysts

Are present in both outer and inner surfaces

Present only on the inner surface.

Involved gene
  • PKD 1 on chromosome 16
  • PKD 2 on chromosome 4

PKHD on chromosome 6

(Statement 2)

Protein affected

polycystin

Fibrocystin (Statement 3)

Histology

Complications
  • Coronary or hypertensive heart disease (40%). (Statement 4)
  • Infection (25%).
  • Ruptured berry aneurysm or hypertensive intracerebral haemorrhage (15%).
  • Neonatal period:
    • Respiratory failure due to pulmonary hypoplasia.
    • Renal failure.
  • Childhood and adolescence:
    • Progressive renal failure leading to ESRD.
    • Complications of CKD.
    • Complications from hepatic fibrosis.

Images

 

Hematuria (Option A): Incorrect because it is a common feature due to cyst rupture.

Hypertension (Option B): Incorrect because it occurs due to RAS activation.

Renal failure (Option C): Incorrect because PKD leads to progressive CKD and ESRD.

questions.text: All of the following are true about Crohn’s disease except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Rectum is involved

Explanation:

  • Crohn’s disease is a chronic inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) that can affect any part of the gastrointestinal (GI) tract from the mouth to the anus, but it classically spares the rectum. This is a key differentiating feature from ulcerative colitis, which always involves the rectum.

Crohn’s Disease

Feature

Explanation

Transmural involvement

Inflammation extends through the entire thickness of the bowel wall

Serpiginous ulcers

Deep, linear ulcers give a cobblestone appearance to the mucosa

Skip lesions

Areas of normal mucosa interspersed with diseased segments

Recurrence

More common than ulcerative colitis, even after surgery

Rectal sparing

Unlike ulcerative colitis, Crohn’s disease rarely affects the rectum

 

Serpiginous ulcers (Option B): Incorrect because Crohn’s disease typically forms serpiginous (snake-like) ulcers.

Transmural involvement (Option C): Incorrect because Crohn’s disease affects all layers of the bowel wall.

Recurrence (Option D): Incorrect because Crohn’s disease commonly recurs even after resection.

questions.text: Identify the tarsal bone labeled in the image below.
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Navicular

Explanation:

The navicular bone is a boat-shaped tarsal bone located on the medial side of the foot, between the talus (posteriorly) and the cuneiform bones (anteriorly). The X-ray shows a lateral view of the foot, with the navicular bone labeled in its characteristic position between the talus and the midfoot structures.

Tarsal Bones and Their Positions

Bone Group

Bones

Description & Function

Tarsals

Provide mechanical support and structure to the foot.

Proximal Group

Talus

Transmits body weight to the foot.

Articulates at three joints:

Superiorly: Ankle joint (tibia/fibula)

Inferiorly: Subtalar joint (calcaneus)

Anteriorly: Talonavicular joint (navicular)

Calcaneus

Largest tarsal bone, forms the heel.

Articulates at two joints:

Superiorly: Subtalar joint (talus)

Anteriorly: Calcaneocuboid joint (cuboid)

Intermediate Group

Navicular

Boat-shaped; articulates with talus, cuneiforms, and cuboid.

Has a tuberosity for tibialis posterior tendon attachment.

Distal Group

Cuboid

Lateral; articulates with calcaneus and fourth/fifth metatarsals.

Features a groove for fibularis longus tendon.

Cuneiforms (3)

Medial, intermediate, lateral; wedge-shaped.

Help form the transverse arch; attach to various muscles.

Metatarsals

I-V (1-5)

Connect tarsals to phalanges; numbered medial to lateral.

Have a head, neck, shaft, and base; facilitate movement and support.

Phalanges

Great Toe: 2 (proximal, distal)

Toes 2-5: 3 each (proximal, intermediate, distal).

Each phalanx has a base, shaft, and head; provide structure to toes.

Calcaneus (Option A): Incorrect because the calcaneus is located posteriorly and is the largest tarsal bone forming the heel.

Cuboid (Option B): Incorrect because the cuboid is on the lateral side of the foot, articulating with the 4th and 5th metatarsals.

Talus (Option D): Incorrect because the talus is superior to the navicular, articulating with the tibia and fibula to form the ankle joint.

questions.text: Which patient has better prognosis in breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Luminal A

Explanation:

  • Among the molecular subtypes of breast cancer, Luminal A has the best prognosis due to its hormone receptor positivity, low proliferation index, and good response to endocrine therapy.

Molecular Subtypes of Breast Cancer

Subtype

Receptor Status

Prognosis

Treatment Response

Luminal A

ER+, PR+, HER2-

Best prognosis

Good response to endocrine therapy (Tamoxifen, Aromatase inhibitors)

Luminal B

ER+, PR±, HER2±

Intermediate

Responds to endocrine therapy but has higher proliferation than Luminal A

HER2+ (non-luminal)

ER-, PR-, HER2+

Poorer prognosis

Requires Trastuzumab (Herceptin)

Triple-negative (Basal-like)

ER-, PR-, HER2-

Worst prognosis

Chemotherapy is the only option; high recurrence

 

HER2+ (Option A): Incorrect because HER2+ cancers tend to be aggressive, though targeted therapy (Trastuzumab) has improved survival.

Triple negative (Option B): Incorrect because triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has the worst prognosis due to aggressive nature and lack of targeted therapy.

Luminal B (Option C): Incorrect because Luminal B has a worse prognosis than Luminal A due to a higher proliferation rate.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presenting with an unsteady gait, forgetfulness, labile moods, and Kayser-Fleischer rings was diagnosed with Wilson’s disease. Which of the following options correctly indicates the gene mutated in this condition and its location?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) ATP7B gene on chromosome 13

Explanation:

  • Wilson’s disease is caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene located on chromosome 13.
  • The ATP7A gene on chromosome 17 is associated with Menkes disease.

Wilson’s disease

  • It is a genetic disorder caused by ATP7B gene mutations, leading to impaired copper transport and accumulation in the liver, brain, and other organs.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Kayser-Fleischer Rings: These are characteristic brownish-green rings seen in the cornea due to copper deposition and are a hallmark feature of Wilson's disease.
    • Serum copper is raised, while ceruloplasmin levels (a copper-binding protein) are decreased in Wilson's disease.
    • Increased urinary copper excretion is a characteristic finding.
  • Findings:
    • Low levels of Serum Ceruloplasmin.
    • Increased 24-hour Urinary Copper Excretion (Most specific).
    • Liver Function Tests (LFTs) may show abnormalities.
    • Kayser-Fleischer Rings Examination: Greenish-brown rings in the cornea.
    • Genetic Testing: For ATP7B gene mutations, confirming diagnosis.
    • Liver Biopsy (Gold standard): Demonstrates hepatic copper accumulation.
    • Brain Imaging: MRI to assess neurological involvement.

questions.text: The prevention of lateral dislocation of the patella during knee flexion is by-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Vastus Medialis

Explanation:

The vastus medialis, particularly its oblique fibers (VMO - Vastus Medialis Obliquus), plays a crucial role in preventing lateral dislocation of the patella by exerting a medial pull on the patella during knee flexion. This counteracts the lateral pull of the quadriceps, especially the vastus lateralis.

Patellar Stability and Dislocation Prevention

Structure

Role in Patellar Stability

Vastus Medialis (VMO)

Exerts a medial pull on the patella, preventing lateral displacement

Patellar Ligament

Connects the patella to the tibial tuberosity but does not prevent lateral dislocation

Gracilis

A medial thigh muscle responsible for hip adduction, not involved in patellar stability

Rectus Femoris

A major knee extensor, but does not prevent lateral displacement

Patellar Ligament (Option B): Incorrect because it primarily stabilizes the patella in the superior-inferior direction, not against lateral forces.

Gracilis (Option C): Incorrect because it is a medial thigh muscle involved in hip adduction and does not influence patellar stability.

Rectus Femoris (Option D): Incorrect because it is a knee extensor, contributing to overall quadriceps function but not directly preventing lateral patellar displacement.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old girl was brought to the outpatient department by her mother saying she noted some abnormality in her genital area. On examination, there was the presence of pubic and axillary hair.

Which of the following is the least likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 21-hydroxylase deficiency

Explanation:

  • 17a-hydroxylase deficiency results in low blood levels of estrogens, androgens, and cortisol, leading to compensatory increases in adrenocorticotropic hormone.
  • This stimulates the production of 11-deoxycorticosterone and corticosterone.
  • Symptoms include delayed puberty with primary amenorrhea and hypertension, caused by inefficient sex steroids and excessive mineralocorticoid production.
  • Clinically, females exhibit hyperandrogenism or heterosexual precocious puberty.

Variants of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH):

 

Ambiguous genitalia in female

Under virilization in Males

With salt wasting &

Hyperkalemia

21 hydroxylase deficiency

3 beta hydroxy steroid dehydrogenase deficiency

With Hypertension

11 Beta hydroxylase deficiency

17- hydroxylase deficiency

questions.text: A child, upon disturbing a bee hive, had several stings. After a few minutes, the child developed symptoms of shock, respiratory failure, and vascular collapse. Which of the following is the principal mediator of this reaction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Histamine

Explanation:

  • The reaction indicates anaphylaxis, a severe allergic response to bee stings. Histamine, released by mast cells and basophils, is the principal mediator, causing vasodilation, increased vascular permeability, bronchoconstriction, and smooth muscle contraction, leading to shock, respiratory failure, and vascular collapse.

Type I hypersensitivity reactions involve an immediate (early) and a late-phase reaction.

 

Early phase reaction

Late phase reaction

Onset

Immediate (within minutes of allergen exposure).

Delayed (several hours after exposure) and can last for days.

Cells involved

Mast cells, basophils.

Eosinophils, T lymphocytes.

Cellular events

Activation of mast cells and basophils.

Recruitment and activation of leukocytes, especially eosinophils.

Mediators

Histamine, leukotrienes (LTB4, LTC4, LTD4), prostaglandins (PGD2) and Platelet-activating factor (PAF).

Cytokines (e.g., IL-4, IL-5, TNF), chemokines (e.g., eotaxin).

Initiating event

Exposure to allergen triggers cross-linking of IgE on mast cells/basophils.

Recurrent inflammation, sustained by recruited leukocytes.

Effect on tissues

Vasodilation, increased vascular permeability, smooth muscle contraction.

Sustained inflammation and tissue damage due to leukocyte infiltration.

Clinical manifestations

Allergic rhinitis (hay fever), urticaria (hives), Angioedema bronchoconstriction.

Allergic asthma exacerbation, persistent inflammation, and tissue damage.

Therapeutic Approach

Antihistamines for symptomatic relief.

Adrenaline in anaphylactic shock.

Broad-spectrum anti-inflammatory drugs (e.g., steroids) to suppress inflammation and prevent tissue damage.
