questions.text: Identify the arrow-marked chamber.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Left Atrium

Explanation:

The left atrium is located posteriorly in the heart and receives oxygenated blood from the pulmonary veins. In cross-sectional imaging, it is centrally positioned and posterior to the right atrium and ventricles. The given image corresponds to a transverse section of the heart, showing the left atrium in its expected anatomical location.

Anatomy of the Chambers of the Heart

Feature

Right Atrium

Right Ventricle

Left Atrium

Left Ventricle

Location

Right, anterior

Right, inferior

Left, posterior

Left, inferior

Function

Receives deoxygenated blood from vena cava

Pumps deoxygenated blood to the lungs via pulmonary artery

Receives oxygenated blood from pulmonary veins

Pumps oxygenated blood to the body via aorta

Wall Thickness

Thin

Thin

Thin

Thickest

Valves Associated

Tricuspid Valve

Pulmonary Valve

Mitral Valve

Aortic Valve

Key Structures

Crista terminalis, fossa ovalis

Trabeculae carneae, moderator band

Pulmonary veins opening, interatrial septum

Papillary muscles, chordae tendineae

The left atrium lies posteriorly and superiorly, making it distinct in cross-sectional anatomy. It is crucial in pulmonary circulation, ensuring efficient oxygenated blood flow into the left ventricle.

Right Atrium (Option A): Incorrect because the right atrium is anterior and positioned to the right, unlike the marked posterior chamber.

Right Ventricle (Option C): Incorrect because the right ventricle is more anterior and lies inferior to the right atrium.

Left Ventricle (Option D): Incorrect because the left ventricle is thicker-walled and positioned inferiorly compared to the left atrium.

questions.text: Identify the class of immunoglobulin shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ig A

Explanation:

IgA:

  • Two types – IgA1 and IgA2
  • Major immunoglobulin in colostrum, saliva, and tears
  • Two Forms: Monomeric serum IgA and dimeric secretory IgA
  • Secretory IgA:
    • Two monomer units joined together at their carboxy terminals by a glycopeptide termed the J chain
    • Produced by plasma cells near mucosal or glandular epithelium
    • Secretory piece or secretory component in the IgA protects IgA from bacterial proteases, especially in areas with abundant bacterial flora (e.g., intestines)
    • Role in Local Immunity: Concentrated in secretions, it forms an "antibody paste" on mucosal surfaces to protect against respiratory and intestinal pathogens.
    • Resistance: Relatively resistant to digestive enzymes and reducing agents
    • Activates the alternative complement pathway

IgG (Option B) Each subunit of IgG consists of two heavy chains (alpha chains) and two light chains (kappa or lambda chains) connected by disulfide bonds.

IgM (Option C) can be monomeric (when present as a membrane-bound antibody on B cells) or pentameric (secreted) in nature, i.e., five IgM monomeric units are joined with each other by a J chain to form a complete IgM pentamer having 10 Fab regions and 10 valencies.

IgE (Option D) Each subunit of IgE consists of two heavy chains (alpha chains) and two light chains (kappa or lambda chains) connected by disulfide bonds.

Immunoglobulin Functions:

  • IgG: Protects body fluids and gives long term immunity
  • IgA: Protects body and mucosal surfaces
  • IgM: First antibody produced in acute infection
  • IgE: Mediates allergic hypersensitivity
  • IgD: Present on the surface of B lymphocytes

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy is rushed to the ER after having choked on a bone while eating. He is responsive but unable to speak. What is to be done next?

choices.text: Deliver 5 back slaps and 5 chest compressions

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Perform Heimlich maneuver

Explanation:

  • The patient is an adult who has choked on a bone while eating.
  • The next best step is to perform the Heimlich maneuver by giving 5 abdominal thrusts.

 

Heimlich Maneuver:

  • The rescuer should stand or kneel behind the patient and wrap his arms around the patient's waist.
  • With one hand, he makes a fist, and using the other hand, he drives the fist into the patient's abdomen with a rapid, forceful upward thrust to dislodge the foreign body.
  • This is continued until the foreign body is expelled or if the patient becomes unresponsive.
  • If the patient becomes unresponsive, immediately start CPR.

 

Bag and mask ventilation (Option A): This intervention may be necessary if the patient becomes unresponsive and stops breathing, it is not the initial step in managing a conscious patient with an airway obstruction due to choking.

Endoscopic removal(Option B): may be necessary if other methods fail or if the obstruction is not cleared by basic interventions, it may not be the initial step in managing a conscious patient with a clear airway obstruction.

Deliver 5 back slaps and 5 chest compressions (Option C): This is done in the case of an infant and not an adult.

questions.text: The dermatome of the area marked in the given below image is-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) L4

Explanation:

The area marked in the image corresponds to the medial aspect of the leg, which is supplied by the L4 dermatome. The L4 dermatome extends from the anteromedial thigh, over the knee, and down to the medial malleolus.

Dermatome Distribution of the Lower Limb

Dermatome

Region Supplied

L1

Inguinal region

L2

Anterior thigh

L3

Lower anterior thigh and medial knee

L4

Medial leg and medial malleolus

L5

Lateral leg, dorsum of foot, great toe

S1

Lateral foot, sole, little toe

S2

Posterior thigh and leg

S3-S5

Perineum and anal region

L5 (Option B): incorrect because it supplies the dorsum of the foot and lateral leg, not the medial leg.

S1 (Option C): incorrect because it supplies the lateral foot and sole, not the medial side.

S2 (Option D): incorrect because it is distributed over the posterior thigh and leg, not the anterior or medial aspect.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe the vertical plane that separates the body into anterior and posterior sections?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Coronal plane

Explanation:

The coronal plane (frontal plane) is the vertical plane that divides the body into anterior (front) and posterior (back) sections. It runs perpendicular to the median plane and is commonly used in imaging and anatomical descriptions.

Anatomical Planes of the Body

Plane

Description

Division

Clinical Relevance

Coronal (Frontal) Plane

Vertical plane passing side to side

Anterior and Posterior

Used in chest X-rays and CT scans

Sagittal (Median) Plane

Vertical plane passing front to back

Left and Right

MRI brain imaging, midline structures

Transverse (Axial) Plane

Horizontal plane

Superior and Inferior

Used in CT and MRI scans

Oblique Plane

Diagonal plane

Varies

Used in specialized imaging

Transverse plane (Option B): incorrect because it divides the body into superior (upper) and inferior (lower) sections.

Axial plane (Option C): incorrect because "axial" is another name for the transverse plane, which divides the body into top and bottom sections.

Median plane (Option D): incorrect because it divides the body into equal left and right halves, not anterior and posterior sections.

questions.text: Which malignancy is most commonly associated with asbestosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Mesothelioma

Explanation:

  • Asbestosis, a pneumoconiosis caused by asbestos inhalation, is strongly associated with mesothelioma, a malignancy of the pleura or peritoneum.
  • Asbestos exposure also increases the risk of lung, laryngeal, ovarian, colon, and pleural cancers.
  • Smoking significantly amplifies the risk of asbestos-related lung carcinoma, making asbestos workers, especially smokers, more likely to die from lung cancer than mesothelioma.
  • Compared to other occupational lung diseases, which affect the upper lobes of the lungs, it commonly affects the lower lobes.
  • Adenocarcinoma (primary bronchogenic carcinoma) is the most common type of cancer, accounting for about 45%, followed by squamous cell carcinoma.
  • Lung mesothelioma is a more specific tumour associated with asbestos exposure. It is common but is less prevalent than Adenocarcinoma.

 

Anthracosis (Option B), associated with bronchial arthrofibrosis (BAF), is a condition characterised by the black staining of the bronchial mucosa, which can obstruct the bronchial lumen. It typically manifests in elderly non-smokers, either male or female, with a chronic course of symptoms like dyspnea and/or cough. It occurs due to the accumulation of carbon, silica, and quartz particles in macrophages, mucosa, and submucosa, leading to anthracosis.

Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) (Option C) is the most common form of primary liver cancer. It typically develops in individuals with chronic liver diseases such as cirrhosis, which can be caused by chronic Hepatitis B or C infection. Other causes of cirrhosis include alcohol abuse, autoimmune diseases, chronic liver inflammation, and iron overload (hemochromatosis). HCC arises from long-term liver damage and scarring.

Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) (Option D) is the most common type, accounting for approximately 90–95% of adult kidney cancers. It originates in the lining of the proximal convoluted tubules (PCTs). Symptoms of RCC include blood in the urine, flank pain, abdominal mass, weight loss, fever, high blood pressure, night sweats, and malaise. When RCC metastasises, it commonly spreads to the lymph nodes, lungs, liver, adrenal glands, brain, or bones.

questions.text: Identify the virus given in the image below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) HIV

Explanation:

  • Structural genes
    • GAG gene encodes the core structural proteins of the virus
      • p24: capsid protein
      • p17: matrix protein
    • POL gene encodes enzymes crucial for viral replication
      • Reverse transcriptase
      • Integrase
      • Protease
    • ENV gene encodes the envelope proteins necessary for virus entry
      • gp120: surface glycoprotein
      • gp41: transmembrane protein
  • Non-Structural Proteins
    • Tat: transcription activator
    • Rev: regulating viral expression
    • Nef: negative Regulatory Factor
    • Vif: Viral infectivity factor
    • Vpr: Viral protein R
    • Vpu: Viral protein U
  • HIV mainly targets immune cells, particularly CD4 cells, and enters the host cells using its envelope glycoprotein, gp120.

The virus's ability to destroy CD4 cells and evade the immune response is central to its pathogenicity, leading to significant immunosuppression and increased susceptibility to opportunistic infections.

EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus) (Option B) A dsDNA virus from the Herpesvirus family, has an icosahedral capsid and lacks the characteristic HIV glycoprotein spikes.

CMV (Cytomegalovirus) (Option C) is a Herpesvirus, but it is larger and does not have the bullet-shaped core of HIV. It is known for "owl’s eye" inclusion bodies in infected cells.

Coronavirus (Option D) has a crown-like appearance due to large spike proteins (S-protein) and a positive-sense ssRNA genome.

questions.text:
A disorder is characterized by recurrent hair-pulling resulting in noticeable hair loss. Which of the following statements about this disorder is not accurate?

[

choices.text: The onset is typically in adolescence or early adulthood
Associated with feelings of pleasure or relief after hair-pulling
Caused by a bacterial infection of the scalp

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Caused by a bacterial infection of the scalp

Explanation:

  • The disorder depicted in the image appears to be Trichotillomania (Hair-Pulling Disorder), which is characterized by recurrent hair-pulling leading to hair loss.
  • Trichotillomania is not due to a bacterial infection but rather a psychiatric disorder

Trichotillomania:

  • It is a psychiatric disorder in which obsessive, recurrent pulling of one’s hair results in hair loss (Options A, C)
  • It is seen in adolescents or young adults, more commonly in girls (Option B)
  • Patchy hair loss with broken hair of variable lengths is seen in commonly accessible sites like the frontoparietal area of the scalp.
  • In the Friar Tuck sign or Tonsure pattern, there is uneven hair loss in a circular pattern with surrounding hairs remaining unaffected.

 

  • Perifollicular haemorrhages can also be seen because of trauma to the scalp.
  • Skin biopsy shows empty hair follicles, with some forming soft twisted hairs described as tracheomalacia.
  • Treatment includes cognitive behavioural therapy and antipsychotic medications like SSRI and paroxetine.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a patient who presents with a swelling in the midline of the neck, based on the biopsy findings, which reveal orphan Annie's eye nuclei as depicted in the image provided?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Papillary carcinoma

Explanation:

  • Papillary thyroid carcinoma, the most common thyroid cancer, is characterised by "orphan Annie's eye" nuclei, which appear empty with a pale, ground-glass appearance under microscopy.

Papillary carcinoma thyroid:

  • It is the most common type of thyroid cancer and is characterised by lymphatic spread.
  • It often presents with a nodule in the anterior neck and lymphadenopathy.
  • Associated with BRAF mutations and RET-PTC fusion.
  • HPE shows
    • True papillae: Fingerlike projections with fibrovascular core.
    • Orphan Annie eye nuclei: Optically clear nucleus produced due to artefact.
    • Intranuclear cytoplasmic inclusions (INCI).
    • Nuclear groove or coffee bean nucleus.
    • Presence of psammoma bodies: Dystrophic calcifications
  • It has the best prognosis among thyroid malignancies.

 

Follicular carcinoma (Option A) is a malignant thyroid tumour of follicular cells lacking papillary carcinoma’s distinctive features. It typically affects older individuals and presents as a solitary thyroid mass or, less commonly, as bone metastases. It is more cellular, with a thick, irregular capsule, necrosis, and frequent mitotic activity.

Toxic nodular goitre (Option C), also known as Plummer disease or a toxic multi-nodular goitre (MNG), is characterised by a hormonally active and leads to hyperthyroidism. Treatment often includes radioactive iodine, which is absorbed by the thyroid and destroys hormone-producing cells, reducing or eliminating hormone production and potentially decreasing the size of the goitre.

Medullary carcinoma (Option D) of the thyroid (MTC), a neuroendocrine tumour, originates from the C cells of the thyroid, which produce calcitonin. MTC accounts for less than 5% of all thyroid cancers. Unlike other thyroid cancers, MTC does not accumulate radioiodine but secretes calcitonin. Symptoms may include a lump in the throat, hoarseness due to vocal cord involvement, or difficulty breathing if the tumour obstructs the windpipe.

questions.text: A 22-year-old college student presents with small, depigmented lesions which have been there for over 2 years now as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Vitiligo

Explanation:

  • The image shows depigmented patches on the arm, which are characteristic of Vitiligo.

Vitiligo:

  • Vitiligo is an acquired pigmentation disorder featuring well-defined depigmented macules on the skin.
  • Biopsies show epidermal melanocyte loss. Lesions may be localized or generalized, coalescing into large depigmented areas.
  • Wood's lamp, emitting ultraviolet A (UV-A) light, aids in diagnosis by revealing bright blue-white fluorescence with sharply demarcated borders in vitiligo lesions, particularly in individuals with pale skin.

Melasma (Option A):

  • Melasma presents as hyperpigmented (brownish) patches, often on sun-exposed areas like the face.
  • It is associated with pregnancy, oral contraceptive use, and sun exposure.

Psoriasis (Option C):

  • Psoriasis features erythematous plaques with silvery-white scales, usually on extensor surfaces like elbows and knees.
  • It does not cause depigmentation.

Dermatitis Herpetiformis (Option D):

  • This is a chronic, intensely pruritic vesicular disease associated with celiac disease.
  • It presents as grouped vesicles and papules rather than depigmented patches.

questions.text: Which is the first primary tooth to erupt?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lower central incisor

  • The first primary tooth to erupt is the lower central incisor.

Primary Dentition

Time of eruption

Lower central incisor

6 months

Upper central incisor (Option A)

7 months

Upper lateral incisor

8 months

Lower lateral incisor

9 months

1st Molar

1 year

Canine (Option C & D)

1.5 years

2nd Molar

2 years

questions.text: Which artery is being palpated in the image shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Posterior tibial artery

Explanation:

The image demonstrates palpation of the posterior tibial artery, which is typically assessed posterior to the medial malleolus, just behind the ankle joint. This pulse is an important clinical marker for peripheral circulation, especially in conditions like peripheral artery disease (PAD).

Arterial Supply of the Lower Limb

Artery

Origin

Course

Palpation Site

Clinical Importance

Posterior Tibial Artery

Popliteal artery

Runs posterior to medial malleolus

Behind medial malleolus

Evaluated in PAD (absent in vascular diseases)

Anterior Tibial Artery

Popliteal artery

Passes through interosseous membrane to anterior leg

Difficult to palpate directly

Supplies anterior compartment of the leg

Dorsalis Pedis Artery

Continuation of anterior tibial artery

Runs along dorsum of foot

Lateral to extensor hallucis longus tendon

Commonly used in vascular assessments

Popliteal Artery

Continuation of femoral artery

Located in popliteal fossa

Deep in the popliteal fossa

Can be affected in popliteal artery entrapment syndrome

Anterior tibial artery (Option A): incorrect because it is located in the anterior compartment of the leg and is not palpated posterior to the medial malleolus.

Dorsalis pedis artery (Option C): incorrect because it is palpated on the dorsum of the foot, lateral to the extensor hallucis longus tendon.

Popliteal artery (Option D): incorrect because it is located deep in the popliteal fossa and requires deep palpation behind the knee.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman has been experiencing left knee pain for one month. The knee is tender to touch, and an X-ray reveals a 5cm mass in the distal femoral epiphysis with a "soap bubble" appearance. Microscopy findings are provided below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Osteoclastoma

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation and histopathological image reveal numerous multinucleated giant cells within a bone lesion, which highly suggests Osteoclastoma (Giant cell tumour of bone).

Giant cell tumour (Osteoclastoma):

  • It is a benign but locally aggressive tumour, characterised by numerous multinucleated osteoclast-type giant cells.
  • It occurs in the third to fifth decades of life.
  • Pathogenesis:
    • The neoplastic cells are primitive osteoblast precursors that express high levels of RANKL, promoting the proliferation of osteoclast precursors and their differentiation into mature osteoclasts.
    • This increased activity of osteoclasts is responsible for the tumour being highly lytic and expansile due to uncontrolled bone resorption.
  • Giant cell tumours develop within the epiphysis and may extend into the metaphysis.
    • Mostly located near the knee, involving the distal femur or proximal tibia.
    • Although rare, they can metastasise to the lungs but typically regress spontaneously and are rarely fatal.
  • Morphology:
    • Grossly, the tumours are large, red-brown masses that frequently undergo cystic degeneration.
    • Histologically, the tumours consist of uniform oval mononuclear tumour cells and abundant osteoclast-type giant cells with 100 or more nuclei.

 

Chondroblastoma (Option A) is a benign, chondroid-producing tumour that usually arises in the epiphysis or apophysis of skeletally immature individuals. It is characterised by a sheet-like proliferation of chondroblasts and presents with pain, joint stiffness, and swelling. Chondroblastomas rarely show a soap bubble appearance on X-ray.

 

Osteosarcoma (Option C) is a malignant bone tumour, typically found in the metaphysis of long bones. It is most common in children and young adults, particularly around sites of bone growth. It can present with bone pain, swelling, and fractures but does not typically exhibit the soap bubble appearance associated with giant cell tumours.

 

Osteochondroma (Option D) is a benign bone tumour that forms on the surface of bones, usually near the growth plate. It comprises bone and cartilage and tends to stop growing after skeletal maturity. They do not present with a soap bubble appearance and are typically not located in the epiphysis.

questions.text: A woman delivered a healthy baby and to control her postpartum hemorrhage an artery was ligated. Then later she developed pain under her gluteus muscle. Which was the artery ligated ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Internal iliac artery

Explanation:

In cases of severe postpartum hemorrhage (PPH), ligation of the internal iliac artery is a common life-saving procedure. However, this artery also supplies the gluteal region via the superior and inferior gluteal arteries. Ligation can lead to ischemia and pain in the gluteal region, which explains the symptoms seen in this patient.

Internal Iliac Artery and Its Branches

Artery

Origin

Major Branches

Supply

Clinical Significance

Internal Iliac Artery

Common iliac artery

Anterior and posterior divisions

Pelvic organs, gluteal region, perineum

Ligation used in PPH management

Uterine Artery

Anterior division of internal iliac

Anastomoses with ovarian artery

Uterus, cervix, vagina

Commonly ligated in hysterectomy

Superior Gluteal Artery

Posterior division of internal iliac

Branches to gluteal muscles

Gluteus medius, minimus, and tensor fascia lata

Injury can cause Trendelenburg gait

Inferior Gluteal Artery

Anterior division of internal iliac

Supplies deeper gluteal structures

Gluteus maximus, sciatic nerve

Injury affects hip extension

 

Uterine artery (Option A): incorrect because it primarily supplies the uterus and is ligated in hysterectomy or uterine artery embolization, but does not directly cause gluteal pain.

Superior gluteal artery (Option B): incorrect because while it supplies the gluteal muscles, it is a branch of the internal iliac artery and is not directly ligated in PPH.

Inferior gluteal artery (Option C): incorrect because, though it supplies the gluteal region, it is also a branch of the internal iliac artery and is rarely ligated alone.

questions.text: What does the presence of painless sores on the vulval area indicate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Condylomata acuminata

Explanation:

  • The above image shows rough finger-like, cauliflower-like growth over the vulva is suggestive of condyloma accuminata, caused by human papillomavirus (HPV 6 > HPV 11).

Condyloma acuminata (anogenital warts):

  • Benign, moist, soft, pedunculated wart found on the external genitalia and has low malignant potential.
  • Site: They may be found in the genital area such as the penile shaft, scrotum, or labia majora of the vagina, or in the anal area.
  • Appearance: They are generally pink and project out from the surface of the skin. Size may vary; they usually appear small but can merge into large masses.
  • Microscopy:
    • A branching villous structure with connective tissue stroma.
    • Epidermis showing hyperkeratosis and acanthosis (thickening).
    • Cytoplasmic vacuolization of the squamous cells (koilocytosis) is Characteristic.
    • No evidence of dysplasia.

 

The table below shows the clinical features of HPV and the types responsible for various lesions:

Clinical lesion

Oncogenic potential

HPV types

Plantar warts

Benign

1

Common skin warts

Benign

2, 4, 27, 57

Epidermodysplasia verrucosa

Mostly benign, rarely progresses to malignancy

5, 8, 9, 12, 17

Anogenital warts

Laryngeal papilloma

Intraepithelial neoplasia

Low malignant potential

6, 11

Palmar warts in butchers

Low malignant potential

7

Carcinomas of the cervix & other genital mucosa/larynx/oesophagus

High malignant potential

16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 51, 52, 56, 58, 59, 68

 

Genital herpes (HSV-2) (Option A):

  • Presents with painful vesicles and ulcers, not large warty growths.
  • Associated with burning, itching, and systemic symptoms (fever, malaise).

Gonococcal vulvovaginitis (Option C):

  • Presents with purulent vaginal discharge, dysuria, and irritation, not warty lesions.

Condyloma lata (Secondary Syphilis) (Option D):

  • Presents as flat, moist, velvety, painless plaques rather than exophytic growths.
  • Associated with generalized lymphadenopathy and systemic symptoms.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a 5-year-old boy who has weight loss, fever, and a painless swelling in his jaw area, with anaemia and lymphocytosis revealed by a CBC and biopsy findings shown in the accompanying image?\
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Burkitt’s lymphoma

Explanation:

The clinical presentation of weight loss, fever, painless jaw swelling, along with a starry sky appearance on histology and anaemia with lymphocytosis on CBC, strongly suggests Burkitt’s lymphoma.

  • It is an aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma, typically associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection, HIV, and chromosomal translocations leading to c-myc oncogene overexpression.
  • It is classified into three clinical groups: endemic, sporadic, and immunodeficiency-related.
  • Clinical symptoms include:
    • Painless swelling: The most common symptom is the presence of one or more painless, rapidly enlarging masses, typically involving lymph nodes.
    • Heavy night sweating
    • Intermittent high fever
    • Significant weight loss (more than 10% of body weight)
  • Associated with the translocations of the MYC gene on chromosome 8, t(8:14).
  • It has three primary subtypes:
    • Endemic Burkitt's lymphoma: Commonly affects children in malaria-endemic areas of Africa, often presenting with tumours in the jaw or facial bones.
    • Sporadic Burkitt's lymphoma: More frequently seen in non-endemic regions and usually involving the ileocaecal region and peritoneum
    • Immunodeficiency-associated Burkitt's lymphoma: Found in patients with conditions such as HIV/AIDS or other forms of immunodeficiency.

 

Hodgkin's disease (Option A) is a cancer of the lymphatic system, characterised by uncontrolled proliferation of lymphocytes. It often presents with painless swollen lymph nodes, but the hallmark feature is the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells (large, abnormal lymphocytes with two nuclei resembling "owl eyes"). HL is treated with chemotherapy, radiation, and stem-cell transplantation.

 

Acute lymphocytic leukaemia (ALL) (Option B) is a malignancy of the blood and bone marrow characterised by the rapid production of immature white blood cells. Common symptoms include fatigue, pallor, frequent infections, and unusual bleeding, but it does not typically present with localised swelling, as seen in Burkitt’s lymphoma.

 

Chloroma (Option C), also known as granulocytic sarcoma or myeloid sarcoma, is a rare tumour composed of myeloblasts, usually associated with acute myeloid leukaemia (AML). It can form in various tissues such as the bones, skin, lymph nodes, and central nervous system, but it does not present with the distinctive symptoms or patterns of Burkitt's lymphoma, such as the characteristic jaw swelling. Chloromas are often nonspecific and can include symptoms like fatigue, weight loss, and pain.

questions.text: Which of the following cartilage do not calcify with age?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Epiglottis

Explanation:

The epiglottis is composed of elastic cartilage, which does not undergo calcification with age. In contrast, cartilages made of hyaline cartilage- such as the thyroid, cricoid, and parts of the arytenoid cartilage- tend to calcify and ossify over time.

Laryngeal Cartilages and Aging Changes

Cartilage

Type

Function

Calcification with Age

Thyroid

Hyaline

Protects vocal cords, supports larynx

Yes, calcifies and ossifies

Cricoid

Hyaline

Provides structural support to the airway

Yes, calcifies and ossifies

Arytenoid

Hyaline (except vocal process, which has elastic cartilage)

Controls vocal cord movement

Yes, except vocal process

Epiglottis

Elastic

Prevents food from entering airway

No, remains flexible

Thyroid cartilage (Option A): incorrect because it is composed of hyaline cartilage, which calcifies and ossifies with age.

Arytenoid cartilage (Option B): incorrect because it has both hyaline and elastic components. The hyaline part calcifies, but the elastic part (vocal process) does not.

Cricoid cartilage (Option D): incorrect because it is made of hyaline cartilage, which undergoes calcification over time.

questions.text: A child who is exclusively fed rice water presents with a swollen abdomen and a pale, unenergetic expression, and shows signs of malnourishment with decreased serum protein and albumin levels. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Kwashiorkor

  • The presence of oedema, signs of malnutrition, and decreased serum protein and albumin levels point to the diagnosis of kwashiorkor.

Kwashiorkor

Marasmus (Option B)

Pitting Edema: Characterized by swelling, often starting in the legs and feet, leaving a persistent indentation when pressed.

Severe Wasting: The child appears extremely thin, with prominent bones and little body fat.

Sugar Baby Appearance: The child may look deceptively healthy due to oedema, despite being malnourished.

Monkey Facies: A sunken appearance of the cheeks due to loss of fat, giving an aged look.

Muscle Wasting: Despite the swollen appearance, muscle loss is present, leading to weakness and hypotonia.

Baggy Pants Appearance: Loose, sagging skin around the buttocks caused by significant muscle and fat loss.

Mental and Neurological Symptoms: The child is apathetic, irritable, and may have feeding difficulties.

Alertness: Children with marasmus remain mentally alert.

Hair Changes: Hair may lose colour, become thin, and show alternating bands of colour ("flag sign").

Absence of Edema: Unlike kwashiorkor, marasmus does not involve swelling or oedema.

Skin Changes: Includes hyperpigmentation, peeling skin ("flaky paint" appearance), and colour changes, particularly in the buttocks, perineum, and thighs.

Hypoglycemia Risk: The liver's reduced capacity to produce glucose increases the risk of low blood sugar.

Gastrointestinal Issues: Anorexia, vomiting, and abdominal distension. Anaemia is present due to nutritional deficiencies.

Hypothermia Risk: The child may struggle to maintain body temperature due to energy depletion.


 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Indian childhood cirrhosis (Option C) is a chronic liver disease in infants and children that presents with jaundice, pruritis, lethargy, and hepatosplenomegaly. It is related to copper accumulation in the liver and is not the given scenario.

Kawasaki disease (Option D) is a vasculitis that affects medium-sized arteries, especially the coronary arteries and presents with fever, strawberry tongue, bilateral conjunctivitis, rash, and desquamation of hands and feet. This is not the given scenario.

questions.text: In the scenario of a man who fell into a manhole and sustained perineal injury, leading to difficulty in urination and presence of blood at the urethral tip, a diagnosis of bulbar urethral injury was determined. In this particular case, where would the urine accumulation be the least expected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) The medial portion of the thigh

Explanation:

  • In bulbar urethral injury, the spongy urethra is damaged, leading to extravasation of urine into the superficial perineal space.
  • Urine can track into the perineum, scrotum, penis, and anterior abdominal wall due to the continuity of the Colles' fascia, Dartos fascia, and Scarpa's fascia.
  • However, it does not spread into the thigh because Colles' fascia is firmly attached to the fascia lata of the thigh, preventing urine from tracking into the medial thigh.

Urine Extravasation in Urethral Injuries

Type of Urethral Injury

Common Cause

Urine Accumulation

Areas Restricted

Bulbar urethral injury (Spongy urethra rupture)

Straddle injury (e.g., falling on a hard object)

Perineum, scrotum, penis, anterior abdominal wall

Thigh (due to attachment of Colles' fascia)

Membranous urethral injury

Pelvic fractures

Retropubic space, perineum

Scrotum and penis (if Buck’s fascia remains intact)

Penile urethral injury

Blunt trauma or catheterization

Confined within Buck’s fascia if intact, or perineum if ruptured

None if Buck’s fascia is disrupted

Perineum (Option A): incorrect because urine accumulates in the superficial perineal space due to the injury.

Anterior abdominal wall (Option B): incorrect because urine can track upward via Scarpa’s fascia.

Root of the scrotum (Option D): incorrect because urine spreads into the scrotum via continuity with Dartos fascia.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with easy fatigability, back pain, and multiple lytic lesions in the skull. The bone marrow biopsy finding is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Multiple Myeloma

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of easy fatigability, back pain, and skull lytic lesions, along with Russell bodies in bone marrow biopsy, strongly suggests multiple myeloma, which commonly causes bone pain and elevated serum proteins.

Multiple myeloma is a cancer of plasma cells, which normally produce antibodies to fight infections. In this disease, malignant plasma cells proliferate uncontrollably in the bone marrow, crowding out healthy blood cells and producing abnormal proteins that cause complications. Early symptoms may be absent, but when present, they include:

  • Bone pain, especially in the spine or chest
  • Nausea
  • Constipation
  • Loss of appetite
  • Confusion or mental fogginess
  • Fatigue
  • Frequent infections
  • Weight loss
  • Weakness or numbness in the legs
  • Excessive thirst

 

CML (Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia) (Option A) is a blood and bone marrow cancer that leads to an overproduction of white blood cells. In its chronic phase, the disease can often go unnoticed until detected by a blood test. Symptoms include:

  • Weakness
  • Fatigue
  • Shortness of breath with daily activities
  • Fever
  • Bone pain
  • Unexplained weight loss
  • Pain or fullness in the left side of the abdomen due to an enlarged spleen
  • Night sweats

 

CLL (Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia) (Option B) is a slow-progressing blood and bone marrow cancer, typically occurring in older adults. It may not cause symptoms in the early stages and is often discovered during a routine blood test. Later symptoms include:

  • Painless swelling of lymph nodes
  • Weakness or fatigue
  • Feeling full due to spleen or liver enlargement
  • Fever and frequent infections
  • Easy bruising or bleeding
  • Unexplained weight loss
  • Drenching night sweats

 

Hairy Cell Leukemia (Option D) is a cancer of the B lymphocytes (a type of white blood cell). The leukaemia cells in this condition look "hairy" under a microscope. Symptoms may be absent or include:

  • A feeling of fullness in the abdomen, making it difficult to eat large meals
  • Fatigue
  • Easy bruising
  • Frequent infections
  • Weakness
  • Unintentional weight loss

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a farmer who has a swollen foot and multiple discharging sinuses, as depicted in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Mycetoma

Explanation:

  • The most probable diagnosis for a farmer with a swollen foot and multiple discharging sinuses is Mycetoma

Mycetoma (Madura Foot)

  • Definition: Chronic granulomatous infection with subcutaneous masses, draining sinuses, and grains in exudates
  • Types:
    • Eumycetoma (fungal)
    • Actinomycetoma (bacterial)

Clinical Presentation

  • Initial Lesion:
    • Painless nodule; may be asymptomatic for years
  • Progression:
    • Leads to swelling, ulceration, and pus discharge from sinuses containing grains
  • Complications:
    • Severe deformities, osteomyelitis, potential amputation due to extensive tissue damage

 

Microscopic Examination

Type

Causative Agents

Microscopic Features

Eumycetoma

Madurella mycetomatis, Curvularia lunata, Scedosporium spp., Acremonium spp.
  • Hyphae or thick-walled grains (black/white).
  • Histology shows suppurative granulomas with neutrophils.

Actinomycetoma

Actinomadura madurae, Nocardia spp.

Thin, branching filaments visible with Gram staining. Similar granulomas to eumycetoma but distinct morphology.

 

Diagnostic Techniques

  • Biopsy and Culture:
    • Tissue biopsy for visualization of pathogens.
    • Culturing exudates for specific organism identification.
    • Special stains to differentiate fungal and bacterial infections.
  • Imaging Studies:
    • X-rays and MRI to assess bone involvement in advanced cases.

Treatment

Type

Treatment Approach

Eumycetoma

Surgical excision with antifungals (itraconazole, ketoconazole). High recurrence rates.

Actinomycetoma

Prolonged antibiotic therapy (e.g., trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, dapsone) along with surgical intervention.

 

Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC) (Option B):

  • SCC can develop in chronic ulcers or scars but is not characterized by multiple discharging sinuses with granules.

Nocardia (Option C):

  • While Nocardia can cause actinomycetoma, which is a type of mycetoma, Nocardia alone does not fully describe the condition seen in the image.
  • The term mycetoma broadly refers to both eumycetoma (fungal) and actinomycetoma (bacterial), including those caused by Nocardia.

Sporotrichosis (Option D):

  • A subcutaneous fungal infection (Sporothrix schenckii) that spreads along lymphatics (sporotrichoid spread) but does not present with multiple sinus tracts and granules.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child presents with a persistent cough for 15 days. Upon examination, cervical lymphadenopathy is observed. A lymph node biopsy image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Tuberculosis

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation and caseating granulomas (central necrosis surrounded by epithelioid macrophages and lymphocytes) in the biopsy strongly suggest Tuberculosis.

Type of Granuloma

Examples

Caseating Granuloma

Tuberculosis, Histoplasmosis, Coccidioidomycosis, Syphilis

Non-caseating Granuloma

Sarcoidosis, Crohn’s disease, Leprosy

Foreign Body Granuloma

Silicosis, Asbestos-related diseases, Foreign body reactions

Immune Granuloma

Wegener’s granulomatosis, Giant cell arteritis

Durck’s Granuloma

Cerebral malaria

Stellate Granuloma

Cat scratch disease

 

Causes of granuloma formation

Infectious causes

Non-infectious causes
  • TB (Caseating and non-caseating granuloma)
  • Leprosy
  • Syphilis
  • Malaria (Durck granuloma)
  • Cat-scratch disease and Lymphogranuloma venerum (Stellate granuloma)
  • Q fever (Doughnut granuloma/ Fibrin ring granuloma)
  • Sarcoidosis (Naked granuloma)
  • Giant cell arteritis
  • Crohn’s disease
  • Churg-Strauss syndrome (Eosinophilic granuloma)
  • Berylliosis (Foreign body granuloma)

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy has non-blanching rashes on the legs and buttocks. He also complains of joint pains, abdominal pain, vomiting, and blood in the stool. Lab investigations revealed normal platelet count and urine analysis shows haematuria +++ and proteinuria +. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Henoch Schonlein purpura (HSP)

  • The clinical scenario of purpura in legs and buttocks, arthritic pain, abdominal pain and normal platelet level are characteristic of Henoch-Schönlein Purpura (HSP).

Henoch-Schönlein Purpura (HSP)

 

 

Aetiology
  • The exact cause is unknown.
  • Immune-mediated vasculitis, often following an upper respiratory infection.
  • Genetic predisposition, with HLA-B34 and DRB1, was observed in some cases.
  • Most common in Males.

 

 

Pathology and Pathophysiology
  • Inflammation of small blood vessels affecting skin, joints, intestines, and kidneys.
  • Triggered by immune system response to infections.
  • Leakage of fluid and blood cells into tissues.
  • Immune complex deposition, particularly IgA, in affected vessels.

Clinical Features
  • Palpable Purpura: Raised, purplish-red rash, mainly on lower limbs and buttocks.
  • Joint Involvement: Joint swelling, commonly in knees and ankles.
  • Abdominal Pain: Often severe, may include vomiting, diarrhoea, gastrointestinal bleeding, or intussusception
  • Renal Involvement: Less common, presents as Chronic renal failure.

Diagnosis

Clinical Criteria:

  • Palpable purpura plus at least one of:
    • Diffuse abdominal pain
    • Arthritis or arthralgia
    • Biopsy-proven IgA deposition
    • Renal involvement (hematuria &/ proteinuria)


Laboratory involvement:

  • Elevated ESR or CRP indicates inflammation.
  • Platelet Counts are normal.

Complications
  • Intussusception.
  • Chronic Renal Failure due to Long-term kidney damage, in severe cases.
  • Neurological Complications: Rare; may include seizures, headaches, or peripheral neuropathy.

Treatment
  • Mild Cases: Rest, hydration, and pain relievers.
  • Moderate to Severe Cases: Corticosteroids (e.g., prednisone) to reduce inflammation.
  • Severe or Resistant Cases: Additional immunosuppressive medications may be required.

Prognosis
  • Full recovery in most cases.
  • Variable based on renal involvement.


Malar rash is virtually pathognomonic in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) (Option A). It involves the cheek, bridge of the nose, and lower eyelids but characteristically spares the nasolabial folds.

In Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) (Option C), children present with a sudden appearance of bruises and mucosal bleeding like epistaxis, oral oozing and prolonged bleeds with superficial trauma. The platelet levels are low in this condition unlike the given scenario.

Polyarteritis arteritis nodosa (Option D) rare in childhood, is characterised by the presence of either a biopsy showing small and mid-size artery necrotising vasculitis or angiographic abnormalities.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the diagram showing the development of ovarian follicles.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Antral follicle

Explanation:

  • Antral follicles are characterized by the presence of a fluid-filled cavity (antrum) surrounding the oocyte.
  • These follicles have multiple layers of granulosa cells, a well-developed theca interna and theca externa, and contribute to hormone production. The presence of the antrum differentiates them from primary follicles, which lack this cavity.

Development of Ovarian Follicles

Stage

Characteristics

Primordial follicle

Oocytes surrounded by a single layer of flattened granulosa cells. Dormant until puberty.

Primary follicle

Granulosa cells become cuboidal, zona pellucida begins forming around the oocyte. No antrum.

Secondary follicle

Multiple layers of granulosa cells and theca cells form. Early follicular development but no antrum yet.

Antral follicle

Fluid-filled antrum appears, granulosa and theca cells differentiate. Prepares for ovulation.

Graafian follicle

Fully matured, large antrum, ready for ovulation.

Corpus luteum

Formed after ovulation, secretes progesterone to support pregnancy. If there is no fertilization, it degenerates.

Primary follicle (Option A): Incorrect because primary follicles lack an antrum and have a single or multilayered granulosa cell arrangement.

Primordial follicle (Option C): Incorrect because primordial follicles are the earliest stage, with a single layer of flattened granulosa cells and no antrum.

Corpus luteum (Option D): Incorrect because the corpus luteum is a post-ovulatory structure that does not resemble a developing follicle and lacks an antrum.

questions.text: Supravital stains are used in the identification of all except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Copper in tissue

Explanation:

  • Supravital stains are typically used to identify cellular components such as reticulocytes (immature red blood cells), Heinz bodies (denatured haemoglobin), and ribosomal RNA (which is seen in reticulocytes as a network). However, copper in tissue is not identified using supravital stains; it requires special staining techniques like rhodanine stains.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 35-year-old male who is experiencing hair loss, based on the provided examination findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Alopecia areata

Explanation:

  • Given the patchy nature of the hair loss, alopecia areata is the most likely diagnosis.

 

Alopecia areata:

Alopecia areata is a T-cell-mediated autoimmune condition targeting the anagen hair bulb causing non-scarring hair loss. Clinical features include,

  • Localized patches of hair loss on the scalp that emerge over a few weeks. It can also affect other areas, such as the beard, eyebrows, eyelashes, and extremities.
  • Variants:
    • Alopecia Totalis: Complete hair loss from the scalp.
    • Alopecia Universalis: Complete hair loss from all over the body.
    • Ophiasis: Occipital hair loss.

  

 

  • Exclamation-mark hair, with a narrower proximal end than the distal end, is commonly observed at the periphery of lesions and is a pathognomonic finding in patients with alopecia areata.
  • Pitting of nails that is superficial, geometric and regular

 

Non-scarring alopecia

Exclamation mark hair

Regular nail pitting

 

The pull test is positive, Very gentle traction on the unaffected hair at the margin of the patch of hair loss can remove all of the hair from the roots painlessly. It is a distinguishing feature of alopecia areata

Tinea capitis (Scalp Ringworm) (Option A):

  • Fungal infection of the scalp, common in children.
  • Presents with scaly patches, broken hairs, and black dots (not smooth bald patches).
  • KOH mount shows fungal hyphae.
  • Can progress to kerion (severe inflammatory form).

Kerion (Option B):

  • Severe inflammatory form of tinea capitis with painful, boggy swelling, pustules, and abscesses.
  • Often associated with secondary bacterial infection.
  • More common in children.

Androgenic alopecia (Male Pattern Baldness) (Option D):

  • Gradual thinning of hair in a defined pattern (bitemporal recession, vertex baldness).
  • Hormone-related (DHT sensitivity).
  • No well-defined patches of baldness.

questions.text: A 78-year-old male presents with fatigue, breathlessness, and palpitations. On examination, he has pedal oedema, with a pulse rate of 55 bpm, BP of 100/70 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 94%. ECG is normal, and echocardiography reveals restrictive cardiomyopathy. A cardiac biopsy stained with Congo red shows apple-green birefringence under polarised light. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cardiac amyloidosis

Explanation:

  • The hallmark feature is apple-green birefringence under polarised light after Congo red staining, characteristic of amyloid deposits.
  • Cardiac amyloidosis causes restrictive cardiomyopathy, presenting with symptoms like fatigue, breathlessness, and oedema.
  • Congo red stain identifies amyloid fibrils in tissue.

Amyloidosis is abnormal extracellular deposits of fibrillar proteins that cause tissue damage and functional compromise.

  • These proteins are misfolded and aggregate, forming amyloid deposits.
  • Amyloid deposits appear as eosinophilic, hyaline, and extracellular substances on hematoxylin and eosin stains.
  • They are confirmed by Congo red staining, which shows red under ordinary light and apple-green birefringence under polarised light.

Morphology: Amyloid deposition is often widespread, but organ involvement can vary:

  • Kidney: Most commonly and severely affected, with amyloid deposits in the glomeruli, arteries, and arterioles.
  • Spleen: Enlarged, showing two patterns of amyloid deposits: "sago spleen" (follicular) and "lardaceous spleen" (sinusoidal).
  • Liver: Amyloid deposits in the space of Disse; liver function is generally preserved despite enlargement.
  • Heart: Commonly involved in senile systemic amyloidosis, with deposits starting subendocardially and in the myocardium.
  • Other organs: May include the tongue (macroglossia), lungs (respiratory tract involvement), and brain (Alzheimer's plaques).

Types:

Type of Amyloidosis

Amyloid Protein

Associated Conditions

Primary Amyloidosis (AL)

Amyloid Light Chain (AL)

Plasma cell disorders (e.g., multiple myeloma)

Secondary Amyloidosis (AA)

Amyloid-Associated (AA)

Chronic inflammation (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis, IBD)

Hereditary Amyloidosis

Transthyretin (TTR)

Familial amyloid polyneuropathies (e.g., familial Mediterranean fever)

Hemodialysis-Associated

β2-Microglobulin

Long-term hemodialysis

Senile Systemic Amyloidosis

Transthyretin (TTR)

Ageing, mutations in TTR

Localised Amyloidosis

Varies (often AL type)

Specific organs (e.g., tongue, lung, skin, bladder)

Endocrine Amyloidosis

Medullary thyroid carcinoma (Acal)

Endocrine tumours (e.g., medullary thyroid carcinoma, pancreatic islet tumours)

questions.text:
An HIV patient presents with persistent diarrhea. Microscopic examination of the stool reveals oocyst of size 4 to 8 µm as shown below. Identify the causative organism.

​​​ ​​ ​​ ​​ ​​
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Cryptosporidium

Explanation:

Features

Cryptosporidium (Option A)

Cyclospora (Option B)

Cystoisospora (Option D)

Transmission

Ingestion of contaminated food/water, autoinfection

Ingestion of contaminated food/water

Ingestion of sporulated oocysts

Infective form

Sporulated oocyst

Sporulated oocyst

Sporulated oocyst

Diagnostic form

Sporulated oocyst

Unsporulated oocyst

Unsporulated oocyst

Incubation Period

2-14 days

1-7 days

1-4 days

Oocyst shape

Round

Round

Oval

Oocyst size

4-6 µm

8-10 µm

20–33 µm

Sporulated oocyst

Four sporozoites

Two sporocysts, each having four sporozoites

Acid-fastness

Uniformly acid-fast

Uniformly acid-fast

Autofluorescence

–

Sporulation of the oocyst

Inside the host cells (enterocytes)

soil

Zoonotic potential

Yes

Treatment

​​

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presented with dark-coloured urine, oliguria, hypertension, and facial puffiness for 3 days. The urine test is positive for albumin. He had a history of throat infection 2 weeks back. On microscopic examination, enlarged, pale glomeruli and epithelial humps are seen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

  • The child here presents with dark urine, proteinuria, oliguria, hypertension and oedema with a history of throat infection 2 weeks back all suggest the diagnosis of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.

Feature

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN)

Clinical Presentation

Acute nephritic syndrome: Hematuria, oliguria, edema, hypertension

Proteinuria

(1+ to 2+) levels of proteinuria

Hematuria

Common, with cola-colored urine due to gross hematuria

Urinary Casts

Red blood cell casts (indicating glomerular inflammation)

Serum Albumin

Usually normal unless severe renal impairment

Blood Urea and Creatinine

Elevated due to impaired renal function

Serum Complement C3

Low in 90% of cases, returns to normal in 8-12 weeks

Cholesterol

No significant hypercholesterolemia

ASO/Anti-DNase B Titers

Elevated ASO titers (pharyngitis) or anti-DNase B (skin infection)

Post-staphylococcal glomerulonephritis (Option A): While Staphylococcus aureus infections can also cause glomerulonephritis, they are less commonly associated with the classic immune complex deposits seen in PSGN.

Nephrotic syndrome (Option C) involves the clinical findings of hypoalbuminemia, oedema, proteinurua and hyperlipidemia. Even though some clinical findings are similar to that given in the scenario, nephrotic syndrome does not cause dark-coloured urine

IgA nephropathy (Option D) or Berger nephropathy is a chronic glomerular disease in children characterised by an increased concentration of IgA in the mesangial glomerular deposits with no systemic disease. It presents with gross hematuria within 1-2 days of a previous upper respiratory or GI infection and not after weeks; hence, it is not the diagnosis here.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 30-year-old woman who has lacy lesions in her mouth and genital area, while her proximal nail fold has extended onto the nail bed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Lichen planus

Explanation:

  • The combination of lacy lesions in the mouth and genital area, along with nail changes, strongly suggests lichen planus.

 

Lichen Planus:

Clinical Features

  • 6 P’s → Pruritic, Purple, Polygonal, Planar Papules & Plaques
  • Mucosal involvement → Wickham striae (reticular white lines)
  • Koebner phenomenon: This phenomenon refers to the development of lesions at sites of trauma to uninvolved skin
  • Histology → Sawtooth infiltrate of lymphocytes at the dermal-epidermal junction
  • Association → Hepatitis C

 

Treatment

Topical (First-line for mild cases)

  • Corticosteroids (Clobetasol, Betamethasone)
  • Calcineurin Inhibitors (Tacrolimus, Pimecrolimus) – for oral/genital LP
  • Antihistamines – for pruritus relief
  • Local anesthetics (Lidocaine gel) – for painful oral lesions

Intralesional (For hypertrophic LP)

  • Intralesional corticosteroids (Triamcinolone injections)

Systemic (For severe, widespread, or refractory cases)

  • Oral corticosteroids (Prednisolone)
  • Dapsone
  • Hydroxychloroquine (HCQS)
  • Azathioprine, Mycophenolate mofetil (MMF)

Phototherapy (For generalized LP, especially in children)

  • Narrow-band UVB (NBUVB) phototherapy

 

Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris (Option A):

  • Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris (PRP) typically presents with scaly, red follicular plaques and islands of sparing near the axilla called islands of sparing
  • It histopathologically exhibits a distinctive checkerboard pattern marked by alternating areas of hyperkeratosis and parakeratosis.

Psoriasis (Option B):

  • Features silvery scales on erythematous plaques, commonly on extensor surfaces.
  • Nail changes include pitting, oil-drop sign, and onycholysis, but not pterygium formation.
  • Oral lesions are rare.

 

Pityriasis rosea (Option C):

  • Starts with a herald patch followed by oval, scaly lesions in a "Christmas tree" pattern.
  • No oral/genital lesions or nail involvement.

questions.text: Which is correct about ABO and Rh incompatibility leading to erythroblastosis fetalis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Cytotoxic

  • ABO and Rh incompatibility leading to erythroblastosis fetalis involves a cytotoxic type of reaction, also known as type II hypersensitivity.

Pathophysiology of Erythroblastosis

Cell-mediated hypersensitivity (Option B) reactions, also known as type IV hypersensitivity, are not involved in the development of erythroblastosis fetalis.

Erythroblastosis fetalis does involve an antigen-antibody reaction (Option C), but the specific mechanism is cytotoxic.

Immune complex-mediated (Option D) reactions type III hypersensitivity involves the formation of antigen-antibody complexes that deposit in tissues and trigger inflammation and are not involved in erythroblastosis fetalis.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child was brought to her paediatrician for routine well-child care. Her physical examination is normal except for a systolic murmur and a widely split-second heart sound that does not vary with respiration. She has no family history of heart disease. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Atrial septal defect

  • The systolic murmur and a widely split-second heart sound in an otherwise normal child indicate an atrial septal defect.

Atrial septal defect

Pathophysiology:

Feature

Description

Left-to-Right Shunting

Oxygenated blood flows from the left to right atrium; the degree of shunting varies with defect size and vascular resistance.

Right Heart Volume Overload

Increased blood flow causes enlargement of the right atrium and ventricle, and dilation of the pulmonary artery.

Pulmonary Vascular Resistance

May increase with time, after remaining low during childhood, and lead to reversal of shunt and cyanosis.

Clinical Manifestations:

Symptoms

Description

Asymptomatic

Many children are asymptomatic.

Failure to Thrive

Poor growth and weight gain.

Exercise Intolerance

Difficulty with physical activity.

 

Physical Examination Findings:

Finding

Description

Widely Split and Fixed S2

The second heart sound is split and fixed due to increased right ventricular diastolic volume.

Systolic Ejection Murmur

Soft murmur at the left upper sternal border, caused by increased flow across the right ventricular outflow tract.

Mid-Diastolic Murmur

Rumbling murmur at the lower left sternal border due to increased flow across the tricuspid valve.

Children with total anomalous pulmonary venous connection (Option A) are not asymptomatic and often present with cyanosis and congestive cardiac failure with equal saturation levels across all four heart chambers. Examination findings of fixed split S2, systolic ejection murmur, and cyanosis are seen. Hence, it is not the given scenario.

In ventricular septal defects (Option B), there are left-to-right shunts that are symptomatic depending on the size of the defect and may vary from asymptomatic with normal pulmonary artery pressure and a loud, harsh or blowing holosystolic murmur to pulmonary hypertension and symptoms of congestive cardiac failure.

Pulmonary stenosis (Option D) is the narrowing of the pathway from the right ventricle to the pulmonary artery, possibly affecting the infundibulum, valve, or main pulmonary artery. It is a component of the Tetralogy of Fallot and often presents with severe cyanosis from birth. The clinical findings include an ejection click heard after S1 (closer to S1 as the severity increases) and a split S2 in moderate to severe cses.

questions.text: Dystrophin protein is absent completely in which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy

Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD) is a genetic disorder caused by mutations in the dystrophin gene characterised by progressive muscle degeneration and weakness.

  • DMD progresses rapidly and leads to loss of ambulation in the early teenage years.
  • It is associated with cognitive impairment and a high incidence of cardiomyopathy and respiratory complications, which typically determine life expectancy.

Aspect

Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD)

Becker Muscular Dystrophy (BMD) (Option A)

Type of Mutation

Frameshift mutations lead to a disrupted reading frame

In-frame mutations that preserve the reading frame

Dystrophin Protein
  • Dystrophin deficient
  • Truncated and unstable (< 3% of normal)
  • Abnormal dystrophin
  • Partially functional (20–90% of normal)

Clinical Severity

Severe, early onset, rapid progression

Milder, later onset, slower progression

Inheritance Pattern

X-linked recessive

X-linked recessive

Age of onset

Early childhood (Before 5 years)

Later childhood (After 5-7 years)

Myasthenia gravis (MG) (Option C) is a chronic autoimmune disease of the neuromuscular junction (postsynaptic end plate) that leads to abnormal neuromuscular transmission or blockade.

Blockade of presynaptic calcium channels at the neuromuscular junction is characteristic of Lambert-Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome (LEMS) (Option D). In LEMS, autoantibodies target voltage-gated calcium channels (VGCCs) on presynaptic nerve terminals. This leads to a reduction in acetylcholine (ACh) release, which causes muscle weakness.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about colostrum?

choices.text: It is the breastmilk that is seen in the initial 3-4 days
It contains a large number of antibodies
It contains a high amount of lactose and low amounts of protein

questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - It contains a high amount of lactose and low amounts of protein

The colostrum contains low amounts of lactose and a high amount of protein.

  • Colostrum is the initial, thick, yellow milk produced during the first 3-4 days after birth.
  • Rich in antibodies (particularly secretory IgA), immune cells, and vitamins A, D, E, and K.
  • This early milk provides crucial protection and immunity for the newborn.

Milk Type

Time of Production

Appearance

Quantity

Key Components

Colostrum

Initial 3-4 days after delivery (Option A)

Yellow and thick

(Option B)

Small
  • It is high in antibodies (Option C), immune-competent cells, and vitamins A, D, E, and K.
  • Rich in immunoglobulins and proteins.
  • Low in lactose

Transitional Milk

From 3-4 days until two weeks

Thinner than colostrum

Moderate
  • Decreased immunoglobulins and proteins.
  • Increased fat and sugar.

Mature Milk

Follows transitional milk

Thinner and watery

Variable
  • Consistent in nutrient composition
  • Balanced in nutrients essential for growth
  • Higher lactose content.

questions.text: A 31-year-old lady with diabetes mellitus delivers a term neonate. Which of the following problems may be associated with the baby born to this lady?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Hypoglycemia

  • A neonate born to a diabetic mother develops hypoglycemia due to hyperinsulinemia in the neonate as a result of maternal hyperglycemia.

Infant of a diabetic mother:

  • Diabetes is one of the most common endocrine disorders affecting women during pregnancy.
  • Infants of diabetic mothers (IDM) have a higher incidence of congenital malformations, estimated to be between 2.5 and 12%, with an excess of cardiac problems.
  • Pathogenesis:
  • Problems in IDM:

Macrosomia/Large for Date Baby
  • Increased risk of birth trauma if forceps are used in obstructed labour.
  • Increased chances of perinatal asphyxia in prolonged labour.

Metabolic
  • Hypoglycemia (vs Option A)
  • Hypocalcemia (vs Option C)
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Polycythemia
  • Neonatal jaundice

CVS
  • The most common congenital abnormality in infants of diabetic mothers (IDM) is congenital heart disease (CHD).
  • The most common congenital heart disease in IDM is ventricular septal defect (VSD). (vs Option B)
  • The most specific congenital heart disease in IDM is the transposition of the great arteries (TGA).

Respiratory System
  • Respiratory distress syndrome or hyaline membrane disease due to delayed maturation of surfactant.

CNS
  • The most common congenital neurologic abnormality in IDM: Neural tube defects.
  • Most specific neurologic abnormality in IDM: Sacral agenesis or caudal regression syndrome.

Renal
  • Renal vein thrombosis
  • Renal agenesis
  • Duplication of ureter
  • Hydroureteronephrosis

GI
  • Duodenal atresia
  • Lazy/small left colon syndrome

Long Term Problems
  • Blindness
  • Obesity
  • Nonketotic hypoglycemia
  • Deafness

questions.text: In a child presenting with febrile seizures, which is the first-line drug used to control the seizures?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Midazolam

  • The first-line drug used to control febrile seizures is midazolam.

Febrile Seizures:

  • Definition: Seizures occurring in children (6 months to 5 years) with fever (>38°C), without underlying neurological issues or prior unprovoked seizures.
  • Causes: Can be triggered by upper respiratory infections, gastroenteritis, viral exanthem, bacterial infections, malaria, or immunization.
  • This must be distinguished from seizures caused by intracranial infection or those triggered by fever in children with epilepsy.

Types of Febrile Seizures:

  • Simple Febrile Seizure:
    • Generalized seizure lasting <15 minutes.
    • Occurs once within 24 hours during a fever in a neurologically normal child.
  • Complex Febrile Seizure:
    • Accounts for 15-20% of cases.
    • Characterized by focal signs, seizure duration >15 minutes, or multiple seizures during the same febrile illness.
  • Febrile Status Epilepticus:
    • Seizure lasts >30 minutes.
    • Prolonged seizure with significant risk.

Risk Factors for Recurrence:

  • Age <18 months
  • Family history of febrile seizures
  • Multiple seizures in the first episode
  • Seizure at a low temperature (<40°C)

Management of Febrile Seizures:

  • Acute Management at Home:
    • Use nasal midazolam or rectal diazepam to stop the seizure.
  • Hospital Management (Status Epilepticus):
    • Follow standard protocols for status epilepticus.
    • Maintain airway, breathing and circulation.
    • IV Lorazepam (0.1 mg/kg) or midazolam (0.1 mg/kg) is administered
    • If seizures persist, IV phenytoin (Option B) or Fosphenytoin is given
    • Later drugs like IV sodium valproate (Option A), levetiracetam, phenobarbitone (Option D), and midazolam infusions are used for persistent seizures.
    • In non-responsive cases, IV ketamine and oral topiramate are considered.
  • Lumbar Puncture:
    • Indicated in cases where meningitis is suspected (especially in younger children or those who have already received antibiotics or unvaccinated children).

Prophylaxis for Recurrence:

  • Indications for Prophylaxis:
    • Children with risk factors for recurrence
    • Frequent recurrences (2 in 6 months or 4 in 1 year).
  • Medications:
    • Oral benzodiazepines (e.g., diazepam 0.6-0.8 mg/kg/day or clobazam 0.8-1 mg/kg/day).
    • Start at the first sign of fever and continue for the first 48 hours to reduce recurrence by 80%.

questions.text: A 3-day-old male neonate who has not yet passed meconium developed abdominal distension. There is no history of fever. On rectal examination, forceful expulsion of stool was observed. A barium enema is performed; the findings are shown in the image below. Which of the following is the gold standard for the diagnosis of the above condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Rectal biopsy

  • The clinical scenario and image showing narrow aganglionic segment, transition zone, and proximal dilation here suggests Hirschsprung disease, and rectal suction biopsy is the gold-standard investigation for diagnosing it.

Hirschsprung Disease

  • It is the most common congenital motility disorder and is characterised by the absence of ganglionic cells in the distal intestine.

Pathophysiology:

  • The absence of ganglionic cells (aganglionosis) in the distal segment of the intestine leads to tonic contraction and functional obstruction of the affected bowel segment.

Clinical Presentation:

  • Neonates: Delayed passage of meconium, constipation, obstruction
  • Later presentation: Chronic constipation, failure to thrive, enterocolitis

Classification:

  • Short Segment (75%): Limited to the segment distal to the splenic flexure.
  • Long Segment (20%): Extends proximal to the splenic flexure.
  • Total Colonic Aganglionosis (5%): The entire colon is affected.

Diagnosis:

  • X-ray: Reveals bowel distension and air-fluid levels.
  • Barium enema: Narrow aganglionic segment, transition zone, proximal dilation
  • Anorectal manometry: Absence of rectoanal inhibitory reflex
  • Rectal suction biopsy: The Gold Standard Test for confirming Hirschsprung disease.
    • Procedure: A biopsy must be taken 2 cm above the dentate line and must include adequate submucosa.
    • Staining:
      • Acetylcholinesterase: Identifies hypertrophied nerve bundles and the absence of ganglion cells.
      • Calretinin: Used as an alternative when acetylcholinesterase staining is inadequate.

Management:

  • Primarily Surgical: Resection of the aganglionic bowel and pull-through of normal bowel.
  • Medical Management: Stabilization and treatment of enterocolitis prior to surgery.
  • Surgical Approach: Trend toward less invasive techniques, including laparoscopic and single-stage procedures.

Ultrasonography (Option A) and MRI abdomen (Option B) are not the gold standard methods for diagnosis of Hirschsprung disease.
Anorectal manometry (Option D): Evaluates rectoanal inhibitory reflex (RAIR) with high sensitivity and specificity (>90%), but not considered the definitive test for young infants and hence not the gold standard.

questions.text: A child is brought to the paediatrician with short stature. On evaluation, growth hormone levels are found to be high and insulin-like growth factor (IGF-1) levels are low. Which among the following could be the abnormality here?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - GH receptor anomaly

The raised levels of growth hormone and low levels of IGF-1 suggest growth hormone insensitivity which is due to GH receptor anomaly.

  • GH stimulates the liver to produce insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1), which in turn promotes the growth of bones and tissues.
  • If there is a GH-receptor anomaly in the liver, leads to GH insensitivity.
  • Hene, IGF-1 is not sufficiently produced lowering its concentration in the body.

Growth Hormone Receptor anomalies:

  • Laron syndrome: Mutation of the GH receptor leading to growth hormone insensitivity.
  • The GH receptor has an extracellular, transmembrane, and intracellular domain.
  • Mutation of the extracellular domain
    • Affects the binding of the hormone
    • GH-binding protein activity is low
  • Mutation of the transmembrane domain:
    • Affects the anchoring of the receptor to the plasma membrane
    • Normal or high GH-binding protein
  • Mutation of the intracellular domain:
    • Interferes with JAK/STAT signalling

GH deficiency (Option A): If the child had GH deficiency, both GH and IGF-1 levels would typically be low.

GHRH deficiency (Option B): Growth hormone-releasing hormone (GHRH) deficiency would typically lead to low GH secretion because GHRH stimulates the release of GH.

IGF-1 deficiency (Option D): Low IGF-1 levels can cause short stature, but the presence of high GH levels suggests that the issue lies not in the production of IGF-1 but in the action of GH itself.

questions.text: A 5-year-old male with a known history of asthma developed sudden onset breathlessness and wheezing. He was rushed to the emergency, where the preliminary assessment was done. The pulse is 140/min, respiratory rate 28/min, and the FEV1 is 40% of the predicted value. Which of the following is the best next step in treatment in this case?

choices.text: A high concentration of oxygen should be given by a face mask + Salbutamol nebulization
High doses of SABA to be given by a nebulizer only
Sedatives should be added to alleviate anxiety
Nebulized anticholinergics to be added immediately as the mainstay of treatment

questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - A high concentration of oxygen should be given by a face mask + Salbutamol nebulization

  • The FEV1 of 40%, tachypnea and tachycardia suggest that the acute exacerbation of asthma here is of the severe type that should be managed by providing oxygen therapy and salbutamol nebulization.

Life-Threatening Asthma Management

Overview
  • Most severe asthma exacerbations require immediate attention.
  • Indicators: Cyanosis, silent chest, poor respiratory effort, exhaustion, altered mental state, PEF <30%, oxygen saturation <90%.

Immediate Management
  • Oxygen Therapy: Administer for hypoxemia.
  • Systemic Bronchodilators: Terbutaline or adrenaline subcutaneously; inhaled bronchodilators (salbutamol, ipratropium).
  • Systemic Corticosteroids: IV hydrocortisone (5 mg/kg).
  • ICU Transfer: For monitoring and advanced care.

ICU Management
  • Continuous Monitoring: Vital signs, oxygen saturation, PEF.
  • If Improvement Noted:
    • Continue inhaled bronchodilators (salbutamol/terbutaline) every 20-30 minutes.
    • Maintain hydrocortisone at 2-3 mg/kg every 6-8 hours until the patient can take oral medication.
  • If No Improvement or Deterioration:
    • Consider slow intravenous infusion of magnesium sulfate (50 mg/kg).
    • Alternatively, administer a loading dose of theophylline.
  • If these measures fail, prepare for mechanical ventilation.
  • Address Underlying Causes: Check for acidosis, pneumothorax, electrolyte imbalance, and infection.

Options B, C, and D are insufficient methods for the treatment of severe acute exacerbation of asthma and are hence incorrect.

questions.text: A 10-month-old child undergoes treatment for diarrhoea with hypokalemia but the child does not respond to the treatment appropriately and on examination muscular weakness is noted, what is the most likely cause of treatment failure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Hypomagnesemia

  • In a child with diarrhoea with hypokalemia, presenting with muscular weakness and a failure to respond to treatment is suggestive of hypomagnesemia.

Hypomagnesemia:

Aetiology:

  • Gastrointestinal losses (diarrhoea, steatorrhea, vomiting, IBD, celiac disease, etc)
  • Potassium-lowering agents (ex: patiromer)
  • Renal losses:
    • Genetic diseases causing renal magnesium loss (Gitelman syndrome, Barter syndrome, familial hypomagnesemia with hypercalciuria and nephrocalcinosis, etc)
    • Drugs (amphotericin, cisplatin, diuretics, mannitol, glucose, etc)
  • Other metabolic disorders
    • Hypokalemia
    • Hypercalcemia
    • Diabetes
    • Chronic kidney disease
  • Other causes:
    • Poor intake
    • Hungry bone syndrome
    • Pancreatitis
    • Insulin
    • Intrauterine growth restriction
    • Infants of diabetic mothers

Clinical features:

  • Secondary hypocalcemia
  • Associated hypocalcemia or severe hypomagnesemia causes:
    • Tetany
    • Chvostek sign
    • Trousseau sign
    • Seizures
  • Persistent hypocalcemia due to hypomagnesemia causes rickets in rare cases
  • Hypokalemia
  • Ecg:
    • Flat T waves
    • Lengthening of ST segment
    • Arrhythmias

Treatment:

Severe hypomagnesemia

  • Parenteral magnesium
  • Dose: 25-50 mg/kg
  • Slow IV infusion (IM in neonates)

Long term therapy
  • Oral administration
  • Magnesium gluconate
  • Magnesium oxide
  • Magnesium sulfate
  • IM injections (minimize diarrhoea)
  • Nighttime nasogastric infusion (minimise diarrhoea)

Options B, C, and D are incorrect as these are not associated with hypokalemia in diarrhoea.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient presents with anaemia. Both his father and paternal aunt experienced similar illnesses and were effectively treated with splenectomy. The patient's peripheral blood smear resembles the one depicted in the accompanying illustration, showing spherocytes. What other abnormalities can be anticipated?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Howell-Jolly bodies

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation, along with microscopic findings, indicates hereditary spherocytosis.
  • Howell-Jolly bodies, remnants of nuclear material normally removed by the spleen, persist in red blood cells in splenectomised patients and can be seen on a peripheral blood smear.

Hereditary spherocytosis (HS) is an inherited disorder caused by intrinsic defects in the red cell membrane skeleton that render red cells spheroid, less deformable, and vulnerable to splenic sequestration and destruction.

It has an autosomal dominant inheritance(75%) characterised by ankyrin mutation and an autosomal recessive inheritance characterised by spectrin mutation.

Pathophysiology of hereditary spherocytosis:

 

  • The most specific morphologic finding is spherocytosis: Dark-staining (hyperchromic) spherocytes lacking the central zone of pallor.
  • Other features include reticulocytosis. The characteristic clinical features are anaemia, splenomegaly, jaundice, and an increased risk of gallstones.
  • Severity ranges from asymptomatic to severe hemolytic anaemia requiring transfusions.
  • Early complications include neonatal jaundice and hemolytic crises.
  • Late complications include gallstones and rarely iron overload.

 

Decreased osmotic fragility (Option A): In hereditary spherocytosis, osmotic fragility increases, not decreases. Red blood cells are more prone to bursting in hypotonic solutions.

Decreased reticulocytes (Option B): Reticulocyte count is typically increased in hereditary spherocytosis, especially in cases of hemolysis, as the bone marrow compensates by producing more immature red blood cells.

Heinz bodies (Option C) are formed due to oxidative damage to haemoglobin and are typically seen in G6PD deficiency or other conditions involving hemoglobinopathy.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a 10-year-old boy with Down syndrome who presents with a mediastinal mass (SVC-like syndrome), based on the provided bone marrow histology shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) ALL (Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia)

Explanation:

  • Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL) is the most common leukemia and cancer in children, often seen in patients with Down syndrome.
  • It is a clonal malignancy where lymphoblasts, early lymphoid precursors, proliferate abnormally, replacing normal hematopoietic cells in the bone marrow.
  • Bone marrow in ALL shows lymphoblasts with condensed nuclear chromatin, small nucleoli, and scant agranular cytoplasm, which are characteristic of lymphoblastic leukemia.
  • Precursor B-cell ALL shows large purple malignant lymphoblasts on bone marrow aspirate smears.
  • Normal lymphoblasts mature into B-cells or T-cells that fight infections, but in ALL, they fail to mature properly.
  • T-cell ALL may present as a mediastinal mass, potentially causing superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome.
  • Both peripheral blood and bone marrow in ALL show increased lymphoblasts.
  • ALL has a poorer prognosis in adults compared to children.

Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL)

  • Lymphoblasts in bone marrow >=20%
  • Cytoplasmic vacuolations
  • They contain fat (Oil Red O Positive)
  • Hand mirror-shaped cells

 

Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML)

  • Blasts ≥ 20%
  • Myeloblasts with AuerRods

 

Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL):

  • Smudge cells (or parachute/basket cell): Due to the fragility of lymphocytes during slide preparation
  • Convent Girl Appearance: Lot of homogenous, small, mature-like, round lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm

Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML)

  • Leukocytosis
  • Cell Types: Neutrophils( multilobed nucleus), metamyelocytes (indented nucleus), myelocytes (D-shaped nucleus), and eosinophils (orange cells)
  • College girl/garden party appearance: Due to the variety of cell appearances
  • Shift to the Left: Presence of immature cell types, mainly immature neutrophils, in the blood.

 

 

 

AML (Acute Myeloid Leukemia) (Option A) is a blood and bone marrow cancer primarily affecting adults caused by the uncontrolled proliferation of myeloblasts (immature white blood cells).
