It is characterised by an abundance of abnormal cells that fail to mature into healthy blood cells, leading to symptoms like infections, anaemia, and easy bleeding.

Aplastic Anemia (Option B) is a serious condition where the bone marrow fails to produce enough blood cells, leading to low blood counts and symptoms like easy bruising, heavy menstrual bleeding, shortness of breath, fatigue, and frequent infections. It can be inherited or acquired, with acquired cases often linked to immune system dysfunction.

Juvenile Myelomonocytic Leukemia (JMML) (Option D) is a rare blood cancer in young children, characterised by abnormal development of monocytes and myelocytes (types of white blood cells). Treatment often involves chemotherapy followed by a bone marrow transplant. Unlike ALL, JMML does not typically present with lymphoblasts.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with a lump in the upper outer part of her breast. Histopathological analysis of the mass reveals a signet ring appearance. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Colloid carcinoma

Explanation:

  • Colloid carcinoma, or mucinous carcinoma, is characterised by extracellular mucin and signet ring cells, where mucin pushes the nucleus to one side, creating a ring-like appearance. This carcinoma typically occurs in older women and presents as a soft, mobile mass.

Mucinous or Colloid Carcinoma:

  • A subtype of infiltrating ductal carcinoma.
  • Location: Upper outer quadrant (most common).
  • Clinical findings:
    • Soft to firm lump due to mucilage.
    • It may be mistaken for a benign tumour.
  • Histopathology:
    • Gross: Soft, rubbery texture with pale gelatinous/jelly consistency.
    • Microscopy: Tumour cells arranged in clusters or islands with pools of mucin extracellularly and may be intracellularly (called signet ring cell).
    • FNAC: Chicken wire blood vessels.
  • Excellent prognosis.

Source: https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Histopathology_of_mucinous_invasive_ductal_carcinoma_of_the_breast.jpg

  • Gross pathology (upper left) of biopsies of mucinous carcinoma shows gelatinous areas (which are transparent compared to normal yellow fatty tissue).
  • Histopathology shows clusters or nests of tumour cells floating in pools of extracellular mucin.

 

Papillary carcinoma (Option B) of the breast accounts for about 0.5% of all breast cancers, primarily affecting postmenopausal women aged 60 to 80. It generally has a favorable prognosis. Clinically, it may be asymptomatic or present with bloody nipple discharge or a palpable mass. On mammography, it appears as a high-density mass with circumscribed margins, sometimes accompanied by satellite nodules, microcalcifications, or a dilated ductal pattern.

Medullary carcinoma (Option C) of the breast is typically well-circumscribed, moderately firm, and has a fleshy grey-tan cut surface, often appearing lobular or nodular with areas of haemorrhage, necrosis, or cystic degeneration. Tumours are usually smaller than 3 cm, with a median size of 2 to 3 cm. Patients commonly present with a palpable mass in the upper outer quadrant, which is well-defined clinically and on imaging. Axillary lymphadenopathy may also be present, indicating potential metastatic involvement.

Phyllodes tumour (Option D) is a rare fibroepithelial neoplasm with a spectrum from benign to malignant, classified by the WHO based on nuclear atypia, stromal cellularity, mitotic activity, tumour margins, and stromal overgrowth. These tumours typically present as nodular masses with clear boundaries, although some may be ill-defined due to surrounding tissue invasion. The tumour is lobulated, solid, and firm, with a grey or grey-yellow colour, often containing narrow gaps or cavities filled with a clear, bloody, or jelly-like fluid.

questions.text: A patient presents with abdominal pain and distension. An x-ray was taken which showed dilated bowel loops as given in the image below. Identify the segment involved.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Jejunum

Explanation:

  • The x-ray shows dilated bowel loops with valvulae conniventes (plicae circulares), which are seen throughout the lumen, indicating jejunal obstruction. These folds are closely spaced and extend across the entire diameter of the bowel, a hallmark feature of the jejunum on imaging.

 

Radiological Features of Bowel Obstruction

Segment

Radiological Features

Jejunum

Valvulae conniventes (plicae circulares) seen throughout the bowel, giving a stacked coin or coiled spring appearance.

Ileum

Less prominent valvulae conniventes, fewer folds, and a featureless appearance compared to the jejunum.

Duodenum

Dilated duodenum in proximal obstruction, "double bubble" sign in duodenal atresia.

Transverse Colon

Haustral markings (do not completely cross the lumen), wider spacing than jejunal folds.

 

Differentiating Features Between Small Bowel and Large Bowel Obstruction:

Feature

Small Bowel

Large Bowel

Number of loops

Many loops visible

Few loops visible

Position of loops

Central abdomen

Peripheral (framing the small bowel)

Wall/Mucosal pattern

Valvulae conniventes (complete circular folds)

Haustra (incomplete bands)

Diameter

>3 cm

>6 cm (Caecum >9 cm)

Gas Pattern

Multiple air-fluid levels, "string of beads"

Distended colon, air-fluid levels

 

 

Ileum (Option B): Incorrect because ileal loops have fewer mucosal folds (valvulae conniventes are less prominent), and the dilatation does not show the characteristic stacked-coin appearance of the jejunum.

Duodenum (Option C): Incorrect because duodenal obstruction typically shows a "double bubble" sign in congenital cases or proximal dilatation with stomach involvement.

Transverse Colon (Option D): Incorrect because haustral markings do not completely cross the lumen and are more widely spaced, unlike valvulae conniventes of the jejunum.

questions.text: During wound healing, the cells that appear first, due to chemotaxis, at the site of the wound are:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Neutrophils

Explanation:

  • Neutrophils are the first cells to migrate to the site of injury due to chemotaxis during the inflammatory response.
  • They are crucial in the initial stages of wound healing, where they help to clear debris, bacteria, and other pathogens.

Events in wound healing

Day 0

Platelets and Fibrin form blood clots.

Day 1

Blood clot remains and recruitment of neutrophils (acute inflammation).

Day 2

Blood clots remain; neutrophils accumulate, followed by the formation of a thin epithelial layer.

Day 3

Chronic inflammation sets in, and macrophages replace neutrophils.

Granulation tissue begins (blood vessel formation starts)

Day 5
  • Maximum granulation tissue (Maximum neovascularisation)
  • Collagen bridging starts

Day 21(3rd Week)

Maximum collagen deposition (Type I collagen.)

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl presents with a severe headache, photophobia, and a high fever of 101°F. On examination, papilledema and nuchal rigidity were present. Kernig’s and Brudzinski's signs were positive. CSF examination shows reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased leukocytes with a predominance of neutrophils. Gram staining of the CSF is shown below. The causative organism is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Neisseria meningitidis

Explanation:

The clinical scenario of severe headache, photophobia, high fever along with papilledema, nuchal rigidity, kernig’s sign and brudzinski sign being positive points towards bacterial meningitis. Gram staining of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) showing gram-negative diplococci suggests the diagnosis of Neisseria meningitidis.

Lab Investigations of N. Meningitidis:

Investigation

Findings

Cerebrospinal Fluid (CSF) Analysis
  • Appearance

Cloudy or purulent
  • White Blood Cell Count (WBC)

Elevated (pleocytosis), typically >1,000 cells/µL, with predominance of neutrophils
  • Protein

Elevated
  • Glucose

Decreased
  • Gram Stain

Presence of gram-negative diplococci
  • Culture

Growth of Neisseria meningitidis on chocolate agar or Thayer-Martin agar
  • Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR)

Detection of Neisseria meningitidis DNA
  • Latex Agglutination Test

Positive for Neisseria meningitidis antigens

Blood Tests
  • Culture

Growth of Neisseria meningitidis
  • White Blood Cell Count

Elevated leukocytosis with left shift

CSF findings in Meningitis:

Parameter

Bacterial Meningitis

Viral (Aseptic) Meningitis

Fungal Meningitis

Tuberculous Meningitis

Appearance

Cloudy or purulent

Clear or slightly cloudy

Clear or slightly cloudy

Clear or slightly cloudy, Cob web coagulum

White Blood Cell Count
  • Elevated (usually >1,000 cells/µL)
  • Predominantly neutrophils (≥80%)
  • Elevated (usually 50-1,000 cells/µL)
  • Predominantly lymphocytes
  • Elevated (usually 20-500 cells/µL)
  • Predominantly lymphocytes
  • Elevated (usually 50-500 cells/µL)
  • Predominantly lymphocytes

Protein

Elevated (100-500 mg/dL)

Mildly elevated or normal (50-100 mg/dL)

Elevated (100-500 mg/dL)

Elevated (100-500 mg/dL)

Glucose

Decreased (<40 mg/dL or <2.2 mmol/L)

Normal or slightly decreased

Decreased

Decreased

CSF/Blood Glucose Ratio

<0.4

>0.6

<0.4

<0.4

Opening Pressure

Elevated

Normal or slightly elevated

Elevated

Elevated

Gram Stain

Positive for bacteria (gram-negative diplococci, etc.)

Negative

Negative

Negative

Haemophilus Influenzae (Option A) It is a gram-negative coccobacilli arranged in clusters.

Streptococcus Pneumoniae (Option C) is a gram-positive bacterium that can cause bacterial meningitis, but it appears as gram-positive diplococci, giving a lanceolate shape.

Listeria Monocytogens (Option D) is known to cause meningitis in extremes of age i.e. meningitis in infants and elderly. It is a gram-positive rod-shaped bacteria and exhibits differential motility.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of berry aneurysm?

choices.text: Endothelial injury of the vessel due to hypertension
Muscle intimal elastic lamina layer defect

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Muscle intimal elastic lamina layer defect

Explanation:

  • Berry aneurysms, also known as saccular aneurysms or intracranial aneurysms, most commonly occur due to a defect in the muscle intimal elastic lamina layer of the blood vessel wall.
  • This defect weakens the vessel wall, leading to the formation of a small outpouching or sac-like dilation.
  • These aneurysms are frequently found in the arteries at the base of the brain, particularly at the branching points of the major cerebral arteries.

 

Endothelial injury of vessels due to hypertension (Option A): While hypertension can contribute to the development and progression of aneurysms, it is not the most common cause of berry aneurysms.

Muscle and adventitial layer defect (Option C) and Adventitia defect (Option D): Berry aneurysms primarily involve the defect in the muscle intimal elastic lamina layer.

questions.text:
Obliteration of the right cardiac border on chest X-ray indicated pathology involving which of the following structures?

[
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Right Middle Lobe

Explanation:

On a chest X-ray, the right cardiac border is formed by the right atrium. The silhouette sign helps localize pathology:

  • Obliteration of the right cardiac border occurs when a lesion in the right middle lobe is present, as the lobe lies adjacent to the right atrium.
  • The loss of normal heart-lung interface suggests consolidation, atelectasis, or mass in the right middle lobe.

Lobar Localization:

  • Lateral radiograph: Right and left upper lobe bronchi can be seen as two circular radiolucent areas with the right above the left.
  • PA view of the chest: Can locate any structure in the superoinferior dimension as well as the mediolateral dimension.
  • Silhouette sign: Locate any structure in the posteroanterior dimension.

 

  • Left Lung: Only has an oblique fissure, separating the left upper (LUL) and lower (LLL) lobes.
  • Right Lung: Oblique and horizontal fissures separate the right lung's 3 lobes.
    • Oblique fissure divides the RML and RLL.
    • Horizontal fissure divides the RUL and RML.

  

Silhouette Sign:

  • Absence of the depiction of an anatomic soft-tissue border.
  • Produced by an intrathoracic abnormality that touches the borders of the heart or aorta and obliterates those borders on the frontal chest radiograph.
  • The sign actually refers to the absence of a silhouette.
  • Silhouette sign helps localize airspace opacities, atelectasis, or masses in the lung.

 

Localization Using the Silhouette Sign

Obliterated Cardiac Border

Likely Affected Lobe

Right cardiac border (Right atrium)

Right Middle Lobe

Right hemidiaphragm

Right Lower Lobe

Left cardiac border (Left ventricle)

Lingula (Left Upper Lobe)

Left hemidiaphragm

Left Lower Lobe

Right Lower Lobe (Option A): Incorrect because pathology here would obscure the right hemidiaphragm, not the right cardiac border.

Right Atrium (Option B): Incorrect because the right atrium itself is not a lung structure; it is obscured by pathology in the adjacent right middle lobe.

Right Ventricle (Option D): Incorrect because the right ventricle is positioned more anteriorly and is not adjacent to the lung fields visualized on a standard PA chest X-ray.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient who has been working in a factory for the past 20 years presents with breathlessness. HRCT of the chest shows pleural thickening and fibrosis. What is the person suffering from?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Asbestosis

Explanation:

  • The patient's history of working in a factory for a prolonged period, along with the HRCT chest findings of pleural thickening and fibrosis, points towards the diagnosis of Asbestosis, a lung disease caused by the inhalation of asbestos fibres commonly encountered in occupational settings.
  • Prolonged exposure to asbestos can lead to the deposition of fibres in the lungs, triggering an inflammatory response that results in fibrosis and scarring of lung tissue, including the pleura.

Occupational Lung Disease

Associated Agents

Features

Diagnostic Tools

Preventive Measures

Asbestosis

(Option A)

Asbestos fibers

Characterised by progressive pulmonary fibrosis. Symptoms include dyspnea, non-productive cough, and chest pain. Often associated with pleural plaques and increased risk of mesothelioma and lung cancer.

HRCT, pulmonary function tests, occupational history

Use of protective gear, proper ventilation, asbestos abatement programs

Silicosis

(Option C ruled out)

Crystalline silica (quartz dust)

Presents with nodular pulmonary fibrosis, primarily in the upper lobes. Increased risk of TB and other respiratory infections. Chronic exposure can lead to progressive massive fibrosis.

Chest X-ray, HRCT, occupational history

Dust control measures, respirators, regular health check-ups

Coal Worker's Pneumoconiosis (CWP)

(Option B ruled out)

Coal dust

Also known as "black lung disease." Features similar to silicosis but usually affect the upper lungs with coal dust deposition and fibrosis, without the silicotic nodules.

Chest X-ray, HRCT, pulmonary function tests

Dust control, respiratory protective equipment, regular monitoring

Byssinosis

Cotton, flax, hemp dust

"Monday fever" describes worsening symptoms at the beginning of the workweek. Symptoms include chest tightness and wheezing, predominantly in textile workers.

Clinical evaluation, occupational history

Improved ventilation, dust suppression, health education

Berylliosis

(Option D ruled out)

Beryllium and its compounds

Acute or chronic lung disease caused by beryllium. Chronic form mimics sarcoidosis with systemic symptoms and granulomatous inflammation.

Lung biopsy, beryllium lymphocyte proliferation test (BeLPT), imaging

Limiting exposure, personal protective equipment, medical surveillance

Farmer's Lung

Moldy hay, crops, and compost dust

A type of hypersensitivity pneumonitis caused by inhaling organic dust, presenting with malaise, cough, and breathlessness that may become chronic.

HRCT, pulmonary function tests, specific IgG testing for antigens

Respiratory protective equipment, proper storage of agricultural products

questions.text: A 19-year-old male, chronic smoker, presented with fever, a painful lump over his left cheek just below the ear, and difficulty in swallowing or talking. The patient also complained of mild testicular pain. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Mumps

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis for this 19-year-old male with fever, a painful lump below the left ear, difficulty swallowing or talking, and mild testicular pain is parotitis and orchitis most probably due to due to mumps.

Mumps

Causative Organism

Mumps virus (Paramyxoviridae family)

Age Group

5-9 years mostly

Transmission

Respiratory droplets

Period of communicability

7 days before to 7 days after the onset of symptoms

Symptoms

High-grade fever, Headache, Parotitis (Often Bilateral), orchitis

Complications
  • Most Common complication in child : Aseptic Meningitis
  • Most Common complication in Adult : Orchitis ( does not lead to infertility )
  • Oophoritis, pancreatitis, myocarditis, arthritis, thyroiditis & conjunctivitis.
  • Mumps during early pregnancy increases fetal wastage but not malformations.

Neurological Complications
  • Meningitis (Most Common) - 10-30% of cases.
  • Encephalitis, transverse myelitis, and facial palsy are less common.

Treatment
  • Self-limiting
  • Management focuses on symptom relief - pain reduction, hydration, and antipyretics.

questions.text: Which of the following MRI imaging techniques is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) T2 MRI

Explanation:

  • A T2-weighted MRI sequence highlights fluid as hyperintense (bright) and soft tissues differently compared to T1-weighted MRI. It is particularly useful in detecting edema, inflammation, and CSF-filled structures.

Key Features of T2-Weighted MRI:

  • CSF and fluids appear bright (white)
  • Edema and inflammation are hyperintense
  • Gray matter appears slightly brighter than white matter
  • Fat appears relatively darker compared to T1

MRI Sequences & Their Characteristics

MRI Sequence

CSF Appearance

Fat Appearance

Use Cases

T1-weighted

Dark

Bright

Anatomy, fat-containing lesions

T2-weighted

Bright

Darker

Edema, inflammation, tumors

FLAIR

Dark

Dark

White matter lesions, periventricular pathology

STIR

Dark

Dark

Suppresses fat signal, good for musculoskeletal imaging

T1 MRI (Option A): Incorrect because CSF appears dark in T1, while it is bright in the given T2 image.

STIR (Option C): Incorrect because STIR suppresses fat signal but does not necessarily highlight fluids as in T2-weighted imaging.

FLAIR (Option D): Incorrect because FLAIR suppresses CSF signal, making it dark, while in T2 it remains bright.

questions.text: McNaughten's rule is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - IPC 84

McNaughten Rule:

  • Sec. 84 IPC deals with the criminal responsibility of insane persons.
    • It states that: “Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who, at the time of doing it, because of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or what he is doing is either wrong or contrary to the law”.
  • BNS Section 22: Nothing is an offence done by a person who, at the time of doing it, because of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to law.
  • The key principle states that every person is presumed sane until proven otherwise.
  • To establish a defence of insanity, it must be proven that the accused, at the time of the act, had a mental disease that prevented them from understanding the nature of the act or recognising it as wrong.
  • Legal Test of Insanity (Right or Wrong Test): A person is not criminally responsible if they did not know the nature of their act or that it was wrong at the time of the crime. Requirements include:
    • Evidence of a mental disease.
    • The mental disease must be present at the time of the crime.
    • The condition must be severe enough to prevent understanding that the act is wrong or illegal.

IPC 82 (Option A): Deals with children under 7 years of age who are presumed incapable of committing a crime due to their age, and thus cannot be held criminally responsible.

IPC 83 (Option B): Concerns children between 7 and 12 years old. They can be criminally liable, but only if they possess the maturity to understand the nature of their act. It allows a defense of insanity if the child is incapable of understanding the nature of the act.

IPC 85 (Option D): Addresses acts done by persons of unsound mind under the influence of intoxication. If intoxication is involuntary, the person can use it as a defense to not be held criminally responsible.

questions.text: The magnetic field in MRI machines is measured in which of the following units?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Tesla

Explanation:

  • The magnetic field strength in MRI machines is measured in Tesla (T). Most clinical MRI scanners operate at 1.5T or 3T, while higher-field research scanners can go up to 7T or more. The Tesla unit measures the intensity of the magnetic field, which influences image resolution and signal-to-noise ratio.

Radiological Units and Their Applications

Unit

Symbol

Measurement Type

Application

Tesla

T

Magnetic field strength

Used in MRI to measure magnetic field intensity (e.g., 1.5T, 3T, 7T MRI scanners)

Gauss

G

Magnetic field strength

Older unit for magnetic field strength (1T = 10,000G)

Gray

Gy

Absorbed dose of radiation

Measures energy absorbed per unit mass in radiotherapy

Sievert

Sv

Biological effect of radiation

Used in radiation safety to assess exposure risk

Hounsfield Unit

HU

Tissue density in CT

Used in CT scans to differentiate tissues (e.g., bone = +1000 HU, air = -1000 HU)

Becquerel

Bq

Radioactive decay rate

Used in nuclear medicine to measure radioactivity

Curie

Ci

Radioactivity

Older unit (1 Ci = 3.7 × 10¹⁰ Bq), used in nuclear imaging

Roentgen

R

Ionization in air

Used in older radiation exposure measurements

Millisievert

mSv

Radiation dose

Used for radiation protection, CT scan doses are often measured in mSv

Electron Volt

eV

Energy of X-rays/Gamma rays

Used in radiation physics to measure photon energy

Kiloelectron Volt

keV

X-ray photon energy

Important in X-ray and CT imaging for beam quality

HU (Option B): Incorrect because Hounsfield Unit (HU) is used to measure tissue density in CT scans, not MRI.

KHz (Option C): Incorrect because kilohertz (kHz) measures radiofrequency waves used in MRI but not the magnetic field strength.

Hg (Option D): Incorrect because mercury (Hg) is used in measuring pressure (mmHg), not magnetic fields.

questions.text: All are grounds for divorce except :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Poverty

  • Poverty is not a valid ground for divorce according to the Hindu Marriage Act. Financial difficulties or poverty alone cannot be the reason to end a marriage.

Hindu Marriage Act, 1955 (Sections 11, 12, 13):

1. Grounds for Void and Voidable Marriages:

  • Void Marriage (Null from inception):
    • Bigamy (marriage without dissolution of the earlier one)
    • Prohibited degree of relationship (unless custom permits)
    • Sapinda relationship (blood relationships up to 3rd generation through mother and 5th generation through father)
  • Voidable Marriage (Valid until annulled):
    • Impotence
    • Unsoundness of mind at the time of marriage
    • Consent obtained by force, fraud, or misconception of facts
    • Pregnancy of the wife by another person, and the husband is unaware at the time of marriage

2. Grounds for Divorce:

  • Adultery (voluntary intercourse with someone other than the spouse) (Option A ruled out)
  • Cruelty (danger to life, limb, health, or mental health)
  • Desertion (abandonment without reasonable cause)
  • Apostasy (change of religion)
  • Unsoundness of mind (insanity) (Option D ruled out)
  • Virulent leprosy and sexually transmitted diseases (including AIDS) (Option B ruled out)
  • Renouncing the world
  • Husband convicted of rape, sodomy, or bestiality

questions.text: What is the most radiosensitive tissue in our body?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Bone marrow

Explanation:

  • Bone marrow is the most radiosensitive tissue in the human body because it contains rapidly dividing hematopoietic stem cells, which are highly vulnerable to ionizing radiation. Radiation exposure can lead to pancytopenia, increasing the risk of infections, anemia, and bleeding.

Radiosensitivity of Different Tissues

Tissue

Radiosensitivity

Reason

Bone marrow

Highly radiosensitive

Contains rapidly dividing stem cells for blood cell production

Lymphoid tissue

Highly radiosensitive

Rapid cell turnover, easily damaged by radiation

Gastrointestinal mucosa

Moderately radiosensitive

Epithelial cells divide rapidly

Skin

Moderate

Basal layer is sensitive, but outer layers provide some protection

Muscle

Radioresistant

Cells do not divide frequently

Nervous tissue

Highly radioresistant

Neurons are non-dividing cells and less affected by radiation

Skin (Option A): Moderately radiosensitive due to the presence of basal cell layers, but not as sensitive as bone marrow.

Muscles (Option B): Incorrect because muscle cells are highly radioresistant as they do not actively divide.

Nervous tissue (Option D): Incorrect because neurons are non-dividing and among the most radioresistant cells in the body.

questions.text: All of the following are paired cartilages except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Thyroid

Explanation:

The thyroid cartilage is an unpaired cartilage of the larynx, forming the Adam’s apple. It is the largest laryngeal cartilage and consists of two laminae fused in the midline. Unlike the other options, which exist as pairs, the thyroid cartilage is singular.

Type

Cartilage

Paired/Unpaired

Function

Unpaired

Thyroid

Unpaired

Forms the laryngeal prominence (Adam’s apple), provides structural support.

Cricoid

Unpaired

Complete ring, supports larynx, attachment site for muscles.

Epiglottis

Unpaired

Leaf-shaped, prevents food from entering the trachea.

Paired

Arytenoid

Paired

Controls vocal cord movement.

Corniculate

Paired

Sits on top of arytenoids, helps with voice modulation.

Cuneiform

Paired

Provides structural support to the laryngeal inlet.

Arytenoid cartilage (Option A): Incorrect because it is paired, playing a key role in vocal cord movement.

Cuneiform cartilage (Option C): Incorrect because it is paired, embedded in the aryepiglottic folds for support.

Corniculate cartilage (Option D): Incorrect because it is paired, sitting atop the arytenoids to assist in voice modulation.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes with complaints of fever and increasing fatigue for the past week. On examination, he is febrile, hypotensive, and tachycardic. The findings of microscopic examination of his peripheral blood smear are given below. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Plasmodium falciparum

Explanation:

The clinical scenario indicates cerebral malaria. Plasmodium falciparum is one of the species of Plasmodium that causes cerebral malaria in humans characterized by high fever, headache, anorexia, nausea, anemia, hypotension, tachycardia, hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenia, confusion, increased muscle tone, seizures, paralysis, and coma. The presence of "headphone-shaped/banana shaped" trophozoites in the blood smear is characteristic of Plasmodium falciparum, which is the causative agent of malaria.

 

Vivax

Falciparum

Malariae

Ovale

RBC size

Enlarged

Normal

Normal

Enlarged with frayed margins

Pigments

Yellowish brown

Dark brown

Schizont

Large (9-10 μm)

Fills the RBC

Contains 12-24 merozoite

Not seen in the periphery

Small (6 μm), almost fills the RBC and contains 8 merozoites

Gametocytes

Spherical (Option A)

Crescentic

Larger than RBC

Spherical (Option C and D)

Ring form

2.5 μm

Occupies ⅓ rd of RBC size

Cytosol opposite to the nucleus is thick

1.5 μm

Occupies ⅙ of RBC size

It may be

  • Multiple forms
  • Accole (attached to RBC membrane)
  • Double dot/headphone shaped with fragment nucleus

Band form

2.5 μm

Occupies ⅓ rd of RBC size

Cytosol opposite to the nucleus is thick

In Plasmodium falciparum, only gametocyte and ring forms are demonstrated in the PBS, as later stages of the erythrocytic cycle occur in deep vessels and not in peripheral blood.

questions.text: Comment on the diagnosis of CT chest shown below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Aortic dissection

Explanation:

  • The given CT shows an intimal tear in the aorta indicating an Aortic dissection.

 

Aortic Dissection

  • It occurs when a defect or a flap occurs in the aorta, resulting in blood tracking into aortic tissues, splitting the medial layer and creating a false lumen.

 

 

Clinical features:

  • Sudden onset of severe, tearing chest, radiating to the interscapular region
  • Renal pain and renal failure
  • Paraplegia
  • Syncope
  • Weakness
  • Hypotension or shock

 

Investigations:

  • If the patient is stable, CT angiography is the standard investigation of choice.
  • In the case of unstable patients (SBP<100 mm of HG, HR>100 bpm), the preferred investigation of choice will be TEE (TransEsophageal Echocardiography)
  • MRI can also be done if CT is unequivocal.
  • Chest x-ray reveals widening of mediastinum along with left-sided pleural effusion.

 

 

Signs of FALSE LUMEN:

  • Cobweb Sign: Irregularities of False lumen
  • Beak Sign: False lumen forms acute angle with True lumen:

 

Pulmonary embolism (Option B):

  • Filling Defect seen in Pulmonary artery
  • IOC for PE: CT Angiography

 

Cardiac Myxoma (Option C):

  • Low annotating hypodense lesion on the posterior most chamber of the heart (Left Atrium)
  • MC primary Benign cardiac tumor in adults.

 

Aortic aneurysm (Option D):

  • Involve either ascending aorta, thoracic aorta & abdominal aorta
  • Represents localized dilation of the aorta; while an aneurysm may predispose to dissection, an intimal tear specifically indicates dissection.
  • M/C cause for abdominal & thoracic aortic aneurysm: Atherosclerosis

questions.text: An intern observed that a patient in the ward was unresponsive, and an ECG which was performed urgently showed a rhythm as depicted below. DC shock was delivered but the arrhythmia persisted and the patient is still unresponsive. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Start CPR

Explanation:

The next best step in the management of an unresponsive patient with the displayed ECG rhythm, despite the delivery of a DC shock, is to start CPR (Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation).

 

The ECG rhythm depicted suggests ventricular fibrillation (VF), which is a life-threatening arrhythmia characterized by rapid, irregular, and disorganized electrical activity of the ventricles.

 

Ventricular fibrillation results in ineffective pumping of the heart, leading to a lack of blood flow to vital organs and tissues. This can result in a sudden loss of consciousness, cessation of pulse, and, if not promptly treated, irreversible brain damage or death within minutes.and ultimately cardiac arrest.

 

Ventricular fibrillation (VF) is a serious and life-threatening abnormal heart rhythm that occurs when the electrical signals controlling the heart's contractions become chaotic. Instead of a coordinated contraction, the ventricles (the lower chambers of the heart) quiver or fibrillate, leading to ineffective pumping and a significant decrease in blood flow.

 

Ventricular Fibrillation

 

 

Ventricular Tachycardia

 

Management of Shockable (VT/ V Fib) Conditions:

Immediate Recognition

Identify Shockable Rhythm: Recognize VF or pulseless VT.

Activate Emergency Response: Call for advanced life support.

↓

Initiate CPR

Start High-Quality CPR: Perform chest compressions at a rate of 100-120/min, with a depth of 5-6 cm. Continue CPR for 2 minutes.

↓

Defibrillation

After 2 minutes of CPR, deliver a Non-Synchronized DC Shock to restore normal rhythm.

If no change, administer a second shock immediately.

↓

Continue CPR

Resume CPR for 2 Minutes

Place an intravenous or intraosseous line for drug administration.

↓

Administer Epinephrine

Epinephrine 1 mg (1:10,000): Given IV/IO after 2 minutes of CPR to enhance coronary perfusion pressure.

↓

Advanced Airway Management

Secure Airway: Perform endotracheal intubation if necessary.

Capnography: Monitor end-tidal CO2 levels.

Ventilation: Provide 1 breath every 6 seconds post-intubation.

↓

Further Defibrillation

Third Shock: If VF or pulseless VT persists, deliver a third non-synchronized shock.

Continue CPR for 2 More Minutes: Follow with additional CPR.

↓

Administer Antiarrhythmic Medication

Amiodarone 300 mg IV: Administer for shock-refractory VT to stabilize heart rhythm.

↓

Identify and Treat Reversible Causes

 

While synchronized cardioversion (Option A) is a potential treatment for certain arrhythmias, such as supraventricular tachycardia or atrial fibrillation, it is not appropriate for ventricular fibrillation.

Ventricular fibrillation requires immediate CPR followed by defibrillation (DC shock) (Option C) as the initial treatment. Since the patient has already received a DC shock without conversion of the rhythm, repeating the shock without CPR in between is unlikely to be effective.

Administering 1 mg of epinephrine (Option D) is a component of advanced cardiac life support and is typically given during CPR after a shock has been delivered. However, starting CPR should take priority over administering epinephrine.

questions.text: Pulsus paradoxus is seen in:

choices.text: Severe Asthma or Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Severe Asthma or Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease

Explanation:

  • Pulsus paradoxus is an ominous sign in a patient with obstructive lung disease, as it is associated with significant negative intrathoracic (pleural) pressures, affecting venous return to the heart and causing a drop in systolic blood pressure during inspiration. During severe asthma attacks or exacerbations of COPD, airway resistance increases significantly during inspiration and significant rise in negative intrathoracic pressure.

Pulsus Paradoxus

Definition:

A fall in systolic blood pressure >10 mmHg during inspiration.

Pathophysiology:

Exaggerated interventricular dependence → Increased right ventricular filling during inspiration shifts the septum leftward, reducing left ventricular output and causing a more pronounced drop in systolic pressure.

Associated Conditions:
  • Pericardial tamponade (classic association)
    • External pressure on the heart limits filling
    • Inspiration compresses the RV, preventing normal inspiratory RV filling
    • Interventricular septum shifts left, restricting LV filling and output → Marked fall in BP
  • Massive pulmonary embolism
  • Hemorrhagic shock
  • Severe obstructive lung disease (e.g., asthma, COPD)
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Effusive Constrictive Pericarditis
  • Restrictive Cardiomyopathy

Measurement:

 
  • Auscultatory method:
    • Identify the systolic pressure during expiration and independent of respiration.
    • The difference between these two is the pulsus paradoxus.
    • If the difference exceeds 15 mmHg, pulsus paradoxus may be palpable at the brachial or femoral artery.
  • Tachycardia, atrial fibrillation, tachypnea will make it difficult to measure.

Respiratory Changes in Cardiac Output, Blood Pressure, and Pulse Rate:

  • Physiological Changes with Respiration:
    • Inspiration:
      • ↓ Intrathoracic pressure → ↑ Venous return to the right heart
      • ↑ Right ventricular (RV) output
      • ↑ Pulmonary vascular capacitance → Blood is sequestered in the lungs, reducing flow to the left heart
      • ↓ Left ventricular (LV) output → ↓ Blood pressure (BP)
    • Expiration:
      • ↓ Venous return to the right heart → ↓ RV output
      • ↑ Venous return to the left heart → ↑ LV output → ↑ BP

questions.text: What is the appropriate IPC section for the act of inducing abortion without the consent of the woman?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - 313

According to The MTP Act:

  • Indian Penal Code (IPC) – Section 312:
    • Voluntary miscarriage (except when performed in good faith to save the woman’s life) is a crime. (Option A ruled out)
    • Punishments: Simple or rigorous imprisonment and/or fine.
  • IPC Sections 313-316:
    • Relates to causing miscarriage without consent or causing maternal death during the procedure. (Option B)
    • Punishments: Up to 10 years of imprisonment, or even life imprisonment.

Section 318 (Option C) relates to the concealment of the birth of a child and the punishment for actions involving hiding or disposing of a dead child. It does not cover the act of inducing abortion without consent.

Section 317 (Option D) pertains to the exposure and abandonment of a child under the age of 12 years, which is unrelated to the act of inducing abortion without consent.

questions.text: A 55 year old male patient presented with complaints of dyspnea with congestive heart failure. The clinician wants to know whether it's HF with preserved EF or reduced EF. Which of the below investigation is used for calculation of ejection fraction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) MUGA

Explanation:

  • Ejection fraction (EF) is a critical parameter for differentiating heart failure with preserved EF (HFpEF) from heart failure with reduced EF (HFrEF).
  • MUGA scan is a non-invasive nuclear imaging test that accurately calculates EF by analyzing the motion of the heart's ventricles using a radioactive tracer and a gamma camera.

 

Purpose

Scan types

For Myocardial Perfusion

  • Assess ischemia
  • Cold spot: decreased uptake in ischemic areas.
  • Thallium scan (Commonly used) (Option B)
  • Tetrofosmin
  • Sestamibi scan (Option D)

For Myocardial Infarction

  • Assess infarct
  • Hot spot in infarct area as pyrophosphate accumulates and is not metabolized.
  • 99m Tc - Pyrophosphate scan.

For Ventricular Function

  • Evaluate ejection fraction
  • MUGA (Multiple Gated Acquisition) scan (AKA nuclear ventriculography)
    • Radiolabeled RBCs are used
  • Most accurate for ventricular function - Cardiac MRI

For Myocardial Viability

 
  • Assess the viability of myocardium
  • PETscan - Best investigation for myocardial viability. (Option C)
    • Perfusion and metabolism mismatch are observed in the PET scan.
    • Perfusion Agents:N-13 ammonia and Rubidium chloride.
    • Metabolism Agent: FDG-PET is used for glucose metabolism.
      • No FDG uptake indicates a normal heart or an infarct.
      • FDG uptake is present: In the Ischemic Myocardium
    • FDG-PET is combined with perfusion imaging for comprehensive assessment.
      • Uptake in PET with low perfusion indicates reversible dysfunction (suggestive of hibernation).
      • Irreversible dysfunction indicates the presence of scar tissue.
    • Note: Hibernating myocardium is ischemic but viable.

 

Myocardial Viability

questions.text: In case of corrosive acid ingestion, stomach is opened along the?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Greater curvature

  • In forensic autopsies, the stomach is usually opened along the greater curvature to minimize disruption of stomach anatomy and allows the pathologist to collect and examine the stomach contents effectively, which is critical in cases of suspected poisoning.

Procedure for Stomach Dissection:

  1. Two ligatures are applied at the cardiac end of the esophagus and two ligatures are below the pyloric end of the stomach.
  2. The stomach is removed by cutting between the double ligatures at both ends.
  3. The stomach is then opened along the greater curvature.
  4. The mucous membrane is examined for the presence of any stains, congestion, hemorrhage, desquamation, ulceration, sloughing, or perforation.
  5. The contents of the stomach are noted with respect to quantity, nature of material/food, state of digestion, color, and smell.

questions.text: Safety pin appearance is seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Burkholderia pseudomallei

Explanation:

Safety pin appearance is due to bipolar staining shown by some organisms, in this the terminal parts of the organism is darkly stained and centre is poorly satined giving safety pin appearance.

Safety pin appearance is shown by the following organisms:

  • Yersinia pestis
  • Vibrio parahaemolyticus
  • Burkholderia mallei
  • Burkholderia pseudomallei (Option B)
  • Haemophilus ducreyi
  • Klebsiella granulomatis

Option A,C and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Inhaling the cloth soaked in drug is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Huffing

  • Huffing involves inhaling the vapors of an inhalant, typically from a cloth or rag soaked in volatile solvents.
  • It is a method where the substance is directly inhaled through the mouth, and a cloth soaked in the drug is commonly used for this method.
  • Inhalants are substances that produce intoxicating vapors when inhaled, often used by young adolescents.
  • They can cause severe health issues, including cardiac arrest, suffocation, and long-term damage to the brain, heart, kidneys, and liver.

Types of Inhalants:

  1. Volatile Solvents: Liquids that vaporize at room temperature, found in household and business products like paint thinners, dry-cleaning fluids, gasoline, glues, and felt-tip markers.
  2. Aerosols: Products that release vapors when sprayed, such as spray paints, deodorant sprays, hair sprays, and cooking oil sprays.
  3. Gases: Gases like nitrous oxide (laughing gas), chloroform, ether, and halothane, used in medical procedures. Also includes gases found in butane lighters, propane tanks, and refrigerants.
  4. Nitrites: Sold in small bottles called “poppers,” these primarily dilate blood vessels and relax muscles, acting differently from other inhalants that affect the central nervous system.

Bagging (Option A): This involves inhaling vapors from a substance stored in a plastic bag. It is a common method of inhaling gases or solvents but does not specifically refer to inhaling a cloth soaked in a drug.

Spraying (Option B): This refers to inhaling vapors directly from an aerosol or spray can, such as spray paints or deodorant sprays. It is a method of inhaling aerosol inhalants, but it does not apply to inhaling from a cloth soaked in a drug.

Sniffing (Option D): This involves inhaling vapors directly from a container or surface, such as sniffing glue or other substances. However, it does not specifically refer to inhaling from a cloth soaked in a drug.

questions.text: Biceps brachii functions as which type of muscle for lifting the forearm ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Primary mover

Explanation:

The biceps brachii is the primary mover (agonist) for forearm flexion at the elbow joint. When lifting the forearm, it contracts to generate movement by pulling the radius upward.

Muscle Roles in Movement

Term

Definition

Example in Forearm Flexion

Primary Mover (Agonist)

Main muscle responsible for movement.

Biceps brachii flexes the elbow.

Antagonist

Muscle that opposes the primary mover.

Triceps brachii extends the elbow, opposing the biceps.

Synergist

Assists the primary mover by adding force or stability.

Brachialis helps the biceps in flexion.

Fixator

Stabilizes the origin of the primary mover.

Rotator cuff muscles stabilize the shoulder joint during flexion.

Synergistic (Option A): Incorrect because the brachialis acts as a synergist, not the biceps brachii.

Fixator (Option B): Incorrect because fixators stabilize joints, like the rotator cuff stabilizing the shoulder.

Antagonist (Option C): Incorrect because the triceps brachii is the antagonist, opposing biceps action.

questions.text: What is the causative organism of bull neck?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Corynebacterium diphtheriae

Explanation:

  • Primarily caused by toxigenic strains of Corynebacterium diphtheriae.
  • Characterized by the hallmark "bull's neck" presentation due to severe neck swelling from infection and inflammatory response to the diphtheria toxin.

Clinical Features

Complications
  • Sore throat
  • Swelling of neck due to lymphadenopathy and edema, bull's neck
  • Difficulty swallowing (dysphagia)
  • Low-grade fever
  • Pseudomembrane formation in the throat
  • Non-healing ulcers covered by grey membrane on the skin
  • Myocarditis
  • Neurological complications (e.g., paralysis, neuropathy)
  • Renal failure
  • Airway obstruction

Corynebacterium jeikeium (Option B) It is known to cause cutaneous and bloodstream infection (endocarditis) in immunocompromised individuals.

Corynebacterium minutissimum (Option C) It causes erythrasma, a localized infection of the stratum corneum usually affecting the groin and axilla.

Corynebacterium urealyticum (Option D) It is mostly known to cause urinary tract infections.

questions.text: What is the responsibility of the doctor in recording the dying declaration of a victim affected by a fire?

choices.text: To record the statement even in the presence of magistrate
Put the person under oath before declaration

questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - To assess compos mentis

  • A doctor’s responsibility when recording a dying declaration is primarily to assess the mental fitness (compos mentis) of the victim. This ensures that the person is conscious and mentally fit to make a statement about the cause of their death, which is a crucial criterion for the validity of the dying declaration under Section 32 of the Indian Evidence Act (IEA)

Dying Declaration (Sec. 32 IEA):

  1. A statement by a dying person about the cause or circumstances of their death due to an unlawful act.
  2. Legal Basis: Sec. 32 IEA allows dying declarations as evidence; corroboration strengthens its acceptance (Sec. 157 IEA).
  3. Flexibility: No specific form, format, or procedure prescribed by law.
  4. Who Can Record:
    • Ideally a Magistrate, but in urgent situations, a doctor, police officer, or any witness may record it.
    • Evidential value is highest when recorded by a Magistrate.
  5. Key Features and Procedure:
    • Mental State: The person must be conscious and mentally fit (compos mentis).
      • Certified by a doctor if possible, but not mandatory for admissibility.
    • No Oath or Leading Questions:
      • No oath is administered as the dying person is presumed truthful.
      • Avoid leading questions.
    • Narrative Recording:
      • Statement should be recorded in simple narrative form without alterations.
      • Interruptions (e.g., unconsciousness) should be noted, and partial declarations signed by the recorder.
    • Witnesses: Presence of two witnesses strengthens credibility if the Magistrate is unavailable.
    • Submission: Sent to the Magistrate in a sealed cover.
    • Survival of Declarant: If the declarant survives, the statement holds corroborative value but cannot replace oral testimony.
  6. Doctor’s Duties:
    • Certify Mental Fitness:
      • Assess and document the declarant's ability to make a statement.
      • Certification is preferred but not mandatory for the declaration's validity.
    • Record Accurately:
      • Write the statement verbatim in a simple narrative style.
      • Note any interruptions (e.g., loss of consciousness).
    • Act Promptly: Record the declaration without delay if death seems imminent.
    • Presence of Witnesses: Ensure two witnesses are present if possible.
    • Submission: Forward the declaration to the Magistrate in a sealed cover.
    • Expert Opinion: Be cautious when commenting on a patient's ability to speak or act after a fatal injury.

To record the statement even in the presence of a magistrate (Option B): Ideally, a Magistrate should record the dying declaration for it to carry the most weight. However, if the Magistrate is unavailable, a doctor can record the statement, but there is no legal requirement to do so in the Magistrate's presence.

Cross-examine the person (Option C): Cross-examining the person is not part of the process of recording a dying declaration. The purpose is to record their statement, not to question them as a part of a legal cross-examination.

Put the person under oath before declaration (Option D): The dying declaration does not require an oath to be administered because the person is presumed to be truthful when making a statement under the belief of impending death. The law does not mandate an oath or formal swearing before a dying declaration.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is an abductor of the vocal cord?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Posterior cricoarytenoid

Explanation:

The posterior cricoarytenoid muscle is the only abductor of the vocal cords. It pulls the arytenoid cartilages laterally, opening the glottis and allowing air passage during respiration.

Muscles of the Larynx

Muscle

Action

Function

Posterior cricoarytenoid

Abducts vocal cords

Only abductor, opens airway during inspiration.

Lateral cricoarytenoid

Adducts vocal cords

Closes glottis for phonation.

Thyroarytenoid

Relaxes vocal cords

Lowers pitch of voice.

Vocalis

Tenses vocal cords

Fine control of voice modulation.

Lateral cricoarytenoid (Option A): Incorrect because it adducts the vocal cords, closing the glottis.

Thyroarytenoid (Option C): Incorrect because it relaxes the vocal cords, reducing tension.

Vocalis (Option D): Incorrect because it tenses the vocal cords, adjusting voice pitch.

questions.text: A 72-year-old farmer was presented in the hospital with pinpoint pupil & increased secretions. The diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Organophosphorus poisoning

  • The symptoms of pinpoint pupils (miosis) and increased secretions (such as salivation, lacrimation, and bronchorrhea) are highly suggestive of organophosphorus poisoning. Organophosphates inhibit cholinesterase enzymes, leading to the accumulation of acetylcholine at muscarinic and nicotinic receptors.

Symptoms

Muscarinic: Lethargy, Salivation, Diarrhea, Lacrimation, Urination, Miosis, Muscle weakness, Bronchorrhea, Bronchospasm, Bradycardia, Emesis (Mnemonic: DUMBBELLS)

Nicotinic: Muscle weakness, Fasciculation, Areflexia, Muscle paralysis

CNS: Headache, Tremor, Confusion, Slurred speech, Coma, Convulsion

Laboratory Diagnosis
  • RBC/True Cholinesterase (specific)
  • Plasma/Pseudocholinesterase (Most common)
    • Falls rapidly with organophosphorus poisoning
    • Inexpensive, sensitive)
  • Atropine test: If 2 mg of Atropine relieves symptoms, it confirms OP poisoning
  • P-nitro phenol test for confirmation.

Management
  • Resuscitative measures (Airway-Breathing-Circulation)
  • Decontamination
  • Gastric lavage with 1:5000 KMnO4
  • Activated charcoal
  • Atropine sulfate (2-4 mg IV every 10-15 minutes until atropinization)
  • Signs of atropinization: Heart rate>80 beats/min, pupils no longer pinpoint, clear chest on auscultation with no wheeze, systolic BP>80mmHg, Dry axillae
  • Oximes (Pralidoxime) to decrease muscarinic and CNS symptoms
    • removes phosphate group
    • reduces atropine requirement

Cause of Death

Respiratory Muscle Paralysis (RMP)

Alcohol poisoning (Option A): Alcohol typically causes CNS depression, but does not cause pinpoint pupils or excessive secretions

Opioid poisoning (Option B): Opioids cause miosis (pinpoint pupils) but do not cause excessive secretions or the broad range of symptoms seen in organophosphorus poisoning.\

Datura poisoning (Option D): Datura causes mydriasis (dilated pupils) and other anticholinergic symptoms like dry mouth, blurred vision, and tachycardia, which are opposite to the muscarinic symptoms caused by organophosphorus poisoning.

questions.text: Takayasu arteritis most commonly involves:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Arch of aorta

Explanation:

  • Takayasu arteritis most commonly affects the aorta and its major branches, particularly the branches arising from the arch of the aorta. The disease leads to inflammation, thickening, and narrowing of these arteries, which can result in reduced blood flow to various organs and tissues..

Takayasu Arteritis ("Pulseless disease"):

General features:

  • Predominantly affects young females (<20 years)
  • Vascular Involvement:
    • Most commonly affects the aorta and its major branches, particularly the branches arising from the arch of the aorta like brachiocephalic trunk, left common carotid artery, and left subclavian artery.
    • Characteristic ostial narrowing vs. diffuse involvement in atherosclerosis
    • A leading cause of renal artery stenosis in India

Clinical Features:

a) Early Phase (Pre-pulseless):

  • Systemic symptoms: fever, malaise, night sweats
  • Arthralgias, anorexia, weight loss

b) Vascular Phase:

  • Arm claudication
  • Unequal blood pressure between arms
  • Pulseless disease (difficult to appreciate radial artery)
  • Hypertension (32-93%)

Differential Diagnosis:

  • Young female with renal artery stenosis:
    • India: Takayasu arteritis
    • USA: fibromuscular dysplasia (FMD)
  • Arm claudication:
    • Rule out neurogenic claudication (cervical disc disease)

Investigations:

  • ESR/CRP elevation
  • Mild anemia
  • Elevated immunoglobulins
  • Investigation of choice: MR angiography (MRA)
  • Complete imaging of the aorta and major branches needed

Management:

  • First Line: Steroids (40-60mg prednisone/day)
  • Second Line: Methotrexate (up to 25mg/week) for steroid-refractory cases

Important Points for Differential Blood Pressure:

  • Normal difference between arm-leg BP: <20 mmHg
  • Conditions with unequal arm BPs:
    • Takayasu arteritis
    • Supravalvular aortic stenosis with Coanda effect
    • Preductal coarctation of aorta

Major complications: Heart failure, stroke, MI, aneurysm rupture, renal failure

 

Pulmonary artery, Coronary arteries, Abdominal aorta (Option A, B, C) are also affected in takayasu Arteritis but less common than arch of aorta and its branches

questions.text: What is the most probable condition for a 6-year-old child who has not received immunization, presented to the Emergency Room by a concerned mother, experiencing symptoms such as fever, cough, and difficulty breathing? Physical examination reveals the presence of a pseudo membrane on the tonsils that bleeds upon attempted removal, as well as a swollen neck giving a bull-neck appearance.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Diphtheria

Explanation:

The described clinical presentation is most consistent with diphtheria, a bacterial infection caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae. Key findings that support this diagnosis include:

  1. Pseudo membrane on tonsils: A hallmark feature of diphtheria, this greyish membrane adheres firmly to the underlying tissue and bleeds upon removal.
  2. Bull-neck appearance: Swelling of the neck due to cervical lymphadenopathy and soft tissue oedema is a classic sign of diphtheria.
  3. Fever, cough, and difficulty breathing: These are common systemic and respiratory symptoms of diphtheria.
  4. No immunisation history: The lack of vaccination increases susceptibility to diphtheria, which is preventable through the DPT vaccine.

Causes of Membrane over the tonsils include:

  • Moniliasis (Candidiasis)
  • Diphtheria (pseudomembrane)
  • Vincent’s angina (pseudomembrane)
  • Infectious mononucleosis
  • Malignancy of tonsil
  • Trauma
  • Aphthous ulcers
  • Leukaemia
  • Agranulocytosis

 

Infectious mononucleosis (Option A): While it may cause tonsillar swelling and pharyngitis, it does not cause a pseudomembrane or bull-neck appearance. Bleeding upon removal of the membrane is also not characteristic.

Tonsillitis (Option B): Tonsillitis can cause fever and difficulty swallowing, but it does not produce a pseudomembrane or bull-neck swelling. It is usually due to bacterial (e.g., Streptococcus pyogenes) or viral infections.

Candidiasis (Option D): Oral candidiasis can cause white patches on the mucosa, but these are easily scraped off without bleeding, unlike the pseudomembrane in diphtheria. It is also less likely to cause systemic symptoms like bull-neck swelling.

questions.text: Given below is a histological section of the thyroid gland. Which of the following is secreted by the cell marked ‘X’ in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Calcitonin

Explanation:

The marked structure in the image is a parafollicular (C) cell of the thyroid gland. These cells secrete calcitonin, a hormone involved in calcium homeostasis by reducing blood calcium levels.

Thyroid Gland Histology

Cell Type

Location

Hormone Secreted

Function

Follicular cells

Line the thyroid follicles

Thyroxine (T3, T4)

Regulates metabolism.

Parafollicular (C) cells

Between follicles

Calcitonin

Lowers blood calcium by inhibiting osteoclasts.

Thyroxine (Option A): Incorrect because thyroxine (T3/T4) is secreted by follicular cells, not parafollicular cells.

PTH (Option C): Incorrect because parathyroid hormone (PTH) is secreted by the parathyroid gland, not the thyroid.

Serotonin (Option D): Incorrect because serotonin is a neurotransmitter mainly found in the CNS and enterochromaffin cells, not the thyroid.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man presents with complaints of palpitations and syncope. He has a history of inferior-wall myocardial infarction a year ago. Holter study was done and his 24 hour ECG strip obtained is given below. What is the long-term treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer : C) Permanent pacemaker

Explanation:

  • The 24-hour ECG strip suggests the presence of sinus node dysfunction (sick sinus syndrome) characterized by bradycardia (slow heart rate), pauses, and sinus arrests. This condition is commonly seen in individuals who have had a previous myocardial infarction. Long-term treatment for this would be a "Permanent pacemaker."

Sinus bradycardia

Definition

Sinus bradycardia is a cardiac rhythm with normal sinus node depolarization but a rate < 60 bpm.

Diagnostic Criteria

ECG showing sinus rhythm at a rate lower than 60 bpm.

Common Etiologies
  • Normal in athletes
  • Medications (beta-blockers, calcium channel blockers, digoxin)
  • Hypothyroidism, hypothermia
  • Sick sinus syndrome, myocardial infarction
  • Vagal stimulation (e.g., vasovagal syncope)

Clinical Features
  • Asymptomatic (in many patients)
  • Fatigue
  • Dizziness or lightheadedness
  • Exercise intolerance
  • Syncope or presyncope
  • Cognitive slowing
  • Worsening angina or heart failure symptoms

Evaluation
  • Assess hemodynamic stability
  • ECG to confirm sinus rhythm
  • Review medication list for bradycardic agents
  • Evaluate for comorbidities (e.g., hypothyroidism, myocardial infarction)

Management
  • If Hemodynamically Unstable:
    • IV atropine 0.5 mg every 3-5 minutes (max 3 mg)
    • If there is no improvement, consider a temporary pacemaker
  • If Stable, for long term mamagement:
    • Treat underlying causes
    • Withdraw bradycardia-inducing medications
    • Permanent pacemaker

 

Amiodarone (Option A) is an antiarrhythmic medication used to treat various cardiac arrhythmias. However, it is not the primary treatment for sinus node dysfunction.

Atropine only (Option B) is a medication used for acute management of symptomatic bradycardia. It is used only in emergency situations or as a temporary measure before definitive treatment such as a pacemaker is implemented.

Isoproterenol is a medication that acts as a cardiac stimulant and can increase heart rate. While it may be used in certain acute situations, it is not an appropriate long-term treatment for sinus node dysfunction. Additionally, combining atropine and isoproterenol (Option D) is not a typical approach for managing this condition.

questions.text: Which among the following conditions does not result in the development of a grey-white membrane over the tonsils?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Ludwig’s angina

Explanation:

  • Ludwig's angina is a deep neck space infection involving the submandibular, sublingual, and submental spaces. It does not produce a grey-white membrane over the tonsils. Instead, it is characterised by swelling of the floor of the mouth, raised tongue, and difficulty in breathing, speaking, or swallowing.

 

Ludwig’s angina- Anatomy

Primary Spaces

It involves three spaces around the mandible: the sublingual, submandibular, and submental spaces.

  • Sublingual space: Infections here typically arise from the premolars and first molar.
  • Submandibular space: It contains the submandibular gland and lymph nodes, and connects to both the sublingual and submental spaces.
  • Submental space: Infections in the submandibular space can easily spread to the submental and contralateral sublingual spaces.

Secondary Spaces

 
  • The secondary spaces, known collectively as the masticator space, surround the muscles involved in mastication (masseter, medial and lateral pterygoid, and temporalis).
  • These spaces can become involved due to the posterior spread of infection from the primary spaces or from a third molar infection.
  • The primary clinical feature of masticator space infection is significant trismus.

 

Streptococcal tonsillitis (Option A): Although rare, severe forms can lead to exudative tonsillitis, with grey-white deposits on the tonsils. However, this is not as adherent or classic as the membrane seen in diphtheria.

Diphtheria (Option B): Diphtheria is a hallmark condition associated with the formation of a grey-white pseudomembrane over the tonsils, which is firmly adherent and bleeds upon removal.

Infectious mononucleosis (Option D): Caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, it can produce white or greyish exudates on the tonsils, especially in severe cases, alongside fever, sore throat, and lymphadenopathy.

questions.text: Which anatomical plane contains the neurovascular structures supplying the abdominal wall, located below the rectus abdominis muscle and above the transversalis fascia?

choices.text: Between the internal oblique and external oblique
Between the internal oblique and rectus abdominis
Between the internal oblique and transversus abdominis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Between the internal oblique and transversus abdominis.

Explanation:

  • The neurovascular plane of the anterior abdominal wall lies between the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles.
  • This plane contains the intercostal nerves (T7-T11), subcostal nerve (T12), and branches of the lumbar plexus (L1), along with corresponding vessels.

Neurovascular Plane of the Abdominal Wall

Layer of Abdominal Wall

Structures Present

Between skin and external oblique

Superficial fascia, cutaneous nerves.

Between external oblique and internal oblique

No major neurovascular structures.

Between internal oblique and transversus abdominis

Neurovascular plane (intercostal nerves, subcostal nerve, lumbar plexus branches, and segmental arteries).

Deep to transversus abdominis

Transversalis fascia, extraperitoneal fat, peritoneum.

Deep to transversus abdominis (Option B): Incorrect because the neurovascular plane is located superficial to transversus abdominis, not deep to it.

Between internal oblique and rectus abdominis (Option C): Incorrect because the rectus abdominis is enclosed by the rectus sheath, and the neurovascular structures run lateral to it, not between it and the internal oblique.

Between internal oblique and external oblique (Option A): Incorrect because this plane does not contain major neurovascular structures.

questions.text: A patient with Pink color skin & mucosa, a bitter almond smell from breath, and frothy discharge. The cause of death is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - HCN poisoning

  • Cyanide poisoning (HCN) causes pink skin and mucosa, bitter almond odor from the breath, and frothy discharge, which are key diagnostic clues. It is caused by the exposure to hydrogen cyanide (HCN) or cyanide salts. Cyanide interferes with cellular respiration by inhibiting cytochrome c oxidase, an enzyme in the mitochondria, leading to histotoxic anoxia (cells cannot use oxygen, even when it is available in the bloodstream).

Cyanide poisoning

Physical Appearance
  • Gaseous state- Hydrogen cyanide (HCN)
  • Liquid form- Hydrocyanic acid or Prussic acid
  • Solid state- salt forms

Sources of poisoning
  • Electroplating, photographic processes, rubber, and plastic manufacturing industries
  • Insecticide and rodenticide
  • Drug toxicity: Sodium nitroprusside
  • Military chemical warfare agents
  • Burning of plastic furniture, silk, or wool
  • Cigarette smoking
  • Bitter almonds, peach, apricot, plum, apple, pear, cassava

Mode of Action
  • Rapid absorption across both skin and mucous membrane
  • Cyanide salts combine with hydrochloric acid in the stomach to form HCN that is absorbed
  • Inhibition of cytochrome oxidase causes histotoxic anoxia
  • Neurotoxicity

Clinical Features
  • Inhalation: Dizziness, vertigo, and constriction of the throat
  • Ingestion: Nausea, headache, loss of muscular power, hypotension, cardiovascular failure, and convulsion
  • Skin: Brick-red color of skin and mucous membranes
  • Anion gap metabolic acidosis and lactic acidosis

Diagnosis
  • Lee-Jones test
  • Serum cyanide level

Treatment
  • Severe acidosis (pH < 7.1): Administer sodium bicarbonate
  • Antidotal therapy (Eli Lilly cyanide kit approach)
    • First step: Inhalation of Amyl nitrite
    • Second step: Sodium nitrite (3% solution) IV
    • Third step: Sodium thiosulfate (25% solution) IV
  • Other Antidotes
    • 4-dimethylaminophenol (4-DMAP)
    • Hydroxocobalamin (Vitamin B12): Combines with cyanide to form cyanocobalamin, which is excreted in the urine
    • Hyperbaric oxygen
  • Note: Methylene blue is NOT an antidote for cyanide and must NOT be used

Autopsy Findings
  • Bitter almond’s odour
  • Brick-red color of skin and mucous membranes
  • Cyanosis of extremities
  • Hemorrhagic gastritis
  • Disseminated petechiae in brain, meninges, pleura, lungs, and pericardium
  • Pulmonary and cerebral edema

Note:

  • Mechanism of action of nitrites: It converts hemoglobin to methemoglobinemia which causes the detachment of cyanide from the heme group of cytochrome oxidase.
  • Mechanism of action of sodium thiosulfate: Forms non-toxic thiocyanate which is excreted in the urine.

H2S poisoning (Option A): Hydrogen sulfide (H2S) poisoning typically presents with rotten egg smell from the breath, not the bitter almond smell seen in cyanide poisoning. Symptoms include headache, dizziness, nausea, vomiting, and in severe cases, respiratory failure. The skin typically does not have the pink color seen in cyanide poisoning.

CO poisoning (Option B): Carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning leads to a cherry-red skin color, not pink as seen in cyanide poisoning. The breath does not have a bitter almond smell, and the classic symptoms are headache, dizziness, confusion, and weakness, not frothy discharge.

OPC poisoning (Option D): Organophosphate (OP) poisoning typically presents with symptoms such as muscarinic effects (e.g., excessive salivation, lacrimation, urination, diarrhea, gastrointestinal distress) and nicotinic effects (muscle weakness, paralysis). The skin does not have a characteristic pink color, and there is no bitter almond odor from the breath. Frothy discharge is not a typical symptom of OPC poisoning.

questions.text: What is the appropriate approach to treat a child who is attending school and has a repeated occurrence of infections in the upper respiratory tract, difficulty in breathing through the nose, and hearing problems, along with the observation of a palate that is significantly raised in shape?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion

Explanation:

  • Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion is the preferred approach for a child presenting with recurrent upper respiratory tract infections, nasal breathing difficulty, hearing problems, and a high-arched palate. These symptoms suggest adenoid hypertrophy causing upper airway obstruction and Eustachian tube dysfunction, leading to otitis media with effusion (OME).
    • Adenoidectomy relieves nasal obstruction and reduces recurrent infections.
    • Grommet insertion helps in draining middle ear fluid, improving hearing.

Tonsillectomy (Option A): Tonsillectomy alone is not indicated as the child primarily has symptoms related to adenoid hypertrophy and Eustachian tube dysfunction, not recurrent tonsillitis.

Adenoidectomy (Option B): While adenoidectomy addresses the nasal obstruction and infections, it does not directly manage the hearing problems caused by OME. Grommet insertion is essential for addressing middle ear fluid.

Myringotomy with grommet insertion (Option D): While this resolves middle ear fluid, it does not address the underlying issue of adenoid hypertrophy causing nasal obstruction and recurrent infections.

questions.text: In this image of basal ganglia, all of the following are correctly labeled except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 4- Internal capsule

 

Explanation:

The internal capsule is a white matter tract separating the caudate nucleus from the putamen and globus pallidus, whereas the structure labeled as 4 in the image corresponds to the thalamus, which is a relay center for sensory and motor signals.

Basal Ganglia Anatomy

Structure

Function

Location

Caudate nucleus

Motor processes, learning, associative functions

Lateral to lateral ventricle, near thalamus

Putamen

Regulates movements, influences learning

Part of the striatum, lateral to globus pallidus

Globus pallidus

Inhibitory control of movements

Medial to putamen, part of lentiform nucleus

Internal capsule

Contains motor and sensory pathways

Between caudate nucleus and lentiform nucleus

Thalamus

Sensory relay station

Medial to basal ganglia, near third ventricle

1 - Caudate nucleus (Option A): Forms part of the striatum, involved in motor control.

2 - Globus pallidus (Option B): Part of the lentiform nucleus, modulates motor activity.

3 - Putamen (Option C): Works with the caudate to regulate movements.

questions.text: Which poisoning is caused by a bullet retained inside the body?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Lead

  • Lead is a toxic substance that can be released from retained lead bullets, especially if the bullet is lodged in the body for a prolonged period. Lead gradually leaches into the bloodstream and can cause neurological issues (e.g., confusion, memory problems, and in extreme cases, encephalopathy), kidney damage, gastrointestinal symptoms, and anemia.

Causes of Chronic Lead Poisoning:

  1. Ingestion or Inhalation of lead-containing dust.: Most common source
  2. Lead Paint Dust:
    • Major source for children, especially those under 3 years old.
    • Children are at greater risk due to pica (eating non-nutritive materials).
  3. Inhalation by Occupational Exposure: Workers in industries such as white lead manufacturing, lead paint production, plumbing, glass polishing, printing, and glass blowing are at risk.
  4. Contaminated Drinking Water: Absorption of lead from water stored in lead cisterns.
  5. Lead in Tinned Food
  6. Cosmetics and Hair Dyes
  7. Petrol and Gasoline: Percutaneous absorption of tetraethyl lead
  8. Lead absorption from vermilion (red pigment) used on the scalp.
  9. Lead poisoning can result from retained lead bullets or projectiles lodged in the body.

Iron (Option A): Not related to retained bullets. Iron poisoning typically occurs from ingesting large amounts of iron and affects the gastrointestinal system, liver, and kidneys.

Phosphorus (Option B): Occurs from exposure to white phosphorus and causes damage to the liver, but not associated with retained bullets.

Nitrocellulose (Option C): Found in gunpowder, but it does not cause poisoning from retained bullets.

questions.text:
Which of the following findings from a pleural fluid aspirate will suggest an exudative pleural effusion?


	Normal values
	Total S. Protein: 6-8 gm%
	S.LDH: 140-280 IU
	S. glucose: 140-200

choices.text: Pleural: Serum protein ratio > 0.5, pleural: Serum LDH ratio > 0.6 or pleural LDH > ⅔ of serum LDH
Pleural fluid protein = 4.5 gm% and glucose = 30 mg%
Pleural fluid LDH = 90IU and glucose = 30 mg%
Pleural fluid protein = 3.5gm% and glucose = 90 mg%

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Pleural: Serum protein ratio > 0.5, pleural: Serum LDH ratio > 0.6 or pleural LDH > 2/3

Explanation:

To classify the effusion as transudative or exudative, we apply Light's criteria:

  • Pleural fluid protein/serum protein > 0.5
  • Pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH > 0.6
  • Pleural fluid LDH exceeds two-thirds of the normal upper limit for serum LDH

Investigation of pleural fluid

Radiological investigation

X-ray:

  • 200 mL of fluid is needed for detection on the posteroanterior (PA) view.
  • 50 mL of fluid may lead to blunting of the costophrenic angle on the lateral view.
  • A homogeneous opacity with obliteration of the costophrenic angle is typical.
  • This appearance is marked by a curved upper border, known as the Ellis S-shaped curve.
  • Obliteration of cardiophrenic angle.

Ultrasound: More effective than X-ray in detecting fluid presence, showing a clear hypoechoic space indicative of transudate and moving densities suggesting exudate.

Pleural fluid Analysis

Light's Criteria

Differentiates transudative from exudative pleural effusions based on LDH and protein levels in pleural fluid.

  • An exudative pleural effusion meets at least one of the following:
    1. Pleural fluid protein/serum protein > 0.5
    2. Pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH > 0.6
    3. Pleural fluid LDH exceeds two-thirds of the normal upper limit for serum.
  • ~25% of transudates may be misidentified as exudates.
  • If exudative criteria are met but a transudative condition is suspected, measure protein difference; if >31 g/L (3.1 g/dL), likely transudative.

Additional Tests for Exudative Effusions
  • Appearance description
  • Glucose level, If Glucose <60 mg/dL Consider:
    • Malignancy
    • Bacterial infections (empyema)
    • Rheumatoid pleuritis
  • Differential cell count
  • Microbiologic studies
  • Cytology

Standard Peculiarities

  • Heart Failure: NT-proBNP level > 1500 pg/mL indicates effusion due to congestive heart failure
  • Parapneumonic Effusion: Key criteria include:
    • Loculated pleural fluid
    • Pleural fluid pH < 7.20
    • Pleural fluid glucose < 3.3 mmol/L (< 60 mg/dL) ( Option B, C)
    • Positive Gram stain or culture results
    • Presence of visible pus
  • Tuberculous Pleuritis: Diagnosis confirmed by high TB markers in pleural fluid (adenosine deaminase > 40 IU/L or interferon γ > 140 pg/mL)

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Since the criteria suggest an exudate, which is often associated with other conditions like malignancy or infection rather than just congestive heart failure (Option D).

questions.text: The image given below is from a chronic smoker’s oral examination. Identify the lesion given.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Leukoplakia

Explanation:

  • Leukoplakia is characterised by a white patch or plaque on the oral mucosa that cannot be wiped off and cannot be attributed to another identifiable cause. It is commonly associated with chronic smoking, alcohol use, or other irritants. This lesion is considered a precancerous condition and warrants further evaluation and biopsy if necessary.

 

Definition

White patch on oral mucosa, defined clinically, excluding conditions like lichen planus, candidiasis, etc.

Causes
  • Smoking, tobacco chewing
  • Alcohol abuse (especially with smoking)
  • Chronic trauma (ill-fitting dentures, cheek bites)
  • Associated with submucous fibrosis, hyperplastic candidiasis, Plummer-Vinson syndrome

Common sites
  • Buccal mucosa (most common in India)
  • Oral commissures, floor of mouth, tongue, gingivobuccal sulcus, lip mucosa

Age & Gender
  • Men in their 40s are 2-3 times more affected than females.

Clinical types
  • Homogenous: Smooth or wrinkled white patch, lower malignancy risk
  • Nodular (speckled): White patches on an erythematous base, higher malignancy risk
  • Erosive (erythroleukoplakia): Interspersed with red patches, fissures, highest malignancy risk

Malignant potential
  • 1-17.5% risk, average 5% malignant transformation
  • Higher risk in dysplastic lesions and certain locations

Treatment
  • Remove causative factors: Spontaneous regression in some cases.
  • Biopsy: For lesions with high malignant potential.
  • Surgical excision or laser/cryotherapy: For suspicious or small lesions

 

Erythroplakia (Option A): Erythroplakia presents as a red patch on the oral mucosa, often velvety in appearance, and is also a precancerous lesion. However, the lesion in this case is white, not red.

Fordyce’s granules (Option C): These are small, yellow or whitish papules representing ectopic sebaceous glands. They are benign and not related to smoking. They do not appear as a white patch like leukoplakia.

Koplik’s spots (Option D): Koplik’s spots are small white lesions with a red halo, typically seen on the buccal mucosa during the early stages of measles (rubeola). They are not associated with chronic smoking.

questions.text: What is the GCS of a patient with a head injury who opens her eyes in response to a loud voice, localizes pain and is confused and disoriented but can answer questions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) E3 M5 V4

Explanation:

  • Eye opening response (E3): Eyes open to verbal command, speech or shout
  • Motor response (M5): Purposeful movement to painful stimulus
  • Verbal response (V4): Confused and disoriented.

The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is a tool used to assess a patient’s level of consciousness based on three parameters: eye-opening, verbal response, and motor response. Each parameter is scored, and the total GCS score ranges from 3 (deep coma) to 15 (fully awake).

Simplified Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) Table

Category

Response

Score

Eye Opening (E)

Spontaneous

4

To speech

3

To pain

2

None

1

Verbal Response (V)

Oriented

5

Confused conversation

4

Inappropriate words

3

Incomprehensible sounds

2

None

1

Motor Response (M)

Obeys commands

6

Localizes to pain

5

Withdraws from pain

4

Abnormal flexion (decorticate)

3

Abnormal extension (decerebrate)

2

No response

1

 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical Classification

Minor head injury

GCS 15 with no LOC (loss of consciousness)

Mild head injury

GCS 14 or 15 with LOC

Moderate head injury

GCS 9 - 13

Severe head injury

GCS 3 - 8

 

The GCS-P score is calculated by subtracting the Pupil Reactivity Score (PRS) from the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) total score: GCS-P = GCS - PRS.

Pupils Unreactive to Light

Pupil Reactivity Score

Both Pupils

2

One Pupil

1

Neither Pupil

0
  • GCS-P score can range from 1 to 15
  • GCS-P score values between one and 8 denote a severe injury
