questions.text: In an autopsy of suspected poisoning, which organ, along with the stomach, part of the intestine, and liver, is preserved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Kidney

In the context of a suspected poisoning autopsy, the kidney, along with the stomach, part of the intestine, and liver, is preserved for toxicological analysis. This is because the kidneys are essential for filtering toxins from the blood and can accumulate poisons, making them a valuable organ to analyze in cases of suspected poisoning.

For toxicological analysis, various samples and organs should be preserved to identify poisoning or drug use.

  • Blood: Collect venous blood (preferably from femoral, iliac, or axillary veins) in a tube with lithium heparin or EDTA, or fluoride/oxalate if alcohol is suspected.
  • Vomit and Stomach Contents: Place in a clean glass jar or plastic tub with a tight-fitting lid.
  • Feces: For heavy metal poisoning, collect 20-30g of rectal contents in a screw-topped jar or snap-on-lid container.
  • Liver and Other Organs: Liver concentrates many drugs. Half the liver and gallbladder should be placed in a clean container. Bile may also be required for certain drug analyses (e.g., chlorpromazine, morphine).
  • Hair and Nail Clippings: For heavy metal poisoning (e.g., arsenic, lead), collect hair pulled at the roots and nail clippings. These metals are detectable in keratin.
  • Exhaled Air: Collected as required, with no preservative needed.
  • Scene Residues: Collect relevant materials from the scene, such as tablets or containers, with no preservative.
  • Other Organs and Specimens: Urine, sweat, saliva, spleen, kidneys, brain

Lungs (Option B): Not typically preserved unless the poisoning involves inhaled toxins.

Muscle (Option C): Not usually preserved unless there’s a specific reason, such as muscle breakdown from certain toxins.

Heart (Option D): Preserved only if there’s suspicion of cardiac involvement in the poisoning, but not a primary focus in most cases.

questions.text: Identify the parasite.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Giardia lamblia

Explanation:

The given image is of trophozoite stage of Giardia lamblia

Giardia lamblia:

  • It includes 2 stages:
    • Trophozoite (or vegetative form)
    • Cysts (or cystic form).
  • Infective form: Mature cyst
  • Transmission: Feco oral route.
  • Habitat: Mucosa of duodenum and upper ileum.
  • Ingesting a minimum of 10 cysts can cause an infection in a person.
  • Within half an hour of ingestion, the cyst hatches out into two trophozoites, which multiply successively by binary fission and colonise the duodenum.
  • During unfavorable condition , encystment occurs and cyst are passed in stool and remain viable in soil and water for several weeks.
  • Life cycle: Host (only human) → Contaminated food and water (faeco-oral route) → Cyst (ingested form) → excystation occurs → Trophozoite.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Sample: Stool
    • Microscopy: Cyst and trophozoite are seen.
      • Trophozoite: 2 nuclei and four pairs of flagella with pear-shaped or tennis racket-shaped.
  • Cyst: 1-4 nuclei and no flagella.
  • String test: A capsule will have a string, and the capsule is swallowed, then the capsule goes to duodenum and dissolves, then the string is pulled back and, a microscopic examination is done.
  • Duodenal biopsy:
    • Giardia lamblia is a luminal organism
    • Organisms hanging in the lumen
    • Sickle shaped organism is seen.
    • Falling leaf motility is shown.
  • Treatment:
    • Metronidazole
    • Tinidazole (single dose of 2g)

Trichomonas vaginalis (Option B) The trophozoite of Trichomonas is a pyriform or oval-shaped organism with 4 flagella on the anterior end, and 5th flagella remain folded on the outer surface of the undulating membrane. An axosystole runs throughout the length of the body.

Trypanosoma (Option C) is a hemoflagellate with 4 different morphological forms all of them containing 1 nucleus, and kinetoplast. Different forms are Amastigote, Promastigote, Epimastigote and Trypomastigote.

Cyclospora (Option D) It is a coccidian Protozoa, which is usually identified by its oocysts. Sporulated oocysts of cyclospora are round in shape as well as acid-fast, but contain 2 sporocysts, with each sporocyst containing two sporozoites.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents to the emergency department with the following arterial blood gas (ABG) results: pH 7.55, PaCO2 40 mmHg, HCO3- 32 mEq/L. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Metabolic alkalosis

Explanation:

  • The elevated pH (>7.45) and increased bicarbonate (HCO3-) (32 mEq/L), indicates a primary metabolic alkalosis.

Metabolic Alkalosis

  • Metabolic alkalosis is characterized by an increase in arterial pH, elevated serum bicarbonate [HCO3−], and increased PaCO2​ due to compensatory hypoventilation.
  • Often presents with hypochloremia and hypokalemia.
  • Occurs as a mixed disorder with respiratory or metabolic acidosis or alkalosis.
  • Causes
    • Exogenous Bicarbonate Loads
      • Acute alkali administration
      • Milk-alkali syndrome
    • Effective ECFV Contraction (Normotension, K+ Deficiency, Secondary Hyperreninemic Hyperaldosteronism)
      • Gastrointestinal Origin: Vomiting, gastric aspiration, congenital chloridorrhea, gastrocystoplasty, villous adenoma
      • Renal Origin: Diuretic use (thiazides, loop diuretics), posthypercapnic state, hypercalcemia/hypoparathyroidism, recovery from acidosis, non-resorbable anions (e.g., penicillin), Mg²⁺ deficiency, K⁺ depletion, Bartter's syndrome, Gitelman's syndrome
    • ECFV Expansion, Hypertension, K+ Deficiency, and Mineralocorticoid Excess
      • High Renin: Renal artery stenosis, accelerated hypertension, renin-secreting tumor, estrogen therapy
      • Low Renin: Primary aldosteronism (adenoma, hyperplasia, carcinoma), adrenal enzyme defects (11β-hydroxylase, 17α-hydroxylase deficiency), Cushing’s syndrome, substances like licorice, carbenoxolone
    • Genetic Sodium Channel Mutation (Liddle's Syndrome)
    • Gain-of-function mutation in the distal convoluted tubule, causing ECFV expansion, hypertension, K⁺ deficiency, and hypo-reninemic-hypoaldosteronism
  • Clinical Features
    • Neurological: Mental confusion, obtundation, potential seizures
    • Peripheral Nervous System: Paresthesias, muscle cramps, tetany (similar to hypocalcemia effects)
    • Cardiovascular: Aggravation of arrhythmias, particularly in COPD patients
  • Electrolyte Imbalances
    • Potassium (K⁺): Hypokalemia, especially in cases involving secondary hyperaldosteronism or diuretic use.
    • Chloride (Cl⁻): Hypochloremia, frequently accompanying alkalosis, especially in cases of vomiting or diuretic use.
    • Calcium (Ca²⁺): Symptoms may mimic hypocalcemia despite normal levels.

 

Metabolic acidosis (Option A) would show a low pH and low bicarbonate levels.

Respiratory acidosis (Option C) is characterized by a low pH and elevated PaCO₂

Respiratory alkalosis (Option D) would show a high pH with low PaCO₂.

questions.text: A 5 year old child has flexible fingers and can even touch the back of his hand with his wrist extended. The child also demonstrates the sign shown in the image below. On auscultation, a click is heard after S1, followed by a late systolic murmur. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ehlers-Danlos syndrome

Explanation:

  • Hypermobility of joint, the ability to touch the back of the hand with the wrist extended, tongue to nose sign (Gorlin’s sign) and auscultatory findings of mitral valve prolapse suggests that this could be Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS) which is a genetic disorders that affects the connective tissues and shows various systemic manifestations, primarily involving the skin, joints, and blood vessels.

Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome (EDS):

  • Genetically heterogeneous connective tissue disorders
  • Common features:
    • Skin: Soft, hyperextensible, fragile, slow healing, atrophic scars
    • Joints: Hypermobility, subluxations, chronic pain
    • Vascular fragility: Risk of arterial & organ rupture in some types
    • Gorlin’s sign is seen

Classification:

  • 13 clinical types (linked to 20 genes)
  • Common mutations: COL1A1, COL1A2, COL3A1, COL5A1, COL5A2

Major EDS Types & Features:

Type

Gene

Key Features

Classical (cEDS)

COL5A1, COL5A2

Hyperextensible skin, atrophic scars, joint hypermobility

Vascular (vEDS)

COL3A1

Thin skin, visible veins, arterial/organ rupture,

Hypermobile (hEDS)

Unknown

Joint hypermobility, chronic pain, POTS, mitral valve prolapse

Kyphoscoliotic

PLOD1, FKBP14

Severe scoliosis, hypotonia, vascular rupture

Arthrochalasia

COL1A1, COL1A2

Congenital hip dislocation, severe joint hypermobility

Dermatosparaxis

ADAMTS2

Severe skin fragility, sagging skin, large hernias

Periodontal

C1R, C1S

Severe gum disease, tooth loss, vascular fragility

Diagnosis:

  • Clinical criteria + genetic testing (except hEDS)
  • hEDS diagnosed using:
    • Modified Beighton Score ≥4
    • Arthralgia in ≥4 joints
  • Differential diagnoses:
    • Marfan syndrome
    • Osteogenesis Imperfecta
    • Loeys-Dietz syndrome

Management:

EDS is a diverse group of connective tissue disorders with no cure, requiring symptom-based management and specialized care.

  • Multidisciplinary care
  • Musculoskeletal: Physiotherapy, braces, joint protection
  • Vascular monitoring (for vEDS)
  • Low-impact exercise (swimming, walking)
  • Avoid high-impact sports (gymnastics, weightlifting)
  • Emergency preparedness (MedicAlert, ER protocol for vEDS)
  • Psychological support for chronic pain & genetic diagnosis

questions.text: At what level does the spinal cord end in infants?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) L3

Explanation:

At birth, the spinal cord extends down to L3, but as the child grows, the vertebral column elongates more than the spinal cord, and by adulthood, it typically ends at L1-L2.

Spinal Cord Termination in Different Ages

Age Group

Spinal Cord Termination Level

Clinical Relevance

Fetus (24 weeks)

Extends to S1

Early spinal development stage

Newborn (Infants)

Ends at L3

Important for lumbar puncture site selection

Adults

Ends at L1-L2

Safe lumbar puncture site is L3-L4 or L4-L5

L1 (Option A): Incorrect because in infants, the spinal cord does not end as high as L1; this is the adult level.

L2 (Option B): Incorrect because the spinal cord in newborns extends lower, typically to L3.

L4 (Option D): Incorrect because while the spinal cord is lower in fetuses, in infants, it usually stops at L3, not L4.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate position for placement of single lead pacemaker ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Right ventricle

Explanation:

  • The pacemaker lead is typically placed in the right ventricle for most pacemaker implantations. This positioning allows the electrical impulses generated by the pacemaker to be delivered to the right ventricle, which then stimulates the heart muscle to contract and maintain an appropriate heart rhythm.

Pacemakers of the Heart:

Natural Pacemaker sites and their depolarization rates:

  • Sinoatrial node: 60 to 100 beats per minute
  • Atria: less than 60 beats per minute
  • Atrioventricular node: 40 to 60 beats per minute
  • Ventricles: 20 to 40 beats per minute

Artificial Pacemaker:

  • An artificial pacemaker is a small battery-operated device that helps regulate the heart's rhythm by producing electrical impulses. It typically consists of three parts: a generator, leads (wires), and sensors (electrodes). Traditional pacemakers are implanted under the skin, usually on the chest just below the collarbone or in the stomach area, and they connect to the heart through tiny wires.
  • There are several types of traditional pacemakers:
    • Single-lead pacemakers: One lead is placed in the right ventricle.
    • Dual-lead pacemakers: One lead is placed in the right atrium and one in the right ventricle.
    • Biventricular pacemakers (CRT): Three leads are used, placed in the right atrium, right ventricle, and left ventricle.

Wireless pacemakers are smaller and consist of a pulse generator and electrodes in one device. They are implanted inside the heart through a catheter inserted via internal jugular or femoral or subclavian vein, sending impulses to the right ventricle without the need for traditional surgery.

questions.text: During the examination of injury, hair bulbs are noted to be crushed. The probable type of wound is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Laceration

  • Laceration is a tear or split in the skin due to blunt force trauma.
  • Characterized by irregular, ragged edges, bruising, crushed hair bulbs, and underlying tissue damage (e.g., vessels, nerves).
  • This is the correct answer, as hair bulbs being crushed fits the description of a laceration.
  • The irregular edges, bruising, and embedded dirt indicate a laceration resulting from blunt force.
  • Such wounds often show uneven tearing and damage to underlying structures like nerves and blood vessels, consistent with the autopsy findings.

Laceration

  • Laceration is the tearing or splitting of the skin, mucous membranes, muscles, or internal organs due to a shearing or crushing force from a blunt impact over a broad area.
  • When blunt force causes severe bruising and damage to deeper tissues, it is referred to as a crush injury.

Characteristics

  • Irregular Margins: Ragged, uneven edges with pointed or blunt ends, often showing small tears.
  • Swallow Tails: Tearing at the ends of lacerations, diverging.
  • Bruising: Seen around the wound, more pronounced in areas impacted at an angle or with downward force.
  • Tissue Bridges: Deeper tissues are unevenly torn, leaving nerve, vessel, and connective tissue bridges.
  • Hair Damage: Crushed hair bulbs; hair and skin tags may be embedded in the wound.
  • Hemorrhage: Less severe bleeding as arteries are crushed and torn irregularly, retracting and allowing blood to clot.
  • Soiling: Debris like mud, wood splinters, sand, glass, or hair can become embedded, carrying medico-legal significance.
  • Wound Gaping: Impact from an angle causes tearing on the opposite side and abrasion on the impact side, leading to gaping.

Abrasions (Option A) involve superficial skin damage and typically lack deep tissue involvement and significant bruising.

Stab Injury (Option C): A deep, narrow wound caused by a sharp, pointed object (e.g., knife). Typically, stab wounds have clean edges and are not associated with the irregular, bruised margins or crushed hair seen in lacerations.

None (Option D): This option is incorrect because the described injury (with crushed hair bulbs) clearly corresponds to a laceration, not a different type of injury.

questions.text: In nasopharyngeal carcinoma, which of the following is a component of trotter's triad?

choices.text: Conductive hearing loss, ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia, palatal paralysis
Sensorineural hearing loss, contralateral temporoparietal neuralgia, palatal paralysis
Sensorineural hearing loss, ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia, palatal paralysis
Conductive hearing loss, contralateral temporoparietal neuralgia, palatal paralysis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Conductive hearing loss, ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia, palatal paralysis

Explanation:

Trotter's triad is a classic presentation of nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC) involving:

  1. Conductive hearing loss: Due to obstruction of the Eustachian tube by the tumour, leading to middle ear effusion.
  2. Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia: Caused by tumour infiltration into the base of the skull, affecting branches of the trigeminal nerve.
  3. Palatal paralysis: Resulting from involvement of the pharyngeal plexus or cranial nerves IX and X.

 

Sensorineural hearing loss, contralateral temporoparietal neuralgia, palatal paralysis (Option B): Sensorineural hearing loss is not typically seen in NPC unless there is advanced cranial nerve involvement. Neuralgia and paralysis are ipsilateral to the tumour, not contralateral.

Sensorineural hearing loss, ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia, palatal paralysis (Option C): As mentioned, hearing loss in NPC is usually conductive, not sensorineural.

Conductive hearing loss, contralateral temporoparietal neuralgia, palatal paralysis (Option D): While conductive hearing loss and palatal paralysis are consistent with NPC, the neuralgia is ipsilateral to the tumour, not contralateral.

questions.text: Based on the given image, which of the following specimens would not contain filarial worms, considering the presented disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Saliva

Explanation:

The given image is of lymphedema of left leg seen in lymphatic filariasis aka elephantiasis occurs as a result of chronic infection of filariasis, due to lymphatic obstruction ultimately leading to swelling of the limbs. Filarial worms can be found in blood, urine, exudate of lymph varix, and hydrocele fluid, but not in saliva.

Filariasis:

  • Agent:
    • Wucheria bancrofti: Lymphatic filariasis
    • Brugia malayi: Brugian/Malayan filariasis
  • Endemic areas: Bihar, Jharkhand, Uttar Pradesh, Kerala, Gujarat
  • Host:
    • Definitive: Man
    • Secondary/ intermediate: Culex quinquefasciatus or fatigans
  • Mode of Transmission: Bite of the mosquito (vector)
    • W. bancrofti: Culex quinquefasciatus or fatigans (polluted water)
    • B. malayi: Mansonia (ponds, lakes)
  • Incubation period: 8-16 months.
  • Transmission: Cyclodevelopmental
  • Clinical features:
    • Asymptomatic amicrofilariae: No symptoms, smear-negative
    • Asymptomatic microfilariae: No symptoms, smear-positive
    • Acute stage (few months): Fever, lymphadenitis, epididymo-orchitis.
    • Chronic Obstructive stage (>10 years): Hydrocele, chyluria, elephantiasis
    • Occult stage: Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia (hypersensitivity reaction) with absent microfilariae.

Diagnosis of filariasis

1.

Thick blood film
(Investigation of choice)

Nocturnal microfilariae are seen in blood between 10 PM to 2 AM

Lymphatic filariasis

Brugian/Malayan filariasis

Large, smooth (graceful) curve with countable nuclei

Small, kinked at an acute angle with a long head and uncountable nuclei

2.

Rapid Detection Test
  • Also called the filarial strip test
  • Used for monitoring, mapping, and evaluation activities

3.

Membrane filter concentration method
  • Most sensitive methods for detecting low-density microfilaraemia
  • Require specialized equipment.

4.

DEC provocation test:
  • A single oral dose of 100mg DEC followed by blood smear after 1 hour
  • Microfilariae can appear in the daytime.
  • Highest specificity

5.

Serological tests
  • Cannot differentiate between past and present infection

6.

Mass blood survey
  • Thick blood films for epidemiological Survey

questions.text: What is the primary source of arterial supply for the palatine tonsils among the options provided?

choices.text: Tonsillar branch of the facial artery
Descending palatine branch of maxillary artery
Ascending palatine branch of facial artery

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Tonsillar branch of the facial artery

Explanation:

  • The tonsillar branch of the facial artery is the primary arterial supply to the palatine tonsils. The facial artery provides a direct tonsillar branch that supplies the tonsillar bed and adjacent structures.

 

Anatomy of Palatine tonsils

Location

Lateral wall of the oropharynx between the anterior and posterior pillars.

Surface Extensions

Upwards into the soft palate, downwards into the base of the tongue, and anteriorly into the palatoglossal arch.

Medial Surface Epithelium
  • Stratified squamous epithelium with crypts.
  • Crypta magna, or intratonsillar cleft, is located near the upper part of the tonsil.

Lateral Surface

It is covered by a fibrous capsule separated from the tonsil bed by loose areolar tissue.

Tonsil Bed Muscles

Formed by the superior constrictor and styloglossus muscles.

Arterial Supply
  • Tonsillar branch of the facial artery (main supply)
  • Ascending pharyngeal artery
  • Ascending palatine artery
  • Dorsal linguae branches of the lingual artery
  • Descending palatine branch of the maxillary artery.

Venous Drainage

It drains into the paratonsillar vein, which joins the common facial vein and the pharyngeal venous plexus.

Lymphatic Drainage

Flows into the upper deep cervical nodes.

Sensory Nerve Supply

Lesser palatine branches of the sphenopalatine ganglion (CN V) and the glossopharyngeal nerve.

 

Descending palatine branch of maxillary artery (Option B): This artery supplies the palate, including the soft and hard palates, but it is not the main source of blood supply for the palatine tonsils.

Buccal branch of maxillary artery (Option C): This artery primarily supplies the buccinator muscle and cheek mucosa, not the palatine tonsils.

Ascending palatine branch of facial artery (Option D): Although it contributes to the vascularisation of the pharyngeal region, it is not the primary supplier of the tonsils.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 23-year-old male who has been experiencing eye pain, sensitivity to light, and redness for the last two days, following an injury caused by brushing his eyes against leaves and thorns while gardening?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Fungal keratitis

Explanation:

The clinical scenario of pain, redness in eyes following trauma with vegetative matter is suggestive of Fungal Keratitis.

Fungal Keratitis:

Etiology
  • Causative organism: Aspergillus fumigatus >> Fusarium
  • Predisposing factor: Vegetative matter injury (trauma) (Option C)

Clinical Features
  • SIGNS >> symptoms
  • Pain & Foreign Body Sensation
  • Watering/ Photophobia
  • Blurred Vision, Redness

Examination Findings
  • Corneal Ulcer: Greyish-white, dry, elevated, rolled-out margins
  • Pigmented Ulcer: Brownish, dematiaceous fungi
  • Feathery Extensions: Finger-like projections in stroma
  • Sterile Immune Ring: Yellow line of demarcation
  • Satellite Lesions: Small lesions around the main ulcer
  • Hypopyon: Large, immobile, non-sterile, even in small ulcer
  • Perforation: Rare but possible

Investigations
  • Corneal Scraping: For microbiological examination
  • Wet KOH Mount: Filamentous fungi or yeast-like fungi (Candida)
  • Culture: Sabouraud's agar for fungal culture
  • PCR: For rapid identification of pathogens
  • Corneal Biopsy: For deep stromal abscess or negative cultures

Treatment
  • Topical Antifungal Agents: Natamycin 5%, Voriconazole, Amphotericin-B, Nystatin
  • Oral Antifungal Agents: Ketoconazole, Voriconazole (for severe ulcers)
  • Surgical Management:
    • Repeated Scraping: Removal of necrotic material
    • Cauterization Options: Carbolic acid (100%), Trichloroacetic acid (10%–20%), Povidone-iodine (5%)
    • Therapeutic Keratoplasty: Corneal transplantation

Bacterial and Fungal Keratitis:

 

BACTERIAL KERATITIS (Option B)

FUNGAL KERATITIS

Etiology
  • S. aureus (worldwide)
  • S. epidermidis (India)
  • Aspergillus

Examination Findings
  • Fluorescein stain positive ulcer
  • Hypopyon (sterile)
  • Stromal edema
  • Descemet’s membrane folds
  • Keratic precipitates due to anterior uveitis
  • Signs >>> symptoms
  • Dry/rough ulcer
  • Has projecting ends
  • Thick immobile unsterile hypopyon
  • Satellite nodules are infective and have immune reaction- Wessley ring
  • IOP is high

Treatment
  • Empirical monotherapy: Moxifloxacin, gatifloxacin, besifloxacin
  • Duo therapy: Gram positive + gram negative. Combination of Cefazolin with Gentamicin or Cefuroxime with Gentamicin.
  • Cycloplegics and mydriatics
  • Antifungals: Natamycin 5%, amphotericin B
  • Steroids are contraindicated

Simplex Keratitis (Option A): Caused due to infection by Herpes simplex virus (HSV-1). Unlike Fungal keratitis, Simplex keratitis is acquired by kissing or in close contact with an infected person. Dendritic ulcer with budding pattern is suggestive of Simplex keratitis.

Acanthameoba keratitis (option D): Usually seen in contact lens users, pseudodendritic pattern with tapering ends is suggestive of Acanathamoeba Keratitis.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent laryngeal cartilages is least prone to calcification?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Epiglottis

Explanation:

  • Epiglottis is least prone to calcification because it is composed of elastic cartilage, which resists calcification compared to hyaline cartilage. Elastic cartilage maintains its flexibility and does not undergo the age-related ossification seen in other laryngeal cartilages.

 

Type of Cartilage

Paired Cartilage

Unpaired Cartilage

Hyaline Cartilage

(Calcifies with age)

Arytenoid

Thyroid, Cricoid

Elastic Cartilage

Corniculate, Cuneiform

Epiglottis

Epiglottis

  • Unpaired Elastic Cartilage
  • Shape: Leaf-shaped yellow elastic cartilage.
  • Location: Forms the anterior wall of the laryngeal inlet.
  • Attachments:
    • Connected to the hyoid bone by the hyoepiglottic ligament, dividing it into suprahyoid and infrahyoid portions.
    • The petiole attaches it to the thyroid cartilage just above the vocal cords.
  • Anterior Surface:
    • Preepiglottic Space: Located in front of the epiglottis, between the anterior surface and the thyrohyoid membrane/upper thyroid cartilage. Filled with fat, it may be involved in supraglottic cancers or the base of tongue carcinomas.
  • Posterior Surface:
    • Tubercle of Epiglottis: A bulge that may obstruct the view of the anterior commissure during indirect laryngoscopy.
    • Contains pits for mucous glands and occasional perforations, which may facilitate cancer spread to the preepiglottic space.
  • Clinical Significance:
    • Cancer Spread: Supraglottic cancers can invade the pre-epiglottic space through epiglottic perforations.
    • Non-Essential for Swallowing: The epiglottis can be safely amputated in cases of cancer or trauma without significant risk of aspiration.

 

Thyroid (Option A): The thyroid cartilage is made of hyaline cartilage, which tends to calcify with age, especially after the third decade of life.

Cricoid (Option B): Like the thyroid cartilage, the cricoid cartilage is also composed of hyaline cartilage and is prone to calcification as part of the normal ageing process.

Arytenoid (Option C): The arytenoid cartilage consists of hyaline cartilage in its base and elastic cartilage in its apex, but the hyaline portion is susceptible to calcification over time.

questions.text: Which nerve is accountable for causing ear pain following a tonsillectomy procedure among the options provided?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Glossopharyngeal nerve

Explanation:

Glossopharyngeal nerve: The glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) provides sensory innervation to the oropharynx and tonsillar region. It also has referred sensory pathways to the ear through its tympanic branch (Jacobson's nerve). This referral pathway explains the ear pain commonly experienced after a tonsillectomy.

 

Facial nerve (Option B): The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) is primarily involved in motor innervation to the muscles of facial expression and does not provide sensory innervation to the tonsillar or pharyngeal region.

Trigeminal nerve (Option C): The trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V) provides sensory innervation to the face, including the external ear via its auriculotemporal branch, but it is not directly involved in tonsillar pain.

Vagus nerve (Option D): The vagus nerve (cranial nerve X) provides sensory innervation to parts of the larynx and pharynx, but it is less commonly associated with referred ear pain in tonsillectomy cases.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a neonate who presents with symptoms of photophobia and excessive tearing, along with a clinical examination showing a normal tear passage and a clear, but abnormally large cornea, and the presence of Haab's striae in the eye image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Buphthalmos

Explanation:

The presence of classic symptoms- watering, photophobia with abnormally large cornea in a neonate are all consistent with Buphthalmos- Congenital glaucoma.

Primary Congenital Glaucoma:

Types
  • Newborn glaucoma/ True congenital glaucoma: Elevated intraocular pressure is present during intrauterine life, resulting in ocular enlargement at birth. Typically presents within the first month of life.
  • Infantile: ≤ 3 yrs of age
  • Juvenile: > 3 yrs of age

 

(Buphthalmos: meaning "bull-like eyes," is a condition characterized by the enlargement of the eyeball. It typically manifests before the age of 3 years and results from the accumulation and retention of aqueous humor.)

Pathogenesis
  • Trabeculodysgenesis
  • Angle Recess Absence
  • Iris Insertion Types
    • Flat Insertion: Reveals the ciliary body and scleral spur.
    • Concave Insertion: Obscures the scleral spur and ciliary body.

 

Clinical Features
  • Classic Triad: Lacrimation, photophobia, and blepharospasm; often accompanied by eye rubbing.
  • Corneal Signs:
    • Oedema: Early sign, may progress to permanent opacity.
    • Enlargement: Corneal diameter >13 mm confirms enlargement; >16 mm indicates poor prognosis.
  • Haab’s Striae: Tears in Descemet's membrane, visible as opaque lines.
  • Additional Features:
    • Deep Anterior Chamber: Indicates elevated IOP.
    • Optic Disc Changes: Variable cupping and atrophy.
    • Raised IOP: Elevated but not acute.
    • Axial Myopia: Due to increased axial length.

Management

Direct Goniotomy followed by Trabeculotomy - preferred management for Congenital Glaucoma

Keratoconus (Option B): is frequently due to congenital weakness of cornea, though it manifests only after puberty. In keratoconus, the cornea thins near the center and progressively bulges forwards, with the apex of the cone always being slightly below the center of the cornea. Important signs include: Munson sign (acute bulge given to the lower lid when the patient looks down), acute hydrops (due to ruptures in the Descemet’s membrane), Vogt striae and Fleischer ring may be seen in the later stages.

Trachoma (Option C): is the chronic inflammatory disease affecting primarily the conjunctiva, but later secondarily affecting the lids and the cornea. The organism responsible is Chlamydia trachomatis. From the clinical point of view, the diagnostic features of trachoma depend on the following characteristics: Follicles in the upper palpebral conjunctiva (Sago-grain appearance), pannus, limbal follicles or their sequelae as Herbert pits, in later stages, typical stellate trachomatous scarring in the conjunctiva.

Keratoglobus (Option D): is a congenital anomaly in which there is hemispherical protrusion of the whole cornea, occurring bilaterally. It is familial and hereditary. It differs from buphthalmos in that the intraocular pressure is normal, cornea is clear, refractive errors are with-the-rule astigmatism, angle of the anterior chamber normal and there is no cupping of the optical disc.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with a painless genital ulcer, as shown below. A microscopy of a sample from the lesion is also shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Granuloma inguinale

Explanation:

The clinical scenario of beefy red painless genital ulcer is indicative of Donovanosis or granuloma inguinale

  • Klebsiella granulomatis, a gram-negative bacteria, is the causative organism for granuloma inguinale, also known as Donovanosis.
  • Granuloma inguinale is a chronic sexually transmitted disease in which painless, beefy-red ulcers develop in the genital and inguinal regions.

Klebsiella granulomatis

Granuloma inguinale

Symptoms: Painless, beefy-red genital or anal ulcers, tissue granulation, bleeding from lesions

Microscopy: Donovan bodies are seen, they are intracytoplasmic inclusions found in macrophages and are a diagnostic feature of this condition.

Lymphogranuloma venereum (Option B) is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, characterized by a painless genital ulcer with painful lymphadenopathy(Inguinal bubos). The inguinal lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament swell up and appear like groove sign.

Chancroid (Option C) also called Chancre/chancroid, is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi characterized by painful genital ulcer.

Gonorrhea (Option D) is caused by Neisseria Gonorrhoeae. It usually presents as cervicitis, prostatitis, urethritis, or vaginitis associated with purulent discharge out of the urethral or vaginal meatus.

questions.text: AKIN and RIFLE criteria is used for classification of which of the folowing coditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Acute kidney injury

Explanation:

  • The AKIN (Acute Kidney Injury Network) and RIFLE (Risk, Injury, Failure, Loss, End-stage kidney disease) criteria are used to classify and stage acute kidney injury (AKI). These criteria help healthcare professionals assess the severity of AKI and guide treatment decisions.

RIFLE Classification Table for Acute Kidney Injury (AKI):

Class

SCr/GFR Criteria

Urine Output (UO) Criteria

Risk

↑ SCr × 1.5 or ↓ GFR > 25%

< 0.5 mL/kg/h for 6 hours

Injury

↑ SCr × 2 or ↓ GFR > 50%

< 0.5 mL/kg/h for 12 hours

Failure

↑ SCr × 3 or ↓ GFR > 75%

or

Baseline SCr ≥ 353.6 μmol/L (≥ 4 mg/dL) +

↑ SCr > 44.2 μmol/L (> 0.5 mg/dL)

< 0.3 mL/kg/h for 24 hours

or

Anuria for 12 hours

Loss of Kidney Function

Complete loss of kidney function for > 4 weeks

-

End-Stage Kidney Disease

Complete loss of kidney function for > 3 months

-
  • SCr = Serum Creatinine
  • GFR = Glomerular Filtration Rate
  • UO = Urine Output

AKIN (Acute Kidney Injury Network) Classification Table for AKI:

Stage

Serum Creatinine (SCr) Criteria

Urine Output (UO) Criteria

1

↑ SCr ≥ 26.5 μmol/L (≥ 0.3 mg/dL)

or

↑ SCr 150–200% (1.5–2 times)

< 0.5 mL/kg/h for > 6 hours

2

↑ SCr > 200–300% (> 2–3 times)

< 0.5 mL/kg/h for > 12 hours

3

Baseline SCr ≥ 353.6 μmol/L (≥ 4 mg/dL) +

↑ SCr ≥ 44.2 μmol/L (≥ 0.5 mg/dL)

or

↑ SCr > 300% (> 3 times)

or

Patients requiring Renal Replacement Therapy (RRT), regardless of SCr or UO at the time of initiation.

< 0.3 mL/kg/h for 24 hours or

Anuria for 12 hours

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a female patient, aged 65, who visits the outpatient department with symptoms of breathlessness and fatigue? During examination, the patient's neck veins were engorged, and her jugular venous pulse displayed a swift X and Y descent.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Constrictive pericarditis

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis is constrictive pericarditis.
  • Constrictive pericarditis is a condition characterized by inflammation and fibrosis of the pericardium, the sac-like structure surrounding the heart. It leads to the stiffening of the pericardium, impairing the normal filling and functioning of the heart.

Constrictive Pericarditis:

  • Progressive inflammation, thickening, fibrosis, and calcification of the pericardium restrict heart filling.
  • Calcification can extend into the myocardium, impairing myocardial contraction.
  • Restricted ventricular filling leads to elevated atrial pressures, causing:
    • Atrial hypertrophy
    • Atrial dilation
    • Atrial fibrillation (common).
  • Primarily manifests as systemic venous congestion (lung congestion is rare).

Examination Findings:

Finding

Description

Elevated JVP with rapid y descent

Reflects rapid early diastolic filling of the right ventricle due to pressure gradient.

Fatigue

Caused by the heart’s inability to meet circulatory demands.

Rapid, low-volume pulse

Restricted filling limits stroke volume, weakening the pulse.

Pericardial knock

A loud early S3 from the thickened pericardium during diastolic filling.

Kussmaul’s sign

Paradoxical rise in JVP during inspiration.

Hepatomegaly

Liver enlargement due to increased venous pressure.

Ascites

Abdominal fluid accumulation due to systemic venous congestion.

Peripheral oedema

Swelling in the extremities from fluid retention.

Pulsus paradoxus

A fall in systolic BP (10mm Hg) during inspiration, potentially impalpable pulse.

Atrial fibrillation

Common due to atrial hypertrophy and dilation.

 

Cardiac tamponade (Option B): Typically presents with elevated JVP, but it shows a prominent X descent and an absent Y descent (due to impaired filling), not rapid X and Y descents.

Dilated cardiomyopathy (Option C): This condition generally presents with signs of heart failure and an elevated JVP, but the JVP waveform does not typically show rapid X and Y descents.

Restrictive cardiomyopathy (Option D): This condition can present with symptoms similar to constrictive pericarditis, but it usually has a slow Y descent in the JVP rather than a rapid one.

questions.text: Which of the following instruments are sterilized by gamma radiation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Syringes, needles, and catheters

Explanation:

Radiation:

Ionising

Features:

  • High penetration power
  • Sporicidal action +
  • Known as Cold radiation (do not increase surface heat)
  • Examples: Gamma rays, X-rays, Cosmic rays

Uses:

  • Plastics, syringes, catheters
  • Catgut sutures - Gamma (γ) rays

Non-ionising

Features:

  • Low penetration power
  • Only bactericidal action +
  • Examples: UV rays, infrared rays

Uses:

  • Plastics, syringes, catheters

Mechanism of action
  • DNA damage by Dimer formation

Quality control agent

  • Bacillus pumilus

Contaminated clothes and animal carcasses (Option B) These are sterilized through Incineration.

Gloves and aprons (Option C) These are usually sterilized by autoclaving processes.

Bacterial vaccines and intravenous solutions (Option D) These are usually sterilized by autoclaving at 60° C for one hour.

questions.text: A comatose elderly patient with a weight of approximately 70 kilograms is presented to the emergency department. During examination, it was determined that the patient's serum glucose levels were 500mg/dL, arterial pH is 7.30, and there is an elevation in plasma ketones levels. However, the serum potassium levels are within the normal range. In order to treat this patient, which of the following should be added to the saline solution?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Insulin

Explanation:

  • The patient's clinical features suggest diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), a potentially life-threatening complication of uncontrolled diabetes. Insulin is the mainstay of treatment in DKA as it helps lower blood glucose levels and suppresses ketone production.
  • DKA is characterized by hyperglycemia, metabolic acidosis, and the presence of ketones in the blood. To manage DKA, it is crucial to address the underlying cause of hyperglycemia and correct metabolic derangements.

Updated Management of Diabetic Ketoacidosis (ISPAD 2022):

Contraindication of Insulin Drip:

  • Insulin should be withheld if the serum potassium level is below 3.3 mmol/L.
  • The target is to maintain serum potassium levels above 3.5 mmol/L (3.5 meq/L) to start the insulin drip.
  • Hypokalemia can lead to diaphragmatic paralysis and potentially result in respiratory arrest.

 

Bicarbonate (Option B) administration is generally not recommended for DKA unless the patient has severe acidosis (arterial pH <7.0). In this case, the arterial pH of 7.33 does not indicate severe acidosis, and thus, bicarbonate is not necessary.

Potassium (Option C) levels are normal in this patient, so additional potassium supplementation may not be required. However, regular monitoring of potassium levels is essential during the treatment of DKA, as insulin administration can cause a shift of potassium into the cells, leading to potential hypokalemia. If the patient's potassium levels decrease during treatment, appropriate potassium supplementation can be initiated.

The specific dose of 14 units of regular insulin intravenously (Option D) is not mentioned in the initial description and cannot be determined solely based on the given information. The insulin dosage should be individualized based on the patient's clinical condition, blood glucose levels, and response to treatment. It is typically administered as an initial bolus followed by continuous intravenous infusion.

questions.text: Identify the deformity depicted in the image:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Boutonniere deformity

Explanation:

Boutonniere deformity is associated with rheumatoid arthritis, and it presents with

  • Proximal interphalangeal joint flexion (PIP).
  • Distal interphalangeal flexion (DIP) hyperextension.

Resulting in a finger with a bent appearance at the middle joint and extended at the end joint.

Articular deformity and changes in rheumatoid arthritis

Articular changes

Autoimmune inflammation mediates pannus formation, eroding the articular cartilage and bone.

Metacarpophalangeal joint (MCP), proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint and wrist joint are involved

Deformities

 

 

Swan neck deformity (Option A)

  • Extension at proximal interphalangeal joint (PIP)
  • Flexion at the distal interphalangeal joint (DIP): The DIP joint is not involved; flexion occurs due to tension on the tendons attached to the base of Distal phalanges

Boutonniere deformity

  • Flexion at PIP and extension at DIP
  • Both swan neck and boutonniere deformity can occur in different fingers of the same hand.

Z-line deformity (Option C)

  • Subluxation of the first metacarpophalangeal joint.
  • Hyperextension of interphalangeal joint.

 

Mallet finger deformity (Option D) involves an inability to extend the DIP joint due to a tendon injury without affecting the PIP joint. It is usually a sports injury and is not seen in rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: A patient presents with flaccid bullous lesions as shown in the image below involving the entire trunk and oral cavity. Acantholytic cells are seen on Tzank smear. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Pemphigus vulgaris

Explanation:

  • As the patient is presenting with flaccid bullous lesions involving the entire trunk and oral cavity, along with the presence of acantholytic cells on Tzanck smear, the most probable diagnosis would be Pemphigus vulgaris.
  • However, a definitive diagnosis would require additional clinical evaluation, including a biopsy and direct immunofluorescence testing.

Pemphigus vulgaris (PV):

  • PV is the most common chronic autoimmune blistering disease caused by antibodies against desmosomal adhesion proteins.
  • They are characterized by the presence of flaccid blisters filled with clear fluid present on normal skin or an erythematous base.
  • The blisters rupture producing painful erosion.
  • Mucosal involvement is a very important and one of the distinguishing features of PV.

Histopathology:

  • Intraepidermal cleavage with acantholysis (detached keratinocytes) primarily localized to the suprabasal region
  • Separation of basal keratinocytes along the basement membrane zone, resulting in an appearance that resembles a "row of tombstones"
  • The target antigens for PV are most commonly Desmoglein 3 and sometimes Desmoglein 1. The image below shows the common target antigen in Intraepidermal Immunobullous Disorders.

 

Antigen affected

Immunobullous disease-associated

Desmoglein 1

Pemphigus foliaceous (Subcorneal split)

Desmoglein 3 > 1

Pemphigus Vulgaris (Suprabasal split)

Desmocolin

IgA pemphigus

Desmoplakin

Paraneoplastic pemphigus

 

Pemphigus vulgaris

Pemphigus foliaceus

Suprabasal split

Subcorneal splits

DSG 3> 1 is target antigen

DSG 1 is target antigen

Mucosa involved

Mucosa not involved

Pemphigus vegetans is the variant

Pemphigus Erythematosus ( Senear Usher Syndrome) is a variant (a/w SLE)

Clinically present with flaccid blisters and erosions

Clinically present with erosions and rarely blisters

 

Although pemphigus foliaceous may present with similar features it does not classically involve the mucous membranes.

Dermatitis herpetiformis is a chronic, intensely itchy skin condition that is associated with celiac disease caused by gluten insensitivity.. It is characterized by clusters of small, intensely itchy vesicles and papules on the extensor surfaces of the elbows, knees, and buttocks.

Bullous pemphigoid is an autoimmune blistering disorder that primarily affects the elderly. It is characterized by tense bullae that typically occur on the flexural surfaces of the body, such as the armpits and groin.

questions.text: Which is the most common site for head and neck cancer in India?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Oral cavity

Explanation:

  • In India, the oral cavity is the most common site for head and neck cancer. This high prevalence is largely attributed to the widespread use of tobacco in various forms (smoking, chewing, betel quid) and alcohol consumption. Poor oral hygiene and HPV infection are also contributory factors.

 

Nasopharynx (Option A): While nasopharyngeal carcinoma is relatively common in some regions (e.g., Southeast Asia), it is not the most common site of head and neck cancer in India.

Oropharynx (Option B): Oropharyngeal cancers, including those involving the tonsils and base of the tongue, are associated with HPV infection but are less common than oral cavity cancers in India.

Hypopharynx (Option D): Hypopharyngeal cancers are associated with smoking and alcohol use but are less frequent than oral cavity cancers in the Indian population.

questions.text: Addison's disease is characterized by all of the following symptoms except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hyperglycemia

Explanation:

  • Individuals with Addison's disease may experience hypoglycemia (Not Hyperglycemia) (low blood sugar) due to the inadequate production of cortisol, a hormone involved in regulating blood sugar levels.

Addison's disease refers to primary adrenocortical failure.

Etiology

  • Autoimmune: M/C/C Worldwide
    • Sporadic
    • Polyglandular syndromes
  • Tuberculosis: M/C/C in India
  • Histoplasmosis
  • HIV/AIDS
  • Metastatic carcinoma
  • Bilateral adrenalectomy

Clinical features

  • Glucocorticoid insufficiency:
    • Weight loss, anorexia, malaise, weakness, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea or constipation, postural hypotension, shock, hypoglycemia, hyponatremia (Option B) (dilutional), hypercalcemia
  • Mineralocorticoid insufficiency:
    • Hypotension (Option D), shock, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia (Option C)
  • ACTH excess: Pigmentation
  • Adrenal androgen insufficiency: Decreased body hair and loss of libido, especially in females

questions.text: A 35 year old female patient with fever and malar rashes was found to have vegetations on either side of the heart valves. What can be the diagnosis of the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Libman sacks endocarditis

Explanation

  • A 35 year old female presents with fever and malar rashes suggests that this could be systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and the cardiac involvement of SLE shows Libman-Sacks endocarditis (LSE).
  • Libman-Sacks endocarditis is a form of nonbacterial endocarditis (also known as nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis) that is commonly associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). It is characterized by the presence of small, sterile vegetations on both sides of the heart valves, particularly the mitral and aortic valves.

Systemic Involvement in SLE

System

Manifestations

Pulmonary system
  • Pleuritis (most common): Prevalence (30 - 50%)
  • Pneumonitis
  • Atelectasis
  • Reduced lung volume and
  • Pulmonary ﬁbrosis
  • Shrinking lung syndrome, (< 5%)
  • Intra-alveolar hemorrhage
  • Pulmonary HTN (< 5 %) (Option C)
  • Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) (< 5%)

Musculoskeletal system
  • It is the most commonly involved system
  • Polyarthritis (symmetrical)
  • Polyarthralgia
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Myositis
  • Jaccoud arthropathy is a reversible deformity caused by ligament laxity, capsule fibrosis, and muscular imbalance.
  • Axial skeletal involvement is uncommon.

Renal system
  • Lupus nephritis (most common)
  • Proteinuria
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Rarely End-stage Renal Disease (ESRD)

Nervous system
  • Headache, Seizures, Stroke, Polyneuropathy, TIA, Acute confusional state, Movement disorder, Aseptic meningitis, Myelopathy, Psychosis and Mood disorders.

Cardiovascular system
  • Coronary artery disease - common cause of death
  • Pericarditis
  • Coronary vasculitis
  • Myocarditis
  • Libman sacks endocarditis
  • Accelerated atherosclerosis

Hematological manifestations
  • Anemia of chronic disease
  • Leucopenia
  • Lymphopenia
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Autoimmune Hemolytic anemia-MCC of anemia in SLE
  • Splenomegaly

GI involvement
  • Abdominal pain
  • Nausea, diarrhoea
  • Abnormal liver enzymes

Ocular manifestation
  • Sicca syndrome: Dry eyes (keratoconjunctivitis sicca) and dry mouth (xerostomia).
  • Conjunctivitis
  • Episcleritis
  • Vasculitis

 

While infective endocarditis (Option A) can also cause vegetations on the heart valves, the presence of malar rashes suggests an autoimmune condition like SLE rather than an infectious etiology.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a man of 45 years who arrives at the emergency department with an abrupt loss of vision and experiencing painful movements of the eye? Upon examination, a relative afferent pupillary defect is observed in the affected eye. Further visual field testing demonstrates a central scotoma in the same eye.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Optic neuritis

Explanation:

Clinical scenario of sudden visual loss associated with Relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) is suggestive of Optic Neuritis.

Optic neuritis:

Classification of Optic neuritis:

 

Papillitis

Retrobulbar Neuritis

Neuroretinitis (Option D)

Site

Optic disc

Optic nerve behind the eyeball.

Optic disc and surrounding retina in the macular area.

Characteristic features
  • Fundoscopy reveals a blurred disc margin due to leakage and increased capillary permeability, edematous and hyperaemic disc, and physiological cup is obliterated.
  • Pain on eye elevation
  • RAPD (relative afferent pupillary defect) is observed.
  • Fundoscopic examination typically reveals normal optic disc, at least initially, which is why the classic phrase, “the patient sees nothing, and the doctor sees nothing” is often used to describe retrobulbar neuritis.
  • A macular star is seen in fundoscopy (accumulation of lipids).
  • Optic atrophy present

Clinical features
  • Visual loss: Monocular sudden, progressive and profound visual loss is the hallmark of acute optic neuritis.
  • Dark adaptation may be lowered.
  • Visual obscuration in bright light is a typical symptom of acute optic neuritis.
  • Impairment of color vision is always present in optic neuritis.
  • Uhthoff's symptom: Episodic transient obscuration of vision on exertion and on exposure to heat, which recovers on resting or moving away from the heat, occurs in patients with isolated optic neuritis.
  • Pulfrich's phenomenon: Depth perception may be impaired, particularly for the moving object.
  • Visual acuity is usually reduced markedly.
  • Visual field changes: The most common field defect in optic neuritis is a relative central or centrocecal scotoma.
  • Contrast sensitivity is impaired.

Management of Optic neuritis:

Treatment

Indications

Details

Conservative management

(Observation and Monitoring)
  • Mild symptoms
  • Known history of similar episodes
  • Many cases improve spontaneously.
  • Suitable for mild symptoms but not recommended for severe cases or first episodes.

High-Dose Corticosteroids
  • Severe vision loss
  • No history of previous episodes
  • MRI evidence of demyelination
  • Intravenous methylprednisolone (1 g daily for 3 days) followed by oral prednisolone taper as established by the ONTT trial (Optic Neuritis Treatment Trial).

Optic nerve glioma (Option A): is a tumor that can affect the optic nerve, but it is more commonly seen in children and young adults. MRI shows fusiform thickening of the intra-orbital portion of the optic nerve.

Eale's disease (Option C): Also known as retinal vasculitis, typically presents with recurrent episodes of retinal hemorrhages, floaters, and vision loss in young males.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a 14-year-old male who has been experiencing repeated nosebleeds, without any history of injury, along with nasal blockage and excessive nasal discharge? During examination, a solid, purplish growth is observed on the back of the nasopharynx.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma

Explanation:

  • Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma: This benign but locally aggressive vascular tumour occurs predominantly in adolescent males. It commonly presents with repeated episodes of epistaxis (nosebleeds), nasal obstruction, and sometimes nasal discharge. Examination often reveals a solid, vascular, purplish mass in the nasopharynx. This is the most probable diagnosis in a 14-year-old male with these symptoms and findings.

 

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA)

Site of Origin

Posterior nasal cavity, near the superior margin of the sphenopalatine foramen, where the sphenoid and palatine bones meet.

Gross Appearance

Reddish-purple, lobulated, sessile mass covered by mucosa; lacks a capsule despite being benign.

Microscopic Appearance
  • Vascular Tissue: Endothelium-lined spaces with incomplete/absent muscle coats, leading to bleeding; peripheral vessels are thin-walled, central vessels hyperplastic.
  • Stromal Cells: Stellate or spindle-shaped cells that produce collagen, affecting tumor firmness.

Immunohistochemistry
  • Fibroblasts, collagen, myofibroblasts, mast cells, and occasionally giant cells are present.
  • Reactivity to smooth muscle actin and beta-catenin, suggesting beta-catenin’s role in growth.

Growth Factors
  • JNA development likely results from a combination of hormonal influence, growth factors, and genetic factors.
  • Androgen Receptors: Present in 75% of JNA tumors, indicating male hormone involvement.
  • VEGF: Promotes endothelial and stromal cell growth.
  • IGF-II: Role is less clear.
  • Genetics: C-MYC proto-oncogene found in larger tumors; may interact with androgen receptor and beta-catenin genes.

 

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma (Option A): This malignant tumour usually occurs in older adults and is rare in this age group. It often presents with neck lymphadenopathy, nasal obstruction, or ear symptoms but is unlikely to present with a solid, vascular growth in a young male.

Rhabdomyosarcoma (Option B): This is a malignant soft tissue tumour that can occur in the nasopharynx but is rare and less likely to cause repeated epistaxis without systemic signs like weight loss or fatigue.

Pyogenic granuloma (Option C): This is a vascular lesion but typically occurs on the nasal septum or oral mucosa, not in the nasopharynx. It is usually smaller, friable, and more superficial.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions leads to the development of wing beating tremor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Wilson’s disease

Explanation:

  • Wing beating tremor, also known as asterixis, refers to a flapping tremor of the hands and arms resembling a bird's wing flapping. It is associated with the presence of hepatic encephalopathy, which can occur in various conditions affecting the liver and central nervous system. Among the options, Wilson's disease is the most likely cause of wing beating tremor.
  • Wilson's disease is a genetic disorder characterized by impaired copper metabolism. The accumulation of copper in the brain can result in neurological symptoms, such as movement disorders. One of the characteristic movement disorders seen in Wilson's disease is a wing beating tremor.
  • It can be elicited by having patients extend their arms and bend their wrists back. In this maneuver, patients who are encephalopathic have a “liver flap” that is, a sudden forward movement of the wrist.

Clinical Features of Wilson's Disease

Hepatic Symptoms
  • Chronic Hepatitis: Jaundice, hepatomegaly, elevated liver enzymes due to copper accumulation in the liver.
  • Cirrhosis: Portal hypertension, variceal bleeding as a result of long-term copper accumulation and fibrosis.
  • Acute Liver Failure: Coagulopathy, jaundice, encephalopathy.

Neurological Symptoms
  • Movement Disorders: Tremors (flapping or wind-beating tremor), dystonia, ataxia, dysarthria due to copper accumulation in the basal ganglia.
  • Parkinsonism-like symptoms : Rigidity, bradykinesia, cogwheel rigidity from copper accumulation in the basal ganglia.
  • Psychiatric: Depression, personality changes, cognitive decline.

Ocular Features
  • Kayser-Fleischer Rings: Brown/greenish rings in the cornea due to copper deposition in Descemet's membrane.

 

  • Sunflower Cataract: Rare, (copper deposition in the lens).

Renal Features
  • Renal Tubular Acidosis (Fanconi Syndrome): Due to copper accumulation in renal tubules.

Hematologic Features
  • Hemolytic Anemia: Copper-induced red cell damage.

Skeletal Features
  • Osteopenia, osteoporosis, joint arthropathy

questions.text: An El Tor Vibrio was identified as the causative agent of a diarrhea epidemic. Which of the following is not a characteristic feature of this organism?

choices.text: Resistant to El Tor phage V
Not susceptible to group IV phage

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Resistant to El Tor phage V

Explanation:

Differences between classical cholera and El Tor vibrios:

Tests/Characteristics

Classical

El Tor

Tests:

Hemolysis of sheep RBCs

Negative

Positive

Voges-Proskauer (Option C ruled out)

Negative

Positive

Chick erythrocyte agglutination

Negative

Positive

Polymyxin B sensitivity (Option B ruled out)

Sensitive

Resistant

Group IV phage susceptibility (Option D ruled out)

Susceptible

Not susceptible

El Tor phage 5 susceptibility (Option A)

Not susceptible

Susceptible

Others:

Mortality

Higher

Lower

Carrier rate

Low

High

questions.text: A young lady presented to the ENT OPD with a history of sudden onset unilateral hearing loss, tinnitus, and dizziness following an episode of acute otitis media two weeks back. Rinne’s test and fistula test were positive. She had refused treatment then and currently came with complaints of worsened hearing loss in the affected ear. On examination, the fistula test was negative. What would be the most likely finding on the Rinne test in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) False negative

Explanation:

  • The most likely explanation for this scenario is that, after initial inner ear involvement (possible labyrinthine fistula or perilymphatic fistula), progressive damage (possibly sensorineural deafness due to labyrinthitis or complete loss of function) has occurred.
  • Rinne’s test would likely show a "false negative" result
  • The Rinne test compares bone conduction (BC) to air conduction (AC) of sound. In conductive hearing loss, BC > AC (i.e., the sound is heard better through bone conduction). In sensorineural hearing loss, AC > BC (i.e., the sound is heard better through air conduction).

  • In severe sensorineural hearing loss, the patient cannot hear either air or bone conduction. So Rinne’s test appears negative (bone > air), mimicking a conductive loss, even though it’s actually profound sensorineural loss.

  • The fistula test, now negative, suggests no more labyrinthine response; severe sensorineural loss is present.

 

True Positive (Option A): A true positive result would suggest that air conduction is better than bone conduction in the ear with hearing loss, which is inconsistent with the clinical picture of worsening hearing loss and a likely sensorineural component.

True Negative (Option B): A true negative would indicate that the patient has normal hearing, which does not match the patient's reported symptoms of hearing loss and worsening condition.

False Positive (Option C): A false positive result on the Rinne test would suggest that bone conduction is better than air conduction in a patient with sensorineural hearing loss. However, given the worsening hearing loss, this is unlikely in this case.

questions.text: What could be the most likely diagnosis for a 5-year-old boy presenting with severe itching, sensitivity to light, and sticky discharge from his eyes. Upon examination the following findings were seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Vernal keratoconjunctivitis

Explanation:

The patient's symptoms of intense itching and sticky (ropy) discharge, along with the presence of hard, flat-topped papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva with a cobblestone appearance as shown in the image are characteristic of Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis (VKC).
Vernal keratoconjunctivitis (Spring catarrh):

  • It is a recurrent bilateral conjunctivitis that tends to occur with the onset of warm weather. It primarily affects young children and adolescents, particularly boys.
  • Type I & IV HSR reaction > Type IV HSR

Course

The condition typically starts in childhood and may resolve on its own over 5–10 years.

Symptoms

Burning, Itching, Photophobia (sensitivity to light), and lacrimation (excessive tearing).

Signs
  • Palpebral Form: Hypertrophied palpebral conjunctiva with a cobblestone appearance; bluish-white color; dense fibrous tissue with thickened epithelium.
  • Limbal or Bulbar Form: Opacification at the limbus, gelatinous thickening, and Horner–Trantas dots

Pseudogerontoxon/cupid’s bow (which resembles arcus senilis) is a grayish-white ring at the limbus seen in severe limbal vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC).

  • Shield ulcers are a significant complication of VKC, particularly in severe cases. These microerosions typically form on the upper third of the cornea.
  • Mixed form: Exhibits characteristics of both the tarsal (palpebral) and limbal subtypes, typically presenting in only one eye.
  • Maxwell Lyon's sign is a pseudomembrane formed due to excessive mucus deposition on the papilla resulting in cobblestone papillae.

Histology

In the palpebral form, hypertrophied papillae are observed, rich in eosinophils and other inflammatory cells.

Treatment
  • Topical therapy:
    • Antihistamines - Levocabastine & emedastine
    • Mast cell stabilizers - Sodium cromoglicate
    • Mild steroids - Fluorometholone and loteprednol etabonate,
    • Acetylcysteine can control excess mucus.
  • Local therapy: Subtarsal steroid injections and cryotherapy for severe cases.
  • Surgical treatment: Excision of giant papillae and treatment of shield ulcers with debridement and amniotic membrane or bandage contact lens.
  • Cold compresses and tinted glasses for comfort.
  • Avoid eye rubbing

Trachoma (Option A): Sago-grain appearance of conjunctiva is seen in Trachoma.

Phlyctenular conjunctivitis (Option C): Type of hypersensitivity reaction to endogenous antigens like bacterial antigens, staphylococcal & tuberculosis antigens. It presents as a small, white, or yellowish nodule (phlyctenule) near the limbus and conjunctival congestion.

Xerophthalmia (Option D): Xerophthalmia is a spectrum of ocular disease caused due to vitamin A deficiency. It is characterized by night blindness (earliest feature), conjunctival xerosis, Bitot’s spot, corneal xerosis, ulcer, keratomalacia.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the Little's area?

choices.text: Keisselbach’s plexus is present in the Little’s area
It is situated at the posteroinferior part of the nasal septum
Anastomoses of 7 major arteries occur here

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Keisselbach’s plexus is present in the Little’s area

Explanation:

  • Little's area, also known as Kiesselbach's plexus, is a highly vascular region located in the anterior part of the nasal septum. It is a site of frequent epistaxis (nosebleeds) due to the rich network of blood vessels that anastomose here.
  • Keisselbach's plexus is a network of arteries formed by anastomoses of branches from the internal carotid artery (like the sphenopalatine artery) and the external carotid artery (including the superior labial artery and anterior ethmoidal artery), which supply the nasal septum.
  • Kiesselbach’s plexus, also known as Little's area, is a highly vascularised region in the anteroinferior portion of the nasal septum, where multiple arteries converge.
  • It is the most common site of anterior epistaxis, especially in children and young adults.

 

  • Vessels involved in forming the plexus

Artery

Branch of

Sphenopalatine artery

Maxillary artery

Anterior ethmoidal artery

Ophthalmic artery (from internal carotid artery)

Greater palatine artery

Maxillary artery

Superior labial artery

Facial artery (from external carotid artery)

Note: Posterior ethmoidal artery is not part of this plexus

Clinical Significance:

  • Anterior epistaxis occurs most often in children and young adults, usually due to trauma (nose-picking), dry air, infections, or irritants.
  • Epistaxis in this area is typically mild and self-limiting and can be controlled with local pressure or simple cauterization.

 

It is situated at the posteroinferior part of the nasal septum (Option B): is incorrect because Little's area is located at the anteroinferior part of the nasal septum, not the posterior.

Least common site for epistaxis (Option C): is incorrect because Little's area is the most common site for epistaxis, not the least.

Anastomoses of 7 major arteries occur here (Option D): is incorrect because the anastomoses of the major arteries involved in Little’s area are primarily derived from the internal and external carotid arteries, but not seven arteries. The arteries involved are generally 4-5, not seven.

questions.text: What is the Battle sign?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Mastoid ecchymosis

Explanation:

  • Mastoid ecchymosis is correct because Battle's sign refers to the presence of ecchymosis (bruising) over the mastoid process, which is typically a sign of a basilar skull fracture. This bruising appears behind the ear and is a late sign of head trauma.

 

Periorbital hematoma (Option B) is incorrect because periorbital hematoma, also known as "raccoon eyes," refers to bruising around the eyes, which is a sign of trauma to the face or base of the skull, but it is not Battle's sign.

Bezold abscess (Option C) is incorrect because a Bezold abscess is a collection of pus in the neck, often caused by a middle ear infection, and does not relate to the bruising over the mastoid.

Perichondritis (Option D) is incorrect because perichondritis refers to inflammation of the cartilage of the ear, typically caused by infection, but it does not involve bruising behind the ear.

questions.text: An elderly patient was rushed to the casualty following bouts of severe breathlessness. He reported a history of fever and cough for the past 3 days. Lab tests were done, and target sequences for the RdRp gene, E gene, N gene, and ORF1 were detected. What was the test done?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Real-time RT-PCR

Explanation:

The detection of the target sequences against the RdRp gene, E gene, N gene, and ORF1 confirms the diagnosis of coronavirus. Real-time RT-PCR is a gold standard test for the diagnosis of coronavirus

Real-Time RT-PCR for COVID-19 Diagnosis

  • Real-time reverse transcriptase PCR (RT-PCR) is the gold standard for diagnosing COVID-19.
  • Turnaround Time: The average time from sample receipt to result generation is approximately 4-5 hours.
  • Capacity: Can process up to 90 samples in a single run, making it efficient for frontline testing.
  • Gene Targets:
    • Screening (Genus Specific):
      • Spike protein (S)
      • Envelope protein (E)
      • Membrane protein (M)
      • Nucleocapsid protein (N)
    • Confirmation (Species Specific for SARS-CoV-2):
      • RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRp)
      • Open reading frames (ORF1a/b)
      • N2 nucleocapsid
  • Principle of Testing:
    • Qualitative real-time PCR amplifies target genes in the specimen using a thermocycler.
    • Fluorescence is generated when the amplicon binds to the probe, with the cycle threshold (Ct) indicating positivity.
    • A sample is considered positive if both screening and confirmatory genes are detected with a Ct value ≤ 40 cycles.
  • Detectability: NAAT can be positive as early as day 1 of symptom onset (usually 5 days post-infection) and generally declines by the third week, often becoming undetectable thereafter.

Automated Real-Time RT-PCR

  • Systems include Truenat and CBNAAT (Cartridge-based nucleic acid amplification test, e.g., GeneXpert).
  • Widely accessible
  • Turnaround Time: Quick results in 30-60 minutes.
  • Automation: Fully automated with minimal handling, reducing biosafety hazards.
  • Gene Targets:
    • CBNAAT: E gene for screening, N2 gene for confirmation.
    • Truenat: E gene for screening, RdRp gene for confirmation.
  • Disadvantages: Limited to 1-4 samples per run, suitable for low sample loads (24-48 samples/day).

Antigen Detection

  • Rapid chromatographic immunoassay (SD Biosensor) for qualitative detection of SARS-CoV-2 nucleocapsid protein.
  • Sample Collection: Nasopharyngeal swab immersed in viral extraction buffer to inactivate the virus and release the antigen.
  • Point-of-Care Testing: Conducted at the bedside within one hour; antigen stability is limited to one hour.
  • Performance: Highly specific (99–100%) but moderate sensitivity (50–84%); symptomatic but negative patients should be referred for RT-PCR testing.

Options A, B, and C are incorrect

questions.text: A patient with a history of fever for the past 4 days and sudden onset of breathlessness was admitted to ICU as he was deteriorating. He was unresponsive to the incremental flow rate of oxygen and his oxygen saturation was progressively decreasing. A chest x-ray was ordered and the findings are shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) ARDS

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis of this patient is Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS).
  • ARDS is a severe lung condition characterized by widespread inflammation and damage to the alveoli (air sacs) in the lungs. It can be triggered by various factors, including infection, sepsis, trauma, or inhalation injury. The key features of ARDS include acute onset of severe hypoxemia (low oxygen levels) that is refractory to supplemental oxygen, bilateral pulmonary infiltrates on imaging (such as the chest X-ray), and impaired lung compliance.

Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS):

  • ARDS is a diffuse neutrophilic alveolitis caused by infective & non-infective triggers.

Berlin definition of ARDS:

  • Onset within 1 week of a known clinical insult, or new or worsening respiratory symptoms
  • Bilateral opacities on chest X-ray, not fully explained by effusions, lobar/lung collapse or nodules
  • Respiratory failure not fully explained by cardiac failure or fluid overload.
  • Objective assessment (e.g. by echocardiography) must exclude hydrostatic oedema if no risk factor is present Impaired oxygenation

Pathophysiology:

  • Activated neutrophils & macrophages → capillary permeability ↑ → alveolar damage
  • Protein-rich exudate accumulation → hyaline membrane formation
  • Cytokine & chemokine release → inflammatory cell recruitment
  • Surfactant loss → alveolar collapse & ↓ lung compliance
  • Hypoxaemia & hypercapnia due to ventilation-perfusion mismatch

ARDS Severity (PaO2/FiO2 Ratio in kPa):

  • Mild: 40–26.6 kPa (300–200 mmHg)
  • Moderate: 26.6–13.3 kPa (200–100 mmHg)
  • Severe: ≤ 13.3 kPa (≤ 100 mmHg)
    (Measured on ≥5 cmH₂O PEEP or CPAP)

(CPAP = continuous positive airway pressure; PEEP = positive end-expiratory pressure)

Management:

  • Supportive care: Lung-protective mechanical ventilation, negative fluid balance, and treat underlying cause
  • Severe ARDS: Requires prone positioning, extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO)

 

Atelectasis (Option A) refers to the collapse or incomplete expansion of lung tissue. It can result from blockage of the airways, compression of the lung, or surfactant deficiency. While atelectasis can cause localized or segmental lung collapse, it typically does not lead to widespread bilateral infiltrates and severe hypoxemia.

Pulmonary fibrosis (Option C) typically presents with a gradual onset of symptoms, such as shortness of breath and cough, and the chest X-ray findings would show a reticular or honeycomb pattern.

questions.text: In the context of medical treatment, the V-Y procedure is employed for which of the subsequent conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Ectropion

Explanation:

The V-Y procedure is used in the management of mild cases of Cicatricial Ectropion.

Ectropion:

Type of Ectropion

Description

Causes

Clinical Features

Treatment

Involutional Ectropion
  • Most common; age-related
  • Horizontal laxity
  • Canthal tendon laxity
  • Epiphora
  • Tarsal thinning
  • Lagophthalmos
  • Medial conjunctivoplasty for mild cases.
  • Horizontal lid shortening for moderate cases.
  • Byron Smith's modified Kuhnt-Szymanowski operation for severe cases.
  • Lateral tarsal strip technique for generalized ectropion.

Cicatricial Ectropion
  • Scarring of anterior lamella
  • Trauma/surgery
  • Scarring conditions (e.g., blepharitis)
  • Scarring
  • Skin fibrosis
  • Mild cases: V-Y operation. (Option B)
  • Mild to moderate cases: Z-plasty (Elschnig's operation).
  • Severe cases: Excision of scar tissue and full-thickness skin grafting.

Paralytic Ectropion
  • Facial nerve palsy (Bell’s)
  • Bell’s palsy
  • Trauma/surgery
  • Exposure keratopathy
  • Temporary measures: Topical lubricants, eyelid taping, suture tarsorrhaphy.
  • Permanent measures (if needed): Horizontal lid tightening with/without middle lamellar buttress, palpebral sling operation.

Mechanical Ectropion
  • Mass or lesion pushing eyelid
  • Tumors
  • Conjunctival growths
  • Eyelid displacement
  • Conjunctival chemosis
  • Treat the underlying mechanical causes.

Congenital Ectropion
  • Present at birth
  • Tarsal plate atrophy
  • Down syndrome
  • Associated eyelid malformation
  • Mild cases may not require treatment.
  • Moderate or severe cases: Horizontal lid tightening and full-thickness skin graft.

V-Y procedures have NO benefit in treatment of Entropion (Option A), Blepharophimosis (Option C) and Ptosis (Option D).

questions.text: What is the preferred medication for treating Hyperthyroidism during the second trimester of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Carbimazole

Explanation:

  • Carbimazole is the preferred medication for treating hyperthyroidism during the second trimester of pregnancy. Carbimazole is a thyroid peroxidase inhibitor that has higher potency and longer half life than propylthiouracil. However, it crosses the placenta easily, and can cause aplasia cutis in the fetus. For this reason, Carbimazole is not administered during the 1st trimester.

Management of Hyperthyroidism in Pregnancy

Medical Management

First Trimester:

  • Propylthiouracil 100-300mg/day (three times daily)
  • Mechanism: Inhibits hormone synthesis + Thyroxine to Triiodothyronine conversion

Second/Third Trimester:

  • Methimazole 5-15mg/day (once daily)

Monitoring:

  • Thyroid Function Tests every 2-4 weeks
  • Thyroid Stimulating Hormone Receptor Antibodies: 18-22 weeks, 30-34 weeks
  • Target: Free Thyroxine upper normal, Thyroid Stimulating Hormone slightly low

Thyroid Storm Protocol
  1. Propanolol
  2. Potassium Iodide/Lugol's solution (60 minutes post-antithyroid drugs)
  3. Propylthiouracil/Methimazole administration
  4. Glucocorticoids
  5. Intensive care support
  6. Mortality: 20-30% if untreated

Teratogenicity

Methimazole Embryopathy:

  • Aplasia cutis
  • Choanal/esophageal atresia
  • Dysmorphic facies

PTU Associated:

  • Isolated anomalies
  • Situs inversus
  • Renal tract malformations

Contraindications
  • Radioactive iodine
  • First trimester thyroidectomy

Fetal Surveillance

Ultrasound markers:

  • Thyroid dimensions
  • Fetal heart rate (>160/min significant)
  • Growth parameters
  • Hydrops features
  • Bone maturation

 

Propyl Thiouracil (Option A): While propylthiouracil is the drug of choice during the first trimester of pregnancy due to lower risk of birth defects, it is not the preferred option during the second trimester. The switch to carbimazole is recommended after the first trimester due to its better efficacy and safety profile.

Sodium iodide (Option C): This medication is contraindicated during pregnancy as it can cross the placenta and affect fetal thyroid function. It can cause fetal hypothyroidism and goiter formation.

Radioactive iodine (Option D): Radioactive iodine is absolutely contraindicated during pregnancy as it readily crosses the placenta and can affect the fetal thyroid gland, potentially causing miscarriage or serious developmental issues. It should never be used during any stage of pregnancy.

questions.text: A COVID patient presented with fever, nasal congestion, and unilateral headache. Later, he developed facial pain and numbness, along with a blackish lesion. On Sabouraud Dextrose Agar (SDA), a cotton-wooly growth is seen. H&E staining shows non-septate hyphae branching at right angles/obtuse angles. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Mucormycosis

Explanation:

Mucormycosis

It is an invasive disease caused by zygomycetes (phycomycetes) - Rhizopus, Mucor and Absidia. Rhizopus Arrhizus is the most common pathogen

Rhizopus:

 Absidia

 Mucor (Lactophenol cotton blue stained):

 

Pathogenesis

Begins in the respiratory tract or nasal cavity, where spores germinate and form mycelia → invade adjacent tissues, leading to local destruction.

Fungi invade blood vessels, causing thrombosis and infarction in affected areas, which contributes to its high mortality rate (Angio-invasiveness)

Common Sites

  • Rhinocerebral Form: Involves the nose, nasal sinuses, and orbit; frequently seen in diabetic patients.
  • Pulmonary Infections: When the lungs are the primary site, the fungi can invade lung arteries, leading to serious complications.
  • Others: Cutaneous mucormycosis, GI mucormycosis, Disseminated mucormycosis

Clinical Features
  • Rhinocerebral Zygomycosis:
    • Facial swelling, nasal discharge (often black), fever, and mucosal necrosis.
    • Rapid progression can lead to severe complications, including visual loss and neurological symptoms.
  • Pulmonary Zygomycosis:
    • Symptoms may include cough, fever, and hemoptysis

Diagnosis

Histological Examination:

Diagnosis is confirmed by identifying broad, non-septate (or sparsely septate) hyphae.

Culture:

  • After incubation for 3-4 days on Sabouraud agar at 30-37°C, the colonies are grey-white with a thick cottony, fluffy surface.
  • Under the microscope, nonseptate, broad hyphae with aerial sporangiophores which end in a sporangium (a sac containing spores are seen.)

a. 

b.

a. Sabouraud's dextrose agar (SDA) medium showing Rhizopus growth

 

b. Microscopy of LPCB stained preparation demonstrating morphology of Rhizopus spp. (non-septate hyphae, sporangiophore, sporangium and spores)

Treatment:
