  • Intravenous amphotericin B combined, where appropriate, with surgical drainage is the recommended treatment.
  • Medical control of diabetes is required.

Aspergillosis (Option A) is a fungal infection caused by Aspergillus. Aspergillus is a septate fungus showing acute angle (< 45°.) dichotomous branching. It is commonly seen in immunocompromised individuals presenting with aspergilloma in pre-existing cavitary lesions (tuberculosis) in the lung, allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA).

Bacterial orbital cellulitis (Option B) is a bacterial infection that affects the soft tissues surrounding the eye. It can cause symptoms such as fever, nasal congestion, and facial pain. It will not show hyphae and SDA agar is not used for the culture.

Cavernous sinus thrombosis (Option D) is a rare condition characterized by the formation of a blood clot within the cavernous sinus, a large vein at the base of the skull.

questions.text: PR segment in ECG indicates:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Atrioventricular nodal conduction

Explanation:

  • The PR segment represents the period of atrioventricular nodal conduction in the cardiac cycle.

Component

Cause

Normal Duration and Size

P wave

Atrial depolarization is initiated by the SA node. (Option A Ruled Out)
  • 0.08–0.11 seconds
  • 2–2.75 small boxes
  • <2.5 mm (0.25 mV) in amplitude/ height
  • <0.12 sec (120 msec or 3 small boxes) in width

PR interval

Time from onset of atrial depolarization (P wave) to onset of ventricular depolarization (electrical impulse passing through AV node) (Option B)
  • 0.12–0.20 seconds
  • 3–5 small boxes

Q wave

Initial depolarization of the interventricular septum, directed from left to right.
  • <0.04 seconds
  • <1 small box
  • Depth: <1/4 of R wave or ~1–2 mm (<0.5 small boxes)

QRS complex

Ventricular depolarization - the time taken for the electrical impulse to spread through the ventricles. (Option C Ruled Out)
  • <0.10 seconds
  • <2.5 small boxes in width
  • Height: 5–30 mm (1–6 big boxes)

QT interval

Time from the start of ventricular depolarization to the end of ventricular repolarization.
  • Duration depends on HR.
  • HR inversely proportional QT length. Rate-corrected (QTc) 330–350 msec
  • ~11 small boxes

ST segment

Represents the early part of ventricular repolarization. It is isoelectric (flat). (Option D Ruled Out)

 
  • 0.08–0.12 seconds
  • 2–3 small boxes
  • Normally isoelectric (flat), deviations >1 small box indicate pathology

T wave

Represents the later stage of ventricular repolarization.
  • <0.04 seconds
  • 2.5–6.25 small boxes
  • Height: Varies. Normally <5 mm (1 big box) in limb leads, <10 mm (2 big boxes) in precordial leads

U wave

Unknown origin; possibly related to repolarization of Purkinje fibers or ventricular walls.
  • Not always measurable

questions.text: An 11-month-old baby was brought by his mother with complaints of the left upper eyelid moving up and down while breastfeeding that disappears when the baby is not breastfeeding. She gave a history of the child being diagnosed with left eye ptosis. What is this condition called?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Marcus -Gunn jaw-winking

Explanation:

The clinical presentation is suggestive of Marcus-Gunn jaw winking ptosis, characterised by retraction of the ptotic lid with jaw movements due to stimulation of ipsilateral pterygoid muscle.

Congenital synkinetic ptosis (Marcus Gunn jaw-winking ptosis):

  • Retraction of the ptotic lid with jaw movements due to stimulation of ipsilateral pterygoid muscle.
  • It occurs due to trigemino-oculomotor synkinesis. The pathophysiology of Marcus Gunn Jaw winking phenomenon is a congenital misdirection of mandibular branch of trigeminal nerve, i.e., this synkinetic movement results from a congenital aberrant connection between motor branches of the trigeminal nerve controlling muscles of mastication and superior division of the oculomotor nerve controlling the levator palpebrae superioris.

Symblepharon (Option A): Symblepharon is the adhesion between the palpebral and bulbar conjunctiva due to burns, chemical injuries, surgery, and ulcer.

Blepharophimosis syndrome (Option B): Blepharophimosis syndrome is a congenital anomaly characterized by blepharophimosis (decreased horizontal length), ptosis, congenital ectropion, and telecanthus.

Lagophthalmos (Option C): Lagophthalmos is the inability to close the eyelids voluntarily.

questions.text: What is the interpretation of elevated serum Calcium levels in a patient with normal serum alkaline phosphatase, PTH, and Vitamin D3 levels?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Multiple myeloma

Explanation:

  • Multiple myeloma is a malignant plasma cell disorder characterized by the excessive production of monoclonal immunoglobulins (M-protein). In multiple myeloma, serum calcium levels can be elevated while SAP, PTH, and vitamin D3 levels remain normal. This occurs due to osteolytic lesions and release of calcium from damaged bone tissue due to increased osteoclast activity stimulated by cytokines produced by malignant plasma cells.
  • The normal SAP levels in multiple myeloma help distinguish it from other bone disorders, as SAP is typically elevated in conditions with increased osteoblastic activity. In multiple myeloma, the predominant process is osteolytic rather than osteoblastic, hence SAP remains normal despite bone involvement.

Diagnostic Criteria for Multiple Myeloma

  • Presence of clonal bone marrow plasma cells or biopsy-proven bony/extramedullary plasmacytoma and anyone or more of the following myeloma-defining events:
  • Evidence of one or more indicators of end-organ damage attributed to the plasma cell disorder, specifically: (CRAB)
    • Hypercalcemia: Serum calcium >0.25 mmol/L above the upper limit of normal or >2.75 mmol/L (>11 mg/dL). PTH levels, Vit-D levels are normal
    • Renal Insufficiency: Creatinine clearance <40 mL/min or serum creatinine >177 μmol/L (>2 mg/dL).
    • Anemia: Hemoglobin >20 g/L below the lower limit of normal or haemoglobin <100 g/L or <10g/100ml.
    • Bone Lesions: One or more osteolytic lesions identified on skeletal radiography, CT, or PET-CT.

Biomarkers of Malignancy (any one of the following):

  • Clonal bone marrow plasma cells ≥60%.
  • Involved: uninvolved serum-free light chain ratio ≥100.
  • 1 focal lesion on MRI studies.

Serum markers: Hypercalcemia, ↑ β2 microglobulin

 

Vitamin D intoxication (Option A): In vitamin D intoxication, both serum calcium and vitamin D3 levels are typically elevated. Additionally, PTH levels are usually suppressed due to the negative feedback mechanism between vitamin D and PTH. Since vitamin D3 levels are normal in this case, vitamin D intoxication can be ruled out.

Hyperparathyroidism (Option B): Hyperparathyroidism is characterized by increased PTH levels, which stimulate the release of calcium from bone, resulting in elevated serum calcium levels. In this case, since PTH levels are normal, hyperparathyroidism is not the likely diagnosis.

Nutritional rickets (Option D): This option is incorrect as nutritional rickets is a condition caused by a deficiency of vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate. In rickets, serum calcium levels would typically be decreased rather than elevated. Additionally, vitamin D levels would be low, which is not the case here.

questions.text: Which of the following treatments is appropriate for a 3-month-old child with a mucopurulent discharge from the right puncta and a history of increased watering in the right eye, as noticed by the mother?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Sac massage with topical antibiotics

Explanation:

The clinical presentation is suggestive of Congenital Dacryocystitis. As the infant’s age is less than 6 months, Lacrimal sac massage with topical antibiotics would be the preferred management.

Treatment of Dacryocystitis:

< 6-9 months

Lacrimal sac massage with topical antibiotics (Option C)

9 months - 4 years

Bowman’s probing with syringing (Option A) (Option B)

> 4 years

Dacryocystorhinostomy (Option D)

questions.text: Which of the following interfere with iron absorption?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Phytates

Explanation:

  • Phytates are naturally occurring compounds found in certain plant foods such as whole grains, legumes, and nuts. These compounds have the ability to bind to iron and form insoluble complexes in the digestive tract, significantly reducing iron absorption and bioavailability.

Factors Increasing Iron Absorption

Factors Decreasing Iron Absorption
  • Acidic stomach environment
  • Vitamin C (ascorbic acid) (Option A Ruled Out)
  • Empty stomach
  • Meat proteins
  • Citric acid
  • Haem iron sources (meat, fish)
  • Fermented foods
  • Iron deficiency state
  • Reduced stomach acid
  • Proton pump inhibitors
  • Antacids
  • Tetracycline (chelates iron)
  • Phytates (Option B) (in cereals, legumes)
  • Tea and coffee (tannins)
  • Calcium-rich foods
  • High fiber meals

 

Vitamin C (Option A): Vitamin C, also known as ascorbic acid, enhances iron absorption rather than interfering with it. It helps in the conversion of non-heme iron (the form of iron found in plant-based foods) to a more absorbable form.

Oxalate (Option C): Oxalate, found in certain foods like spinach, rhubarb, and beet greens, can affect calcium absorption, but it does not affect iron absorption. While oxalates can bind to minerals, their primary impact is on calcium rather than iron metabolism.

Myoglobin (Option D): Myoglobin is a protein found in muscle tissue that stores oxygen and is found in food such as meat. While myoglobin does contain iron, it is not involved in the absorption of iron from the diet.

questions.text: Most sensitive and specific marker for MI is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Troponin

Explanation:

  • Troponin as the most sensitive and specific biomarker for myocardial infarction (MI). Troponin is a regulatory protein complex found specifically in cardiac muscle tissue. It begins to rise within 3-6 hours of injury, peaks at 24-48 hours, and can remain elevated for 7-10 days, providing a wide diagnostic window. Cardiac troponins (cTnI and cTnT) have nearly absolute myocardial tissue specificity and high clinical sensitivity.

Cardiac Biomarkers for Acute Myocardial Infarction (AMI):

1. Cardiac Troponin:

  • Preferred biochemical markers due to their sensitivity and specificity.
  • Criteria for ACS: Requires rise and/or fall in biomarker values, with at least one value above the 99th percentile upper reference limit.
  • Troponin T (cTnT) and Troponin I (cTnI) increase significantly after STEMI.
  • Can detect concentrations <1 ng/L in non-ischemic conditions.
  • Troponin levels:
    • Increase within 3-6 hours.
    • Peak at around 36 hours.
    • Remains elevated for 7-10 days after STEMI.
  • Troponin should be measured at presentation and repeated at 1-3 hours (high-sensitivity assays) or 3-6 hours (conventional assays).
  • Further troponin tests are advised beyond 3-6 hours if AMI remains a possibility or there is diagnostic uncertainty.

Causes of elevated Serum Troponin other than MI

Cardiorespiratory Causes

Non-Cardiorespiratory Causes

  • Pulmonary embolism
  • Aortic dissection
  • Acute pulmonary edema
  • Tachyarrhythmias
  • Myocarditis/Myopericarditis
  • Cardiac trauma
  • Cardiac surgery/ablation
  • Prolonged hypotension
  • Severe sepsis
  • Severe burns
  • Stroke
  • Subarachnoid hemorrhage
  • End-stage renal failure
  • Cardiac troponin levels remain elevated for several days after an acute myocardial infarction (AMI), making them unreliable for detecting reinfarction.

2. Creatine Phosphokinase (CK) and CK-MB:

  • CK rises within 4-8 hours.
  • Peaks by 24 hours.
  • Returns to normal within 48-72 hours.
  • CK lacks specificity for STEMI since it can be elevated in skeletal muscle disease, trauma, or injections.
  • CK-MB isoenzyme is more specific for the heart
  • CK-MB elevated:
    • Cardiac surgery
    • Myocarditis
    • Electrical cardioversion
  • CK-MB/CK ratio >2.5 suggests a myocardial source, though it's not diagnostic.
  • CK-MB levels normalize within 48 to 72 hours, so a subsequent rise can confirm reinfarction.

3. Lactate Dehydrogenase (LDH):

  • Increase in the blood 6 to 12 hours after ACS.
  • Peak within 24 to 72 hours.
  • Normalize within 8 to 14 days.
  • LDH is no longer used to diagnose myocardial infarction because it is not specific to cardiac myocytes.

4. Heart-type Fatty Acid-Binding Protein (H-FABP):

  • Sensitivity of H-FABP in detecting AMI within 4 hours of symptom onset was 60%, significantly higher than troponin (18.8%) and CK-MB (12.5%).
  • But the specificity of H-FABP in detecting AMI was less than that of troponin and CK-MB.

 

Cytokeratin (Option B): Cytokeratin is a protein found in epithelial cells and has no role in cardiac injury detection. It is primarily used as a tumor marker for certain types of cancers and has no relevance in diagnosing myocardial infarction.

Myoglobin (Option C): While myoglobin is released during muscle injury and rises earlier than troponin (2-3 hours after injury), it lacks cardiac specificity as it is found in both cardiac and skeletal muscle.

CPK-MM (Option D): Creatine Phosphokinase-MM is the skeletal muscle isoform of CPK. It is predominantly found in skeletal muscle. Its elevation can occur in condition causing skeletal muscle damage, making it a poor choice for specific MI diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is given lifelong for patient receiving prosthetic mitral valve replacement?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Warfarin

Explanation:

  • Warfarin is given as the lifelong medication for patients with prosthetic mitral valve replacement. All mechanical valves require long-term anticoagulation because they can cause systemic thromboembolism or may develop valve thrombosis or obstruction.
  • Warfarin, a vitamin K antagonist, works by inhibiting the clotting proteins in the blood, providing necessary anticoagulation to prevent thromboembolic complications in patients with mechanical heart valves.
  • For patients with mechanical heart valve replacements, warfarin therapy requires a higher target INR range of 3.0 to 3.5. This higher intensity of anticoagulation is necessary to prevent thromboembolic complications associated with mechanical valves.

Warfarin Use

Target INR Range

Atrial Fibrillation

 

 

 

 

2.0 - 2.5

Venous Thromboembolism (VTE) Prophylaxis

Bioprosthetic Heart Valves (first 3 months)

Post-Myocardial Infarction

Treatment of DCT, PE, TIA

2.5 - 3.0

Mechanical Prosthetic Heart Valves

 

3.0 - 3.5

Recurrent Thromboembolism

 

Aspirin (Option A): While aspirin is an antiplatelet agent that acts on blood platelets, it alone is insufficient for mechanical valve anticoagulation. Unlike warfarin, which inhibits the circulating blood clotting proteins, aspirin's antiplatelet action is not potent enough to prevent valve thrombosis in mechanical valves.

Clopidogrel (Option B): Clopidogrel, like aspirin, has anti-platelet action and is not adequate for mechanical valve anticoagulation. Both these drugs act on platelets and not on clotting proteins, making them insufficient for preventing mechanical valve thrombosis.

Atorvastatin (Option C): Atorvastatin is an anti-dyslipidemic drug that has no anticoagulant properties. While patients with prosthetic valves may require statins for other cardiovascular indications, the primary requirement is anticoagulation, not lipid management.

questions.text: A mother brought her 16-year-old daughter to the hospital with complaints of primary amenorrhea. On evaluation axillary and pubic hair were present and other secondary sexual characteristics were normal. LH and FSH levels are normal and USG showed an absence of a uterus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) MRKH syndrome

Explanation:

  • The patient presents with classic features of Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome.
  • MRKH syndrome is a congenital disorder characterized by the absence or underdevelopment of the uterus and upper two-thirds of the vagina in females with normal ovarian function and secondary sexual characteristics. It is characterized by:
    • Primary amenorrhea with normal secondary sexual characteristics
    • Normal hormonal levels (LH and FSH)
    • Absence of uterus on imaging
    • Normal external genitalia
    • Normal ovarian function

 

Turner syndrome (Option A): Turner syndrome patients have short stature, webbed neck, shield-shaped chest, and ovarian dysgenesis.

Androgen insensitivity syndrome (Option C): Androgen insensitivity syndrome patients have XY karyotype and lack pubic and axillary hair.

Swyer syndrome (Option D): Swyer syndrome patients do not develop secondary sexual characteristics due to lack of sex hormone production.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication of expectant management in unruptured ectopic gestation?

choices.text: Initial serum beta hCG level <200 mIU/mL

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Gestational sac size >4 cm

Explanation:

  • Expectant management (watchful waiting) involves monitoring without immediate intervention
  • A gestational sac > 4 cm is associated with an increased risk of rupture and complications, making expectant management unsafe. This size indicates a more advanced ectopic pregnancy, which typically requires active intervention, such as medical management with methotrexate or surgical treatment.

 

Indications for Expectant Management:

  • Initial beta-hCG level < 1000 IU/ml & falling
  • Gestational sac size < 4 cm
  • No fetal heartbeat on TVS
  • No evidence of bleeding or rupture
  • Asymptomatic patient

 

Initial serum beta hCG <200 mIU/mL (Option A): Appropriate for expectant management as it indicates very early or potentially non-viable pregnancy.

Asymptomatic (Option C): A favorable factor for expectant management in stable patients without concerning symptoms.

Decreasing beta hCG (Option D): Suggests possible spontaneous resolution, making expectant management appropriate.

questions.text: The number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births is called-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Maternal mortality ratio

  • The number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births

MCH Indicators

Maternal death:

  • It is the death of the mother, anytime during the pregnancy, labor/ delivery, or also 42 days post delivery.
  • If the death of the mother occurs during any of these, it is called maternal death.
  • The commonest cause of maternal death in India is PPH (Postpartum Haemorrhage).

Indicator

Formula

India Value

Most Common Cause

Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) (Option C)

Infant deaths / Live Births × 1000

33

Low Birth Weight (LBW) & Prematurity

Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR)

Maternal deaths / Live Births × 100,000

122

Postpartum Hemorrhage (PPH)

Under 5 Mortality Rate (U5MR) (Option B)

Total Under 5 deaths / Live Births × 1000

39

Low Birth Weight (LBW) & Prematurity

Neonatal Mortality Rate (NNR)

Neonatal deaths / Live Births × 1000

24

Low Birth Weight (LBW) & Prematurity

Perinatal Mortality Rate (PNMR) (Option D)

Perinatal deaths / Live Births × 1000

23

Low Birth Weight (LBW) & Prematurity

Stillbirth Rate (SBR)

Total Stillbirths / Live Births × 1000

22

Maternal infections / Abruptio placentae

questions.text: For assessing the viral load in a test sample, which test utilizes the provided graph?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Real-time RT PCR

  • The above image shows the cycle threshold or Ct value of Real time RT PCR which is used to assess the viral genetic load.
  • In the graph above, the cycle number is on the x-axis and relative fluorescence is on the y-axis.

Real-Time RT PCR

  • CT value (cyclical threshold) - Inversely Proportional to virus load.
  • The CT or threshold cycle value is the cycle number at which the fluorescence generated within a reaction crosses the fluorescence threshold, a fluorescent signal significantly above the background fluorescence.
  • At the threshold cycle, a detectable amount of amplicon product has been generated during the early exponential phase of the reaction. The threshold cycle is inversely proportional to the original relative expression level of the gene of interest.

Antigen test (Option A): A rapid antigen test, is a rapid diagnostic test suitable for point-of-care testing that directly detects the presence or absence of an antigen.

CBNAAT (Option C): The cartridge-based nucleic acid amplification test (CBNAAT) assay is a real-time polymerase chain reaction (PCR) cartridge-based assay for the simultaneous detection of Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex and rifampicin resistance from biological specimen samples within two hours.

TruNat (Option D): TrueNat is a comprehensive test for screening and confirming the COVID-19 virus in India.

questions.text: Which of the following is the initial step when an immunization survey is being conducted?

choices.text: Completing the cluster and summary forms
Calculating the total fertility rate of the area

questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Cluster identification

  • The initial step in conducting an immunization survey is Cluster identification.

The major steps of an immunization survey are as follows:

  • Planning the survey by finding the clusters and deciding how many interviewers are required.
  • To conduct the survey in which the interviewers visit houses and get information on the immunization status of the clusters (Option B)
  • To tabulate the data by completing the cluster and the summary forms (Option C)
  • To analyse the data which helps in evaluating the immunization status and the reasons for the failure of immunization.
  • To take action on the reports made by evaluating the data.

Calculating the total fertility rate of the area (Option D): This is not typically part of an immunization survey; it is more relevant to demographic studies.

questions.text: Which vaccine among the options exhibits a seroconversion rate that is quicker than the incubation period of the corresponding disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Measles:

  • Amongst the above options, measles vaccine has a faster seroconversion rate as compared to the incubation period of the disease and this is why measles vaccine is given when a disaster or an epidemic occurs.

Seroconversion:

  • is the transition from the point of viral infection to when antibodies of the virus become present in the blood.
  • Seroconversion rates are one of the methods used for determining the efficacy of a vaccine.
    • The higher the rate of seroconversion, the more protective the vaccine for a greater proportion of the population.
    • Seroconversion does not inherently confer immunity or resistance to infection.
    • Only some antibodies, such as anti-spike antibodies for COVID-19, confer protection.

Coronavirus (Option A): The coronavirus vaccine has almost the same seroconversion rate as compared to the incubation period of the disease.

Polio (Option C): The seroconversion rate of the polio vaccine is slower than its incubation period.

Mumps (Option D): The mumps vaccine has a slower seroconversion rate than its incubation period.

questions.text: As per the guidelines for disposing of biomedical waste, what color bag should be used to discard used cotton swabs?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Yellow

  • As per biomedical waste management guidelines, used cotton swabs, which are categorized as infectious waste contaminated with body fluids, should be disposed of in yellow bags.

Colour

Waste Type

Type of bag or container to be used

Method of disposal

Yellow
  • All infectious waste.
  • Human anatomical waste.
  • Animal anatomical waste
  • Soiled waste (contaminated with blood, body fluids, dressings and swabs, blood bags).
  • Expired or discarded medicines
  • Chemical waste.
  • Microbiological and other clinical laboratory waste.
  • Yellow coloured non chlorinated plastic bags.
  • Incineration
  • Plasma pyrolysis
  • Deep burial

Red
  • Contaminated waste (recyclable): Tubing, bottles, intravenous tubes and sets, catheters, urine bags, syringes (without needles), vacutainers and gloves.
  • Red coloured non chlorinated plastic bags.
  • Autoclaving or microwaving/hydroclaving, and then sent for recycling (not to landfill).

Blue
  • Glassware: Broken or discarded and contaminated glass including medicine vials and ampoules except those contaminated with cytotoxic waste.
  • Metallic body implants.
  • Cardboard boxes with blue coloured markings.
  • Disinfection or autoclaving/microwaving, hydroclaving and then sent to recycling.

White
  • Waste sharps including metals: Needles, syringes with fixed needles, scalpels or any other sharp object that may cause puncture and cuts.
  • Puncture proof and leak proof containers.
  • Auto or dry heat sterilization followed by shredding and mutilation or encapsulation.

questions.text: For a population of 10,000, what does a sex ratio of more than 1000 mean?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Males are less than 5000

  • The sex ratio is defined as the number of females per 1000 males in a given population. A sex ratio of more than 1000 indicates that there are more females than males in the population.

For a population of 10,000:

  1. If the sex ratio is greater than 1000, it implies that the number of females exceeds the number of males.
  2. This means that the number of males must be less than half of the total population (i.e., less than 5000).

Sex Ratio: Number of females per 1000 males.

  • Importance in Demography: Crucial for understanding population dynamics.
  • Influencing Factors:
    • Mortality differences between genders.
    • Sex-selective migration.
    • Sex ratio at birth.
  • Implications of Low Sex Ratio:
    • Indicates a preference for male children.
    • Results in gender inequities.
    • This leads to neglect of girls, higher female mortality in youth, female infanticide, and foeticide.
    • Increases maternal mortality.
    • Bias towards males in population counts.

Males are less than 500 (Option A): This is incorrect because the male population being so low would result in an extremely skewed sex ratio, which is unrealistic in this context.

Females are less than 500 (Option B): This is incorrect because a sex ratio greater than 1000 implies there are more females, not fewer.

Females are less than 5000 (Option D): This is incorrect because for the sex ratio to exceed 1000, the number of females must be more than 5000.

questions.text: A couple has given birth to their first child. Based on the nuclear family cycle, which phase is the family entering into?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Extension

  • Based on the nuclear family life cycle, the family enters the "Extension" phase after the birth of their first child. This phase begins with the birth of the first child and continues until the birth of the last child.

No.

Phases of Family Life Cycle

Beginning of Phase

End of Phase

I

Formation

Marriage

Birth of 1st child

II

Extension

Birth of 1st child

Birth of last child

III

Complete Extension (Option B)

Birth of last child

1st child leaves home

IV

Contraction (Option C)

1st child leaves home

Last child leaves home of parents

V

Completed Contraction (Option D)

Last child leaves home of parents

1st spouse dies

VI

Dissolution

1st spouse dies

Death of survivor (extinction)

questions.text: The school health programs are managed by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Primary health centre

  • School health programs are managed by the Primary Health Centre (PHC) within their jurisdiction.
  • PHCs are responsible for ensuring school health services, including periodic checkups and health education, in their assigned areas.

 

School Health Services

1. History:

  • Bhore Committee: Launched the concept of school health checkups.
  • Renuka Roy Committee: Recommended school health checkups once every 4 years.

2. Current Recommendation:

  • School health checkups are recommended once every 6 months.

 

School Health Administration

1. Responsibility:

  • Primary Health Centres (PHCs): Responsible for school health services in their respective jurisdictions.

2. Coverage:

  • Each Medical Officer should cover 5,000-6,000 children per year.

3. Village Level:

  • School Health Committees can be established to ensure health services at the village level.

District hospitals (Option B): are higher-level healthcare facilities that provide secondary level care to the population within a district. They primarily focus on advanced medical care and management of more complex health issues.

The sub-center (Option C): Sub-centres provide basic healthcare services at the village level but do not have the capacity to manage school health programs.

Sub-divisional hospitals (Option D): also known as taluka hospitals or community health centres, are healthcare facilities at the sub-district level.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis of a 35-year-old male with a history of prolonged corneal ulcer who now presents with a deformed eye as shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Anterior staphyloma

Explanation:

The history of a prolonged corneal ulcer is suggestive of low body immune response or infection by a virulent strain of bacteria leading to sloughing of the whole cornea, leaving a narrow rim behind along with iris prolapse resulting in the false cornea that cannot withstand raised intraocular pressure and results in forward bulging of the cornea with iris tissue. As a result an ectatic cicatrix forms called Anterior Staphyloma as seen in the image.

Staphyloma:

It is ectasia of the outer coats of the eye (cornea, sclera, or both) with an incarceration of the uveal tissue.

Based on the site affected, staphyloma can be classified as

Types of staphyloma

Causes

Anterior

Pseudocornea (following corneal ulcer) (Option D)

Intercalary

Perforating injuries of the peripheral cornea, marginal corneal ulcer, anterior scleritis, and scleromalacia perforans

Ciliary

Glaucoma, scleritis, and trauma to the ciliary region

Equatorial (approx 14 mm behind the limbus)

Scleritis, degenerative myopia, and chronic uncontrolled glaucoma

Posterior

Degenerative high axial myopia

Treatment:

  • Treat underlying condition
  • Local excision and repair with a corneal and scleral patch graft
  • Large staphyloma: Staphylectomy and keratoplasty, or enucleated and replaced with an implant

Megalocornea (Option A): Rare bilateral nonprogressive congenital defect that is characterized by an increased corneal diameter greater than 12.5 to 13 mm at birth and a deep anterior chamber with normal intraocular pressures and clear cornea.

Conjunctivitis (Option B): Is the inflammation or infection of the transparent membrane that lines your eyelid and eyeball. Typical symptoms include redness and a gritty sensation in your eye, along with itching.

Buphthalmos (Option C): Meaning "bull-like eyes," is a condition characterized by the enlargement of the eyeball secondary to congenital Glaucoma. It typically manifests before the age of 3 years and results from the accumulation and retention of aqueous humor.

OP185

questions.text: Re-infection with which of the following will lead to catastrophic symptoms even in the presence of antibodies?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Dengue

  • Re-infection with Dengue can lead to catastrophic symptoms even in the presence of antibodies, due to antibody-dependent enhancement (ADE).
  • When an individual is re-exposed to a different Dengue serotype, the immune response can trigger severe forms such as Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever or Dengue Shock Syndrome, leading to life-threatening complications.

Re-infection and Antibody-Dependent Enhancement in Dengue:

  • First Exposure: Leads to immune sensitization to Dengue virus.
  • Re-exposure: With a different Dengue serotype (e.g., DENV-2) can trigger antibody-dependent enhancement (ADE).
  • Outcome: ADE can lead to severe Dengue, Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever (DHF), or Dengue Shock Syndrome (DSS).
  • Mechanism: Cross-reactive antibodies from the first infection enhance the severity of the disease during the second infection.
  • Result: Increased risk of severe illness due to immune system overreaction to the second Dengue serotype.

questions.text: Marsupialization is an ideal treatment of choice for condition X involving the female reproductive tract, the lesion responsible for condition X is located at?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Bartholin gland

Explanation:

  • Marsupialization is a minor surgical procedure used to treat Bartholin cysts. Bartholin cysts are fluid-filled lumens that can form on the bartholin glands on either side of the labia.

Marsupialization Procedure:

  • Creates a permanent opening in the cyst wall
  • Involves creating a "pouch" for drainage
  • Takes approximately 15 minutes
  • Can be performed under local or general anesthesia
  • Recovery typically takes 2 weeks

Marsupialization is not indicated for pathologies involving Perineal body (Option A), Vagina (Option C) & Cervix (Option D).

questions.text: What could be the likely diagnosis for a pregnant woman with high blood pressure, experiencing pain in the abdomen, vaginal bleeding, and a decrease in fetal movements?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Abruptio placenta

Explanation:

  • Placental abruption (abruptio placentae) is an unusual yet serious complication of pregnancy.
  • The placenta develops in the uterus during pregnancy. It attaches to the wall of the uterus and supplies the baby with nutrients and oxygen.
  • Placental abruption occurs when the placenta partly or completely separates from the inner wall of the uterus before delivery. This can decrease or block the baby's supply of oxygen and nutrients and cause heavy bleeding in the mother.
  • Placental abruption often happens abruptly. Left untreated, it endangers both the mother and the baby.

 

Placenta previa (Option B): While this condition also presents with vaginal bleeding, it is typically painless and not associated with hypertension. The bleeding in placenta previa is bright red and occurs without abdominal pain or uterine tenderness.

Hydramnios (Option C): Excess amniotic fluid condition that presents with increased uterine size and maternal discomfort but does not cause acute bleeding or pain. It is not typically associated with hypertension or decreased fetal movements.

Preterm labor (Option D): While this can occur with placental abruption, it does not present with vaginal bleeding, hypertension and reduced fetal movements. Preterm labor typically presents with regular uterine contractions and cervical changes

questions.text: What is the term used to describe the act of disseminating a specific organized belief system or political perspective through the use of information with the intention of implanting it in people's minds?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Health propaganda

  • Propaganda is information that is used to promote or publicize a point of view or a cause.
  • Propaganda often has the connotation of being biased or misleading in some way-not telling the entire truth because of the need to promote a view, cause, product, or person.

 

Health Education (Option C)

Propaganda

Mode of acquisition

Actively acquired knowledge and skills (active thinking).

Knowledge (may be false or exaggerated) is instilled in people's minds (facts).

Develops
  • Reflective behaviour.
  • Trains people to use judgment before acting.
  • Individuality.
  • Personality.
  • Self-expression.
  • Reflexive behaviour.
  • Aims at impulsive action.
  • A standard pattern of attitudes and behaviours according to what would be used- a set pattern of behaviour.

Appeals to

Reason

Emotion

Knowledge acquisition

By self-reliant activity

Spoon-fed and received

Process centered on

Behaviour: aims at developing favourable attitudes, habits, and skills.

Information: no changes of attitude- behaviour designed.

Doctrine(Option A): simply means group or set of beliefs held or taught by a group. So, it is not something which can be used to spread a particular systemised doctrine itself.

Health information (Option D): is any data related to a person’s health or disability including previous medical histories, injuries, signs and symptoms, etc.

questions.text: The usage of the given device in the picture is:

choices.text: Measure the length of the uterus

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Menstrual regulation/aspiration

Explanation:

The device shown in the image is a Karman cannula, also known as the Karman curette. This device is primarily used for menstrual regulation or aspiration procedures, which involve the removal of uterine contents through suction. Key points about the device include:

  • It is commonly used for early pregnancy termination or menstrual regulation in cases of missed or incomplete abortion.
  • The procedure typically employs vacuum aspiration with the Karman cannula to safely evacuate the uterine cavity.
  • The device is specifically designed for use during the early stages of pregnancy, ensuring minimal trauma to the uterine walls.

questions.text: During the USG examination of a woman at 28 weeks of gestation, you observe her amniotic fluid index to be 12.8 cm. At what stage does this measurement typically reach its highest value in a healthy pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 32 weeks of gestation

Explanation:

  • In a healthy pregnancy, the amniotic fluid index (AFI) typically reaches its highest value around 32 to 34 weeks of gestation.
  • After this period, the amniotic fluid volume might start to gradually decrease as the pregnancy progresses toward full term.
  • AFI is an important measurement during ultrasound examinations, as it helps assess the amount of amniotic fluid surrounding the fetus.

questions.text: What type of visual impairment does a person have if their vision is less than 3/60 but greater than 1/60 in their better eye, and their field of vision is limited to less than 10 degrees from the center of fixation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Social blindness

Explanation:

Vision < 3/60 but > 1/60 with field of vision < 10 degrees is suggestive of Social Blindness.

NPCB Classification of Visual Impairment

The National Programme for Control of Blindness (NPCB) in India defines blindness as "visual acuity of <3/60 in a better eye with best possible correction" and central visual field <10 degrees. The NPCB further categorizes visual impairment as:

Classification

Visual Acuity

Visual Impairment

Visual acuity of less than 6/18 in the better eye with available correction

Low Vision

Visual acuity of less than 6/18 to 6/60

Economic Blindness (Option B)

Visual acuity of less than 6/60 to 3/60

Social Blindness (Option C)

Visual acuity of less than 3/60 to 1/60

Manifest Blindness (Option D)

Visual acuity of less than 1/60 to the perception of light

Absolute Blindness

No perception of light

 

 

WHO Classification of Visual Impairment

The World Health Organization (WHO) defines blindness as "visual acuity of less than 3/60 (Snellen) or its equivalent".

The International Classification of Disease 11 (2018) classifies vision impairment into distance and near-presenting vision impairment

Classification

Visual Acuity

Mild Distance Vision Impairment

Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/12

Moderate Distance Vision Impairment

Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/18

Severe Distance Vision Impairment

Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/60

Blindness

Presenting visual acuity worse than 3/60

Near Vision Impairment

Presenting near vision acuity worse than N6 or M0.8 at 40 cm with existing correction

questions.text: Which method would be most effective in delivering statistical data to emphasize the significance of routine antenatal care for pregnant mothers, when educating a small, uneducated village during your rural posting?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Pictogram

  • Pictograms are the best way to present the data to the “man in the street” and those who cannot understand the orthodox charts i.e. to uneducated people as mentioned in the question.
  • Small pictures or symbols are used to present the data. Fractions of the picture can be used to represent the numbers smaller than the value of the whole symbol.

Histogram: (Option C)

  • It represents the frequency of continuous variables or quantitative variables.
  • Height is a quantitative or continuous variable (can take many possible values and also in between values)
  • It can be expressed in decimals and there is no gap in between.

Bar Diagram:

  • Simple bar diagrams represent the frequency of discrete variables like gender.
  • Discrete variables:These variables take fewer values and no in between values.
    • Examples: Religion, Blood groups
    • These are not represented in decimals so there are gaps.

Pictograph:

  • Used for graphical representation of qualitative variables
  • Used to teach something to a layman (illiterate).

Box and Whisker Plot:

  • A method of quantitative data representation.
  • Used to represent quartiles.
  • It comments on the type of distribution i.e., normal or skewed.
  • There is equal distribution on both sides (no outliers).
  • It is a normal distribution.
  • Tails are also equally distributed.

 

Frequency Polygon: (Option D)

  • It is drawn above a histogram.
  • Midpoints are joined by a straight line (frequency polygon).
  • Height is continuous (quantitative data).
  • If the number of observations is very large and group intervals are reduced, then frequency polygon loses its angulature and becomes a curve i.e., frequency curve.

A line chart is used for showing trends of events or incidence of cases over time. It has both rise and fall.(Option B)

Line chart

questions.text: A 24-year-old female primigravida with a history of 3 months of amenorrhoea undergoes USG. The USG done is shown below. What is the USG suggestive of?

choices.text: Multiple renal cysts in the fetus

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hydatidiform mole

Explanation:

  • The ultrasound findings include a heterogeneous mass in the uterine cavity with multiple anechoic spaces, most commonly referred to as a "snowstorm" appearance which indicates a complete molar pregnancy.
  • Typically, USG findings of molar pregnancy reveal a distended endometrial cavity containing a heterogeneous intrauterine mass with multiple cystic spaces demonstrating a snowstorm appearance with absent fetal parts.

 

Ectopic pregnancy (Option A): Ectopic pregnancy refers to the implantation of the fertilized egg outside of the uterus, typically in the fallopian tubes. USG findings would show an empty uterine cavity with or without an adnexal mass or free fluid in the pelvis. The described findings do not suggest ectopic pregnancy.

Multiple renal cysts in the fetus (Option C): This option refers to the presence of cysts in the fetal kidneys. However, the scenario does not mention any fetal renal abnormalities, and the focus is on the patient's amenorrhea and the ultrasound findings related to the pregnancy.

Oligohydramnios (Option D): Oligohydramnios refers to a reduced amount of amniotic fluid surrounding the fetus. While it is possible to evaluate amniotic fluid levels using ultrasound, the given scenario does not mention any findings related to amniotic fluid levels or fetal well-being.

questions.text: A woman, who is in her 8th week of pregnancy, has come seeking medical termination of pregnancy (MTP). What would be the correct dosage of misoprostol to be given through the mucosal route?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 800 mcg

Explanation:

  • Misoprostol is typically administered 1 to 2 days (24 to 48 hours) following the ingestion of mifepristone. The recommended dosage of misoprostol depends on the gestational age. For gestations up to 9 weeks (63 days), misoprostol can be administered through vaginal, buccal, or sublingual routes.
  • The recommended dose is 800 μg for vaginal, buccal, or sublingual administration and 400 μg for oral administration.

 

Option A, B, C: These options (200 mcg, 400 mcg, and 600 mcg) are incorrect because they represent lower dosages that are less likely to be effective for pregnancy termination at 8 weeks. Higher doses are needed to ensure the successful completion of the abortion process.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the outpatient department with a history of trauma near the eye and now presents with symptoms of fever, severe pain, and swelling in the left eye. On examination, no abnormal findings were observed. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Preseptal cellulitis

Explanation:

Symptoms like fever, pain and swelling limited to the region anterior to the orbital septum with no abnormal ocular findings is suggestive of Preseptal cellulitis.

 

Orbital cellulitis:

Definition

Orbital cellulitis is an acute infection of the soft tissues of the orbit located behind the orbital septum.

Etiology
  • Sinusitis: Ethmoid sinusitis (most common) carries a high risk of causing orbital cellulitis. (Option A)
  • Underlying dental problem.
  • Dacryocystitis (inflammation of the lacrimal sac).
  • Endogenous cause: Septicemia
  • Exogenous cause: Fracture or surgery of the orbit.

Causative Organisms
  • Staphylococcus aureus (most common)
  • Haemophilus influenzae (most common in children)
  • Streptococcus pneumoniae
  • Streptococcus pyogenes

Clinical Features
  • Preseptal cellulitis: Fever, pain, swelling, tenderness on the outer eyelid region. (Option D)
  • Orbital cellulitis: (Option A)
    • Painful, unilateral Proptosis (swelling and severe pain worsened by eye movement or pressure)
    • Restriction of eye movements (due to proptosis)
    • Decreased visual acuity

Staging

Modified Chandler staging system:

  • Stage I: Preseptal cellulitis/ periorbital cellulitis (limited anterior to the orbital septum) (Option D)
  • Stage II: Inflammatory orbital oedema/ Orbital cellulitis (Posterior to orbital septum)
  • Stage III: Subperiosteal abscess
  • Stage IV: Orbital abscess
  • Stage V: Cavernous sinus thrombosis

 

Treatment

  • Antibiotics (IV): Empirical therapy treats orbital cellulitis by giving Ceftazidime, Vancomycin, and Metronidazole.
  • Monitoring of optic nerve function
  • Surgery: Drainage of an orbital abscess or infected sinuses should be considered if there is a lack of response to antibiotics.

questions.text: A study to determine the association between maternal smoking histories from pregnant women during their antenatal visits and then subsequently assessing the birth weight of their babies soon after delivery. What type of study is this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Prospective cohort

This involves identifying a cohort of individuals (in this case, pregnant women) and collecting data on exposures (e.g., maternal smoking) during the study period, then following them forward in time to assess outcomes (e.g., birth weight of babies).

  • In this study, smoking history is recorded during antenatal visits (before the birth), and birth weight is measured after delivery. Hence, it is prospective.

Cohort studies are a type of observational study design that follows a group of people (a cohort) over time to assess the outcomes of exposure to certain risk factors or interventions.

Indications to conduct a cohort study:

  • Exposure Assessment
  • Incidence Calculation
  • Time Relationship
  • Rare Exposures
  • Multiple Outcomes
  • Long Latency Period
  • Natural Course

Retrospective cohort (Option B): This would involve looking back at existing records to determine past exposure (e.g., smoking history from medical records) and linking it to outcomes (birth weight).

Case-control study (Option C): This would start with cases (e.g., low birth weight babies) and controls (normal birth weight babies) and then look back to determine maternal smoking history.

Cross-sectional study (Option D): This would assess both exposure (smoking history) and outcome (birth weight) at the same point in time, which is not the case here since birth weight is assessed after delivery.

questions.text: Which of the following treatment options is most frequently used for recurrent pterygium?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Conjunctival autograft

Explanation:

A conjunctival autograft (limbal conjunctival tissue from the same or other eye) is the most frequent preferred management for recurrent pterygium.

Management of pterygium:

 

 

 

 

 

 

Management

Reassurance/Observation: if not causing any visual problems (Option C)

Medical treatment:

  • Tear substitutes for small regressive pterygium with dry eye
  • Topical steroids for associated inflammation
  • Protection from UV rays with sunglasses

Surgical excision for:

  • Progression of lesion towards the pupillary area causing excessive astigmatism and visual impairment
  • Restricted ocular movements
  • Disfiguring
  • Diplopia

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Procedures
  • Bare sclera technique: (Option D)
    • The pterygium is excised from the cornea and conjunctiva, leaving a bare sclera
    • Associated with a high recurrence rate
  • Autoconjunctival graft: (Option A)
    • A piece of limbal conjunctival tissue from the same or the other eye or An amniotic membrane graft is used to cover the bare sclera
    • Sutured at the limbus to cover the defect
    • Less recurrence rate
  • Surgical excision with lamellar keratectomy and lamellar keratoplasty for deeply infiltrating recurrent recalcitrant pterygia
  • Old methods (not used now):
    • McRaynold’s operation
    • Postoperative use of beta irradiations

Post-operative therapy and care
  • Prevent recurrence:
    • Mitomycin C 0.02% drops
    • Complications like scleral necrosis, cataracts, and iritis

questions.text: The minimum requirements of a health worker job are given: should be a woman, a resident of the village, 25 to 45 years old, and have a formal education till 8th standard. What is the health worker called?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - ASHA worker

  • It is a cadre of workers created under National Rural Health Mission (NRHM) in the year 2005. Only a slight difference has now been in the minimum educational qualification.
  • It is now requested or asked, she should be a minimum 8th pass.

ASHA (Accredited Social Health Activist)

ASHA is a woman (married, divorced, or widowed) resident of the village, aged 25-45 years, with education up to 8th grade.

Population Norm for ASHA

The general norm is 1 ASHA per 1000 population. In tribal, hilly, and desert areas, this may be relaxed to 1 ASHA per habitation.

Role and Responsibilities of ASHA
  • Health Activist: Create awareness and provide information on health determinants, existing services, and the importance of health and family welfare.
  • Counselor: Provide counseling on birth preparedness, safe delivery, and family planning.
  • Mobilizer: Help the community access health services, such as immunizations, sanitation, and nutrition.
  • Provider: Offer basic care for common illnesses and first-aid, and act as a depot for essential medications.
  • Community Engagement: Work with village health committees and panchayats for planning and awareness.

Specific Responsibilities of ASHA
  1. Promote health and sanitation practices.
  2. Advise on child care, immunization, and reproductive health.
  3. Assist with family planning and treatment of minor ailments.
  4. Mobilize pregnant women and children to health services
  5. Provide basic medical care and support for diarrhea, fever, and tuberculosis (under DOTS).
  6. Serve as a depot holder for essential drugs and medical supplies.

Role and Integration with Anganwadi

The Anganwadi worker helps guide ASHA, particularly in organizing Health Day activities, mobilizing village women and children, and promoting nutrition and health education.

Role and Integration with ANMs (Auxiliary Nurse Midwives)

ANMs guide ASHA in areas like immunization, safe pregnancy, and health education, and assist in organizing Health Days. ANMs also help with training and monitor ASHA's performance.

Anganwadi worker (Option A): there is no maximum age limit (65 years at most) in most states.

Nurse (Option B): the candidate should have a minimum of Bachelor of Science in Nursing (BSN)

Midwife (Option C): the candidate should atleast have passed 12th standard exams. Most midwives have bachelor's degrees in health related fields.

questions.text: To avoid overcrowding, what is the maximum number of people allowed to live in a house with 2 rooms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - 4 people

  • Maximum no. of persons recommended in case of 2 rooms is more than 3, and to avoid overcrowding maximum no. of persons allowed are 4

Overcrowding: Overcrowding refers to the situation in which more people are living within a single dwelling than there is space for, so that movement is restricted, privacy secluded, hygiene impossible, rest and sleep difficult.

Criteria for overcrowding:

  • Person per room criteria
  • Floor space per person criteria
  • Sex separation criteria.

Number of Rooms

Maximum Number of Persons Recommended

1

2

2

> 3

3

5

4

7

5

10

6

Add 2 persons for each additional room after 5

questions.text: Highest sodium content is present in which of the following foods:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Canned soup

  • Canned soup is known to have a very high sodium content because salt is often added as a preservative and for flavor enhancement.
  • Sodium levels in canned soups can vary but are often significantly higher than in fresh or minimally processed foods.

Micronutrients:

  • Required in small amounts from a fraction of milligrams to several grams.
  • Micronutrients consist of vitamins and minerals.
    • Minerals classification:
      • Major Minerals (PYQ): Calcium, Phosphorous, Sodium, Potassium, Magnesium
      • Trace Elements: Required In Quantities Less Than A Few Milligrams/Day
        • Eg Iron, lodine, Fluorine, Zinc, Copper, Cobalt, Chromium, Manganese, Molybdenum, Selenium, Silicon, Nickel, Tin
        • Trace Contaminants With No Known Function: Lead, Mercury, Barium, Boron, Aluminum

Sugar cane, barley, and fresh fruit juices (Options A, B, and D): naturally contain very little sodium

questions.text: A patient with carcinoma endometrium is treated with pelvic external beam irradiation to the whole pelvis. Which of the following organs is most radiosensitive in the pelvic region?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ovary

Explanation:

  • The ovary is one of the most radiosensitive organs in the pelvic region.
  • Gonadal toxicity following exposure to radiation therapy mainly involves a decline in the endocrine functions that sustain the production of sex hormones and germ cells.
  • Pelvic radiotherapy results in ovarian injury and diminished follicle reserve; the extent of damage is largely based on the patient's age, treatment dose, and irradiation field.

 

Vagina (Option B), bladder (Option C), and rectum (Option D), are less radiosensitive compared to the ovaries. Although these organs may be exposed to radiation during treatment, the ovaries are typically the most affected and require careful consideration to minimize the potential long-term consequences of radiation exposure.

questions.text: Which of the following indicators is the best to know the overall burden of disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Disability-adjusted life years (DALY)

  • DALY (Disability Adjusted Life Years) measures disease burden by combining years lost due to premature death and years lived with disability.

Disability Indicators:

Quality-adjusted Life Years (QALY)

(Option A)

 
  • Quality and quantity of life lived.
  • Assesses number of years of life added due to the intervention and hence the benefit and value for money of the intervention
  • QALY - 1 year of life lived in perfect health
  • Positive indicator of the cost-effectiveness of an intervention.
  • Scored between 0 (death) and 1 (perfect health).

Disability-adjusted Life Years (DALY)

 
  • DALY= Years of life lost to premature death + years lived with disability
  • 1 DALY: 1 year of healthy life lost
  • It is a measure of the burden of disease and the effectiveness of intervention

Year of life lost (YLL):

  • Calculated from the number of deaths at each age multiplied by the expected remaining years of life according to a global standard life expectancy.

Years lost to disability (YLD):

  • Where the number of incident cases due to injury and illness is multiplied by the average duration of the disease and a weighting factor reflecting the severity of the disease on a scale from 0 (perfect health) to 1 (dead).

DALY = YLL + YLD

Health Adjusted Life Expectancy (HALE) (Option B)

  • The average number of years a newborn is expected to live in full health considering the current age-specific mortality rate.
    Healthy Life Expectancy

HALE = Life Expectancy at birth + adjustment of time spent in poor health

HALE = LE-DALY

Life Expectancy

  • Average no. of years a newborn is expected to live, considering the current age-specific mortality rate.

Sullivan’s index (or DFLE) (Option D)

  • Disability-free life expectancy (DFLE) with the current pattern of mortality and disability.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presented with cyclical abdominal pain and a midline hypogastric lump. She has not achieved menarche yet. The per vaginal examination is shown below, and a blush swelling is seen along with it. What is the likely cause of her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Imperforate hymen

Explanation:

The presentation is consistent with imperforate hymen, a condition where the vaginal opening is obstructed by a membrane, leading to cryptomenorrhea.

  • The cyclical abdominal pain and hypogastric lump are caused by the accumulation of menstrual blood in the uterus (hematometra) and vagina (hematocolpos).
  • The blush swelling on per vaginal examination indicates the blocked vaginal opening.
  • Treatment for imperforate hymen involves making a cruciate incision and removing the hymenal membrane to restore normal menstrual flow.

Bartholin cyst (Option A): Bartholin cyst presents as labial swelling, not midline hypogastric lump.

Transverse vaginal septum (Option B): Transverse vaginal septum causes obstructive symptoms, but it is not visible externally.

Endometrioma (Option D): Occurrence of Endometrioma is unlikely before menarche.

questions.text: A man suffered trauma to the eye from a punch while fighting with another person. What is the most common site of fracture in orbit?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Floor

Explanation:

Floor is the weakest wall of orbit due to the presence of Inferior orbital fissure (although medial wall of the orbit is the thinnest wall). Trauma to the orbit can result in fracture of the floor of the orbit - known as ‘Blowout fracture’

Blow-out fracture:

Description
  • Blow-out orbital fractures result from trauma causing backward displacement of the eyeball and an increase in intraorbital pressure, leading to a resultant fracture.

Classification
  • Pure blow-out fractures: Not associated with involvement of the orbital rim.
  • Impure blow-out fractures: Associated with other fractures in the middle third of the facial skeleton.

Clinical Features
  • Periorbital oedema and blood extravasation (e.g., subconjunctival ecchymosis)
  • Emphysema of the eyelids, more common with medial wall fractures
  • Paraesthesia and anaesthesia in the distribution of the infraorbital nerve (lower lid, cheek, side of nose, upper lip, and upper teeth)
  • Ipsilateral epistaxis (bleeding from maxillary sinus)
  • Proptosis, often due to orbital oedema and haemorrhage
  • Enophthalmos (due to orbital fat escape, muscle entrapment, and cavity enlargement)
  • Diplopia

Radiography
  • X-ray: Water’s view shows ‘hanging drop’ opacity of the superior maxillary antrum due to herniated orbital contents.
  • CT/MRI: Coronal sections show extent of the fracture and herniation- hanging drop or tear drop sign

Management

General Measures and Medical Treatment:

  • Avoid nose blowing
  • Systemic antibiotics to prevent sinus infection
  • Analgesics and anti-inflammatory drugs
  • Cold compresses to decrease swelling

Surgical Management:

  • Optimal surgery time: 10-14 days after injury
  • Surgical indications: Persistent diplopia, large herniation, tissue incarceration, enophthalmos >3mm

Orbital Surgeries:

  • Orbitotomy: 4 approaches: anterior, lateral, transfrontal, and temporofrontal
  • Exenteration: Removal of all orbital contents and periorbita through an incision along orbital margins.

questions.text: Miss. Uma presents to you with complaints of mass descending per vaginum for the past 6 months. On examination, you notice a grade 3 uterovaginal prolapse and a decubitus ulcer over the prolapse. Which of the following is a cause for this decubitus ulcer and treatment?

choices.text: Venous congestion and reduction of the prolapsed part into the vagina and daily packing with glycerine and acriflavine

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Venous congestion and reduction of the prolapsed part into the vagina and daily packing with glycerine and acriflavine

Explanation:

  • This is a case of Decubitus ulcer and it is seen often in a patient with uterovaginal prolapse, which occurs due to localized tissue damage and venous congestion.
  • Treatment of this ulcer is often done with moist vaginal packing using acriflavine and glycerin-soaked roller gauze.

 

Complications of prolapse:

  • Kinking of ureter
  • Chronic UTI
  • Decubitus ulcer
  • Stress incontinence
  • Cancer of vagina

 

Decubitus Ulcer:

[1]

 

  • Decubitus ulcer is a complication of pelvic organ prolapse. It usually occurs when the disease has advanced and it is a feature of long-standing uterovaginal prolapse.
  • Affected women are usually concerned not just about their prolapse but about the developing ulcer. This ulcer has been attributed to venous congestion in the affected organ.
  • Venous congestion causes edema of the local tissue which may decrease tissue strength thereby making it more friable. All these may reduce the strength of the vaginal tissue.
  • Also, friction between the prolapsed organ and the patient's clothes may play a role. It is also of concern when surgery is contemplated because the affected tissues appear friable which may cause difficulties during vaginal hysterectomy.
  • This may eventually lead to a delay in surgery thereby depriving the affected women of the cure for their physical and psychosocial problems.
  • In women with uterovaginal prolapse, ulcers may be associated with cervical intraepithelial neoplasia and cervical malignancy. Also, decubitus ulcers may be a source of infection with its attendant risk of postoperative infection.
  • Treatment is reduction of the prolapsed part into the vagina and daily packing with glycerine and acriflavine.

 

Malignancy and excision (Option A): Decubitus ulcers in prolapse are not caused by malignancy, and excision is not a standard treatment for such ulcers.

Infection and antibiotics (Option C): While infection can complicate a decubitus ulcer, it is not the primary cause. Therefore, antibiotics alone are not the appropriate treatment in this case.

Trauma and dressing (Option D): Trauma can contribute to the development of a decubitus ulcer, but it is not specified in the given scenario. Dressing alone would not address the underlying cause of venous congestion in uterovaginal prolapse.

questions.text: Cardiac output reverts to pre-pregnancy levels by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 10 days postpartum

Explanation:

  • Cardiac output increases during pregnancy to meet the increased demands of the growing fetus and maternal physiological changes.
  • After delivery, it takes some time for cardiac output to return back to pre-pregnant levels.
  • The timeframe for cardiac output to return to pre-pregnant levels varies among individuals but generally occurs within 10 days postpartum.
  • Several factors influence the age at which cardiac output normalizes, including the individual's overall health, fitness level, and any complications experienced during pregnancy or childbirth.

questions.text: The pregnancy test kit launched by the government is called:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - NISHCHAY

  • NISHCHAY is a home-based pregnancy testing kit.
  • It falls under the family planning component of the RMNCH+A strategy of the RCH (Reproductive Child Health) program.

Family Planning Programme:

Mission Parivar Vikas
  • It aims to promote family planning and reduce the population
  • Nayi pahel kit- family planning kit for newlyweds
  • Saas bahu samelan- encourages daughter-in-law and mother-in-law to discuss family planning
  • Saarthi- family planning mobile van

NISHCHAY
  • Home testing UPT provided by ASHA

Jansankhya sthirata kosh
  • Population stabilization fund ADD ON: provides incentives for delaying marriage, birth spacing

Gather approach
  • Contraception counseling method
  • Stands for Greet, Ask, Tell, Help, Explain, and Return

NIKSHAY (Option B): Technology-based surveillance for TB patients (TB DOTS - NTΕΡ).

NIKSUTH (Option C): Technology-based surveillance for Leprosy patients.

AXSHYA (Option D): Nationwide TB initiative funded by the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, TB, and Malaria.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with a malodorous vaginal discharge that started a week earlier. On examination, the Whiff's test is positive, and the Gram stain shows the presence of clue cells. This infection is commonly treated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Metronidazole

Explanation:

  • In this patient, bacterial vaginosis is confirmed by:
    • Presence of clue cells on microscopy
    • Positive Whiff test
  • Clue cells are epithelial cells embedded with rod-shaped bacteria
  • The antibiotic of choice is Metronidazole, a nitroimidazole antimicrobial

 

Diagnosis Methods and Treatment for Bacterial Vaginosis

Diagnostic Methods

Amsel's Criteria

  • Presence of clue cells (more than 20% of the total cell population)
  • Positive whiff test
  • Vaginal pH greater than 4.5
  • Thin, white, homogeneous vaginal discharge
 

Microscopic Examination

  • Detection of clue cells in vaginal smear
 

Molecular Methods

  • Detection of ribosomal RNA of Gardnerella vaginalis using PCR

Treatment:

First-Line Treatment

  • Oral Metronidazole: 500 mg BD for 7 days
  • Tinidazole 2 g orally for 3 days

Alternative Treatment

  • Clindamycin 300 mg orally BD for 7 days

Nystatin pessary (Option B): Nystatin pessary is used to treat vaginal candidiasis, characterized by thick, white, cottage cheese-like discharge without malodor. The presence of clue cells and positive Whiff test rules out candidiasis.

Tetracycline (Option C): Tetracycline is not the first-line treatment for BV due to its broad spectrum and potential to further disrupt vaginal flora. It is more commonly used for conditions like chlamydia.

Azithromycin (Option D): This macrolide antibiotic is primarily used to treat cervicitis caused by Chlamydia trachomatis and does not effectively target the anaerobic bacteria involved in BV.

questions.text: What dose of folic acid is recommended for a woman who wants to become pregnant but has a history of pregnancy complicated with a neural tube defect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 4 mg/day

Explanation:

  • For women who have a history of a pregnancy complicated by a neural tube defect (NTD), the recommended dose of folic acid is higher than the standard prenatal recommendation. The standard daily recommendation for folic acid in pregnancy is 400 micrograms (mcg) per day.
  • However, in cases where there is a history of a previous pregnancy affected by NTD, the recommended dose of folic acid is typically higher, usually around 4,000 micrograms (4 milligrams) per day.
  • This higher dosage is prescribed to help reduce the risk of recurrence of NTDs in future pregnancies.

 

400 mcg/day (Option A): This is the standard recommended dose of folic acid for most women of childbearing age who are planning a pregnancy. However, for women with a history of an NTD-affected pregnancy, a higher dose is recommended to provide additional protection.

1 mg/day (Option B) & 2 mg/day (Option C): While this is a higher dose compared to the standard recommendation, it is still lower than the recommended dose for women with a history of an NTD-affected pregnancy. The specific recommendation in this case is a higher dose of 4 mg/day.

questions.text: What is the condition characterized by painless vision loss?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Central retinal vein occlusion

Explanation:

The above fundoscopy image given is that of ‘splashed tomato’ appearance and sudden painless loss of vision are classical features of ischaemic central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO). Splashed sauce appearance is characterized by severe tortuosity and engorgement of all branches of the central retinal vein involving the peripheral and posterior retina.

CRVO:

Risk Factors

Age > 50 years (primary risk factor), Hypertension, Diabetes Mellitus, Hyperlipidemia, Glaucoma (increased IOP), Smoking, Hypercoagulable states

Pathogenesis

Thrombosis driven by venous stasis, endothelial damage, and hypercoagulability

Types

Non-ischemic CRVO (Venous stasis retinopathy) (75% of cases)

  • Mild to moderate, unilateral blurring of vision
  • Fundus: Mild venous congestion and tortuosity, flame-shaped hemorrhages, mild macular edema

 

Ischemic CRVO (Hemorrhagic retinopathy)

  • Severe, sudden visual loss, massive venous engorgement, "splashed-tomato" hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, macular edema
  • Marked vein sheathing, collaterals, neovascularization, chronic cystoid edema

Investigations
  • Ocular Exam: Visual acuity, IOP, Slit-lamp exam (NVI), Gonioscopy (NVA)
  • Goldmann Perimetry and ERG: Differentiating ischemic vs non-ischemic CRVO
  • Fundus Fluorescein Angiography (FFA): Assess retinal perfusion
  • Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT): Assess macular edema, sub-retinal fluid

Treatment
  • Systemic Management: Control of systemic conditions (hypertension, diabetes, hyperlipidemia, hyperhomocysteinemia)
  • Medical Treatment: Intravitreal anti-VEGF (e.g., Bevacizumab), intravitreal steroids (Triamcinolone, Dexamethasone implant)
  • Laser Therapy: Panretinal photocoagulation (PRP) for neovascularization
  • Surgical: Pars plana vitrectomy for complications

Complications

Neovascular glaucoma, Neovascularization of the iris (NVI), Vitreous hemorrhage, Proliferative retinopathy, Chronic macular edema

Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) (Option A): Cherry red spot seen on fundoscopy.

Branched retinal artery occlusion (BRAO) (Option B): Focal area of ischaemia due to vascular occlusion of branch of retinal artery.

Branched retinal vein occlusion (BRAO) (Option B): Sectorial superficial retinal hemorrhages are seen on fundoscopy.

questions.text: Serial monitoring of serum beta hCG is required for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Molar pregnancy

Explanation:

Hydatidiform mole or molar pregnancy is classified as a benign form of GTD and is characterized by abnormal growth of trophoblastic tissue in the uterus. This results in swollen, fluid-filled villi and significantly elevated β-hCG levels (often in the range of 100,000 mIU/mL or higher). Though initially benign, they can sometimes progress to persistent gestational trophoblastic disease or malignancy.

Downs syndrome (Option A): Downs syndrome is diagnosed through prenatal screening and NIPT.

Pregnancy-associated with Neural tube defects (Option B): Neural tube defects are detected through ultrasound and genetic testing.

Rh-negative pregnancy (Option D): Rh-negative pregnancy doesn't require routine hCG monitoring.

questions.text: An 8-month-old baby on examination shows signs of vitamin A deficiency. What is the dose of vitamin A to be administered to the baby?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - 100,000 IU orally

  • For infants aged 6-11 months, the recommended dose of vitamin A to treat deficiency is 100,000 IU administered orally.
  • This dosing is based on WHO guidelines for vitamin A supplementation in children to prevent and treat deficiency, which is crucial for proper immune function, vision, and overall health.

 

<6 months

6 months-1 year

> 1 year

Day 0

50000 IU

1 lakh IU

2 Lac IU

Day 1

50000 IU

1 lakh IU

2 Lac IU

Day 2

50000 IU

1 lakh IU

2 Lac IU

questions.text: Which kit would you recommend for the treatment of a 20-year-old female who has recently engaged in sexual intercourse and is experiencing vaginal discharge and lower abdominal pain when following the syndromic management approach for sexually transmitted infections at the Suraksha clinic in the local primary health center?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Yellow

  • Lower abdominal pain with vaginal discharge indicative of PID (Pelvic Inflammatory Disease).
  • Hence, the kit to be prescribed is a yellow kit that covers the syndrome.

Colour-coded STD kits along with medicines:

Kit

Colour

Indication

Medicines

1

Grey
  • Urethral discharge
  • Cervicitis
  • Ano-rectal discharge

Azithromycin, cefixime

2

Green

Vaginitis

Secnidazole, fluconazole

3

White

Non-herpetic genital ulcers

Azithromycin, B. Penicillin

4

Blue (Option A)
  • Genital ulcers
  • Penicillin allergy +

Azithromycin, doxycycline

5

Red (Option B)

Herpetic genital ulcers

Acyclovir

6

Yellow

Lower abdominal pain

Cefixime metronidazole, doxycycline

7

Black (Option C)

Inguinal bubo

Azithromycin, doxycycline

8

Brown

Anorectal discharge syndrome

Cefixime, doxycycline

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a woman who has a previous infertility history and is currently undergoing HMG treatment, based on the following findings in the USG?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome

Explanation:

Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome is a clinical symptom complex associated with ovarian enlargement resulting from exogenous gonadotropin therapy. OHSS is characterized by ultrasound showing enlarged ovaries and multiple cysts.

Key Features:

  • Exaggerated response to excess hormones
  • Occurs with injectable hormone medications for ovarian stimulation
  • Causes ovarian swelling and pain
  • USG shows bilateral symmetric enlargement (>12 cm) with multiple cysts

Theca lutein cyst (Option B): Theca lutein cysts occur with hCG excess, not with HMG therapy (multiple gestations, molar pregnancies)

PCOD (Option C): While PCOS can show multiple follicles, they are typically smaller and more uniform in size. Also, PCOD diagnosis requires clinical, laboratory, and imaging findings

questions.text: Which of the following is used to reduce the selection bias in a clinical trial?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Randomization

  • Randomization in clinical trials minimizes selection bias by randomly assigning participants to treatment or control groups.
  • This ensures equal chances of placement, reducing the influence of confounding factors
  • It balances known and unknown variables across groups, enhancing comparability and mitigating selection bias.

Randomisation
  • The technique where every participant will get an equal and known chance of being allocated to either the treatment group or the control group.
  • Eliminates both known and unknown confounders.
  • Selection bias is avoided by randomisation, which arises when the participants are not representative of the target population.

In a clinical trial, patients are randomly assigned to receive either a new drug or a placebo, balancing out confounding variables.

 

Types of Bias

Subject Bias

Investigator Bias

Analysis Bias
  • Recall bias
  • Hawthorne bias
  • Reporting bias
  • Non-response bias
  • Selection bias
    • Berksonian
    • Neyman
    • Reporting
  • Publication bias
  • Misclassification bias
  • Interviewer bias
  • Pygmalion bias
  • Golem bias (blunting of response due to demotivated observer)
  • Statistical bias

Selecting the population, intervention, and written informed consent (Options A, B, and D): do not directly address selection bias.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions are associated with oligohydramnios?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Renal agenesis

Explanation:

  • Renal agenesis occurs when one or both kidneys fail to develop during embryonic development. Around the 13th week of gestation, the kidneys begin producing urine, which contributes to amniotic fluid. Impaired kidney development leads to oligohydramnios, characterized by low amniotic fluid levels, which can be detected via ultrasound and serves as a strong indicator of renal agenesis.

 

Clinical Manifestations:

  • Potter facies: Low-set ears, beaked nose, prominent epicanthic folds, downward slant to eyes
  • Pulmonary hypoplasia causing respiratory failure
  • Limb deformities
  • Reduced fetal urine excretion
  • Oligohydramnios causing fetal compression

 

Associated Complications:

  • Growth restriction
  • Limb contractures
  • Mortality
  • Delayed lung maturation
  • Inability to endure childbirth

 

Neural tube defect (Option B): Neural tube defects are associated with polyhydramnios.

Esophageal atresia (Option C): Esophageal atresia occurs due to excess amniotic fluid (polyhydramnios).

Premature birth (Option D): Premature birth is a complication of oligohydramnios, not a cause.

questions.text: What type of statistical diagram is used in the given text to illustrate the population change between 1983 and 1989 in a specific location?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Component bar graph

  • A Component bar graph, also known as a Stacked bar graph, displays the parts-to-whole relationship within a category.
  • It may not be suitable for depicting population change over time unless the population is divided into different components.

Types of bar diagrams:

Image

Explanation

Simple Bar Diagram

  • Simple bar diagrams represent the frequency of discrete variables like gender.
  • Discrete variables:These variables take fewer values and no in between values.
    • Examples: Religion, Blood groups

​​Compound Bar Diagram

  • There are gaps (discrete data) represented with multiple bars.
  • It is qualitative in the first quarter.
  • It is a Multiple bar diagram/Compound bar diagram.

Component Bar Diagram

  • Same bar has been divided into different components and each component represents its frequency.
  • It is a frequency of discrete variables.
  • It is known as the Component bar diagram.

 

 

Histogram (Option A)
  • It is not a bar diagram.
  • It represents the frequency of continuous variables or quantitative variables.
  • Height is a quantitative or continuous variable (can take many possible values and also in between values)
  • It can be expressed in decimals and there is no gap in between.

 

A line chart is used for showing trends of events or incidence of cases over time. It has both rise and fall. (Option B)

Line chart
