Multiple bar graphs (Option D): as the name suggests, consist of multiple bars representing different categories or variables. They are typically used to compare values between different groups or categories, rather than tracking changes over time.

questions.text: During your internship, you notice the following instrument being used by the senior resident. The uses of this instrument include all the following except?

choices.text: To differentiate between chronic inversion and fibroid polyp
It is used to diagnose cervical stenosis
It is used in fallopian tube recanalization
It is used to measure the uterine cavity and the cervical length

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) It is used in fallopian tube recanalization

Explanation:

  • The instrument shown is a Sims uterine sound, not used for fallopian tube recanalization.

 

Primary Uses of Sims Uterine Sound:

  • Measuring uterine and cervical length (Option D)
  • Diagnosing cervical stenosis (Option B)
  • Differentiating chronic inversion from fibroid polyp
  • Assessing uterine tilt/position
  • Facilitating D&C procedures
  • IUD placement guidance
  • Used in fallopian tube recanalization (Option C)

questions.text: A 56-year-old multiparous woman presented with grade II/III uterine prolapse with cystocele. She complains of passing urine on coughing and sneezing. What type of urinary incontinence is seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Stress incontinence

Explanation:

The clinical manifestations indicate Stress Urinary Incontinence (SUI), which is involuntary leakage of urine during physical activities involving increasd intra-abdominal pressure.

  • Urine leakage with increased intra-abdominal pressure (coughing, sneezing)
  • Associated pelvic organ prolapse (uterine prolapse with cystocele)
  • Risk factors present: multiparity, postmenopausal status
  • Physical examination shows grade II/III uterine prolapse

Urinary incontinence is the most common complication associated with pelvic organ prolapse.

 

Risk Factors:

  • Age and menopause
  • Multiparity
  • Obesity
  • Smoking
  • Constipation
  • Pelvic organ prolapse
  • Pregnancy
  • Puerperium

 

Grades of Stress Incontinence:

  1. Grade I: Severe stress
  2. Grade II: Moderate stress
  3. Grade III: Mild stress

 

Overflow incontinence (Option A): Overflow incontinence presents with constant dribbling due to bladder outlet obstruction

Urge incontinence (Option B): Urge incontinence involves sudden, strong urge to urinate with an overactive bladder.

Neurogenic bladder (Option D): Neurogenic bladder results from disrupted nerve signals between the bladder and brain, causing dribbling urine & inability to perceive that the bladder is full.

questions.text: According to WHO, what is the minimum number of antenatal visits?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - 8

  • According to the WHO, the ideal number of antenatal visits (or Antenatal care contact) is 8.

Schedule of visits:

  • 1st Trimester: 1 visit ( in the first 12 weeks)
  • 2nd Trimester: 2 visits ( at 20 & 26 weeks)
  • 3rd Trimester: 5 visits ( at 30, 34, 36, 38 and 40 weeks)

It recommends that pregnant women have their first contact in the first 12 weeks of gestation, with subsequent contacts taking place at 20, 26, 30, 34, 36, 38, and 40 weeks’ gestation.

questions.text: Which serotype of HPV is responsible for Ca Cervix?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 16,18,31,33

Explanation:

Primary serotypes strongly associated with cervical cancer are HPV-16 and HPV-18

  • These high-risk types contribute to approximately 70% of all cervical cancer cases worldwide
  • Other high-risk types include HPV-31, HPV-33, and HPV-45.

Risk types of Human Papilloma Virus

Low Risk

6, 11, 42, 43, and 44.

High Risk

16, 18, 31, 33, 34, 35, 39, 45, 51, 52, 56, 58, 59, 66, 68, and 70

16 and 18 are responsible for most cancers.

(Option A & C): HPV-19 is not a high-risk type for cervical cancer.

(Option B): HPV-32 is considered a low-risk type.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old primigravida at 10 weeks gestation comes to the ER with nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. Nausea and vomiting began one day back, and now the patient is unable to tolerate fluids. She complains of pain in the right upper quadrant, which started a few hours back. On examination, her temperature is 100.2 F, her pulse is 119 bpm, and her BP is 110/70 mm of Hg. She has swelling of her lower limbs up to the ankles bilaterally. Abdominal examination shows a gravid uterus corresponding to 10 weeks of gestation and tenderness in the right upper quadrant, with mild guarding and is diagnosed as acute appendicitis. What is the next step of management?

Laboratory Findings: Complete blood count:


	Haemoglobin: 11g/dl
	Leukocytes: 13,000 cells/μl
	Platelets: 150,000 cells/μl


Liver Function tests:


	AST: 40U/L
	ALT: 48U/L


Urinalysis:


	Protein: negative
	Pus cells: 1-2/HPF
	Bacteria: none


USG abdomen: Reveals a 9.7mm diameter, aperistaltic, non-compressible, dilated, blind-ending structure arising from the base of the caecum.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Do appendicectomy

Explanation:

The patient shows classic symptoms of appendicitis:

  • Nausea and vomiting (1 day)
  • Right upper quadrant pain
  • Unable to tolerate fluids
  • Leukocytosis (13,000 cells/μl)
  • USG shows 9.7mm diameter, aperistaltic, non-compressible, dilated blind-ending structure from cecum

Acute appendicitis requires immediate surgery regardless of gestational age to prevent maternal and fetal complications.

 

Management Protocol for appendectomy in pregnancy:

  • Immediate appendicectomy indicated
  • Pre-operative care includes:
    • GI intubation
    • Parenteral replacement of IV fluids and electrolytes
    • Administration of Antibiotics
  • Antibiotics and IV fluids until surgery
  • Analgesics after diagnosis
  • Poor prognosis in pregnancy due to increased risk of abortion, sepsis, preterm labor
  • Can be performed under general/spinal anesthesia with laparoscopy or open method

 

Wait till 2nd trimester (Option B): Acute appendicitis is a surgical emergency; delaying treatment will increase the chances of complications.

Conservative management (Option C): Conservative management is not recommended with clear appendicitis signs.

Reassurance (Option D): Reassurance alone is inappropriate for suspected acute appendicitis.

questions.text: You are a doctor in a village. A 1-year-old child who is not taking feeds presents with fever and cough for 2 days. On examination, he is calm, with a respiratory rate of 51 breaths/min, and stridor is present. According to IMNCI (integrated management of neonatal and childhood illnesses). How is he classified?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Severe pneumonia

  • A calm child with stridor and fast breathing in the age group of 2 months- 5 years is classified as having Severe Pneumonia

(Options A and B ruled out)

ARDS (Option D): ARDS is not classified under IMNCI guidelines. It is a critical care diagnosis based on specific criteria such as:

  • Acute onset of respiratory distress.
  • Bilateral infiltrates on chest imaging.
  • PaO₂/FiO₂ ratio ≤300 mmHg.

questions.text: Which filter is used in a colposcope?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Green

Explanation:

  • In Colposcopy, a green (red-free) light filter is used to add contrast to aid vascular pattern visualization.
  • Colposcopy is a diagnostic procedure in which a lighted magnifying instrument called a colposcope is used to examine the cervix, vagina, and vulva.
  • The procedure is performed to evaluate patients with an abnormal Papanicolaou (Pap) test, those who test positive for high-risk human papillomavirus (HPV) DNA, or those with a suspicious appearing cervix, even if screening for dysplasia is negative.
  • It may also be performed as a posttreatment follow-up of cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) and invasive carcinoma.

Black (Option A): Black filter is not used in colposcopy as it restricts light and makes visualization difficult

Red (Option B): Red filter is not commonly used as it can alter the color perception of cervical tissue

Yellow (Option D): Yellow filter, while capable of enhancing certain tissue characteristics, is not typically preferred for routine examinations

questions.text: Which of the following instruments are considered the gold standard for measuring intraocular pressure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Goldmann applanation tonometer

Explanation:

The gold standard instrument for measuring intraocular pressure is Goldmann applanation tonometer.

Applanation Tonometry:

  • Concept: Measures IOP based on the force needed to flatten the cornea's surface (Imbert-Fick Law: P = W/A).
  • Goldmann Applanation Tonometer: (Option B)
    • Most popular and accurate; uses a double prism on a slit lamp.
    • Technique:
      • Cornea is anesthetized and stained with fluorescein.
      • Cornea and biprisms are illuminated with cobalt blue light.
      • The prism touches the cornea, and the inner edges of two semicircles are adjusted to just touch.
      • IOP is read by multiplying the dial reading by ten.

[1]

 

Variable force tonometers:

  • Goldmann applanation tonometer → Gold standard
  • Perkins tonometer (hand held version of goldmann)
    • Draeger tonometer (measures wide range of IOP)
    • Draeger tonometer is similar to Perkins
    • It has a different set of prisms
    • It operates with a motor
  • Pulsair (non-contact tonometer)
  • Tonopen (based on both indentation and applanation) (Option D)
  • Rebound tonometer

Fixed force tonometers:

  • Maklakov tonometer
  • Barraquer tonometer

Gonioscope (Option A): Gonioscope is used to visualize the angle of the anterior chamber.

Hertel’s exophthalmometer (Option C): Hertel’s exophthalmometer is used to measure the protrusion of the apex of the cornea from the outer orbital margin.

questions.text: Which of the following is an absolute contraindication for the device shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Vaginal bleeding

  • The given image is of Copper T, an Intrauterine contraceptive device (IUDs).
  • Vaginal bleeding is an absolute contraindication for the use of IUDs

Contraindications to IUD insertion:

    • Purulent discharge
    • Uterine cavity distortion (fibroid, congenital malformations) (Options C, D)

questions.text: In a patient diagnosed with a stroke, their visual field testing indicated macula sparing homonymous hemianopia. Where is the probable location of the lesion within the optic pathway?

Homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing after a stroke which is indicative of the lesion being at the occipital lobe (visual cortex). It is because they are responsible for macular vision gas dual blood supply via posterior cerebral arteries and middle cerebral artery.

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for maintaining the births and deaths in India?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Vital registration system

  • The Vital Registration System is a comprehensive and continuous system for the registration of births and deaths.
  • It involves the mandatory registration of every birth and death occurrence with the relevant government authorities, typically at the local or municipal level.
  • The system aims to provide a complete and official record of vital events in the country.

Cause of death in India is noted by multiple methods, including:

  • Sample registration system:
    • It is a demographic survey conducted by the Registrar General of India.
    • It collects data on births and deaths through a representative sample of households, including information on the cause of death.
  • Census: (Option B)
    • The census is primarily focused on population enumeration and demographic details.
    • It does not directly record causes of death.
    • During the decennial Census, information on deaths that occurred during the census year is collected.
    • Census enumerators gather data from households, including details of the causes of death reported by family members.
  • Death declaration & medical certificate: (Option C)
    • When a person dies, a medical certificate of cause of death (MCCD) is typically issued by a qualified medical practitioner who attended to the deceased during their last illness.
    • The MCCD provides information about the immediate cause of death, underlying causes, and contributing factors.
  • Lay reporting: (Option D)
    • Lay reporting refers to the reporting of deaths by individuals or non-medical personnel.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a possible cause of the salt and pepper appearance of the fundus in a patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Tuberculosis

Explanation:

  • Tuberculosis is NOT associated with ‘salt and pepper’ appearance of fundus among the given options.

Differential diagnoses of Salt & pepper fundus:

  • Prenatal Rubella (Option A)
  • Congenital Syphilis (Option B)
  • Varicella
  • Mumps
  • Retinitis pigmentosa
  • Leber congenital amaurosis
  • Drugs: Thioridazine (anti-psychotic)

Syndromes associated with Retinitis pigmentosa:

  • Usher syndrome
  • Kearns-Sayre syndrome
  • Refsum’s disease (Option C)
  • Bardet-Biedl syndrome
  • Bassen-Kornzweig syndrome

questions.text: What is the most frequent association of lung malignancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Asbestosis

  • Asbestosis is strongly associated with lung malignancy, particularly bronchogenic carcinoma and mesothelioma.

Asbestosis:

  • Asbestosis is a diffuse interstitial fibrosing disease of the lung.
  • Past exposure to asbestos is specifically indicated by pleural plaques on chest radiographs, which are characterized by either thickening or calcification along the parietal pleura, particularly along the lower lung fields.
  • Pulmonary function testing in asbestosis reveals a restrictive pattern with a decrease in both lung volumes and diffusing capacity.
  • Complications include carcinoma of lung and mesothelioma.

Silicosis (Option B): Silicosis is a lung disease caused by inhaling silica dust, which increases the risk of tuberculosis and may slightly elevate the risk of lung cancer. However, the association with lung malignancy is much weaker compared to asbestosis.

Bagassosis (Option C): Bagassosis is a hypersensitivity pneumonitis caused by exposure to sugarcane bagasse dust. It does not have a known association with lung malignancy.

Byssinosis (Option D): Byssinosis is an occupational lung disease caused by inhaling cotton, flax, or hemp dust. It primarily leads to chronic obstructive airway disease and is not associated with lung cancer.

questions.text: In the image provided, which refractive error is observed in the depicted condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Myopia and astigmatism

Explanation:

  • The image given above is that of Munson’s sign which is the V-shaped conformation of the lower lid produced by the ectatic cornea in downgaze seen in Keratoconus. The refractive error seen in keratoconus is myopia and irregular astigmatism leading to defective vision.

Keratoconus:

Description
  • Progressive, non-inflammatory bilateral ectatic corneal condition affecting the axial part.

Pathology
  • Involves progressive thinning and ectasia of the cornea due to defective synthesis of mucopolysaccharides and collagen.

Clinical Features
  • Defective vision due to progressive myopia and irregular astigmatism (uncorrectable by glasses) (Option B)
  • Blurred and distorted vision, glare, and halos around lights
  • Light sensitivity and ocular irritation
  • Visual loss primarily from irregular astigmatism and myopia, secondary loss from corneal scarring

Examination Findings
  • Distorted Window Reflex: Visual irregularity on corneal reflection.
  • Placido Disc Irregularity: Irregular circles.
  • Slit-Lamp Examination:
    • Thinning and ectasia of the central cornea.
    • Opacity at the apex, Fleischer Ring (brownish ring around the cone due to haemosiderin in the epithelium).
    • Folds in Descemet's and Bowman's membranes.
  • Vogt Striae: Fine, parallel striae at the apex, disappearing with external pressure.
  • Oil Droplet Reflex: Annular dark shadow separating central and peripheral cornea in distant direct ophthalmoscopy.
  • Retinoscopy: Yawning reflex (scissor reflex) with high oblique/irregular astigmatism.
  • Ophthalmoscope Findings: Irregular astigmatism and progressive myopia, poorly corrected by glasses in later stages.
  • Munson's Sign: Localized bulging of the lower lid when looking down (seen in late stages).
  • Keratometer Findings: Malformed, malaligned, and malfocused mires.
  • Corneal Topography: Sensitive method for early detection, shows corneal surface shape.

Management

Spectacle Correction:

  • Effective in the early stages, but contact lenses are more beneficial.
  • Less effective in later stages due to irregular astigmatism.

Contact Lenses:

  • Rigid gas permeable lenses improve vision in early cases.
  • Specially designed scleral lenses (e.g., Rose-K) are useful in early to moderate cases.

Corneal Collagen Cross-Linking (CXL):

  • New treatment modality to slow disease progression.
  • Involves Riboflavin (0.1%) eye drops and UVA radiation.
  • Riboflavin induces cross-linking of corneal collagen to stabilize the stroma and improve contact lens tolerance.

Keratoplasty :

  • Recommended if disease progresses or in cases of acute hydrops (Descemet's membrane tear).
  • Reserved for more advanced diseases or when other treatments fail.
  • Penetrating keratoplasty is common, but Deep Anterior Lamellar Keratoplasty (DALK) is preferred if Descemet's membrane and endothelium are intact, reducing rejection risk.

Intracorneal Ring Segments (INTACS) :

  • Effective in early to moderate cases by flattening the cornea.
  • Less effective in halting progression.

questions.text: When quarantine was introduced in the 14th century for plague, how many days were people who were suspected to have the infection quarantined for?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - 40 days

  • The term "quarantine" originates from the Italian word "quaranta," meaning 40.
  • In the 14th century, during the outbreak of the bubonic plague, authorities in maritime cities like Venice implemented a rule that ships arriving from infected ports had to anchor for 40 days before passengers and crew could disembark.
  • This 40-day isolation period was chosen for religious and practical reasons, as it was believed to be long enough to determine whether someone had the disease.

Public health strategies:

  1. Isolation separates individuals who are already ill and potentially infectious from others for the maximum period of communicability to prevent disease spread. It can occur either in healthcare facilities or at home, depending on illness severity and resource availability. It is a defensive strategy.
  2. Quarantine separates and restricts the movement of individuals exposed to a contagious disease for a maximum known incubation period, but not yet symptomatic to monitor for symptoms and prevent potential disease spread upon becoming infectious.

Isolation and quarantine are examples of primary prevention.

  1. Social distancing is a public health measure involving maintaining physical distance and avoiding crowded places or gatherings. It aims to prevent the transmission of infectious diseases but applies broadly, not specifically to individuals already ill.
  2. Contact tracing is the process of identifying and monitoring individuals in close contact with an infected person. It is used to identify potential secondary cases and implement appropriate measures, such as quarantine or testing, to prevent further transmission.

questions.text: Which benefit does a patient receive when seeking treatment at an ESI hospital under the ESI Act?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Medical benefit

  • When seeking treatment at an ESI hospital, the primary benefit received is medical care, falling under the Medical Benefit category.

Benefits of ESI (Employees State Insurance) Act

Medical Benefit
  • Provides "full medical care," including hospitalization at no cost to insured individuals & families in cases of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.

Sickness Benefit (Option A)
  • Provides 70% of average daily wages in cash during medical leave for a maximum of 91 days within 365 days, as certified by the Insurance Medical Officer/Practitioner.

Extended Sickness Benefit
  • Extended coverage for long-term diseases beyond 91 days; 34 diseases covered if employed for two years.
  • Extended sickness benefit is paid at 80% of the insured person's wages.

Enhanced Sickness Benefit
  • Cash benefits (100% wages) for sterilization procedures:
    • 14 days for tubectomy (women),
    • 7 days for vasectomy (men).

Maternity Benefit (Option C)
  • Cash payments for childbirth, miscarriage, or pregnancy-related sickness:
    • 26 weeks for childbirth,
    • 6 weeks for miscarriage, and
    • 40 days for pregnancy-related sickness.
  • Paid at 100% of the insured woman's average daily wages.

Disablement Benefit
  • Temporary Disablement Benefit (TDB):
    • 90% of wages paid from day one for temporary employment injury, until recovery.
  • Permanent Disablement Benefit (PDB):
    • 90% of wages paid monthly for life, based on certified loss of earning capacity.

Dependent's Benefit (Option D)
  • Dependents receive 90% of the deceased's (due to employment injuries) wages as a shared pension, and they are eligible until age 18.
  • If the daughter marries before 18, the benefit is withdrawn.

Funeral Expenses
  • It offers a cash payment of up to Rs. 15,000 to cover funeral expenses upon the death of an insured individual.

Rehabilitation

 
  • Insured individuals and their families are entitled to continued medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.
  • They have to pay a nominal fee of Rs.10 per month for this benefit.
  • A rehabilitation allowance of Rs.15,000 granted.

Unemployment allowance
  • For eligible employees due to factory closure or retrenchment: 50% of wage for up to two years.

questions.text: What is the proportion of the distribution within one standard deviation of the mean in a normal curve?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A-

  • One standard deviation from the mean captures about 68% of the total data points.
  • This means that 68% of the values in a normal distribution lie within one standard deviation above or below the mean.

A Gaussian/bell-shaped curve showing normal distribution forms when the point of coincidence is equal to mean = median = mode ~ Normal distribution

In a standard normal distribution

  • Mean = Median = mode = 0
  • Standard deviation = 1
  • Total area under the curve = 1

Area under the curve

Observation covered

Mean +/- 1 SD

68.3% ~ 68% of observation

Mean +/- 2 SD

95.4% ~ 95% of observation (Option D)

Mean +/- 3 SD

99.7% ~ 99% of observation (Option C)

Mean +/- ∞SD

100% of observation

34% (Option B): is the percentage of the distribution that falls within the half standard deviation of the mean.

questions.text: If Bajra is mixed with black seeds, what is used to separate them?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - 20% salt water

  • A 20% salt water solution creates a density that makes black seeds sink, while Bajra seeds stay afloat, making the separation easy.

Ergotism:

  • Ergot is a fungus (Claviceps purpurea) that infects food grains such as bajra, rye, sorghum, and wheat during their flowering stages.
  • Consumption of ergot-infested grains can lead to ergotism, characterised by acute symptoms such as nausea, repeated vomiting, giddiness, and drowsiness lasting up to 24 to 48 hours.
  • In chronic cases, ergotism may cause painful cramps in limbs and peripheral gangrene due to vasoconstriction of capillaries.
  • Modern high-yielding varieties of bajra are more susceptible to ergot infestation.
  • Infested grains can be removed in 20% salt water, hand-picking, or air floatation.
  • The upper safe limit for ergot alkaloids in food material is 0.05 mg per 100 grams.

questions.text: What type of resistance is exhibited by the patient who is unresponsive to Isoniazid, Rifampicin, Ofloxacin, and Kanamycin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Extensively drug-resistant

  • Extensively drug-resistant (XDR) is a term used to describe a type of resistance in which the microorganism is resistant to a wide range of antibiotics, including those considered first-line and second-line treatment options.
  • The patient's resistance to Isoniazid, Rifampicin, Ofloxacin, and Kanamycin indicates an extensive resistance pattern, meeting the criteria for XDR.

Classification of TB Patients Based on Drug Testing

Category

Description

Drug sensitive TB

Patients are sensitive to 4 TB drugs: R,H,Z,E (Rifampicin, Isoniazid, Pyrazinamide, Ethambutol).

Mono-resistant (MR)

Resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.

H-Mono-resistant (H-MR)

Resistant to Isoniazid (H) only.

Rifampicin resistant (RR) (Option C)

Resistant to Rifampicin (R) only.

Multi-drug resistant (MDR) (Option A)

Resistant to both Rifampicin (R) & Isoniazid (H).

Poly-Drug resistant (PDR)

Resistant to 2 drugs other than Rifampicin (R) & Isoniazid (H).

Pre-Xtensive resistant (pre-XDR)

Any MDR patient (H+R) resistant to any fluoroquinolone.

Extensive resistant (XDR)

Any MDR patient (H+R) resistant to any fluoroquinolone and Group 4 drugs (Bedaquiline, Linezolid, Levo/Moxifloxacin).

Extremely drug-resistant (Option D): It is likely a variation of the term "extensively drug resistant" (as seen in option b), but it is not a commonly used or accepted term in the context of drug resistance.

questions.text: As a Medical Officer in charge of a Primary Health Center, you intend to engage in a conversation and address health concerns specifically with Antenatal mothers. What would be the ideal number of participants you would include in the focus group discussion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - 6-12

  • This range is generally considered ideal for a focal group discussion. It allows for a sufficient number of participants to provide diverse viewpoints and experiences, while still keeping the group manageable for effective facilitation and participation.

Focus group discussion:

Key Points

Description

Data Collection Technique

Focus Group Discussion (FGD) is a qualitative method, in the form of two-way communication

Participants

6-12 people seated in a circle, guided by a Moderator.

Role of Moderator

The active role of Leading the FGD by asking 10-12 open-ended, guiding questions.

Sociogram Purpose

Reflects the quality and interactiveness of the FGD.

Sociogram Definition

A diagram or chart created by an observer to represent the interaction dynamics during the FGD.

Role of Recorder

A separate individual is responsible for recording the discussion, with participants’ prior permission.

Data Analysis

Focuses on identifying common themes emerging from the discussion.

Communication Style

The FGD is interactive and two-way (Socratic), encouraging dialogue among participants and between participants and the Moderator.

questions.text: A diabetic patient comes to you for advice regarding his diet. You advise him to include foods with a low glycemic index in the diet. Which of the following would you advise him for the same?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Papaya

  • A diabetic patient should include low glycemic index (GI) foods in their diet, as these foods cause a slower and more gradual rise in blood sugar levels.
  • From the options provided: Papaya: Low GI (55 or less) – Recommended for diabetic patients.

Classification

GI Index Range

Examples

Low GI

55 or less

Most fruits and vegetables (except potatoes, watermelon, sweetcorn), whole grains, pasta foods, beans, lentils, oats, quinoa, guava

Medium GI

56-69

Sucrose, basmati rice, brown rice, dairy products (Options B, C)

High GI

70 and above

Corn flakes, baked potato, some white rice varieties (e.g., jasmine), white bread, candy bar, syrupy foods (Options A)

questions.text: You are a junior resident in the ICU. A senior doctor asks you to manage a mechanically ventilated patient whose arterial blood gasses showed features of hypoventilation with respiratory acidosis. Which of the following parameters can you modulate to improve the condition of the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Increase respiratory rate

Explanation:

  • In the above case, the patient has features of hypoventilation along with respiratory acidosis.
    • This indicates that it is a type 2 respiratory failure.
    • It is corrected by increasing the respiratory rate which increases ventilation and decreases CO2 concentration and provides improvement.
    • Therefore in order to correct hypoxia and hypercapnia, respiratory rate needs to be increased.

Four key Ventilator parameters:

  • Respiratory Rate (RR): Breaths per minute. Primarily affects CO2 removal (ventilation).
  • Tidal Volume (TV): Volume of air per breath. Also affects CO2 removal (ventilation).
  • PEEP (Positive End-Expiratory Pressure): Pressure in the lungs at the end of expiration. Primarily affects oxygenation.
  • FiO2 (Fraction of Inspired Oxygen): Percentage of oxygen in the inspired air. Directly affects oxygen delivery.
  • Note: PEEP and FiO2 are for oxygenation, while RR and Tidal Volume are for ventilation (CO2 removal).

 

ABG Abnormality

Ventilator Adjustment

↓ PaO2

↑ PEEP or ↑ FiO2

(Option C ruled out)

↓ PaCO2

↓ respiratory rate or ↓ tidal volume

↑ PaCO2

↑ respiratory rate or ↑ tidal volume

(Option B)

Preferable to adjust RR (Respiratory Rate) over tidal volume in situations where low tidal volume ventilation is beneficial (i.e., ARDS).

 

Decrease FiO2 (Option A): reduces the fraction of inspired oxygen. While important in some situations, it doesn't directly address the CO2 buildup causing respiratory acidosis.

Increased PEEP (Option C): (Positive End-Expiratory Pressure) can improve oxygenation but doesn't directly help with CO2 removal.

Increase plateau pressure (Option D): reflects the pressure in the lungs during a breath hold. While important to monitor to prevent lung injury, simply increasing it doesn't directly improve CO2 removal and can also be harmful.

questions.text: While doing a subclavian venous catheterization, the patient suddenly desaturated and on examination of the chest, there was hyper resonance in the apical area of the right lung. What is the most likely diagnosis here?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Pneumothorax
 

Explanation:

  • Subclavian venous catheterization involves inserting a needle near the apex of the lung.
  • Pneumothorax occurs when air leaks into the space between the lung and the chest wall (pleural space).
    • This can happen as a complication of subclavian line placement if the needle punctures the lung.
    • Hyperresonance on chest examination is a classic sign of pneumothorax.
    • Desaturation (low oxygen saturation) is another expected finding in pneumothorax as the lung's ability to oxygenate blood is compromised.

 

Central Venous Catheter Insertion:

Indications:

  • Inaccessible peripheral veins
  • Hemodialysis
  • Central Venous Pressure (CVP) measurement.
  • Administration of drugs noxious to peripheral veins

Contraindications:

  • Thrombocytopenia:
  • Coagulopathies
  • Abnormal anatomy

Complications:

  • Immediate Complications:
    • Cardiac or vascular complications (arrhythmias, arterial/venous injuries, damage to major vessels)
    • Pulmonary complications (pneumothorax, chylothorax, nerve/tracheal injury, air embolism)
  • Delayed Complications:
    • Infections (sepsis, shock, death)
    • Device dysfunction (blockage, thrombosis, fracture, stenosis, infection)

 

Arterial puncture (Option A): While possible during subclavian line placement, it wouldn't directly cause hyperresonance. It would typically present with pulsatile blood return and potential hematoma formation.

Cardiac tamponade (Option C): This involves fluid accumulation in the sac around the heart, which would cause muffled heart sounds, not hyperresonance.

Chylothorax(Option D): This is the presence of lymphatic fluid in the pleural space, usually due to damage to the thoracic duct. It's less likely to occur acutely during subclavian line placement and wouldn't typically cause hyperresonance.

questions.text: A patient was given halothane for a surgical procedure. After a few minutes, the anesthetist noticed that he developed rigidity and hyperthermia. Which of the following ions is the reason for the above symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Calcium

Explanation:

  • The above patient presents with rigidity and hyperthermia after administration of halothane.
  • This is indicative towards the diagnosis of malignant hyperthermia and the ion involved is calcium.
  • It occurs due to prolonged opening of functionally altered ryanodine receptors, leading to uncontrolled release of calcium from sarcoplasmic reticulum causing sustained muscle contraction.

 

Malignant hyperthermia:

Feature

Description

Definition

Rare, life-threatening reaction to certain anesthetic medications (inhaled anesthetics, succinylcholine).

Inheritance

Often autosomal dominant with variable penetrance (meaning not everyone with the gene will develop the condition).

Underlying mechanism

Mutations in the ryanodine receptor (RYR1) gene cause uncontrolled release of calcium (Ca2+) from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, leading to sustained muscle contraction and heat generation.

Signs/Symptoms

Severe muscle rigidity, rapid rise in body temperature (hyperthermia), increased heart rate, metabolic acidosis.

Treatment

Dantrolene (a ryanodine receptor antagonist that reduces calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum and relaxes muscles).

questions.text: Which inhalational agent is best suited for patients with compromised cardiac function?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Desflurane

Explanation:

  • Desflurane is known for its rapid onset and offset of action, making it a suitable choice for patients with cardiac conditions.
  • It provides good cardiovascular stability and is associated with minimal metabolism in the body.
  • It is less likely to cause myocardial depression and is suitable for patients with compromised cardiac function.

 

Halothane (Option A): was once a commonly used anesthetic agent, but it has largely fallen out of favor due to its potential to cause arrhythmias and myocardial depression.

Isoflurane (Option B): Isoflurane is a widely used inhalational anesthetic agent with a relatively stable cardiovascular profile. It is often considered suitable for patients with cardiac conditions, but it might not be the absolute preferred choice due to newer agents with even better cardiovascular stability.

Sevoflurane (Option D):

  • is also a popular choice for patients with cardiac conditions.
  • It offers a smooth induction and emergence, as well as good cardiovascular stability.
  • It is less likely to cause myocardial depression and is also associated with minimal metabolism in the body.
  • Desflurane and Sevoflurane are often the preferred inhalational agents for patients with compromised cardiac function due to their rapid onset and offset, minimal metabolism, and overall good cardiovascular stability, but the best inhalational agent is Desflurane.

questions.text: Which of the following structures are not pierced during epidural anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Dura

Explanation:

  • Dura is not pierced during epidural anesthesia.
  • The local anesthetic is injected using a Tuohy needle into the epidural space which lies between dura and ligamentum flavum and the site of action is the nerve roots.

 

Structures pierced to reach epidural space:

(Options A, B, and C)

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a middle-aged man with diabetes, who has reported a decline in vision and whose fluorescein angiography displays the depicted image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Proliferative diabetic retinopathy

Explanation:

In the above given image of FFA (fundus fluorescein angiography), neovascularization is noted which is classical of Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (PDR).

 

Abbreviated Early Treatment Diabetic Retinopathy Study (ETDRS) classification of diabetic retinopathy:

Category

Management

Non-Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (NPDR):

No Diabetic Retinopathy

Review in 12 months

Very Mild NPDR:

Microaneurysms only

Review most patients in 12 months

(Option D)

Mild NPDR: (Option A)

Any or all of the: microaneurysms, retinal hemorrhages, exudates, and cotton-wool spots, up to the level of moderate NPDR. No intraretinal microvascular anomalies (IRMA) or significant beading.

Review range 6-12 months, depending on the severity of signs, stability, systemic factors, and patient's circumstances

Moderate NPDR: (Option B)

  • Severe retinal hemorrhages in 1-3 quadrants or mild IRMA
  • Significant venous beading can be present in no more than 1 quadrant
  • Cotton wool spots commonly present

Review in approximately 6 months

 

 

Severe NPDR: (Option C)

The 4-2-1 rule; is one or more of the:

  • Severe hemorrhages in all 4 quadrants
  • Significant venous beading in 2 or more quadrants
  • Moderate IRMA in 1 or more quadrants

Review in 4 months

 

Very severe NPDR:

Two or more of the criteria for severe NPDR

Review in 2-3 months

Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (PDR): (Option D)

Mild-moderate PDR:

New vessels on the disc (NVD) or new vessels elsewhere (NVE), but extent insufficient to meet the high-risk criteria

Treatment is considered according to the severity of signs, stability, systemic factors, and the patient's circumstances such as reliability of attendance for review. If not treated, review in up to 2 months

High-risk PDR:

  • NVD greater than ⅓ disc area
  • Any NVD with vitreous hemorrhage
  • NVE greater than ½ disc area with vitreous hemorrhage

Treatment should be performed immediately when possible and certainly on the same day if symptomatic presentation with a good retinal view

Advanced diabetic eye disease:

It is characterized by tractional retinal detachment. Significant persistent vitreous hemorrhage and neovascular glaucoma.

Vitreoretinal surgery with photocoagulation
